Title: anup gowda: 'Shivaji Surathkal is our homage to the detective genre’
Content: As Shivaji Surathkal: The Case of Ranagiri Rahasya hits theatres today, producer Anup Gowda is a happy man. An engineer, who decided to try his hand at cinema as a dancer and assistant director, among others, took on the mantle of producer with the Ramesh Aravind starrer, a decision he is very proud of. “I knew director Akash Srivatsa from his Badmaash days, so when he said that he had a script apt for Ramesh sir, I gave it a listen and was excited with what I heard. For a suspense thriller, the narration was different and main character sketch was novel. It seemed to be the right film to get started,” says Anup, who has produced the film along with Rekha KN for Anjanadri Cine Creations.Anup adds, “Shivaji Surathkal… is our homage to the detective genre and brings Ramesh sir back to the big screen after three years. The plot of this story can be created for a web series too. It was Ramesh sir who instructed the team to ensure this film would justify a theatrical release. Now, it is this change in treatment that has turned out to be the biggest highlight of the film.”

Title: Sudha Murty is back on the small screen for a cookery show
Content: Writer, tech entrepreneur and philanthropist Sudha Murty will appear on the television cookery show Kitchen Darbar hosted by former Bigg Boss contestant Sujatha Akshaya as part of Women’s Day celebrations. Sudha was last on Kannada television on Weekend with Ramesh . On the show, Sudha will speak about her love for cooking, cooking delicacies and more. Speaking to us, Sujatha says, “It was an honour to have Sudha on the show. Considering that she dedicates much of her time to philanthropical work and writing, she admits that she rarely cooks, but grows vegetables. She also told us that her son Rohan is not a fan of her cooking. During our conversation, Sudha added that her choice of food is a simple vegetarian meal and that her favourites include poha and pickles.”On the episode, which is yet to be telecast, Sujatha treats Sudha to a unique sweet dish. “After trying the sweet, she was very keen to make it at home. Apart fromcooking, she also engaged in conversations about women empowerment, which will be an inspiration, especially for the ladies,” says Sujatha.

Title: Kochi Times Most Desirable Man 2019: Prithviraj
Content: Even for someone like Prithviraj who has experienced dizzying professional highs in his 17-year career and has been equally unfazed by his successes and failures, 2019 was a standout year by his own admission. It was the year he fulfilled his long-cherished dream of turning director, and what a smashing debut he made with Lucifer , taking the box office by storm and creating a record M-Town can be proud of as he steered it into the Rs 200-crore club. He also bid goodbye to the year with yet another hit, Driving Licence It isn’t a surprise that Prithviraj’s awe-inspiring year has been capped with the Kochi Times Most Desirable Man 2019 title, through an online poll and our vote. This is the third time he has won — taking it earlier in 2012 and 2018 — and the actor-director speaks about what desirability means to him, how he manages to keep cool through it all and what we can expect next from himEvery time I have won this title, I’ve maintained that I’m not sure what exactly people find desirable about me; it might be a multitude of things or it could be nothing specific at all. I myself can’t claim to be in touch with the qualities that make me desirable, but if this title means that I, in some way, inspire someone or provide someone with direction, that is flattering to know as an artist and as a person.I think, regardless of gender, the quality that has always appealed to me is self-respect. This manifests itself in multiple ways in a person; for example, in the way you treat people around you.And I think it is very sensual to see a woman who is confident and grounded; somebody who does not aspire to be anything other than themselves.There are many women around me that I find appealing for the reason that I mentioned. I find (filmmaker) Anjali Menon very appealing, because she is a self-assured woman who has great self-respect.The same quality manifests itself in a completely different way in Nazriya, so I find her very appealing.Usually, for my roles, the stages I’ve switched between largely were either putting on or losing a bit of muscle, to look like a normal guy. I’ve been fine with that, because you end up eating more and lifting weights to go from your normal state to becoming muscular, and after the initial muscle aches are gone, it actually gives you a high. I am not going to say, ‘Oh, that’s tough’ and complain, because while it doesn’t come easy, if I have to have a beefed-up physique for a film, I know I will enjoy the process of creating that body.But for the upcoming shoot of my film, Aadujeevitham, I have to take on a thin, emaciated look. That wasn’t a process that I enjoyed, because most of all, it involved long periods of fasting. I do have a dietician, nutritionist and trainer to help me through this, but even with that, I feel weak, dehydrated and my sleep cycle is off the track. It wouldn’t be something I advise anyone to do. It’s not been fun.In terms of my career, I assume, last year, at least in public memory, would revolve around my directorial debut, Lucifer. So, if people were to take stock of my 2019, they would start with Lucifer and I am proud about that. It’s been a long-time dream to make a film of my own. Somewhere down the line, I adopted the tougher way to go about it. I’m assuming the easier way to make a directorial debut would have been to attempt a small film where what happens in a theatre would not be so much of a concern.But to make a mainstream, large-scale commercial entertainer like Lucifer, with Mohanlal playing the lead, was the tougher thing to do. You are really sticking your neck out. I knew with so much on my plate and so much invested, if I go wrong and I do not make a film that is worthy of the hype, the star cast and writer Murali Gopy, I knew that people would take me down. I knew I took a risk and I am proud of Lucifer.Post my debut, if I had to pick one year which was special to me, it has to be 2019. But what has worked in my favour is that I am not attached to my success or my failure. So, if a film becomes a success, I am happy about it and I move on quickly. In 2015, I had four back-to-back films in cinemas that were blockbusters, which I was told was a record in itself in the industry, but strangely, I am not very emotionally connected to that sort of thing. If a film becomes a big failure, I realise and understand it, and I move on. It doesn’t really matter to me.What would claw away inside of me and disturb me is if I have done a film and I walked away from it with the knowledge that I didn’t give it my all. As long as my conviction in my craft is strong enough for me to repeatedly give my 100 per cent every time I attempt a film, I am happy and cool with whatever the results are. Because the results are just a byproduct. It really can’t be the end of your journey. Of course, the means remain the same, you always try your best, but I feel you can no more longer look back and revel in the success than wallow in the despair of your failure.I don’t mind how it looks, but I can’t wait to shave, because I don’t like how it feels. It’s not something I am comfortable with it yet. And it is not a groomed look. I am supposed to just grow it out in and let it take on its own life, so that it seems as unmanageable and unkempt as I can make it for Aadujeevitham. If it looks stylish, it is completely by accident; the idea is to make it look not good.What I like about social media is that it is a medium where you can speak to people without an intermediary. When I put a video on Facebook or a picture on Instagram feed or my Twitter timeline, I am speaking directly to my followers. It is not what someone else says about me. This is great, because you are conveying what you want to without an intermediary.The other side of the coin is a bit scary, because you are speaking to a largely faceless and nameless crowd and the whole concept of anonymity that social media offers sometimes manifests itself in freedom of expression taking on its most ugly form, so there you have to build a wall and know that you are not going to be affected by this banter, whether it is positive or negative.If you want to say something, just do that, don’t engage in a conversation, which is anyway difficult for someone, like an actor, with a public profile and you have a million followers.There have been phases where I have thought I would write. I am yet to discover if I have the faculty to do something like that, but it could be something I attempt. Like directing, however, it is something that requires an investment of time, and right now that is at a premium for me. But it is something new that I could attempt.

Title: Shanvi Srivastava is the most desirable woman of 2019
Content:
FacebookTwitterPintrest

The votes are in and you have chosen the Bangalore Times Most Desirable Women for 2019, from a select bunch of achievers, all under the age of 40. This time around, Shanvi Srivastava wowed audiences and beats everyone to the top. The Mumbai-based actress, who now talks Kannada like a Kannadathi, says that she considers the Kannada film industry a home away from home. Here are excerpts from a chat...It feels great, very flattering, too. I wonder what makes me desirable. Is it the fact that I’ve been open about my life and myself on social media for people to know me inside out to vote for me? If that’s the reason, I am delighted.I do not know if it has, but I’d love it if my efforts have contributed towards this. I love making people happy, which was the reason why I chose to learn the language and be a part of the culture. If that has made them happy and vote for me, I’m more than happy.If I were to look at desirability, the topmost factor would be being myself everywhere and anywhere, without pretensions. The second factor, the earnestness in the work, matters to me. Personally, I look up to Alia Bhatt as a desirable role model, because she is the same everywhere and her hard work and sincerity shows it. So, I’d consider these factors as my desirable traits too.I like the way Ayushmann Khurrana and Vicky Kaushal have turned out. They come across as real both on screen and in real life. They also go and try to realise their full potential through their varied roles, which is very attractive to me.Now, I’m exploring the actor side of me. Earlier, I was this little girl who entered showbiz and was smitten by the glam world. Now, I have decided to explore the actor in me. I’m not a trained actor, nor have I done theatre. It took me some time to sink my teeth in. I want to go beyond being just the glamour quotient and do roles that allow me to explore a different side of me.Who said I’m single... (laughs) or who said I’m committed either. Let’s keep that mysterious.

Title: 6 hours of training for 7 months: Meet Arya, the ace boxer
Content: A picture of himself that Arya posted online — a back shot of him flaunting his ripped physique — went viral on Wednesday. And yesterday, the actor shared another photo of himself and a workout video, taking the internet by storm. The rippling muscles and his lean-mean-machine avatar is for his film with Pa Ranjith , said to be titled Salpetta.“We have finished shooting 50 per cent of the film. I’m playing a boxer in it,” says Arya, refusing to reveal any more details either about the film or his role.He’s always been one of the fittest actors in Kollywood, and had even worked on his physique for some of his films, like Madrasapattinam and Kadamban. “But that’s different from what I have done for this film,” he states, “In those movies, I had to also look bulky. But for this one, I had to have lean mass.”So, how long did it take him to achieve this look? “Seven months of training, with almost six hours of workout every day,” he says matter-of-factly.Ask him to elaborate on his fitness schedule and he says, “I’d do a combination of cardio, boxing and regular gym. I would spend the mornings doing cardio for two hours. And then, I’d practise boxing for an hour- and-a-half, and follow it up with a two-hour session in the gym later in the day. I have a long list of trainers that I have to thank, without whose help I wouldn’t have achieved this physique. Some are from north Madras and some are those with whom I train regularly.”

Title: Chaitanya KM: Aadyaa is a thriller that is about more than just a missing child
Content: Director Chaitanya KM ’s release today, Aadyaa , is a mystery thriller that has Chiranjeevi Sarja Sangeetha Bhat and Sruthi Hariharan in pivotal roles. The film, produced by People Media Factory, is the remake of the Telugu flick Kshanam and traces the search for a missing child. However, the director tells us that he has taken the liberty to explore a psychological phenomenon that takes this narrative to a totally different arc. “The biggest strength of Aadyaa is its cast, which also includes Ravishankar Gowda, Shashank Purushottam and Pramod Shetty, all of who have delivered power-house performances, especially Sangeetha and Sruthi. Chiranjeevi plays Aadi, whose former girlfriend Sangeetha (played by Sangeetha), comes to him years later, requesting help to find her missing child. But as Aadi begins this hunt, the plot thickens,” says Chaitanya about the film.

Title: Shine Shetty hangs out on home turf with Bigg Boss buddies
Content: Shine Shetty, the winner of Bigg Boss Kannada Season 7, is living it up in his hometown, and joining him are his friends from the show — Deepika Das and Chandana . The girls apparently joined Shine during his visit to the Kollur temple, before indulging in all things Mangalurean, in what became an extended vacation. “The temple visit was important, as my family was part of a Chandika Homa to pay our respects to the goddess — Kollar Mookambika. It was my father’s prediction on the Bigg Boss stage about my win, where he said he was 99% sure of my win and that the rest one per cent was left to this goddess that set the purpose for this visit,” explains Shine, who is thrilled with the welcome he got from Mangalureans after his win.Deepika and Chandana, who had planned to visit Kollur once they were all out of the Bigg Boss house, joined him at the temple. They also visited Shine’s grandmother, before heading out to indulge in some typical Kundapur cuisine at a popular hotel. “We had the best of the region, including prawn ghee roast, chicken ghee roast, bangude tawa fry and neer dosa. Chandana is a vegetarian and could only eat fried rice,” smiles Shine and adds, “Whats most touching is that everyone shows so much love and tells me they are proud that a Mangalurean has won Bigg Boss for the first time. When I didn’t have money, I couldn’t eat at the best of hotels. Today, when I have the money, hotel folks are refusing to take money from me. It’s my first visit home after my victory and it’s been so memorable.”The trio were also part of a family get-together before they took off to relax at a beach house on the outskirts of Kundapur.

Title: Producer Sudhir KM on Popcorn Monkey Tiger
Content: With just a song and a film teaser released, the Dhananjaya-starrer Popcorn Monkey Tiger has followed quite the unconventional promotional pattern. And this entire plan was all director Suri’s brainchild, says producer Sudhir KM . “When it is a Suri film, you can be assured that it is packed with punches. Right from filmmaking to promotional content, he has experimented with multiple factors,” says Sudhir, adding, “It is a gripping narrative with multiple riveting characters to watch out for — Dhananjaya ’s fans will get to see him in a never-seen-before avatar. Charan Raj’s music elevates the story’s allure further. Visually, this movie showcases conventional places like Mumbai, Udupi, Mangaluru , Mysuru, Gokak, and more, in a nouveau manner.” The Studio 18 production releases in about 300 theatres across the state, and in multiple theatres across the country. “We are also releasing the movie in the United States of America , Dubai and Australia too,” Sudhir signs off.

Title: Maha Shivaratri 2020: From intense physical training to meditation: Actors' guide to portraying Shiva
Content: A perfectly sculpted physique with six pack abs and a chiselled frame – this was not how one would describe gods on the small screen earlier. But with Mahadev's entry in TV shows, the rules changed. Actors chosen to play Shiva were supposed to be lean, fit – a modern avatar of the god. With Shiva emerging as one of the most popular gods on the small screen, playing him became the most ambitious role for actors. From training hard to meditating for hours, they made every effort to be the 'most talked about Shiva' on television. On Mahashivratri, some of these actors who played Shiva on screen tell us why playing the god has been the most challenging role of their careers.In an earlier interview with us, Mohit Raina , who portrayed one of the most popular Shiva of the small screen in ' Devon Ka Dev Mahadev ', said that the role was a turning point in his career. "I have spent almost a 1000 days in this role. It's been a wonderful journey. While portraying the role, my life and focal point was Mahadev. Our approach was always very personal and human. We wanted to show Lord Shiva's relationship with his wife, son and daughter, his bhakts and his mood swings as well. I know people have inhibitions before opting for mythological or period shows because they tend to get typecast. But Mahadev was a turning point in my career," he had said at the time. Tarun Khanna is playing Shiva for the eighth time, now on the show 'Devi Aadi Parashakti'. "This number would have been 12 if I would not have refused some other offers," says the actor, who has earlier played Shiva in shows like 'Santoshi Maa', ' Karmfal Daataa Shani ' and 'Ram Siya Ke Luv Kush'.Tarun shares that over the years, he has seen how the portrayal of Mahadev has changed on screen. "He is not just a god now, he is the hero and it is important for him to look smart. I would say that Mahadev went for a modern makeover. Earlier, actors were just asked to look divine. Now, we have to maintain a certain physique, look gentle but also look like someone who can be aggressive. That is the reason why today's Shiva appeals to all age groups. Earlier, I was playing the role of Chanakya, but to play Shiva again I had to lose 7kg in one and a half months," says Tarun, adding that this is his last show as Shiva.Sourabh Raaj Jain, who has been a popular face in mythological shows, says he was doubtful if he would be able to step away from playing Vishnuand play Shiva in 'Mahakaali – Anth Hi Aarambh Hai'. "When I was offered the role of Shiva after playing Krishna in 'Mahabharat', I was surprised at how different the two roles were. They aren't just two mythological characters. No amount of previous experience in a mythological show can prepare you for the role of Shiva. For me, the first difficulty was to break my image of Vishnu and Krishna. I was doubtful if theaudience would accept me as Shiva, but I took it as a challenge and I think I succeeded to a great extent. I had to put on some muscle weight," says Sourabh, adding, "My portrayal was slightly different than other shows and may be that helped me. The show was about women empowerment and how Shiva supports and motivates Parvati to fight her own battles, and the entire experience was beautiful."Vikkas Manaktala, who played Shiva in ' Namah ', could only live his dream of playing the character for three months. But it was a challenge nonetheless. "I used to shoot for 12-13 hours a day and spend around two hours commuting. But I would always dedicate two hours for physical training each day. My martial arts training and working out in the gym helped me get the desired physique for the role," says Vikkas, whorealised that maintaining a calm and composed demeanour on screen was the bigger challenge. "To play Shiva, your expressions and attitude have to be calm. That was really difficult for me. I started meditating and that helped me get the right expressions for the role,” he says, recalling that doing taandav with 8kg of jatas on his head was the most memorable part of playing Shiva. "To balance your head and dance with 8kg of weight was difficult. But I did that shot in one take and I take that as an achievement," he says.At a time when almost every mythological show has an actor playing Shiva, it was a task for Rohit Bakshi to do something different. The actor played the role of Shiva in ' Siya Ke Ram '. "I think I got the role for my smile and had very little time to prepare for the show, so I couldn't think much about physical transformation. I decided that at a time when everyone was focusing on looks, I would focus on my body language and will keep that smile on my face. I didn't realise it would be so tough as one has to maintain that smile in every single frame, even as you talk," shares the actor.

Title: Krishnaa in Indie film about a biracial man’s need to belong
Content: In only her second film as a lead actress, Krishnaa , actor Ravi Bhat’s daughter, has bagged an Indie movie. Called Kid Happy , the film, directed by Kris Cheppaikode and his fiancée Meghan Scibona, is a feature about Kal, a biracial American played by Naren Weiss , who travels to South India to find his father, who he has never met.“On his journey, he meets a feisty girl, Mallika, who is everything he had never imagined an Indian woman to be. I play her. The essence of the film is that he tries to find home and his true belonging with his father, but ends up doing so with Mallika,” says Krishnaa excitedly.The film, she adds, is meant for American audiences, who have a different perspective about India and its people. “Kid Happy is a biographical retelling of our director Kris’ life, with added fictional elements for cinema. This is Kris’ attempt at showing the world that India is more than just slums and cows and that it is a beautiful country,” says the actress. “Most of the film was shot in India. We were in Agumbe for three weeks, with another week’s schedule in Bengaluru. The team had another few days shoot in New York, but my role does not play out there,” she adds.So, how did this come about? “Many years ago, Kris was an apprentice to my aunt Vinaya Prasad’s late husband, Prasad. So, he knew the family and kept in touch through the years, even after Prasad’s passing. He would visit us on each of his trips to India and that is how he got to know me. A few years ago, he got to know that I was getting into acting. In fact, when he wrote the script of Kid Happy, he had me in mind while penning the character of Mallika,” she explains.The film, which is currently in post-production, is slated to do the festival circuit before making a theatrical outing.

Title: A crane accident on set of Indian 2 costs three lives and raises questions on safety measures
Content:
Read Also:Kollywood film

The film industry has been in a state of shock and disbelief since the news of the crane crashing down on the set of Shankar’s Indian 2 and claiming three lives first broke. While three technicians died instantaneously in this horrific accident, 11 more people were injured. Lyca Productions, which is bankrolling the Kamal Haasan-starrer, released an official statement expressing their grief over this unfortunate accident and identified the three personnel who lost their lives as Krishna (assistant director), Chandran (art assistant) and Madhu (production assistant).A source from the production unit, on condition of anonymity, told us how this tragedy unfolded, “Shankar was filming a sequence with Kamal and Kajal Aggarwal at EVP Film City, when the lighting truss fell from a height. The technicians were changing the lighting when the truss got dislodged from its bearings and came crashing down. Three of those who came under the weight of the truss died on the spot, and the others were immediately rushed to Saveetha Medical Hospital. The team always has an ambulance on hand, and the injured were taken to the hospital without losing much time. Shankar, Kamal and Kajal, who were near the spot, were unhurt. The director and his team were at the hospital till everyone got discharged.”Though everyone working on the film is covered by insurance, the source also added, “Subaskaran, Chairman of Lyca, is on his way to India from the UK. There’s no way we can put a price tag on the lives that were lost, but the production house will be offering financial support to their families.”Kamal Haasan expressed his sadness on this unfortunate tragedy. He tweeted, “Although I have met and overcome several accidents, the mishap that happened today is brutal. I stand alone having lost three of my comrades. More than my pain, the anguish of their families will be several times more. I partake in their anguish as one among them. My deepest condolences to them.”When we reached out to Kajal, who was shooting with Kamal on the location that fateful night, she told us that she was “still in shock”. “Grateful to God” for her “miraculous escape”, Kajal had earlier tweeted, “Words cannot describe the heartache I feel at the unexpected, untimely loss of my colleagues from last night, Krishna, Chandran and Madhu. Sending love, strength and my deepest condolences to your families. May god give strength in this moment of desolation.”She further wrote, “In so much shock, denial, trauma from the monstrous crane accident last night. All it took was a fraction of a second to stay alive and type this tweet. Just that one moment. Gratitude. So much learning and appreciation for the value of timeand life.”We always insist that for the benefit of producers, every film crew takes insurance, but only few do that. In fact, we had even made this a rule three years ago. From what I have heard, this (Indian 2) crew had used an industrial crane and had involved non-members. This was also against our rule. Using this type of crane in a place like EVP Film City, which lacks basic facilities, was taking a huge risk. We always request film crews to shoot only with our members and equipment.— Angamuthu Shanmugam,general secretary, Film EmployeesFederation of South India (FEFSI)Electrician Selvaraj, working on the set of this Vijay-starrer in 2018, had to be rushed to the hospital when a focus light, which was hanging from a crane, fell on his head.During the second season of Bigg Boss Tamil, in 2018, AC mechanic Gunasekharan, repairing an AC that was malfunctioning, on the second floor, slipped and fell. He was rushed to the hospital but succumbed to his injuries.In 2017, Michael, one of the technicians on the set, accidentally stepped on a live electric wire and died.One of the most tragic deaths in the industry happened in 2014 on the set of the film Midnight Rider. Camera assistant Sarah Jones was struck by a train, as the production company had not secured a permit to film on the tracks. According to reports, the director of the film, Randall Miller pleaded guilty to felony,involuntary manslaughter and criminal trespass. He spent a year in jail and worked out settled with the family of Sarah. The film was never released.It was in this movie that Vin Diesel’s stunt double, Harry L O'Connor, lost his life while filming the scene where he had to rappel down a line and land on a submarine — he slammed into the bridge at high speed, and died on impact.When filming the moving car stunt, cameraman Conway Wickliffe was killed by the vehicle as it missed a 90-degree turn and crashed into a tree.Set dresser David Ritchie was killed on the set of the 2008 film Jumper when the crew was breaking down a set. Ice and rock that had been frozen to form a wall for an exterior design came unstuck, killing Ritchie and injuring one other person.Daniel Radcliffe’s stunt double, David Holmes, injured his neck on the set and was paralysed. A flying stunt went awry, and he was thrown against a wall. The accident left Holmes with limited mobility in his arms and hands at the age of 25.The largest number of on-set deaths in film history took place during the filming of this 1989 Indian made-for-TV movie. A total of 62 extras and crew members died after a fire broke out and they were trapped inside the burning film studio. Director and star Sanjay Khan suffered major burns and spent 13 months in hospital undergoing 72 surgeries.Actor Jayan was killed during the filming of a stunt scene in this 1980 Malayalam film, when the helicopter he was boarding crashed`100 cr, `200 cr ena maarthattikollum naam kadainilai oozhiyanukku padhukappu thara mudiyavillai. Cinema-vil kadainilai oozhiyanukku kooda kaapedu irukka vendum engira nilaiaieidhavendum– Kamal Haasan

AnushreeClaim to fame: She is one of the most popular Kannada TV anchors. In 2019, she began her own talk show on social media that has got her more followers than many of the leading film stars. Aditi Prabhudeva Claim to fame: TV star Aditi seems to have struck gold on the big screen too. The year 2019 has had five releases in 2019 — all of which increased herpopularity, especially in the film Ranganayaki. She has six films in the pipeline this year.Relationship Status: She claims she doesn’t step out of home to meet any boys!Desirability Quotient: Her carefree attitude and ‘good girl’ vibes.11. Rachita RamClaim to fame: Last year saw her pack in some really good performances, which included Seetharama Kalyana, I Love You and Ayushman Bhava. She's got a host of feisty performances lined up this year.Relationship Status: No time for love, we hearDesirability quotient: Her dimples make men go weak in the knees12. Aakanksha SinghClaim to fame: This former Hindi TV actress made her Kannada debut in Pailwaan, opposite Sudeep. While she has not signed any other Kannada film yet, her songs from the film have won her fans galore.Relationship Status: She’s married to Kunal Sain.Desirability Quotient: Her fit and fabulous avatar is so inspiring.13. Shruti PrakashClaim to fame: This former Bigg Boss Kannada contestant made her debut with Londonalli Lambodara, which won her some appreciation.Relationship Status: Work keeps her occupied, she says.Desirability Quotient: She sings, looks good and is accessible on social media too!14. Asha BhatClaim to fame: She made her filmi debut with Junglee, which won her some good reviews. She's set to enter Sandalwood with the Darshan-starrer Roberrt shortly.Relationship Status: All work and no play, we hear.Desirability quotient: Her million dollar smile and dreamy eyes.15. Radhika Pandit Claim to fame: She made her onscreen comeback last year with Aadi Lakshmi Puraana. She's currently tied up with her two children and seems to enjoying motherhood.Relationship Status: Married to Kannada star YashDesirability quotient: Her expressive eyes can mesmerize anyone16. Ragini Chandran Claim to fame: A dancer and entrepreneur, she runs a popular dance studio in Bengaluru. After being a popular face in advertisements, she’s all set to debut on the big screen with Law, backed by Puneeth Rajkumar.Relationship Status: Hubby-actor Prajwal Devaraj and she are all about #fitspo!Desirability Quotient: She’s every bit the traditional Indian beauty.17. Manvita KamathClaim to fame: She continued her golden run after Tagaru with a Filmfare Award. While she had one release in Relax Satya, she has a couple lined up for this year.Relationship Status: She's single and ready to mingleDesirability quotient: She can woo someone with her words18. Anupama GowdaClaim to fame: She has decided to bid a temporary break to television and concentrate only on cinema. She's also bagged herself an indie Hindi film.Relationship Status: There are many in queue, we hear!Desirability quotient: She's the perfect girl-next-door19. HariprriyaClaim to fame: Last year, she was seen in the maximum number of films, some of which were all centered around her. She's got an equal number of films lined up this year as well.Relationship Status: She's kept her private life safely guarded.Desirability quotient: Calm and composed, she’s the girl who seems to have got it all.20. Sruthi Hariharan Claim to fame: She won a lot of accoldades for her role in Nathicharami, which even included a Filmfare Award. She also gave birth to a baby girl - Janaki - who has kept her busy right though.Relationship Status: Married to dancer Raam KumarDesirability quotient: She's the perfect beauty with brains.21. Kavitha GowdaClaim to fame: TV actress Kavitha has been making her way into the film industry. Last year, she was seen in Gubbi Mele Brahmastra and Birbal. BhavanaClaim to fame: After the 2018 hit Tagaru, she was seen in an endearing, mature and very nuanced performance in the 2019 film 99, which saw her paired alongside Ganesh.Relationship Status: Married to businessman Naveen.Desirability Quotient: Demure and classy, she’s has the knack of lighting up the screen with her presence.24. Aashna BishtClaim to fame: This youngster has her eyes set on showbiz dreams. Nabha Natesh Claim to fame: This Bengaluru hudugi has become one of the most sought after girls in the Telugu film industry, especially with the release of her film iSmart Shankar.Relationship Status: She's focussed on her work only, it seems.Desirability quotient: This vivacious girl seems to be high on energy always and has a winsome smile.26. Sree LeelaClaim to fame: She owned 2019 with two good outings — Kiss and Bharaate. Shraddha SrinathClaim to fame: She had a great 2019, with releases across four languages. Nishvika Naidu Claim to fame: She's slowly inching her way towards claiming the 'Next Big Thing' tag in the Kannada film industry with one good performance followed by another.Relationship Status: There are murmurs regarding a certain co-star.Desirability quotient: One of the few women who can look as hot in a sari as in a bikini.30. Title: Trump ally Roger Stone gets 40 months prison amid meddling firestorm
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Former Trump campaign adviser Roger Stone departs after he was sentenced to three years and four months in pri... Read More

WASHINGTON: Donald Trump 's longtime ally Roger Stone was sentenced Thursday to 40 months in prison for impeding a congressional investigation, in a case that ignited a firestorm over the US president's political interference in the justice system.

Stone, a veteran Republican operative and one of Trump's oldest confidants, was convicted in November of lying to Congress, tampering with a witness and obstructing the House investigation into whether the Trump campaign conspired with Russia to cheat in the 2016 election.

"The truth still exists," said US District Court Judge Amy Berman Jackson as she handed down the sentence.

"The truth, still matters. Roger Stone's insistence that it doesn't, his belligerence, his pride in his own lies are a threat to our most fundamental institutions, to the very foundation of our democracy."

Stone was not immediately sent to prison as Jackson said implementation of the sentence would be delayed while she considered his request for a new trial.

Trump sparked a scandal by decrying a "miscarriage of justice" after prosecutors he smeared as corrupt recommended a prison sentence of seven to nine years, in accordance with federal sentencing guidelines.

The president has also taken to Twitter to attack the jurors in the case and Jackson, who last year jailed former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort for unlawful lobbying and witness tampering.

Attorney General Bill Barr , who has been blasted for being too close to Trump, personally intervened to have the "extreme and excessive" recommendation withdrawn, prompting all four prosecutors to quit the case.

Trump took to Twitter to praise Barr for getting involved in the "totally out of control" process after a new prosecutor suggested a more lenient sentence of three to four years.

Stone is the sixth aide of Trump -- who was impeached last year for abusing his power but acquitted by the Senate -- to be convicted of charges arising from special counsel Robert Mueller 's probe into Russian election interference.

Barr said the president's comments had had no impact on his the decision, but has found himself vilified by Democrats who accuse him and the president of undermining the rule of law.

In addition, more than 2,000 former Justice Department officials have signed a statement calling for Barr to resign.

"A person should not be given special treatment in a criminal prosecution because they are a close political ally of the president," the open letter said.

In a rare public rebuke, Barr -- one of Trump's most staunch defenders -- said the president's Twitter pronouncements in ongoing cases were making his job "impossible."

"I think it's time to stop the tweeting about Department of Justice criminal cases," Barr said in an interview with ABC News.

Multiple US media outlets have also reported that Barr has informed the president's inner circle that he might resign if the tweets continue.

His public attempt to distance himself from the president was met with skepticism however by critics who accuse Barr of having repeatedly acting more like the Trump's personal lawyer than a public servant.

Despite his attorney general's warning, Trump continued this week to be vocal in his support for Stone, who appeared in court in a striped suit and a polka-dot tie.

The self-avowed "dirty trickster" was convicted of lying in testimony to Congress about acting as an intermediary between the Trump campaign and WikiLeaks, which released documents hacked by Russia that embarrassed rival Hillary Clinton during the 2016 White House race.

The seven-count indictment also accused Stone of threatening an associate to stop him from cooperating with investigators.

Stone accused jury members of being biased against him and appealed to overturn their verdict.

Jackson had previously forbidden Stone from posting on social media about his trial, after he shared a picture of her on Instagram with what appeared to be the crosshairs of a gun sight.

"He was not convicted and is not being sentenced for exercising his first amendment rights, his support of the president's campaign or his policies," the judge said.

"He was not prosecuted, as some have complained, for standing up for the president."

Stone, known for his flashy fashion sense, could potentially receive a presidential pardon.

"President Trump could end this travesty in an instant with a pardon, and there are indications tonight that he will do that," news anchor Tucker Carlson said Tuesday in a Fox News segment shared by Trump on Twitter.

The president has already commuted the sentence of nearly a dozen people this week including former Illinois governor Rod Blagojevich, who was jailed for corruption, and a New York police chief imprisoned for tax fraud.

The flurry of clemency actions -- 11 in total -- raised expectations that Trump is considering wielding his power in more controversial cases involving close former associates, including Stone.

Title: ‘India has to put in Rs 76k crore more a year to cut road deaths by 50%’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representational photo.

STOCKHOLM: India would require to make an additional investment of around Rs 76,300 crore annually for the next 10 years (at conversion rate of Rs 70 per US dollar) to meet the global target of reducing road fatalities by 50%, according to a new estimate released by the World Bank on Thursday.

The World Bank in its report "Driving Road Safety in India" has estimated that this investment will bring economic benefits equivalent annually to 3.7% of GDP.

Quoting an analysis by the bank and Bloomberg Philanthropies, the World Bank in its report report claimed that reduction in road crash fatalities and injuries by half would result in an estimated 14% increase in GDP over a period of 24 years.

The report was released in Stockholm where the Global Ministerial Conference on Road Safety was held. Union road transport minister Nitin Gadkari on Wednesday had assured the global leaders that India will meet the expectation of reducing road fatalities. He said it was a huge concern as India has 11% of all road deaths reported across the globe.

Advocating for more investment to make roads safer, the World Bank report has claimed that the estimated population welfare gains from achieving a 50% fatality reduction over this 24 year period will be equivalent to 16.3% of the GDP.

This is for the first time an estimate has been worked out projecting the benefit that India can reap by reducing the number of road fatalities. So far the discussion have been around how the annual socio-economic cost of all road accidents could be close to 3% of country’s GDP, which was based on an estimate prepared by the Planning Commission.

Hartwig Schafer, World Bank vice president for South Asia said, "Years of rapid economic growth in South Asia, followed by a steep rise in vehicle ownership have led to mounting traffic deaths and contributed to lost economic opportunities."

On Wednesday, Gadkari had told the global audience that India will focus on fixing the deficiencies in road engineering and stricter enforcement of traffic rules to put a brake on the high number of road fatalities.

"High number of blackspots simply shows what’s wrong with the road design,” he added.

The leaders from over 140 countries including India and its neighbouring countries participated in the global summit, which adopted the resolution to reduce road deaths by 50% in the next 10 years.

Leaders from different countries accepted that barring a couple of developed nations, all others have failed to meet the target of 50% reduction of fatalities between 2010 and 2020, which was declared as the UN Decade of Action. “We may have to take some smart actions, else we will have same results," said Ogla Algayerova, executive secretary of UN Economic Commission for Europe.

She added human being is the only rare species on the plant that wants to destroy themselves.

Title: Coronavirus causes tennis tournament in China to be cancelled
Content:
Representative Photo by AFP

XI'AN: A tennis tournament scheduled for next month in China was cancelled by the women's professional tour because of concerns over a deadly viral outbreak.The WTA announced Thursday that it was calling off the Xi'an Open "due to the coronavirus outbreak."The hard-court event was supposed to be held April 13-19, with 32 singles players and 16 doubles teams. There would have been $115,000 in prize money at stake.A statement issued by the WTA said the tour is "watching the situation closely" and will "continue to communicate with medical experts as information evolves on this virus."The viral outbreak has infected more than 75,000 people around the world, most in China, where about 2,100 deaths have been reported.Numerous sporting events in China have been cancelled, postponed or moved. The country forfeited its Davis Cup matches at Romania scheduled for March 6-7 because its men's tennis team won't travel to the competition.

Title: Celebrating Indian fashion at the French Embassy
Content:
Raising a toast: French Ambassador Emmanuel Lenain and Rahul Mishra Ati in Rahul Mishra's design. A few of the designer's outfits were displayed at the event Ati in Rahul Mishra's design. A few of the designer's outfits were displayed at the event Promoting sustainable couture:

Fashion talks: Sunil Sethi, Chairman, FDCI, with Géraldine Lenain, French Ambassador's wife

Fashion talks: Sunil Sethi , Chairman, FDCI, with Géraldine Lenain, French Ambassador's wife A tribute to Wendell Rodricks : Click ready: Tanira and Arjun Dang Click ready: Tanira and Arjun Dang All smiles: Gautam Bhimani with wife Rashi All smiles: Gautam Bhimani with wife Rashi The French Embassy has witnessed many fashion events and glamorous gatherings in the past. There have been many examples of how the French have been promoting the idea of fashion diplomacy. And the latest event celebrating fashion at the embassy was a reception hosted by the French Ambassador Emmanuel Lenain for designer Rahul Mishra . Rahul recently became the first Indian designer to be welcomed as a 'guest member' on the Paris Haute Couture Calendar.Rahul displayed a few of his designs at the event to give the guests an idea about 'sustainable couture'. The designer said, "In the early stages of my life, I was taught how design and fashion can bring some solutions and changes to society. As a designer, I make clothes and I constantly think about how the process of fashion can be a bit more inclusive and how I can promote sustainability. Therefore there's a lot of hand embroidery in my designs. If you see the French fashion history, that's what even they believed in – creating everything with their hands."Rahul and the French Ambassador paid a special tribute to the late designer Wendell Rodricks, whose sudden demise shocked the fashion industry. The ambassador said, "As we speak of celebrated Indian haute couturiers attached to France, I would like to take a moment to pay tribute to Wendell Rodricks. He had longstanding ties with our country, where he attended fashion design courses and was invited to the Paris prêt-à-porter salon back in 2007. It may be recalled that he was conferred the 'Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et Lettres' (Knight in the National Order of Arts and Letters) in 2015."Rahul added, "Wendell was the one who taught me that it is the process of creation that matters. He was someone who always promoted and gave platform to young talent."In Video: French Ambassador Emmanuel Lenain hosted a reception for designer Rahul Mishra

Title: Restaurant Review: Protein Rush
Content: I ate my way through charming Chembur and enjoyed every bite of the vibrant, dripping with flavour, authentic Sindhi food, the plump sweetness of gulab jamuns, freshly made garma-garam bhature, chatpatti chaat and more. Guiding me through Chembur were many a fab Chembur-based #Foodieblinddate. Bringing me to the unique ‘Protein Rush’ were a globetrotting foodie twosome. Internationally renowned, brilliant curator of fashion trade shows in New York, Las Vegas and Miami, Raj Anand is most known for curating the Paris Fashion and home décor shows. Curating these trade shows comes naturally to his fashionable colleague Rishabha Bhandari. Not surprising that these two are regulars at this health food, high-protein mecca.Seriously small, boxed-in space. Seats maybe 14 or 16 diners. An equally tiny open kitchen and a shelf with ready-to-eat packets, tangy tomato chick peas and more.What’s common between pizzas, toasties, soups, salads, Lebanese, Indonesian and an all-day breakfast menu (oats and pancakes) is that they are all high in protein and made in olive oil. Also, free of maida, MSG, preservatives and sugar.Vegetarians, ask for the ‘Black Rice Pot Rice’, delicious with paneer and exotic vegetables. The black rice has a tasty bite to it and double the amount of protein and fibre and antioxidants than brown rice, informed the owner, Akshay Sandhu, who is always present atthe café.Chicken summer salad orange dressing is a delightful refreshing meal. Ask for the ‘Gado Gado Salad’ with peanut butter dressing. From the all-day breakfast menu, go for the tasty overnight oats. A unique dessert, ‘Pineapple Overnight’ was sparkled with oats with chia seeds. Available in many flavours.The tiny space can get cramped when packed. Service is slow. Green omlette stuffed with spinach and feta cheese could do with more punch, but its accompaniment of sweet potato chaat (beetroot option) was delicious. While ‘Desi Chicken Pizza’, rich with 100 grams of protein (base made of pulses and soya protein), is layered with pesto and pav bhaji masala, it was too bland considering it’s a “desi” chicken pizza. As Raj points out, more vegetarian options are needed.The restaurant is devoted to more than your pleasure. It is watching over your well-being. It ensures that its dishes are protein-packed and preservative, maida and sugar-free. Generously portioned. Some need to be fine-tuned for flavour.This eatery is open through the day and it’s a perfect place to get a high-protein snack. Go if you’re into fitness. Don’t go if you’re looking for a rich, masala-laden meal or a gourmet one. The name flexes its muscles and says it all — ‘Protein Rush’.PROTEIN RUSHShop no 7, Fairlawn Cooperative Housing Society, VN Purav Marg, Dreamland Society, Borla, Union Park, ChemburContact: 09152155050Timing: 7.30 am to 12 pmAverage meal for two: Rs. 1500

Title: Gajraj Rao: People aren't bad. Woh 'log kya kahenge' se darte hain
Content:
ke liye dheere-dheere waise hi karna chahiye kyunki hum toh waise hi rahenge.





One of the most striking features of 2018's National Award-winning film ' Badhaai Ho ' was the chemistry between Neena Gupta and Gajraj Rao . As we meet the actors in Delhi and the two begin the interview with a 'pehle aap, nahi pehle aap', that same chemistry is evident in real life, too. They are promoting their second collaboration – ' Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan ' – which brings the duo back to the genre of a family entertainer about an unconventional subject, a homosexual son. In a candid chat with us, they talk about being the 'poster couple' for unconventional films, their evolving personal equation, and how and why mothers and fathers are different. Excerpts:I feel mothers are more accommodating towards their kids' so-called mistakes or things that are considered to be mistakes by our society. Fathers, on the other hand, are considered as cold-hearted, but that is not always the case. In our society, fathers – or boys in general – are told "don't be a girl" since their childhood. They say "mard ban!" so he has to play the role of the mard in school, college and office. But his emotions are the same as that of a mother and that is what Shankar Tripathi (his character in the film) is trying to say when he asks, "Tumhare paas dil hai toh main kya battery se chalta hoon?". I don't think any dialogue writer has ever a more interesting dialogue than this for a middle-class father in Hindi cinema.As a mother, I feel that he is heartless, aur inhe sirf gussa karna aata hai. Maar diya, dant diya aur kaha, 'Jao, so jao'. I also do that half the time, but I am also soft.99.9% moms aisi hi hoti hain and they will react like this if they get to know that their son or daughter is gay. Years of conservative thinking can't be changed in two minutes. Kids should also understand that they need to give time to their parents. Jaise pataate hain na inter-caste marriageAbsolutely. That is almost not a concept here. They feel, 'humare yahan gays nahin hote'. For an Indian father, their son cannot be gay. This is not a problem of the Indian or South Asian society; it is actually the problem of patriarchy. It took years to end the inhuman practice of Sati so this will also take time. It's not like people will watch this movie on Friday and then on Monday, ladke ko ladke wale dekhne aa jayenge. But it will at least start a conversation because I don't think people are bad. Log ' log kya kahenge ' ke concept se darte hain.I am a typical mother. So I did not need any preparation because I am playing a typical middle-class mother. It is a typical mother's reaction and it could also be to things like inter-caste or inter-religion marriage.I belong to Rajasthan and I have relatives there who strongly believe in traditions. Like the concept of a girl going out of the house and working is alien to many in those places. So I have references of lots of people I've have met over the years at family functions. They are not bad people, it's just that their thinking is different.Hum log filmi nahin hain. The USP of 'Badhaai Ho' was that our lines were not the typical dialogues we see in commercial films. We are relatable.We are real.Ji haan, when people meet us, me or Neena ji, they have a smile on their face, not hesitation. I met a senior citizen in the hotel and he promptly said, "Young man, let's take a picture". Aise treat kiya jaise apna banda hai. So that way, you can say that 'Badhaai Ho' was a turning point for us, in terms of the roles we are being offered both together and individually, too.Aur ek naturalness hai.We pull each other's leg, get angry, have tiffs. We have a large gang of friends who go out regularly. We have become like a family.100%! The preparation you need to do to bond with your co-star, we don't have to waste time on that.I don't have to worry ki inko bura toh nahin lagega. Initially it happened. The first scene we shot for 'Badhaai Ho' together was where he is lying on my lap and reading a poem. We hardly knew each other. So he came up to me and asked, "Are you okay? Are you comfortable? Can I place my head on your lap?" I said okay. He asked me again during the second take, "Excuse me, can I place my head in your lap?" He would actually ask before every take. Now, things are easy.Poles apart! There the awkwardness was because of us but here, it is because of our son. Wahan thoda hasi-mazaak tha. Here, there is taboo. There is a fear of showing your face to the society since Shankar and Sunaina Tripathi's son is gay. Naak katwa di isne. In 'Badhaai Ho', this sentiment wasn't there.

Title: Mall speaks to musician, promises probe
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

A day after issuing a statement that said, ‘no physical abuse was meted out to the guest named Mr. Soumyadeep Sikdar ’, Acropolis Mall authorities have decided to probe the matter further. On Wednesday night, they posted another statement on social media, which said: ‘We have been conducting a departmental enquiry on the incident’. Following CT’s report on the incident , the mall on Thursday even reached out to the musician, who had alleged physical assault by the mall’s security personnel following an altercation over being denied a socket to charge his phone at the food court.

“We invited Soumyadeep to our mall, but he said he was out of the city. So, we reached out to him on the phone. We have assured him that an enquiry into the matter is being conducted. We’ve never faced any such incident in the past and will surely take action against the offender,” an Acropolis Mall spokesperson told CT.

Confirming that he received a call from the mall, Soumyadeep said, “They have apologised and assured me that if any bit of my claim is found to be true, the authorities will take action. The woman on the phone also promised that the result of the enquiry will be emailed to me. I explained my ordeal to her.” Though the Sufi singer is now looking for closure, he is still bemused by the silent spectators of the incident.

No one from the mall has any right to beat up visitors even if the said person has done something wrong. I’m shocked that no one came forward to help me. This could have happened with one of them too. However, I want the matter to end once those guilty are punished. I hope no one else has to face the treatment that was meted out to me — not even those who remained silent spectators when I was being heckled,” Soumyadeep said.

Meanwhile, a separate statement was emailed to CT on Thursday by the mall authorities to clarify their stance. “Considering the outcome we will definitely take necessary steps against the staff, if we find them guilty. There can be individual acts which surely does not define our intention to run the mall ! There are daily briefings which take place to ensure such incidents doesn't occur. (In spite of these precautions it is quite unfortunate that such an incident occurred at our mall.) (sic),” read their statement.

Title: Aanand L Rai: I want to be fearless as a person and as a filmmaker
Content: Over the past 13 years since he entered Bollywood, Aanand L Rai has donned both hats with elan — that of a prolific producer and a fine director. And now, he is excited about his latest release, Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan , which he has co-produced with Bhushan Kumar. The film, starring Ayushmann Khurrana and Jitendra Kumar as the lead romantic pair, deals with the subject of homosexuality in a light-hearted manner. As the movie hits theatres today, Rai talks to BT about being in love with his films, the emotional support he seeks from his actors, and how a serious subject like that of Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan, needs to be told through a heavy dose of humour.When we started working on this subject, Section 377 had not been scrapped. The verdict came during the course of the film and we had to tweak our climax because of it. The reason I decided to make Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan is different.As a filmmaker, I felt the need to understand their world. There was a time when I wasn’t able to understand the universe of Tanu Weds Manu (2011) and Raanjhanaa (2013). Jaise hi mujhe iss topic pe kuch samajh aaya, I thought of sharing it with the audience. As a team, we really wanted to work on this subject, especially when Hitesh Kewalya (writer-director) came up with a good script. It all started with Shubh Mangal Saavdhan (2017), when we presented a subject like erectile dysfunction to the family audience. The idea of the franchise is to bring all the topics that are discussed behind closed doors into people’s drawing rooms. It is all about how you make them family entertainers. Ayushmann knew that we were working on this subject, and he got sold on the idea the moment he heard the script.The film is not about the romance between two men, it is about the society accepting two men involved in a romantic relationship. Hum logon ko lagta hai ki yeh unki problem hai, par actually problem hamari hai. It is our problem that we don’t understand a human relationship like this. So, the only way to reach out to the audience, with a heavy subject like this, is through a good dose of humour.I would say that my films are set in middle-class settings, not small towns. I understand that world much better. That’s the way I have been brought up and it reflects in my movies. Today, I might be a filmmaker, living in a bigger home, driving a bigger car, but I will always remember my upbringing. I was born and brought up in Delhi, in a middle-class family. My mom was a fine arts teacher in a government school. I remember growing up in a government colony. So, be it Lucknow, Kanpur or Haridwar, the backdrop of my film will always bemiddle class.It is not easy to get a script for an actor who you understand so well. I am just waiting for the right script to direct him. My process is different — I first fall in love with the story and then decide upon the actor. However, we have discussed the idea of working together as a director-actor. He is looking forward to a pure romance or a pure action film. I told him action toh nahi, magar pure romance pe kuch soch sakte hai.Like I said, I am a director who falls in love with his stories and that encourages me to make a film. I think I was in awe of Zero, I was madly in love with it. I think I overdid it. Bolte hai na, zyada pyaar bachche ko bigaad deta hai. I think this is what happened with Zero, but the experience taught me a lot. As far as my association with Khan saab (SRK) is concerned, I will relish it all through my life. I got a partner in him, so it was never a star I worked with. He was an emotional partner, who gave me a lot of support. I am not a craftsman, so I need emotional support every time I make a film. When I was working with Khan saab, he never made me feel like it was such a huge film. He made me believe in my story, and made me go through the journey the way I wanted to. However, like it happens after the release of every film of mine, I went silent post the release of Zero, too. That is all. Our association was not affected by the film’s box-office performance. I think silence is the best way to take both,success or failure. Just go quiet. Absorb. Learn. Understand.I won’t be careless. In fact, I have never been careless in my life. I was always a good student, and will remain a good student throughout my life. No experience has disturbed me as such, it has only made me understand a few things. So, I am looking at playing my innings the same way, I have been playing since the last 10-15 years. I can’t change myself. I am fearless. Once again, I am in love with my film and my story and I am enjoying it. I want to be fearless as a person, and as a filmmaker.

Title: Aanand L Rai: 'Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan' is about conversation between two generations
Content: His filmography is an ode to India's heartland. And with ' Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan ', Aanand L Rai is continuing that love story. The filmmaker tells us why he chose to set another film in a small city, why this had to be a family film and why he brought Neena Gupta and Gajraj Rao back together on the screen. Excerpts:'Shubh Mangal Saavdhan' was a very taboo topic – talking about erectile dysfunction. But I always saw that as a family film. For me, it was not just about erectile dysfunction, it was about these two generations, from the middle class, and the conversations between them. My reason to make the film was ki bahut saari baton mein ek communication gap aa jata hai, woh hatna chahiye. And I thought, if this goes well, we should come up with more topics and make these two generations come closer and have more communication, let's make this into a series – pick up a topic and bring these generations closer, talking about things, making each other understand about their point of view.Even this film, it's not about gay relationships. It's about people like us, who are a little homophobic. It's a conversation between these two generations. And I always believe, that the younger generation is more clear and less judgmental about things, which I really like.I definitely believe that it is changing. It's a very progressive India. We are growing as a country, we are opening up. We were different 50 years ago, changed a little 25 years ago, then 10 years ago and now we will change more.In 'Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan' you will see Ayushmann not playing a victim. In his previous films, in one way or another, he was playing a victim. But in this film he is a voice, a strong voice. He is very clear with his thoughts.We always knew that we are dealing with a difficult space. So this was like… putting a sugar coating on a bitter medicine. Gajraj Rao and Neena Gupta are that sugar coating in a subject like this. I wanted those faces, those actors, that talent, who can… when you look at them, you feel like yeh toh apne hi hain, you know? With a subject like this, I needed them to bring the audience in front of the screen, ki ab humse ye kahani suno. But when you see them on screen, they are definitely not the same couple you saw in 'Badhaai Ho'. They are such brilliant actors that they changed themselves in 30 seconds for this setting. But that lovability you cannot take away, you will fall in love with them all over again.I am not choosing the locations. I am choosing the world. Talking about a gay relationship in a Allahabad is quite different from talking about a gay relationship in Mumbai. Maybe my daughter, who is born and brought up in Mumbai, sees LGBTQ relationships differently than what I used to think when I was studying. The changing dynamics is pushing me further inside India, because that’s where my country is living. So setting it in Kanpur or Allahabad or Meerut, actually makes my stories live better.Definitely you can set it there. But if I want to connect with a larger audience, where it is affecting, then I shouldn't. It is a different kind of writing, when you are writing about a couple that has lived in Mumbai for 20 years and when you are writing about a couple who has been living in Saharanpur for the last 20 years. It is not just about the setting, it's about the life they have lived.I needed someone who looks vulnerable. He should look a part of the family and a boy who takes time to decide. And Jeetu is a fine actor, he understood those nuances and playing someone you are not. Anyway as an actor you play different roles, but here it was a major thing, you have to change the psyche, understanding that perspective and emote accordingly. I also needed a fresher to the screen, so that whatever nuances he brings, it looks like ki ye isi ka hai.Yes, because I really thought that it is high time that he should not play a victim. I thought that in this film he should be the voice, rather than the voice affecting him. That's why Ayushmann also loved it. It was new. You will see a new Ayushmann.Yes, we didn't want to run away from it. We decided that in the trailer also we will show it, be on the front foot. We are really proud of the film, we didn't want to go on the back foot and think pata nahi audience ko kaisa lagega. I wanted people to get comfortable, not grab eyeballs. I wanted it to not be a big deal.-- Sharmila.Bhowmik@timesgroup.com

Title: Take a bao!
Content:
Stir-fried vegetables with kimchi

Honey-sriracha glazed sprouts

Grilled paneer with sesame

Tofu with spicy mayo

Roast chicken and teriyaki mushroom

Pickled onions

Custard

Banoffee pie with banana, cream and honey

It’s been called the Burger of the Far East, an open sandwich, and more. And if you haven’t tried the fluffy, open dumpling known as a ‘bao’ yet, it may be time to do so now. This Chinese steamed bun filled with veggie or meat-based ingredients can be made as creatively as possible. It makes for a meal-on-the-go and can pack a healthy bite, too. Once a street food fave in Taiwan, baozi or baos are increasingly being added to mainstream menus, today.The bao is traditionally made with red bean or lotus paste. But it has moved into other flavours, too. And a trend is seeing the Far Eastern bao being infused with flavours of India! Affirms corporate chef Onkar Samarth, “I love the bao, it’s one of my favourites. I’ve used a different ingredients in the fillings, not just Oriental. I’ve made Maharashtrian baos such as a Sauji masala bao, a South-Indian style kathal bao (jackfruit) and a puran poli bao; it turned out great.”Chef Rakesh Talwar has given the bao a Rajasthani twist. “I have added laal maas to the filling and the bao complemented the spice of the laal maas,” he says.When it comes to desserts, restaurateur Neelam Saini Sircar, says the bao is an opportunity to get creative. “I’d do a raspberry- kalakand bao. The bao holds the kalakand (made of chenna) and raspberry well. I’d call it a progressive dessert. It may also be a great idea to do a beetroot halwa bao.”Talk about Instagrammable desserts! Just as one can create latte art, the trend here is to create similar cute designs on baos. One can make everything from minions to create characters like Hello Kitty to Minions, pandas and Angry Birds. It’s done using edible food colouring for the face and custard, red bean paste and sweet potato for the stuffing. Kids will love it.Soft, round baos are steamed in bamboo baskets. You actually have bao artists called ‘baoists’ who ensure the bun is made with a certain quality and that it adheres to the right making practiceSweet or savoury, this bun pairs best with green tea.

Title: Celebrating Indian fashion at the French Embassy
Content: The French Embassy has witnessed many fashion events and glamorous gatherings in the past. There have been many examples of how the French have been promoting the idea of fashion diplomacy. And the latest event celebrating fashion at the embassy was a reception hosted by the French Ambassador Emmanuel Lenain for designer Rahul Mishra . Rahul recently became the first Indian designer to be welcomed as a 'guest member' on the Paris Haute Couture Calendar.Ati in Rahul Mishra's design. A few of the designer's outfits were displayed at the eventRahul displayed a few of his designs at the event to give the guests an idea about 'sustainable couture'. The designer said, "In the early stages of my life, I was taught how design and fashion can bring some solutions and changes to society. As a designer, I make clothes and I constantly think about how the process of fashion can be a bit more inclusive and how I can promote sustainability. Therefore there's a lot of hand embroidery in my designs. If you see the French fashion history, that's what even they believed in – creating everything with their hands."Fashion talks: Sunil Sethi , Chairman, FDCI, with Géraldine Lenain, French Ambassador's wifeRahul and the French Ambassador paid a special tribute to the late designer Wendell Rodricks, whose sudden demise shocked the fashion industry. The ambassador said, "As we speak of celebrated Indian haute couturiers attached to France, I would like to take a moment to pay tribute to Wendell Rodricks. He had longstanding ties with our country, where he attended fashion design courses and was invited to the Paris prêt-à-porter salon back in 2007. It may be recalled that he was conferred the 'Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et Lettres' (Knight in the National Order of Arts and Letters) in 2015."Rahul added, "Wendell was the one who taught me that it is the process of creation that matters. He was someone who always promoted and gave platform to young talent."Click ready: Tanira and Arjun DangAll smiles: Gautam Bhimani with wife Rashi

Title: Govt move may lower creamy layer threshold
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

File photo used for representational purposes only.

NEW DELHI: Proposing a major change in the concept of ‘ creamy layer ’ for OBCs, the government may rule that ‘salary’ be considered a part of ‘gross income ’ to decide if a backward class individual is eligible to avail Mandal reservations in public employment and education.

Top sources in the ministry of social justice and empowerment said inclusion of salary in calculating the creamy layer for OBCs was decided as per the recommendations of an expert committee. A proposal to this effect is likely to be moved for the government’s consideration.

If the move goes through, it will significantly raise the bar to qualify for the 27% quota benefits as more are likely to be excluded as ‘creamy layer’ — the cut-off that rules an OBC as affluent.

As per the guiding 1993 Office Memorandum on creamy layer, ‘salary’ and ‘agricultural income’ are not included in ‘gross income’ which only comprises ‘income from other sources’. In contrast, factoring in salary would make it much easier to qualify an OBC as affluent. Observers believe the decision will be controversial with the backward castes.

While the 1993 OM is clear on the subject, confusion arose after the Centre, over the last six years, started including salary in case of OBCs from PSU backgrounds while continuing to exclude it for those working in state and central governments.

It lowered the bar for disqualification from quota in case of the first category and triggered court battles. Madras and Delhi High Courts termed the practice “discriminatory” and asked the Centre to remedy the situation in favour of OBCs from PSU backgrounds.

An expert committee was appointed in March 2019 to resolve the situation. As reported by TOI, the panel suggested that the Income Tax Act be made the benchmark to calculate the creamy layer cut-off for all OBCs across the board. The I-T Act includes ‘salary’ and ‘other sources’ but leaves out ‘agri income’.

According to sources, the social justice ministry has also decided to review the income ceiling for creamy layer, as is mandatorily done every three years and was last effected in 2017.

The expert panel is learnt to have recommended that income ceiling should be ‘indexed’ to a fixed parameter to decide the quantum of raise, as against the subjective revision done till now.

While a final decision has not yet been taken, sources said the income ceiling could be increased from the present Rs 8 lakh per annum to above Rs 11 lakh.

Title: CAA major ‘downturn in India’s religious freedom’: US Cong body
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: Ahead of President Donald Trump ’s visit, a bipartisan US federal government entity which has often clashed with the Indian government in the past issued a ‘factsheet’ on why the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) represents a significant downturn in religious freedom in India.

The United States Commission on International Religious Freedom (USCIRF) said Muslims alone would suffer from the National Register of Citizens (NRC) as non-Muslims would be ensured protection by the CAA. While it linked CAA and NRC, as of now, the Indian government has said that NRC was not under discussion.

In December last year, the USCIRF, established by the US Congress to monitor threats to religious freedom abroad, had said the law was “a dangerous turn in the wrong direction; it runs counter to India’s rich history of secular pluralism and the Indian Constitution, which guarantees equality before the law regardless of faith”. It had sought sanctions against home minister Amit Shah and other “principal leadership’’ of the law, which was then before Parliament as a bill.

The ’factsheet’ concluded that the NRC process in Assam and challenges plaguing it demonstrated that Indian citizens could be stripped of their citizenship in a nationwide NRC. “With protections for non-Muslims in place under the CAA, however, any future NRC process would largely impact Muslims alone,’’ it said.

According to the USCIRF, the law essentially granted individuals of selected non-Muslim communities in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan refugee status within India and reserved the category of “illegal migrant” for Muslims alone.

Indian officials here said the CAA should be appreciated by those genuinely interested in religious freedom as it addressed the human rights of persecuted religious minorities who were not in a position to return to their homes.

While referring to Shah’s remark in Parliament that the CAA was only meant to protect those who had suffered from religious persecution in neighbouring states, the USCIRF said the Act did not require members of the listed non-Muslim religious groups to provide any proof of persecution and omitted Muslim minority communities such as Shias and Ahmadiyas who faced severe persecution in Afghanistan and Pakistan due to their faith.

While it recalled PM Narendra Modi ’s statement that there had been no discussion in the government on NRC, the USCIRF mentioned Shah’s contradictory statements and also BJP’s 2019 manifesto which called for NRC in other parts of the country in a phased manner.

The ‘factsheet’ further said there were serious concerns that the CAA served as a protective measure for non-Muslims in case of exclusion from a nationwide NRC — a proposed list of all Indian citizens — and that was evident from the rhetoric of BJP politicians.

“The CAA and NRC must also be understood in the context of the growing prominence of BJP’s Hindutva ideology. This ideological frame views India as a Hindu state (with its definition of Hinduism inclusive of Buddhists, Jains and Sikhs) and Islam as a foreign and invading religion,” it said.

Title: Don't miss Ayushmann Khurrana and Vicky Kaushal's bromance ahead of their movie releases!
Content:
Ek hi din hum dono bhai aa rahe hain! Dher saara pyaar aur sammaan, Lekar aa rahe hain Vicky aur Ayushmann. Bhoot… https://t.co/5vjFPgvqD0 — Ayushmann Zyada Khurrana (@ayushmannk) 1582211673000
