Title: O Panneerselvam expresses hope that revenue would grow next year
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

O Panneerselvam

CHENNAI: Deputy chief minister and state finance minister O Panneerselvam on Thursday expressed hope that the revenue in the coming fiscal would be better than that of this year.

He said in the assembly that though DMK MLA PTR Palanivel Thiagarajan had pointed out that having revenue deficit would prevent the government from spending on asset creation, the government schemes like giving free goats to the poor would improve rural economy.

The state was facing revenue deficit because of lower tax devolution from the Centre. If public debt was increasing, so was GSDP, he said. Debt as a percentage of GSDP was well within the 25% mark prescribed under FRBM, said Panneerselvam.

He agreed to DMK’s suggestion to set up a committee to study state’s own tax revenue.

Title: Donald Trump's India visit: ‘Kem Chho’ echoes louder across America
Content:
Motera Stadium was a veritable fortress with security personnel everywhere on Thursday

AHMEDABAD: With the jam-packed SP Stadium greeting US president Trump on Monday, it will be ruled by the ‘Kem Cho’ spirit of the state, even as the event has got official name of ‘ Namaste Trump .’ But Trump’s America is no stranger to the greeting - in 2017, a total of 4.34 lakh Americans told the Census officials that they speak Gujarati as second language at home.The number of Gujarati users increased by 84% from 2.35 lakh in 2000 to 4.34 lakh in 2017. As the US Census will take place in 2020, Gujarati is also included as one of the 59 languages — including eight Indian languages — in which forms would be available. Several states of the US, notably New Jersey, New York and Illinois, have sizeable Gujarati populations.International Mother Language Day on February 21 is being celebrated on the theme ‘Languages without Borders.’ Significantly, in the past two decades, Gujarati learning and writing has seen a surge thanks to technology and NGOs, experts say.Preety Sengupta, a New York-based author of 48 books, made history when she was conferred Kumar Chandrak and Narmad Chandrak for her writings. Known for her lyrical travelogues, Sengupta, who was brought up in Ahmedabad, hates ‘diaspora writing’ tag. “It was a shock of settling into America for first few years. The pen then again started flowing — I am sure a lot of writers from my generation went through that process and tried to capture those emotions in their writings,” she said.Today, 50-odd major and minor Gujarati periodicals thrive in various parts of the US, primarily propelled by the Gujarati Samaj and social organizations.

Title: ICRA cuts outlook on Indian pharma
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: ICRA has revised its outlook on the domestic pharmaceutical industry from stable to negative in view of the lockouts in parts of China, amid the coronavirus outbreak . Of the total imports of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) and intermediates into India, China accounts for 65-70%, while in specific APIs like cephalosporins, azithromycin and penicillin, the dependence is as high as 80-90%.

The viral outbreak and the consequent lockout in China has resulted in a shutdown of production units in the country. The situation is more alarming in case of intermediates of stages prior to APIs and key starting materials (KSMs), which are the building blocks for drugs, where in some cases, China is the exclusive supplier. For instance, PenG and 7ACA, the key raw materials required for manufacturing cephalosporins are made in China only.

For some input materials, even if alternate sources are available, China remains the preferred source given the economical rates. Though a majority of the pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities in China are located far from the coronavirus-affected sites, there has been a disruption in the supply chain.

According to ICRA, domestic formulations manufacturers have an inventory of 1.5-2.5 months on an average, and thus they have not been impacted as yet. However, a shortage of APIs and KSMs due to the extended lockout in China will adversely impact production of the formulations manufacturers. Coupled with an increase in API prices due to supply shortage, this will impact the profitability of the domestic formulations manufacturers.

The extent of impact of production shutdowns and increase in prices of raw materials on the profitability of domestic pharmaceutical manufacturers would, however, vary depending on each company’s product and raw material sourcing mix and the quantum of inventory held, a note said.

Title: College manager arrested for giving copying tips in Mau
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Varanasi: Madhuban police, arrested the manager of Harivansh Memorial Inter College (HMIC) Pravindra Mall in Mau district for giving copying tips to students and advising them to leave currency notes in answer sheets during board exams. He was presented before the court on Thursday.

A video of the manager giving such tips during annual function of the college went viral on social media. After the video came into his knowledge, district magistrate Mau Gyan Prakash Tripathi ordered the district inspector of school to probe into the matter. The manager was arrested after a student uploaded the video on the CM’s complaint portal following which the CM’s office issued directives to expedite the probe.

Inspector Madhuban Sanjiv Dubey said an FIR was lodged against Mall under section 4/10 of UP Public Examinations (prevention of unfair means) 1998 and 66D of IT Act on a compalint filed by principal of the college on Thursday.

With the commencement of UP Board exams on February 18, a video of Mall advising the students about tricks of copying and to escape the wrath of invigilators went viral on social media. In the video he could be found saying, “Ask fellow students the answers because that is not copying. Stay quiet when you are caught as the invigilator might let you off but if you argue, they will spoil your life.” In the video, he also assures cent per cent result. He also advised the students to leave currency notes in answer sheets to get passing marks.

DM said that after the video came into his knowledge he asked the DIOS to probe into the matter and initiate necessary action. The probe revealed that Mall gave such tips during annual function of the college last month. The matter was forwarded to the police for necessary action, said the DM.

Title: Faceless assessment alone cannot determine tax: HC
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Chennai: The e-proceedings facility introduced by the income tax (I-T) department from 2017-18 can lead to erroneous assessments as officials conclude these without “personal hearing” of the assessees, the Madras high court has said.

Though it is a laudable step towards e-governance, officers may not be able to understand transactions and statements of accounts of assessees, said Justice C Saravanan, quashing an assessment order passed by the deputy commissioner of income tax, Circle 1(1), Salem in Tamil Nadu. Further, the HC sent it back to the same I-T officer for a fresh order in two months.

“The government of India has introduced e-governance for conduct of assessment proceedings electronically. It is a laudable step taken by the income tax department to pave way for an objective assessment without human interaction. At the same time, such proceedings can lead to erroneous assessment if officers are not able to understand the transactions and statement of accounts of an assessee without a personal hearing. The officer should have at least called for an explanation in writing before proceeding to conclude that the amount collected by the petitioner was unusual.”

The Salem-based Salem Sree Ramavilas Chit Company had moved the court for quashing a December 27, 2019 order passed by the deputy commissioner. The I-T official had held that the company had not properly explained cash deposits of Rs 67.4 lakh collected during the demonetisation period in 2016.

Challenging the order, the company said the demonetisation order came on November 8, 2016, whereas the company had collected Rs 57.9 lakh during the first week of that month. It is the usual chit fund collection made during the period, it said, adding that the amount was properly accounted for. Standing by its assessment, the I-T counsel said the well-reasoned order did not require judicial interference, and added that from the 2017-18 assessment year onwards, assessments were done only through e-proceedings. The new method negated visit of the assessee to the department and made scrutiny easy.

Under the circumstances, Justice Saravanan said, “In my view, the petitioner (company) has prima facie demonstrated that the assessment proceeding has resulted in distorted conclusion on facts that amount collected by it during the period was huge and remained unexplained. It is liable to be treated as unaccounted money under Section 69A of Income Tax Act, 1961…Since the assessment proceedings no longer involve human interaction and is based on records alone, the assessment proceeding should have commenced much earlier so that before passing assessment order, the respondent assessing officer could have come to a definite conclusion on facts after fully understanding the nature of business of the petitioner.”

The judge then set aside the impugned order, and remitted the case back to the deputy commissioner to pass a fresh order within a period of 60 days. The petitioner shall file additional representation, if any, by treating the impugned order as a show-cause notice, within 30 days.

Title: Additional cash lane at Bhatia toll plaza for vehicles but farmers want exemption
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Surat: At a time when agitation by cooperative leaders and farmers against toll tax payment is gaining momentum, Bhatia toll plaza authorities on Thursday opened an extra lane for cash payment for vehicles.

Navsari MP CR Paatil and Majura constituency MLA Harsh Sanghavi had given an ultimatum to district administration on Wednesday to provide extra cash lane for vehicles registered in the city and district or else they would join the agitation against Bhatia toll plaza authorities.

Paatil told TOI, “We had met district collector on Wednesday and strongly represented Bhatia toll plaza issue. We had demanded an extra cash lane for allowing vehicles registered in the city and district to pass smoothly. Vehicles had to wait in long queues as there was a single cash lane at toll plaza.”

However, farmers and cooperative leaders, who have formed Bhatia Toll Naka Sangarsh Samiti, repeated their demand for total exemption in toll tax payment for local vehicles.

Darshan Naik, member of sangarsh samiti, told TOI, “Our agitation is for exemption from toll payment for vehicles registered in city and district. The agitation will continue till our demands are met.”

Mohan Bhatia, cooperative leader, told TOI, “Local vehicles are exempted from paying toll tax at Kamrej toll plaza located on National Highway (NH) after an agitation by us. Additional cash lane at Bhatia toll plaza was not our demand. We will continue our agitation till local vehicles are given free entry and exit at Bhatia toll plaza.”

Title: Mahashivaratri: Devotees to take out ‘shobha yatras’ in Patna today
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Devotees are set to celebrate Mahashivaratri with devotion on Friday (File photo)

PATNA: Members of different puja committees will take out ‘shobha yatras’ across the city on the occasion of Mahashivaratri on Friday. According to Jaleshwar Mahadev Mandir Samiti secretary Ajay Yadav, a procession will leave the temple in Kankarbagh after worshipping Lord Shiva and return after covering different parts of the city. Another committee, Mahotsav Samiti, will take out a procession from the Shiva temple in Danapur. Samiti chairman Lakshmi Narayan Shah said the procession would culminate at Gauri Shankar Temple at Gaighat. Meanwhile, all Shiva temples in the city, which attract large number of devotees on Mahashivaratri, have been decorated with flowers and colourful lights. Many of them will also organize nightlong ‘jagrans’ where people will sing hymns and songs dedicated to Lord Shiva. City-based priest, Manohar Upadhyay, told this newspaper on Thursday that Mahashivaratri was one of the most important festivals among Hindu women. “Goddess Parvati, the wife of Lord Shiva, is believed to be the epitome of love, beauty, marriage, fertility and children. Devotees, therefore, worship Lord Shiva on Mahashivaratri. Many observe ‘nirjala upwas’ and break the fast the next morning after consuming ‘prasad’. Some also eat ‘singhare ki puri’, ‘halwa’, ‘sabudana kheer’, ‘makhana’, dry fruits, fruits and milk on the occasion,” Upadhyay said and added, “Milk, honey, curd, ghee and ‘bel’ leaves are offered to the Lord amid chanting of mantras like ‘Om Namah Shivay’. Devotees set to celebrate festival: Devotees are set to celebrate Mahashivaratri with devotion on Friday. A number of them will take a dip in the Ganga and visit Lord Shiva temples in the city. Sabzibagh resident, Rishabh Ranjan, who is an ardent follower of Lord Shiva, said, “I believe Lord Shiva has helped me achieve everything. I have a good job and my own house. I, therefore, make sure that I worship the Lord with utmost devotion on Mahashivaratri. I also have a ‘shivalinga’ at my house.” Kankarbagh resident Renu Gupta will offer flowers and milk to the Lord at five different temples. “I have already bought fruits, flowers and other ‘puja’ items for performing the rituals,” she said. Massive crowds were witnessed at makeshift shops selling ‘puja’ items like ‘bel’ leaves and ‘bhaang’ on the eve of Mahashivaratri.

Title: Bihar assembly elections: Parties to roll out red carpet for women voters
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Since women voters have outnumbered their male counterparts in terms of voting percentage in past one decade in the state, political parties are trying their best to strengthen their women cells and attract women voters in the upcoming assembly elections in the state.

In 2010 assembly elections, 54% women and 51% male voters had exercised their franchise. The figure in 2015 assembly elections went up to 59% for women voters and 53.9% for male voters.

With an eye on women voters, the ruling JD(U) has decided to deploy three to four active female workers at each booth. The party has coined the term ‘booth sakhi’ for these workers who will interact with local women and inform them about the work done by CM Nitish Kumar for the welfare of women.

Party’s women cell state president Sweta Vishwash said, “Nitish has worked a lot for women. Prohibition, reservation in government job and panchayati raj system, incentives to female child and scholarship to girl students are some of the examples. One can see transformation in the field of women empowerment.”

Sweta said the ‘booth sakhis’ would inform women voters about girls of their area who received Rs 25,000 scholarship after completing graduation. “We have also planned to hold an all-woman road show in all districts highlighting women empowerment in the state,” Sweta added.

The RJD has also planned to involve more women in its door-to-door campaign. RJD women cell state president Abha Lata said the party would focus on strengthening women base at panchayat level.

“Tall promises made by the CM are actually lying on papers. Our women groups will listen to the grievances of women and provide them all necessary help. Liquor ban has actually come as harassment for women from poor families. Their husbands are being sent to jail and they are running from pillar to post to get them released. Many women are not getting their due pension amount in the state,” Abha said.

The BJP is also trying to involve at least four active women workers at each booth. “We have decided to give one-third representation to women in our block and district level committees,” BJP state spokesperson Nikhil Anand said, adding the party will also rope in local women representatives before the election.

The Congress, on the other hand, has decided to make ‘mahila pracharaks’ at panchayat level. “We will make new women cell members at district, block and panchayat level by mid-March. These members will interact with local women and tell them about Congress’s agenda,” BPCC women cell president Amita Bhushan said.

Title: Narendra Modi: Day after PM Narendra Modi tasted it, ‘litti-chokha’ politics plays out in poll-bound Bihar
Content:
PM Narendra Modi having the traditional Litti Chokha during his visit to the Hunar Haat at India Gate on Wedne... Read More

Had tasty Litti Chokha for lunch along with a hot cup of tea... #HunarHaat https://t.co/KGJSNJAyNu — Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) 1582108226000

PM’s sampling of the Bihari delicacy grabbed headlines and generated political heat in Patna (Photo: Twitter handle of PM Narendra Modi)

यह सुखद संयोग था कि जिस दिन बिहार सरकार किसानों से पटना में संवाद कर रही थी, किसानों की आमदनी दोगुनी करने के उपायों… https://t.co/WkDDmbMYRx — Sushil Kumar Modi (@SushilModi) 1582205460000

Thank you respected PM for liking famous Bihari delicacy! Since Bihar CM can’t ask, I would like to draw your kind… https://t.co/HtMH5YxYpS — Tejashwi Yadav (@yadavtejashwi) 1582121187000

PATNA: Chief minister Nitish Kumar’s dream of seeing at least one Bihari dish on the plates of every Indian came true as PM Narendra Modi took ‘litti-chokha’ national when he tasted the dish at Hunar Haat in New Delhi on Wednesday.PM’s sampling of the Bihari delicacy grabbed headlines and generated political heat in Patna evoking sharp reactions from opposition politicians and lauded by ruling NDA leaders.Deputy CM and senior BJP leader Sushil Kumar Modi took to Twitter on Thursday to praise the PM. “It was a coincidence that when PM Narendra Modi was having litti-chokha in New Delhi’s Hunar Haat, the state government officials were busy in deliberations to make the dream to have a Bihari dish in every citizen’s platter a reality and devising ways to increase the income of farmers in the state.”SuMo’s tweet was in reference to Nitish’s statement in December 2010 in which he had said, “I dream of a day when every people in this nation will have at least one food item in their dish or kitchen from Bihar.”But former CM and HAM (S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi said, “Is this an announcement of the state assembly poll in Bihar due later this year?... Under such circumstances, it (PM tasting the dish) has its political interference.” he said, adding, he is also fond of litti-chokha.Leader of opposition Tejashwi Prasad Yadav, too, took to twitter. “Thank you respected PM for liking famous Bihari delicacy!” He added: “Since Bihar CM can’t talk, I would like to draw your attention towards Bihar’s legitimate share pending quite long.” However, his elder brother Tej Pratap Yadav tweeted in chaste Bhojpuri, “Katano khaee ba litti chokha, Bihari na bhuli dhokha.”The politics of ‘litti-chokha’ can’t be complete without a mention of former CM and RJD chief Lalu Prasad. Lalu, who is at present serving sentence in fodder scam cases, is among the admirers of this Bihari delicacy. “Lalu had said a day after Nitish parted ways from Mahagathbandhan in 2017 that two things have become famous in the country— Bihar Ka litti-chokha aur Nitish Ka ‘dhokha’ (betrayal),” a senior RJD functionary Mohammad Shami Ahmad said.“He (Lalu) played a good host during winters and enjoyed ghee-laced litti-chokha. He was of the opinion that ‘isme milawat ki jungayish hi nahi hai’, the RJD leader, once considered close to Lalu family, said.Litti-chokha has been a favourite dish not only for politicians but also for Bollywood stars. Actor Amir Khan had litti-chokha at a roadside stall near Patna zoo during the promotion of his movie ‘Ghajini’. Ajay Devgn and Sonakshi Sinha had also tasted it during promotion of their film ‘Son of Sardar’.“One of the major reasons behind the popularity of litti-chokha is its price. Besides, it contains ‘sattu’ which keeps the stomach cool and the same time full during scorching summer heat,” said Ramesh Yadav, a seller at Patna Junction.

Title: SGST unearths Rs 22 crore of unaccounted transactions by service providers
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: State Goods and Services Tax (SGST) department has unearthed Rs 22 crore of unaccounted transactions in simultaneous search operations carried out on 37 locations of 20 service providers engaged in mandap decoration, catering and renting out of party plot business in Surat and Ahmedabad on February 18.

Official sources said on Thursday that of the 20 service providers, 12 are from Surat.

SGST officials seized several incriminating documents from the premises of mandap decorators, party plot owners and caterers in Surat and Ahmedabad. Detailed scrutiny of the documents revealed that the service providers were doing business in cash without issuing bills to their customers.

The amount received in cash was not shown in book of accounts and thereby service providers indulged in massive tax evasion. In some cases, it was found that the service providers accepted part payment from their customers in cheque and the rest in cash.

Title: DHFL sees Rs 934 crore Q3 profit, but auditors have concerns
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: Troubled housing finance company DHFL reported a net profit of Rs 934 crore for the quarter ended December 2019 — almost thrice the Rs 313 crore reported in the corresponding quarter of the previous year. The company had reported a loss of Rs 6,705 crore in the preceding quarter ended September 2019.

The audited financial results contain a host of qualifications from the auditors. These include uncertainty over adequacy of securities and value of these loans. The profits were reported despite all lending business of the company coming to a standstill. It is undergoing insolvency proceedings and lenders have invited bids for the company or parts of its business.

Several factors enabled the company to report an increase in net profit. First, it spent only Rs 1,423 crore towards finance costs even as it booked Rs 2,431 crore of interest income. This was partly because it did not provide for an interest amount of Rs 527 crore on borrowings since the insolvency commencement date — that is, December 3 — based on the opinion from legal advisers.

“If the interest was accrued on borrowings, the profit for the quarter and nine months would have been lower by Rs 392.39 crore,” said the cash-strapped company. Also, the only significant provisions made by the company was of Rs 1,139 crore toward the fair value of loans. According to the company, the valuation may change again under the insolvency process and the “recoverability or otherwise of these loans is yet to be ascertained”.

The Enforcement Directorate, which is investigating the company, had said that around 1 lakh retail accounts were fake, and funds were diverted. DHFL chairman and managing director Kapil Wadhawan is jailed in connection with a money-laundering probe against the late gangster and drug smuggler Iqbal Mirchi.

DHFL is currently being managed by an RBI-appointed administrator who has commissioned an independent firm to audit the transactions of the firm. The company said that until the outcome of the enforcement investigations and the administrator-commissioned audit are not known, it is not possible to know the impact on the financial results.

Title: Ship with Chinese crew kept off Chennai port for a day over coronavirus scare
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

M V Magnate, carrying a cargo of steel, has come from Shanghai

CHENNAI: Drama preceded the docking of M V Magnate from Shanghat at Chennai port on Tuesday as two of its crew showed symptoms of fever and were quarantined onboard. They later tested negative for novel corona virus (COVID-19). The bulk carrier with a cargo of steel had to wait for a day in the outer anchorage after staff of pilot boats refused to guide it in.

Ships cannot enter a port unless staff of pilot boats board it and guide the captain to steer it through water channels that lead to the dock. Giant bulk carriers need at least four pilot boats and a tug to guide them.

When M V Magnate, bearing a Panama flag, reached the city port’s outer anchorage, the captain requested permission to be guided into the port, but staff who man pilot boats refused to do it because of a scare that the Chinese crew could be infected with COVID-19 as it had come from Shanghai. Later, workers by the side of the quay also refused to handle the ship if it was brought in, saying they were frightened to touch the ropes that would be thrown out from the ship to moor it. There is no ban on ships from China entering ports in India.

On Wednesday, sources in the port said, the authorities had to send a team led by a health officer on a boat to the ship. “The team checked the crew and found that two of them had symptoms of fever. Then another team reached the ship and collected blood samples of the unwell sailors to be sent to the lab for testing,” he added.

The authorities, meanwhile, convinced the staff and workers to handle the ship as the affected crew had been quarantined onboard. It was brought in after they were informed that the affected sailors had only mild fever and no symptoms of respiratory problem.

Another official said that the ship had to wait for a day at the outer anchorage and the cargo was not unloaded till the results showed that the two crew members had tested negative for COVID-19. “They have docked the ship and the unloading began on Thursday evening. The ship is scheduled to leave the port on Saturday. Now that it has lost a day, the departure may get delayed,” he added.

The protocol put in place at ports includes thermal screening of the crew and passengers and a quarantine facility where people with symptoms of fever can be moved. But all these are to be followed only after ships reach the docks.

Title: Bihar CM Nitish Kumar for industrial use of poplar trees
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Chief minister (CM) Nitish Kumar on Thursday asked the industry department to explore ways for industrial use of poplar variety of trees available in the state by involving the paper industry, as it would help in increasing the income of farmers.

The CM was making the mid-term review of the achievements made under the Bihar Industrial Incentive Policy (BIIP)-2016, besides discussing the amended provisions of the industrial policy. The review meeting was held at the Sankalp auditorium on the premises of the CM’s official residence – 1, Anne Marg.

The CM also asked the industries department to send a team of experts to Uttarakhand to study the functioning of poplar processing plants. The poplar variety of trees, which have grown up in the last eight years, could be used in the paper industry to bring increased returns to farmers, he said.

Nitish said at a time when trade, business and commercial activities have increased in the state, there is a need to explore the areas in which investors could pump in money to establish industries.

The industries department made a detailed presentation at the review meeting which was attended by industries minister Shyam Rajak, chief secretary Deepak Kumar, development commissioner Arun Kumar Singh , finance and energy department principal secretaries S Siddharth and Pratyaya Amrit, respectively, as well as principal secretary to CM Chanchal Kumar, industries department secretary Narmadeshwar Lal and agriculture secretary N Sarwan Kumar, among others.

The CM said the government launched the ‘Hariyali Mission’ in 2012 under which 19 crore saplings of various varieties were planted. He said the poplar variety of trees had grown and matured, and, therefore, were ready for use in the paper industry.

Title: Bihar: After tapping Sharad Yadav, GA allies approach Prashant Kishor
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

PATNA: After their meeting in Patna with LJD chief Sharad Yadav last week, leaders of the three smaller Mahagathbandhan constituents — RLSP chief Upendra Kushwaha, HAM (S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi and VIP chief Mukesh Sahni — met expelled JD (U) functionary Prashant Kishor in New Delhi on Thursday.

Prior to this meeting, Kishor had met Kushwaha alone on Wednesday. As with the Sharad Yadav meeting, RJD and Congress were not represented in the Thursday’s meeting with the three opposition leaders.

RLSP general secretary Madhaw Anand told TOI on Thursday that discussions on a wide range of issues were held in the meeting between Kushwaha and Kishor on Wednesday. “Kishor has been in touch with us and preliminary rounds of discussions are being held as of now. No commitment has been made on poll-rated association from any side as of now,” Madhaw said.

Kishor did not respond to queries made by TOI on his meetings with the Mahagathbandhan leaders.

Political observers speculated that the bid to make a separate approach to Kishor by Kushwaha, Manjhi and Sahni could be an attempt to flex muscle in front of allies Congress and RJD or create a third front in Bihar.

“It is unlikely that Kushwaha and Majhi will accept leadership of RJD chief Lalu Prasad ’s younger son Tejashwi Prasad Yadav in the upcoming assembly elections. So they are trying to flex muscle by holding separate meetings with Sharad Yadav and Kishor,” said D M Diwakar, social scientist and professor of economics at Patna- based A.N. Sinha Institute of Social Studies.

“For me, it is a tactics for eying larger share of seats in the upcoming elections,” Diwakar added.

RJD national vice-president Shivanand Tiwari said all parties are free to pursue their own strategies, while Bihar Congress functionaries were non-committal on their party’s stand on Kishor.

Kishor, however, had claimed on Tuesday that he is not working for any political party or leader in the run up to Bihar elections as of now.

Most opposition parties in Bihar hailed the manner in which Kishor attacked the governance model of CM Nitish Kumar in his presser in Patna on Tuesday, claiming that Bihar of 2005 and that of today are the same.

“PK has expressed the opinion of all people of Bihar, especially the youths. Bihar does not want to look back, rather it aspires to progress in the future…PK’s strategy will act as a catalyst to bring change in Bihar,” Kushwaha had tweeted hours after PK’s presser on Tuesday.

Manjhi, too, had hailed Kishor and said he would be welcomed in Mahagathbandhan for development of Bihar. “Kishor has Bihari DNA… Kishor stands with Gandhian ideologies and it is everyone’s responsibility to stand with him and work on the suggestions given by him for development of Bihar,” Manjhi had said on Tuesday.

Title: Budget poor example of financial mgmt: BJP
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Terming the state Budget as “routine,” opposition BJP on Thursday said the Budget was a very poor example of financial management which had no vision to safeguard the rights and interests of farmers, labourers and women.

Leader of Opposition in the assembly, Gulab Chand Kataria, said the Ashok Gehlot government had already burdened consumers with Rs 12,000 crore annually by increasing the power tariff. “Power companies are reeling under losses. There has been no provision or plan to bring power companies in profit and the government has given an annual burden of Rs 12,000 crore on consumers by increasing power tariff,” Kataria said at a press conference after the Budget.

Deputy leader of opposition, Rajendra Rathore, said Gehlot had merely done some jugglery of words. “He has misled people as the Budget lacks any vision or farsightness,” he added.

State BJP president Satish Poonia termed it a “routine Budget” which is not going to fulfil the expectations of the people. “Every time they blame the Centre government but never admitted that this government so far has a very poor financial management. I believe this is totally a directionless Budget which has failed to fulfil the exactions of various sections of society,” he added.

Title: Groups clash in Bardoli for credit; 15 hurt
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Surat: At least 15 people suffered multiple injuries when two groups came to blows in Bardoli on Thursday on the issue of missing names from the plaque placed under the idol of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj inaugurated a day earlier by BJP leaders. The groups chased and hit each other with hockey sticks and blunt wooden objects on a public road at Dhamdod Naka in Bardoli.

The groups fought with each other on Tuesday night as well but no action was taken by police then. Both groups want names of their leaders to be inscribed on the plaque. The arguments turned violent on Tuesday but no offence was lodged .

After the idol was inaugurated on Wednesday, the argument over names continued and it turned violent when around 25 people from each group reached the spot. They attacked each other with sticks and hockey sticks. They pelted each other with stones as well.

"Police reached the spot and controlled the situation. We have started the process to register the offence and to identify those involved in the clash," a police officer said.

Title: At Rs 42,900, gold touches an all-time high
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Chennai: Gold prices touched an all-time high of $1,612 an ounce on Thursday, as investors parked themselves in safe havens even as they weigh the impact of coronavirus outbreak in China on the global economy. 24 carat domestic gold prices touched a high of Rs 43,050 for 10 grams in Chennai. Prices in Mumbai and Delhi hovered around Rs 42,900. A weak rupee at Rs 71.7/ USD further pushed up prices.

The price rise comes at a time when gold imports are down by 9% and the budget upheld the import duty of 12.5%, holding up the prices and doing away with changes of a pick-up in domestic demand. The World Gold Council saw a 9% drop in the overall gold demand in India in 2019. The gold prices are up by 6% in 2020.

Analysts predict a further rally in prices. “Following concerns still persisting over the spread of Coronavirus, the primary trend of Gold continues to remain bullish.

The near and medium-term oscillators are positive. This has potential to rise towards Rs 41,850 - Rs 42,000 and over the next couple of months on the MCX,” says Arun Kumar, market strategist, Reliance Securities.

Kishore Narne from Motilal Oswal adds that countries such as China, Germany, Japan and Britain looking to increase liquidity, even if the impact of Coronavirus reduces, the prices would go up as this would favour purchase of gold by investors. “In the short term, the price would go upto $1,680 globally and Rs 43,500 in India,” he added.

Title: Cop kills self over financial troubles in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Sata Teja Rabari shot himself with his service revolver on Thursday afternoon at a vacant house in Sector-30, ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: A 53-year-old head constable posted in the security branch of the State Reserve Police Force (SRPF) in Gandhinagar, allegedly committed suicide by shooting himself with his service revolver on Thursday afternoon at a vacant house in Sector-30 of the capital, ostensibly due to financial problems.

Sata Teja Rabari, a native of Ramdhani village of Shihor taluka in Bhavnagar district, had been in the service for around 25 years, said Gandhinagar deputy superintendent of police M K Rana. Rabari had been deployed in the security branch at the state secretariat in Gandhinagar for five years and lived in a flat at Pethapur village.

Rana said Rabari went to a vacant house in the government colony at Sector 30 in his car and shot himself. As a police control room (PCR) vehicle passed by, two cops in the van saw the vehicle in front of the vacant house. Suspecting illegal activity, they went inside and found Rabari in a pool of blood.

Rana further said that a suicide note was found in Rabari’s pocket, in which he described the financial problems he was facing for six months.

“Rabari had also called his wife at around 11.45am and told her that this would be his last call and asked her to take care of their four children. In the note, he also asked his younger brother to take care of his children and fix his elder son’s engagement,” said Rana.

An official of Sector-21 police station, where a case of accidental death was registered, said that Rabari did not say in the note whether he was being harassed by a moneylender.

He just wrote that he was in a financial crisis and it was impossible for him to live any more.

Title: Bihar DGP’s ‘chaupal’ in Hajipur on February 22
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

DGP Gupteshwar Pandey

PATNA: With a view to sharing views with people’s representatives and students , director general of police (DGP) Gupteshwar Pandey will hold a ‘chaupal’ at the Akshaywat Stadium in Hajipur on February 22.

According to Vaishali SP Gaurav Mangla, preparations are afoot to make the ‘chaupal’ a grand success.

“The state police chief wants to have a direct conversation with people’s representatives and students. He will make them aware of their roles in making the society crime-free and maintaining peace and harmony,” the SP told this newspaper on Thursday.

The DGP’s ‘chaupal’ assumes significance in the wake of recent spurt in crimes like loot, murder and extortion in Vaishali.

Tirhut range IG Ganesh Kumar had reviewed the law and order situation in the district on Wednesday and told the SP and the DSP to pull up their socks. “Rising incidents of loot and murder are a headache for the district police. The situation has, however, improved as several cases were cracked in the past couple of weeks,” the IG said.

In January, a notorious liquor smuggler, Baiju Mahto, was killed in an encounter with police under the Lalganj police station area in the district. “His elimination and intensive raids on liquor smugglers have contained the supply of the commodity in the district,” sources in the SP office said.

Title: 300 schoolteachers gherao district education office in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Government teachers stage protest at the office of district education officer in Patna on Thursday

PATNA: More than 300 government schoolteachers ‘gheraoed’ the district education office on Thursday and asked Patna DEO Jyoti Kumar to revoke the termination of two regular teachers and the show-cause notices against four ‘niyojit’ (contractual) teachers. They even tried to take the staff hostage, but the latter locked the office gate and escaped.

The DEO had terminated the services of two regular teachers — Manoj Kumar of Middle School at Nooruddinganj in Malsalami and Mohd Mustafa Azad of Prathmik Vidyalaya in Chakram — on February 17. He also issued show-cause notices to Prem Chandra of Kanya Madhya Vidyalaya in Bankipore, Rameshwar of Rewa Middle School in Masaurhi, Anand Mishra of Raghopur Middle School in Bihta and Virendra Kumar Yadav of Maharajghat Middle School in Patna City on late Wednesday evening.

A ‘niyojit’ teacher of Harnatiya School in Bakhtiyarpur, Jitu Singh, told this newspaper, “The state government will have to fulfil our demand of equal pay for equal work. It won’t be able to fool us this time.”

Manoj, one of the teachers whose services have been terminated, said the protest at the DEO office would continue till their demands were met. “Staging protests is our democratic right and the government cannot threaten us by stopping our salaries or initiating other actions. Such lame attempts will only add fuel to the fire,” he added.

Around 4.5 lakh ‘niyojit’ and regular teachers of government and government-aided schools had gone on an indefinite strike on February 17, demanding equal pay for equal work and old pension scheme, among others.

“Around 70,000 teachers of secondary schools and members of the Bihar School Secondary Teachers’ Association will also join the protest from February 25. How will the government cope with the situation and who will they depute for evaluation of answer sheets?” asked Anand, who was issued a show-cause notice.

He also alleged that the education department had not invited the teachers for talks even though they had submitted a letter in this regard.

Education minister Krishna Nandan Prasad Verma, on the contrary, claimed that the department was ready to talk to the teachers, but their demands could not be fulfilled.

“We will not let the students suffer and look for other ways to get the Intermediate and Matriculation answer sheets evaluated. The results will also be published on time,” he said.

Complaint lodged against teachers: A complaint has been lodged against 22 teachers in Darbhanga and four teachers in Saharsa for forcefully shutting their respective district education offices. One teacher has also been arrested in Begusarai for attacking the DEO.

Title: Prashant Kishor launches ‘Baat Bihar Ki’ campaign
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Prashant Kishor

PATNA: Poll strategist Prashant Kishor launched his ‘ Baat Bihar Ki’ campaign on Thursday with an aim to connect 1 crore people, primarily youths, in the state. A website – www.baatbiharki.in – started functioning from 11am on Thursday. People can also give a call on phone number 6900869008 to join the campaign.

In order to join the campaign through the website, the interested person will be required to fill a simple form, giving details like name, mobile number, WhatsApp number, e-mail ID, gender, age, educational qualification, occupation, reservation category, whether they are willing to contest election and if yes, which election, among others.

“Bihar has not seen any pivotal change in the last 15 years on various social and economic parameters. The situation in Bihar is still the same as it was in 2005...’Baat Bihar Ki’ is an initiative to make sure Bihar is counted as one of the 10 leading states of the country in the next 10 years. The goal is to connect people, who believe in this effort, from village to village and build a strong political leadership,” the introductory message on the home page of the website reads.

Kishor had told media persons on Tuesday that his target is to enrol 1 crore people with this forum to create a group of like-minded people, who would come together to help Bihar find its rightful place among the top 10 states of the country in the next 10-15 years.

Title: Bihar: Visit this college park to learn Gandhi philosophy
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

PATNA: Naubatpur-based Malti Dhari College has developed a park for disseminating moral teaching based on Mahatma Gandhi’s ideals to students and others.

Named as Bapu Naitik Udyan, the park, created in a 60x60 feet lawn, displays several moral teachings on marble plates where students pass their leisure hours, take selfies and share them on social media.

A separate marble plate written with the seven sins listed by Mahatma Gandhi attracts large number of viewers, especially guardians who visit the campus for different works.

College principal Dr Kanhaiya Prasad Sinha said the park was developed as a token of tribute to Mahatma Gandhi on his 150th birth anniversary and now it has become an attraction for both students and guardians.

“A bust of Mahatma Gandhi will soon be installed on a podium in the middle of the park. Some private schools of the neighbouring areas too take this place as a site of excursion and send their children to note down the quotes loaded with ethical values,” Sinha said. Also, the college has developed a meditation spot, Dhyan Sthal, under a peepal tree planted by the chief minister Nitish Kumar in June 2008, Sinha added. A constituent unit of Pataliputra University, Malti Dhari College has about 5,000 students, including a large number of girls.

Shweta Bala, an English teacher and incharge of the cultural activities at the college, said the messages and Gandhi’s quotes displayed at the park had an appeal to students for introspection and many of them take selfies and share them on social media. She said the park cast a positive impact on students who remain mostly busy with their books and examinations and have little time to think over the ethical values.

Title: Shaktikanta Das at MPC: Economy needs more monetary stimulus
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

RBI governor Shaktikanta Das (File photo: PTI)

MUMBAI: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Shaktikanta Das had said at the monetary policy committee (MPC) meeting held earlier this month that the economy needed further monetary stimulus, but refrained from pushing for a rate cut given the uncertainty over inflation. This is revealed by the minutes of the meeting, which were released on Thursday. They further show that all members of the MPC were concerned about inflation.

“The Union Budget has sought to provide counter-cyclical support to the economy while broadly adhering to fiscal prudence. Monetary transmission and bank credit flows have improved, but they need to become stronger. While the macroeconomy needs further monetary stimulus, the inflation outlook continues to be uncertain,” Das had said. The MPC meeting resulted in a unanimous vote for holding rates. However, Das announced a three-year loan to banks at cheap rates to bring down their cost of funds.

The minutes show that the MPC members had expected that inflation would come down. This did not happen because the seasonal winter softening of vegetable prices was delayed and prices of several other food items such as pulses, milk and edible oils continued to rise.

“There is uncertainty about inflation excluding food and fuel, given the recent cost-push shocks, especially of mobile charges, prices of automobiles and essential medicines. Overall, the path of headline inflation is expected to moderate. But, given the prevailing uncertainty, it is prudent to await more clarity based on incoming data,” said Das.

Deputy governor Michael Patra said that the MPC has entered “the tunnel of testing trade-offs” and it may be a while before the light at the end of the tunnel is sighted. “As in December, a monetary policy response to the state of the economy is stifled by higher than expected elevation in inflation. The breach in the upper tolerance band of the MPC’s inflation target band in the December print may well recur in the months ahead,” said Patra.

Other members also strongly expressed the need to tackle inflation. “I find the growing chorus challenging the efficacy of flexible inflation targeting in India worrying. For those who advocate targeting an inflation rate higher than 4%, I am sorry: 4-6% inflation is not price stability!” said economics professor and MPC member Chetan Ghate.

According to Janak Raj, executive director in charge of the MPC, the increase in inflation in non-vegetable food items was more likely to be sustained. “Given this broad-based increase in food prices, there is a lot of uncertainty as to the level at which food inflation will stabilise even as onion prices normalise completely. Food inflation, therefore, needs careful monitoring,” he said.

Title: Hyderabad flooded with smuggled Swiss gold
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Swiss gold is being smuggled into the city in large quantities through land, sea and air, said senior officials of the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) on Thursday.

While the land route from Myanmar is famous for gold smugglers, the sea route from Sri Lanka and multiple air routes are now being used by smugglers to hoodwink police and the DRI.

DRI statistics reveal that in 2019-20, around 25 cases were booked in which 162 kg of gold valued at Rs 60 crore was seized. This was much higher than the 40 kg of gold valued at Rs 13 crore seized in 2018-19.

Sources said overall gold smuggling has increased as the demand in the domestic market has risen. “Switzerland has one of the world's biggest refineries of gold. Gold mined from Africa and elsewhere in the world reaches Switzerland and gold bars are made. There is a huge demand for Swiss origin gold due to its purity. Most of the gold caught by us is of Swiss origin,” said a top DRI official.

DRI officials found the seal of Valcambi Swiss gold in the seized items and it is believed that traders buy them legally in Switzerland at low cost and smuggle it out through aerial routes.

Officially, India is one of the biggest importers of gold from Switzerland and after Switzerland, most gold seized is from UAE.

Investigations also revealed that using the sea route from Sri Lanka, the gold reaches Ramanathapuram in Tamil Nadu, before it's smuggled by road to Hyderabad.

It is smuggled from Myanmar via Guwahati to Hyderabad by land.

Last year, the DRI said that Myanmar-based gold refineries on the borders of Mizoram and Manipur are the transit points of gold smuggling.

In 2018-19, India imported around 982 tonnes of gold worth USD 32.9 billion and more than half of it was from Switzerland, according to import and export data of the Ministry of Commerce.

Title: Marine freighter service to connect Surat with Chennai & Kolkata from February 26
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The service is scheduled to start from February 26

SURAT: Shrimp farming in south Gujarat is set to get a boost following SpiceJet’s decision to launch first ‘marine krishi udaan’. A direct dedicated freighter service to connect Chennai, Visakhapatnam , Surat and Kolkata has been announced by the airline from February 26.

Official sources said Chennai and Visakhapatnam are major shrimp seed producing centres in India. The shrimp seeds are then sent to West Bengal and Gujarat for farming and breeding. However, shrimp farmers face a lot of problems in transporting these seeds as there are no direct dedicated flights from the production centres to locations of cultivation.

SpiceJet officials stated that the direct dedicated freighter service will be launched from Chennai and Visakhapatnam to Surat and Kolkata from February 26. This will improve logistics and connectivity, thus helping enormously in the growth of shrimp farming.

Gujarat Aqua Feed Dealers’ Association (GAFDA) estimates requirement of 500 crore shrimp seeds per annum in Gujarat, mainly in south Gujarat. Majority of shrimp seeds are sourced from Chennai and Visakhapatnam via Mumbai. It takes about 10 hours for the seeds to reach hatcheries, leading to high mortality rate and losses to farmers.

GAFDA president Manoj Sharma said, “The dedicated freighter service to Surat will pave the way for further development of shrimp farming in south Gujarat. This is a good news for shrimp farming community. The demand for shrimp seeds is increasing and we presume that the airline will have to start additional freighter service to cater to the ever-growing demand.”

Sharma added, “The daily requirement of shrimp seeds in south Gujarat is pegged at one crore. Over 800 farmers cultivate shrimps on 7,000 hectare of land. This is going to be a win-win situation for the farmers.”

Airports Authority of India (AAI) inaugurated domestic cargo terminal at Surat airport on January 29. The cargo terminal built at a cost of Rs13 crore is designed to handle all types of cargo, including agriculture, floriculture, valuables, marine, hazardous etc.

Title: DGGI unearths Rs 15.5 crore tax evasion by state’s snack firms
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGI) has unearthed GST tax evasion to the tune of Rs15.5 crore by manufacturers and suppliers of packaged snacks during simultaneous search operations carried out in Surat, Vadodara, Bharuch and Surendranagar on Thursday.

DGGI’s Surat zonal unit had received intelligence about various firms engaged in the manufacturing and selling of packaged snacks for huge evasion of GST. Search operations were carried out in Surat, Bharuch, Vadodara and Surendranagar by DGGI sleuths , an official release said.

Preliminary scrutiny of documents revealed that the firms were miss-classifying their products under harmonized system nomenclature (HSN) code to evade GST payment. The unfried fryum and papad products supplied by the firms are taxable at the rate of 12% under GST. However, these firms were not paying applicable tax thereby evading GST to the tune of Rs15.5 crore.

A DGGI officer said the firms have admitted about misclassification of the items and non-payment of GST. The firms have paid Rs90 lakh and have agreed to pay the remaining tax dues soon.

Title: South Gujarat revs up shrimp output to 45,000 MT in 10 years
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Brakishwater aquaculture farmers’ conclave participants during a field visit on Wednesday

SURAT: South Gujarat has become the largest shrimp producing region in western India and third in the country after Andhra Pradesh and West Bengal . From 300 metric tonne in 2009, shrimp production has crossed 45 ,000 metric tonne per annum in 2019, generating an annual turnover of Rs 2,000 crore.

Gujarat Aqua Feed Dealers’ Association (GAFDA) president Manoj Sharma said, “There is a huge potential to increase shrimp farming in Gujarat, particularly in south Gujarat. There is 3.75 lakh hectare of brakishwater land available in Gujarat, of which hardly 2% is under cultivation.”

Sharma added, “About 800 farmers are involved in shrimp farming on about 7,000 hectare of brackish water land in Surat, Bharuch, Navsari and Valsad. These farmers give direct employment to more than 25,000 people and indirect employment to approximately 30,000 people.”

In his presentation at national brakishwater aquaculture farmers’ conclave organized by Central Institute of Brakishwater Aquaculture (CIBA) in the city on Thursday, Sharma said domestic consumption of shrimps in India is negligible and that about 90% of the production is exported to the United States, China, Japan, West Asia, China and Vietnam .

Sharma said majority of farmers grow venami variety of shrimps. In one hectare of land, farmers can cultivate 5,000 kilogram of shrimps having international value of $30,000. Even if we consider 10% profit, farmers earn $3,000 in a single crop.

Pradip Navik, vice-president of Gujarat Aquaculture Association (GAA), told TOI, “Gujarat has capacity to produce over Rs10,000 crore worth of shrimps, but we are not getting government support when it comes to allotment of land. Majority of brakishwater land is owned by the government in the coastal areas of the state.”

Rahul Bhagwagar, a shrimp farmer from Olpad, who owns 300 ponds, said, “I started with two ponds 10 years ago and now own 250 of them. We have been cultivating 1,400 tonne of shrimps per annum.”

Nehal Gandhi, who owns 400 shrimp ponds in Borsi and Machad villages in Navsari district, said, “Atmosphere and water quality in south Gujarat are conducive for shrimp farming. We want some support from the government to take the blue revolution to a much higher scale. At present, we are cultivating 1,200 tonne per annum.”

Title: Narendra Modi: Day after PM Narendra Modi tasted it, ‘litti-chokha’ politics plays out in poll-bound Bihar
Content:
PM Narendra Modi having the traditional Litti Chokha during his visit to the Hunar Haat at India Gate on Wedne... Read More

Had tasty Litti Chokha for lunch along with a hot cup of tea... #HunarHaat https://t.co/KGJSNJAyNu — Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) 1582108226000

PM’s sampling of the Bihari delicacy grabbed headlines and generated political heat in Patna (Photo: Twitter handle of PM Narendra Modi)

यह सुखद संयोग था कि जिस दिन बिहार सरकार किसानों से पटना में संवाद कर रही थी, किसानों की आमदनी दोगुनी करने के उपायों… https://t.co/WkDDmbMYRx — Sushil Kumar Modi (@SushilModi) 1582205460000

Thank you respected PM for liking famous Bihari delicacy! Since Bihar CM can’t ask, I would like to draw your kind… https://t.co/HtMH5YxYpS — Tejashwi Yadav (@yadavtejashwi) 1582121187000

PATNA: Chief minister Nitish Kumar’s dream of seeing at least one Bihari dish on the plates of every Indian came true as PM Narendra Modi took ‘litti-chokha’ national when he tasted the dish at Hunar Haat in New Delhi on Wednesday.PM’s sampling of the Bihari delicacy grabbed headlines and generated political heat in Patna evoking sharp reactions from opposition politicians and lauded by ruling NDA leaders.Deputy CM and senior BJP leader Sushil Kumar Modi took to Twitter on Thursday to praise the PM. “It was a coincidence that when PM Narendra Modi was having litti-chokha in New Delhi’s Hunar Haat, the state government officials were busy in deliberations to make the dream to have a Bihari dish in every citizen’s platter a reality and devising ways to increase the income of farmers in the state.”SuMo’s tweet was in reference to Nitish’s statement in December 2010 in which he had said, “I dream of a day when every people in this nation will have at least one food item in their dish or kitchen from Bihar.”But former CM and HAM (S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi said, “Is this an announcement of the state assembly poll in Bihar due later this year?... Under such circumstances, it (PM tasting the dish) has its political interference.” he said, adding, he is also fond of litti-chokha.Leader of opposition Tejashwi Prasad Yadav, too, took to twitter. “Thank you respected PM for liking famous Bihari delicacy!” He added: “Since Bihar CM can’t talk, I would like to draw your attention towards Bihar’s legitimate share pending quite long.” However, his elder brother Tej Pratap Yadav tweeted in chaste Bhojpuri, “Katano khaee ba litti chokha, Bihari na bhuli dhokha.”The politics of ‘litti-chokha’ can’t be complete without a mention of former CM and RJD chief Lalu Prasad. Lalu, who is at present serving sentence in fodder scam cases, is among the admirers of this Bihari delicacy. “Lalu had said a day after Nitish parted ways from Mahagathbandhan in 2017 that two things have become famous in the country— Bihar Ka litti-chokha aur Nitish Ka ‘dhokha’ (betrayal),” a senior RJD functionary Mohammad Shami Ahmad said.“He (Lalu) played a good host during winters and enjoyed ghee-laced litti-chokha. He was of the opinion that ‘isme milawat ki jungayish hi nahi hai’, the RJD leader, once considered close to Lalu family, said.Litti-chokha has been a favourite dish not only for politicians but also for Bollywood stars. Actor Amir Khan had litti-chokha at a roadside stall near Patna zoo during the promotion of his movie ‘Ghajini’. Ajay Devgn and Sonakshi Sinha had also tasted it during promotion of their film ‘Son of Sardar’.“One of the major reasons behind the popularity of litti-chokha is its price. Besides, it contains ‘sattu’ which keeps the stomach cool and the same time full during scorching summer heat,” said Ramesh Yadav, a seller at Patna Junction.

Title: Ahmedabad: Man stalks college student, threatens acid attack
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

Title: We have every right to enact agriculture bill: Tamil Nadu minister
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

C Ve Shanmugam

CHENNAI: Law minister C Ve Shanmugam on Thursday said Tamil Nadu was legally competent to enact the bill to protect the Cauvery delta region, since agriculture came under the state list.

The law minister told the assembly that the Union minister for environment, Prakash Javadekar , had informed chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami that the January 16 Central notification did not prevent the state government from taking an appropriate decision in the matter and that the final decision on allowing any particular project would continue to vest with the state government.

The CM had written to the Union minister on February 10, requesting him to add a provision to the amendment notification brought out by the ministry, exempting public hearing for hydrocarbon projects. He wanted the Centre’s backing to declare the Cauvery delta districts as an ecologically sensitive zone.

Javadekar in his February 19 letter, said, “Dear Sri Edappadi K Palaniswami ji, this has reference to your letter dated February 10, regarding concerns on the onshore and offshore of oil and natural exploration projects or activities, while appreciating your concern regarding ecologically fragile agricultural zone situated in the Cauvery delta districts. We would like to bring to your notice the fact that the current notification dated January 16 does not prevent the state government from taking appropriate decision in the matter.”

“Any project proponent will, in the present scheme of things, have to apply to state environment impact assessment authority (SEIAA), which is an organ of the state government and SEIAA will take a final call in the matter. Therefore, the final decision as to whether to allow any particular project in any particular region would continue to vest with the state government. Further, such projects are also required to obtain the consent under the Air and Water Act from the state pollution control board,” said Javadekar in his letter.

Of the 31 petroleum mining licences (PML) and petroleum exploration licences (PEL) granted by the Centre, covering 341 wells, only 16 licences were active. There were no protests by locals over these wells which came into existence since 1958. Of the two licences for hydrocarbons, the AIADMK rejected one in 2013 and had not given sanction for Neduvasal till date, Shanmugam said.

The minister said the Centre had delegated powers to the state under environment protection laws to decide on the polluting industries. The industries must get environmental sanction of the state government under water and air laws. “The state is empowered to ban or shut any polluting industry. You don’t need to fear,” the minister said, pointing to the closure notice issued to Sterlite’s copper smelter unit in Tuticorin and ban on single use plastic by the state government.

Title: Crime rate up, but not much funds for men in khaki
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Be it the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) data or gangster Papla Gujjar’s jailbreak, it wasn’t a great year as far as the state’s law and order was concerned. However, nothing much was given in the Budget provisions for 2020-21 for modernisation of the police force, especially facilitating police stations with technical resources and adequate manpower.

Though chief minister Ashok Gehlot, who also holds the finance portfolio, proposed for consolidating the Special Operations Group (SOG) by adding two new field units and a special anti-narcotics unit, nothing much has come to the kitty of the home department.

Though there was a proposal of Rs 70 crore for purchase of 1,682 new vehicles, nothing much has been done to upgrade the police stations. “The incident of notorious gangster Papla Gujjar has exposed the arrangements one can see at a police station. I think there is a desperate need to have CCTV cameras, proper manpower equipped with arms and more quick response teams,” Omendra Bharadwaj, former DG, Rajasthan Police told TOI. He said recruitment on a big scale is a must and some provisions should have been there to combat cyber crime, the new challenge for the police. “I have found nothing to make the police stronger to check cyber crime,” he added. Some other retired officers criticized the provision of emergency response support system (ERSS).

Title: Tamil Nadu: Push for clarity ignored, DMK, allies walk out
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

M K Stalin

CHENNAI: The DMK , allies Congress and IUML walked out of the assembly in protest after their repeated pleas for referring the bill to a select committee to clarify several issues were not heeded to.

DMK chief M K Stalin said the party wholeheartedly welcomed the legislation, and that the party MPs would raise the issue of explorations in the Parliament, but said the bill should be referred to a committee for further clarification as the Supreme Court had struck down a law enacted by the Gujarat government as natural gas was a central subject. “Certain issues could be clarified if it is sent to the select committee. Only then full victory can be attained,” he said.

Stalin sought to know why the period of elected representatives in the proposed authority was confined to one year, and why delta districts like Trichy , Karur and Ariyalur were excluded from the bill’s purview. “The bill will be good only if the projects in operation are included,” he said, which was also reflected by deputy leader of opposition S Durai Murugan. Congress whip S Vijayadharini said the government should have provided information about existing projects in the bill for better clarity.

Title: Poor diet increases impacted wisdom teeth risk: Dental College survey
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Agra: “People who grow up eating processed, nutrient-poor diet are at the increased risk of impacted wisdom teeth,” says a survey conducted by Dr Z A Dental College (ZADC), Aligarh Muslim University (AMU). The survey covered people of various walks of life, including doctors, teachers, tailors, photographers, students, police personnel, house wives, farmers, shop keepers, engineers, businessmen, labourers and brokers.

Dr G S Hashmi of the department of oral and maxillofacial surgery, who conducted the survey on 5,030 patients, with his team, pointed out that heavy dependency on refined foods was found to be a common reason for the occurrence of third molars or wisdom teeth in most of the subjects who were surveyed.

Hashmi emphasised that the wisdom tooth may grow sideways, emerge only partially or remain completely trapped under gum and bone and is bound to make flossing more difficult, allowing food and bacteria to become trapped.

The doctor further said the survey gave solid evidence that “soft” modern diet, in conjunction with other factors associated with lifestyle, can promote abnormal development of jaws and narrow dental arches that don't fit in those third molars quite as well.

“Wisdom teeth are the last of the teeth to develop. They usually come in between the ages of 17 and 25. While you need the rest of the teeth in your mouth, you don't need an impacted tooth as it could damage the teeth around and cause gum disease and lead to infections and illnesses that can affect the heart, lungs and other organs,” said Hashmi.

He pointed out that it is a better idea to simply have wisdom teeth removed early on as in some cases, fluid-filled cyst or tumor can form around an untreated wisdom tooth.

"The survey showed that 43% of patients with impacted wisdom teeth were in the 15-25 years age group and 17% were aged between 36-45 years. Only 7% were above 45 years,” said Hashmi. He added that 89% of patients suffered bony impaction, while only 11% were found with soft tissue impactions.

Dr Hashmi's survey also showed 41% patients with impaction on the right side of jaw, and 39% having the problem on the left side. It also pointed out that 20% suffered with bilateral impaction.

Title: Gold worth Rs 40L concealed under aircraft seat seized
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Hyderabad: Customs sleuths seized 932 gm of abandoned gold worth Rs 40 lakh inside an aircraft that arrived from Jeddah on Wednesday night.

Acting on specific information, the Air Intelligence Unit (AIU) of customs department rummaged through the Spicejet flight (SG 034) from Jeddah to Hyderabad after it landed at RGI Airport on Wednesday night. The AIU team found gold biscuits weighing 932 gm concealed in the life jacket pouch under a passenger’s seat. “It appears like the smugglers have concealed the gold under the seat for their associates to pick it up during the particular aircraft’s subsequent domestic trips,” said a customs official. A case was registered under the Customs Act.

Title: Man kills wife, get life in jail
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: A man and his aide were sentenced to rigorous life imprisonment by Agra court for murder of his wife.

The accused, Rajeev Agrawal and his aid Santosh, were found guilty by the court of additional district judge XII, Shakeel Ur Rehman Khan on the charges of IPC section 302 (murder) and 201 (causing disappearance of evidence of offence).

On March 14, 2014, Rajeev Agrawal, living separately from his wife Seema Agrawal, brutally murdered her at his rented accomodation in Lashkarpur area under New Agra police jurisdiction.

Speaking to TOI, additional district government counsel Shashi Sharma said, “The horrific murder was witnessed by Rajeev’s two children Saurab and Shruti. In court trial, the two witnesses identified Rajeev as the killer.”

“Motive behind the murder was a loan of Rs 80,000 which Seema had given to her brother Rajesh Agrawal. When Rajeev came to know about the loan amount, he started pressurising Rajesh and Seema to return the money. When Rajesh failed to pay the amount on time, Rajeev murdered his wife. Prior to murder, the couple was living separately. Rajeev had called Seema at his home on the day of the crime,” added ADGC.

Title: Varanasi: Man found murdered, three detained
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

VARANASI: A 25-year-old man was battered to death near Patrakarpuram colony in Cantonment police station area on Thursday.

Police said the victim, Arvind alias Lalu Rajbhar, was attacked with some heavy and blunt object. Cops are examining CCTV footages in the area in which Rajbhar is seen with some youths armed with sticks.

Local residents found the body in a pool of blood on Thursday morning and informed police after which senior officials, including SSP Prabhakar Chowdhary, rushed to the spot for probe.

“Prima facie it appears to be a fallout of some dispute. Empty liquor bottles were also found from the spot. He was attacked with some heavy and blunt object. Further investigations are on,” he added.

Three youths have been detained on the basis of CCTV footage for interrogation.

According to police, Arvind had left home on Wednesday night for decoration of local temple in view of Mahashivratri festival.

Two held for harassing woman: Two men were arrested on Thursday, five days after they shot at a woman near Fathua village, under Sarayinayat police station of Allahabad.

Title: Here's what A R Rahman has to say about daughter Khatija after she gets criticised by Taslima Nasreen for wearing a burqa
Content: AR Rahman's daughter Khatija often gets targeted for her choice of wearing a burqa at events. And it happened again recently when writer Taslima Nasreen commented that she feels suffocating when she looks at Khatija wearing a burqa at events.Taslima posted a picture of Khatija in a burqa and wrote, "I absolutely love A R Rahman 's music. But whenever i see his dear daughter, i feel suffocated. It is really depressing to learn that even educated women in a cultural family can get brainwashed very easily! (sic)"Soon, Khatija gave a befitting reply to Taslima with a post on Instagram . Now, talking about the same, father Rahman said that she has sung a song which received a lot of love and such criticism will never get any kind of retaliation from his side. The music maestro also stated that his daughter replied to Taslima over her comments on the burqa.He went on to add that children are brought up in a way where they understand the good and bad but they also have their own free will. When the singer was quizzed if had a conversation with his daughter over the controversy, he said that she did what she wanted to. He further stated that Khatija's attire is more than a religious thing and it's her choice to wear it and she has all the freedom to wear what she wants!

Title: Killers pumped 26 bullets into gangster in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pawan Anchil Thakur (inset) was shot near Auchandi border, which doesn’t have CCTV coverage. The killers had f... Read More

NEW DELHI: A long-standing turf war in outer Delhi’s Majra Dabas village probably ended in the murder of Pawan Anchil Thakur, who was sprayed with bullets while travelling in his SUV near Ladpur village in outer Delhi on Wednesday. Two members of the Deepak Titri gang have been identified for being involved in his murder.

Auchandi border, the area where Thakur was shot, doesn’t have CCTV coverage. The killers waylaid Thakur in an i20 car and fired 48 rounds, 26 of which hit him. A resident of Majra Dabas village, Thakur had allegedly shot at one of Titri’s associates last year and was jailed. He was given bail in January.

Police have learnt that Thakur had gone to Ladpur village to meet someone. On his way back, while he was about to take a U-turn, the killers intercepted him. Cops suspect that Thakur might have tried to fire at them, but was hit by several rounds. The criminals fled towards Haryana border after the murder. Police suspect the car used for committing the crime was stolen.

Thakur’s body was sent for autopsy at Sanjay Gandhi hospital. The body was handed to his family members on Thursday. Sources said it took nearly three hours for the doctors to remove the bullets from the body. Three X-rays were conducted to locate the bullets.

Sources said Thakur had aligned himself with the Tillu gang after striking a rivalry with Titri, who is suspected to be a close associate of Gogi. The role of Gogi’s henchmen in the murder has not been ruled out. Gogi had used similar modus operandi in murders committed earlier.

Senior officers said that gang wars, which had erupted in the early 1990s with rival groups trying to control land, got subdued after a series of arrests by Delhi Police. However, this created space for new criminals to step in. The new ganglords offered protection to landowners for a share in the real estate pie.

Sources said that gangs have started hiring contract killers for settling their disputes, since it keeps them off the hook. The killers are former members of the gangs that operated in the 1990s or early 2000s seeking an opportunity to take revenge. All logistical support is provided by the gangs that hire them.

Title: Constable held for cheating woman
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Hyderabad: A 24-year-old police constable was arrested for allegedly sexually exploiting a woman on the pretext of marriage and later cheating the victim. He was arrested on Thursday.

A Shiva Kumar Reddy, a constable of the 2018 batch posted at Headquarters ARPC-10611 and resident of Badangpet, was booked for cheating and rape, police said. The constable had lured the victim and sexually exploited her, promising to marry. On January 11, he, however, got married to another woman, after which the victim approached the Malakpet police and lodged a complaint. Kumar was arrested and produced before court.

In a similar case, Panjagutta police had last week arrested a constable for cheating a victim on the pretext of marriage. He planned to get married to another woman after which a case was registered. tnn

Title: Elephant, GIB, Bengal florican move closer to CMS Appendix I
Content:
Great Indian bustard

Bengal florican

Asian elephant

AHMEDABAD: The Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS) includes species that are facing a ‘very high risk of extinction in the wild in the near future.’On Thursday, India moved to include the Asian Elephant , the great Indian bustard and the Bengal florican to the Appendix I of CMS at the Committee of Whole (COW) which unanimously cleared the proposal. The proposal will now be sent for final voting to the plenary session of the conference of parties (COP) to the CMS scheduled on Saturday.In its rationale for including GIB in Appendix I, India cited seasonal fluctuation in numbers of GIB indicating cross-border movement. The government submitted that inclusion of the species, which has only about 150-odd birds left, in Appendix I will help range countries take immediate steps for its conservation including curbs on hunting. The proposal was supported by Saudi Arabia, European Union, Ecuador, Senegal, Peru, Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS), Bolivia, Somalia, Corbett Foundation and Young Naturalist Network. Pakistan, the range country where GIBs stray from India, was not present at the meeting.In its proposal for the Bengal florican, India said the species was on verge of extinction due to habitat loss, habitat degradation and hunting. The species no longer breeds outside protected areas except in a few pockets in the Brahmapurtra flood plains. The bird’s migratory range includes India, Nepal and Bangladesh. In its supporting statement, Bangladesh said the bird has become extinct in that country and no sightings have been recorded since 1882. India’s proposal to include Bengal florican in Appendix I was supported by the European Union, Costa Rica and the Bombay Nature History Society.India stated that mainland Asian elephants or Indian elephants are trying to survive in a continually shrinking, degraded and fragmented habitat. India said the country, being home to 60% of the global population of Asian elephants, has a primary duty to ensure its survival.The current distribution of wild Asian elephants is in 13 countries across South and Southeast Asia spread over an area of 4.86 lakh sq km.

Title: Drunk man tries to kill self, kids
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: A drunk man, along with his three children, was rescued by dial 112 rescue team after he attempted to commit suicide by setting his house ablaze.

The incident took place in Nekpur village under Khandauli police jurisdiction at around 1:30am when Raju (40), in a heavily inebriated state, locked his house from inside and set it home on fire while his kids were inside.

All four were rescued by a team comprising constables Ajeet, Satyendra and Manish.

Rescue team member Ajeet said, “After rescuing the four, we doused the fire with the help of local villagers. The entire house was filled with smoke and it was the kids who opened the locked door from inside.”

“After the incident, Raju’s mother alleged that he was pressuring her to get him married for the second time after his first wife died two years back due to poor health. The man was unable to take care of his kids. We handed over the man to the local police,” constable Ajeet said.

No police complaint has been lodged yet.

Title: ‘Cut’ practice keeping contractors away from water project: Jaleel
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: MP Imtiaz Jaleel on Friday said that the alleged bribe in the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) is keeping contractors and agencies away from the Rs 1,680 crore water project of the city.

Speaking at a press conference at the government guest house in the city on Friday, Jaleel said that the agencies are aware that if they pick a project of the AMC, they will be asked for bribe. Therefore, many prefer to stay away from the tenders invited for Rs 1,680 crore water scheme. Currently, only two agencies have technically qualified the financial bid.
