“No agencies were willing to bid for the tender because they know that there are people in the AMC who will ask for their cut for any project related to the civic body,” MP said.

Jaleel also spoke about the irregularities in the ward reservation of the municipal corporation.

“In the district planning committee meeting held on January 30, deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar made a statement which I completely agree with. Pointing at Shiv Sena, Pawar Pawar said that 8 to 10 corporators of the AMC run the entire business,” Jaleel said.

The MP said that the Aurangabad municipal commissioner should engage a high-level agency to inquire about the bills against which payments were issued by the AMC. “Enquiry should be initiated to see whose area saw the sanctioning of most bills and that too without any work on ground in the last couple of years. The municipal commissioner has decided to lodge an FIR against officials (those failing to produce measurement books).They should be booked under stringent sections because they are hand in gloves for the corruption going in the civic body for the last several years,” Jaleel said.

Irregularities in the

ward formation

MIM state president Imtiyaz Jaleel stated that the irregularities in the ward formation process for AMC elections are quite evident. “I personally met state election commissioner UPS Madan and discussed the irregularities observed in ward formation process. However, several complaints had emerged in the ward formation and we are taking them up,” Jaleel said.

Title: YS Jaganmohan Reddy: Investment done by India Cements is bribe, ED tells court
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

YS Jaganmohan Reddy

HYDERABAD: The Enforcement Directorate (ED) probing into the India Cements episode of YS Jaganmohan Reddy assets case has contended that Rs 140 crore made as investment by N Srinivasan and his India Cements company in various firms were proceeds of crime, made on the basis of high share value projected by Jagan firms.

The investments in 2007-2008 were made in Bharati Cements, Jagathi Publications and Carmel Asia Holdings, the Enforcement Directorate said.

Opposing quash pleas filed by India Cements and its MD Srinivasan, the Enforcement Directorate said a running firm like India Cements, which is one of the major players in the cement industry, bought shares of Bharati Cement, which was yet to commence operations, at 1300 per cent higher value, indicating that it was not an investment but bribe it paid for benefits it derived unduly from Andhra Pradesh government during the chief ministerial tenure of Jagan’s father YS Rajasekhara Reddy.

India Cements, according to the chargesheet filed by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), in the same case derived benefits like land, limestone allotments, additional water allocations, etc. In turn, it made huge investments in Jagan firms and the CBI is calling it a quid pro quo arrangement.

The Enforcement Directorate, in its counter, also said that India Cements sold the shares it acquired in Bharati Cements to a French company for Rs 121 crore and re-invested the same in Jagan’s firms.

The Enforcement Directorate, however, said in another para in the same counter that India Cements used this Rs 121 crore to clear its loans borrowed from HDFC bank, etc. The high court posted the case to April 15 for further hearing.

Title: Locals fume over garbage burning in Kowkoor
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Secunderabad: Residents living near Golf Enclave, Kowkoor complain that the air is the locality has become toxic due to the frequent burning of garbage.

“The environment has become toxic due to garbage burning. I request authorities to take responsibility of spreading awareness on the issue,” said Krishna Chaitanya , a resident. A senior citizen aired similar concerns. “The stench of burning garbage is unbearable. Continued exposure to such fumes will lead to health issues,” he said.

GHMC officials said that they would take action after conducting an inquiry. “GHMC staffers will visit the place in order to catch hold of the people burning garbage and take action. We will also look with the watchman’s guarding the apartments in that locality,” said K Helen Nirmala, GHMC assistant medical officer of health, Alwal circle.

She also said that the decision to conduct awareness campaigns in that area will finalised after speaking to resident welfare associations in Kowkoor.

Title: Workshop on Vedic knowledge on Feb 22-23
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Varanasi: A two-day workshop on Vedic jurisprudence and its impact on contemporary world will be organised at the Centre for Vedic Science, Banaras Hindu University on February 22 and 23. Talking to reporters on Thursday, coordinator Dr Upendra Kumar Tripathi said that the workshop will focus on the scientific study and research of the knowledge embedded in entire Vedic literature.

The inaugural session would be attended by former justice of Supreme Court Dr BN Srikrishna and vice-chancellor of Kalinga Institute of Social Sciences (Deemed University) Odisha, Prof Harekrishna Satapathy. BHU vice-chancellor Prof Rakesh Bhatnagar would preside over the function.

Title: Collector’s ‘comment’ on actor goes viral, deleted
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Hyderabad: Jagtial collector G Ravi on Thursday lodged a complaint with police alleging that unidentified persons logged into his twitter account and commented on an actor.

The collector lodged the complaint after a post from his handle commenting on the photos put up by actress Rashmika Mandanna went viral on social media. Hours later, the comment was deleted.

On February 18, Rashmika Mandanna posted some of her photos on twitter for her fans saying, “Let me look at you for a second and give you a smileeeee!”

Among the comments about the photos, the one from the twitter handle of Jagtial collector (@Collector_JGTL), saying “Chinchaavu Po Radhmika (sic)” went viral on social media. On learning about the tweet, the Jagtial collector G Ravi lodged a complaint with local police.

“The collector lodged a complaint stating that unknown persons logged into his official twitter handle and commented on some posts. We have registered a case under appropriate sections of law and took up the investigation,” Jagtial superintendent of police Ch Sindhu Sharma said.

Title: Cops can come home for statement: Teesta Setalvad
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

AHMEDABAD: Social activist Teesta Setalvad on Thursday sought direction to Gujarat police that they should visit her residence in Mumbai to record her statement instead of insisting on her visit to the city crime branch in connection with the digging of graves and exhuming of 28 bodies of the 2002 riots victims from a mass grave near Pandarwada in Panchmahal district .

Setalvad submitted a note in her quashing petition that is pending since 2017 for an FIR in the gravedigging incident. In this note, the HC was informed that the social activist has been summoned by the investigating officer to the city crime branch on February 27. The summons was issued under provisions of Section 160 of CrPC for the purpose of recording statement of a witness, said her advocate Yogesh Ravani.

The lawyer further said that Setalvad has insisted that the concerned police officer should be asked to go to her residence in Mumbai and record her statement. It was contended that the Supreme Court has laid down a procedure that police should not insist on summoning a woman witness to police station, but instead go to her place and record her statement.

Justice A G Uraizee allowed Setalvad to make changes in her petition and sought reply from the state government.

Title: City to soon get full-fledged passport office
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: The city is all set to get a full-fledged passport office that will help hundreds of applicants from Marathwada.

Aurangabad MP Imtiaz Jaleel said that the proposal sent by him is in final stage. “As per assurance given by regional passport officer Manoj Kumar Rai, it will soon be a reality,” he said.

Addressing a news conference, Jaleel said considering the hardships people face while travelling to regional passport offices for submission and verification of the identity proofs and other relevant documents, he was compelled to take up the issue with the passport authorities.

“I have personally made a representation to the authorities informing them that the Passport Seva Kendra in city-based post office is processing approximately 100 applications every day owing to this flow of applicants heading to Mumbai is very high.”

Title: NMC begins to develop rose garden
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has started to develop a rose garden at Bharat Mata-Ambedkar Udyan situated on Central Avenue at Lakadganj in East Nagpur. The move is as per directives of mayor Sandip Joshi and municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe.

The NMC garden department under deputy commissioner Amol Chorpagar has started to plant rose plants in the garden in a systematic manner. Various species of rose like yellow rose, summer flow rose, double delight, first prize, black lady etc were planted in the garden. The garden has started to bloom with rose plants and lot of flowers on it.

Joshi had directed the department to ensure proper maintenance of all gardens during ‘Walk and Talk With Mayor’. Immediately after assuming charge, Mundhe directed the department to ensure gardens become loveable and peaceful places for citizens.

Accordingly, the garden department has ensured appointment of private agencies for operation and maintenance of all gardens.

The department is planning to develop existing gardens in a concept-wise manner like rose garden in Bharat Mata-Ambedkar Udyan in the coming days.

Title: 18 booked for assaulting bus driver, conductor
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Eighteen people from Kannad were booked for allegedly assaulting the driver and conductor of a state transport bus on Tuesday.

As per the complaint lodged by the bus driver, Sudhakar Shamrao Shirsath (46), the bus overtook a car on the Aurangabad-Nashik road near Hotel Amrapali. During this, the bus scrapped the car.

After travelling for a while, the suspects waylaid the bus. The two suspects in the car entered the bus and started assaulting the bus driver. Soon, about 16 others joined them and began beating up the driver. When the conductor tried to intervene, the suspects assaulted him too.

Later, the injured driver and conductor were rushed to a private hospital. The driver is still undergoing treatment at the hospital.

Based on his complaint, the police have lodged a case against two identified and 16 unidentified suspects for allegedly using criminal force to deter a public servant from performing his duty, voluntarily causing hurt, criminal intimidation. Police informed that the suspects are locals and efforts are being made to nab them.

Title: BJD woman leader dies 8 days after setting self on fire
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Berhampur: A BJD women wing’s leader, who tried to set herself on fire on the premises of the Berhampur SP’s office in protest against her son’s arrest, succumbed to injuries at a private hospital in Bhubaneswar on Thursday.

The woman, 41-year-old Meenakshi Mishra of Panda Colony, under Baidynathpur police station limits, attempted self-immolation on February 12 claiming her son Krutibash Mishra, nicknamed Raja, was falsely implicated in an assault case. Meenakshi had poured kerosene over her and set herself on fire.

Sources said Meenakshi was initially admitted to MKCG Medical College and Hospital with 70 per cent burns and was later referred to SCB Medical College and Hospital in Cuttack after her condition deteriorated. She was finally taken to a private hospital in Bubaneswar, where she passed away. Raja, who is out on bail since February 13, was in the hospital along with her sister and some local BJD leaders.

Meenakshi, who was the chairperson of a women’s organization, had unsuccessfully contested in the Berhampur Municipal Corporation polls (ward number 39) on a BJD ticket.

When asked whether the police would take a lenient view of Raja’s action following his mother’s death, BP Pati, sub-divisional police officer of Berhmapur, said, “The incident is unfortunate but the police will not show any leniency towards Raja. We have registered a case. The trial will happen according to law.” Sources said Raja was arrested by the police on January 28 in an assault case. Police had earlier claimed Raja had seven cases registered against him in the past.

Deepak Patnaik, Raja’s advocate, said, “Raja is out on interim bail till February 24 to look after his mother. We will pray for an extension to his bail so that he can perform her last rites.”

Ruling BJD leaders described the incident as unfortunate. “It’s sad and unfortunate,” senior BJD leader and former MLA (Berhampur) R Ch Chyaupatnik said. The women’s wing of BJD’s Ganjam district unit had earlier submitted a memorandum to the Berhampur SP and demanded an impartial inquiry into the matter.

Opposition party leaders said the government failed to deliver justice to Meenakshi, forcing her to commit suicide. “We demand a high-level inquiry into the matter,” BJP’s Ganjam district president Bibhuti Jena said. Pitabash Panda, former working president of the district’s Congress committee, said the police had failed her.

EoM

Title: 7 held for beating, humiliating 2 Dalit youths in Nagaur
Content:
A screengrab of the video

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

JAIPUR: Seven persons have been arrested in connection with the brutal assault and caste abuse of two Dalit youths in Nagaur on Thursday.An FIR was filed on Wednesday after six videos of the incident went viral.The videos showed two Dalit cousins—one an 18-year-old and another a 23-year-old man —being beaten with rubber belts and the latter being sodomised with a screwdriver.The cousins can be seen begging for their lives and even losing consciousness several times. The attackers poured water and made them regain consciousness before hitting them again. The two were attacked by the group over allegations of theft.The state police have handed over the case to the special Heinous Case Monitoring Unit (HCMU) for investigation, said director general of police (DGP) Bhupendra Singh.They have also added Section 308 (attempt to commit culpable homicide) of the IPC to the sections already included in the FIR. The HCMU was formed after the accused in the Pehlu Khan lynching case were acquitted by a local court for lapses in investigation that led to acquittal. It was formed in August last year. The HCMU is headed by ADG (crime) and will keep track of investigations and trials of serious crimes.The incident, meanwhile, was severely criticised and evoked strong reactions from several leaders, including Congress leader Rahul Gandhi.While chief minister Ashok Gehlot has sought details from DGP Bhupendra Singh and assured prompt action, deputy CM and state Congress president Sachin Pilot announced that a fact-finding committee of the party would be send to Nagaur. The Centre for Dalit Rights too will send its panel to inquire into the matter.Shocked over the incident, Dalit rights activists called it shameful and a blot on the country. Dalits from Nagaur also launched a dharna at the district collectorate, demanding immediate action.“Seven persons have been arrested in the case. Five of them were arrested late on Wednesday and two on Thursday morning. We are investigating the matter further. More arrests are likely,” said Nagaur circle officer Mukul Sharma.In the police complaint, a copy of which is with TOI, one of the victims, said that he had gone to a service centre to service his bike along with his cousin. When they were returning after dropping the bike, one of the accused pushed the complainant and accused him of theft at the cash counter. “We were abused, brutally beaten and humiliated,” he mentioned in the FIR, registered on February 19. He named seven people in his complaint.The FIR was registered under sections 342, 323, 341 and 143 of IPC along with tree other sections of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989, including 3 (1)E for forcibly committing acts on Dalits such as removing clothes or any other similar act which is derogatory to human dignity; 3 (1) for intimidation and abuse; 3 (2) VA for any offence specified in the Schedule, against a person or property, knowing that such person is a member of a Scheduled Caste or a Scheduled Tribe or such property belongs to such a member.Hanuman Singh, one of the seven arrested, has filed a counter FIR against the two Dalit youths under Section 380 (theft) of IPC. In the FIR, Singh mentioned that at around 1.52pm, the two victims came to the service station. One of them stood outside the service centre, while the other entered the place. The employees were then having lunch. One of them broke the cash box and stole Rs 50,000, he alleged.The FIR also says that the duo were caught at Karnu crossroad and brought to the service centre. Police is also investigating the theft allegations. Dalit activists have expressed their anger at the incident. “We are sending our fact-finding team to Nagaur. In this independent country, such incidents are a blot. We condemn such acts. We demand the government take strict action in the matter,” said P L Mimroth chief functionary, Centre for Dalit Rights, Jaipur.

Title: Senior divisional commercial manager, SECR, booked for allegedly molesting booking clerk
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Senior divisional commercial manager (DCM), South Eastern Central Railway ( SECR ), KV Ramana has been booked for allegedly outraging modesty of a booking clerk and also charged with provisions under Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act.

The senior railway officer denied the allegations claiming them to be frivolous. Ramana also said he was being framed for no reason.

A 47-year-old booking clerk, promoted few days ago and shifted to Gondia, stated in her police complaint that Ramana had been making undue advances towards her. She alleged that Ramana tried to misbehave with her on phone and also during personal meeting.

The woman stated that Ramana met her during an inspection at a railway station and since then been trying to lure her with indecent proposals for helping in her career.

The woman had first approached the Shanti Nagar police station but later decided to meet the city police top brass when cops refused to register an offence. Shanti Nagar police, following intervention of the top brass, registered the case and referred it to the superintendent of police, Government Railway Police (GRP).

Senior PI KB Uikey of Shanti Nagar police station stated that the alleged undue advances by the concerned officer took place mostly within limits of the railways. “We had received an application from her about two days back. The case isn’t under city police jurisdiction and hence we have sent it to the concerned GRP unit,” he said.

After coming to know about the FIR against him, Ramana said he had called the woman only once to his office and spoke in presence of women personnel. “She was promoted along with 55 others and routinely transferred,” he said.

Ramana stated that he had called the woman as there was a problem between her and the supervisor at office. “There was no other intention but to intervene as a senior,” he said.

Title: Woman alleges rape, police detain carpet factory owner
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Varanasi: Suriyava police in Bhadohi district, on Thursday, took a carpet manufacturer in custody after a video of a burqa clad woman seeking justice against alleged rape and thrashing, went viral on social media.

The video went viral on Wednesday when Bhadohi police were busy in lodging case of gang rape against BJP MLA Ravindranath Tripathi, his five sons and nephew.

A video showing a burqa clad woman appealing to officials to initiate action against a carpet manufacturer, who thrashed and raped her after taking her to Suriyava area in name of showing a land for purchase went viral on Wednesday. In the video, the woman requested for help while claiming to be a widow.

SP Bhadohi R B Singh said taking note of the incident, he asked Suriyava police to initiate prompt action. SO Suriyava Vijay Pratap Singh said the woman had lodged a complaint of alleged manhandling on February 13. But, after investigation started on the basis of her complaint she alleged that she had been raped also, said Singh adding that the accused has been taken in custody on Thursday morning and is being interrogated. He said that further action will be initiated on the basis of evidences.

Regarding further action in BJP MLA case, the SP Bhadohi said that police investigation and evidence collection is in progress.

Title: Padil RuB inches closer to opening
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

New railway underbridge at Padil on Mangaluru-Bengaluru National Highway 75.

Mangaluru: People are hopeful of the railway underbridge (RuB) at Padil being opened for traffic at the earliest. National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) and Southern Railway , that seemed in no apparent hurry to commission the RuB constructed on the carriageway towards the city on the Bengaluru-Mangaluru National Highway-75 on the city’s outskirts, are now looking to complete the remaining work to facilitate its commissioning.

Incidentally, the RuB on the carriageway towards Bengaluru was commissioned in December 2017 and the pre-cast concrete box for the RuB towards Mangaluru was in place by January 2019. Officials in the construction wing of Southern Railway had cited non-removal of trees and shifting of electrical installations as the reason for not commissioning the RuB. Initially, the plan was to commission this second RuB towards Mangaluru by January.

Shishu Mohan, project director, NHAI project implementation unit, Mangaluru, told TOI that the commissioning of the second RuB towards Mangaluru will help ease traffic congestion at Mangaluru. The construction wing of Southern Railway has almost completed their work, and NHAI will need around 15 days to lay bituminous concrete to a length of 1.1 km to connect the two ends of the road via the new RuB towards Mangaluru, he said.

Barricades have been fixed on either end of the new RuB, dimensions of which have been fixed as per Indian Road Congress standards to prevent oversized vehicles from using the same. Painting work of the RuB too has been completed. Incidentally, this ‘new’ RuB was earlier the only RuB that existed on the Bengaluru-Mangaluru National Highway at Padil. The second RuB was constructed on the road leading towards Bengaluru as part of the four-laning project.

The two RuBs are part of the port connectivity four-laning project on NH-75 between B C Road and Nanthoor in the city that started in 2003. The move by NHAI to collect toll for this 36 km stretch of four-lane road – at Brahmarakootlu and Surathkal—too has irked road users—as its maintenance is not of desired standards. The delay in addressing above bottlenecks has only given users a chance to vent their ire against NHAI for their perceived apathy.

Title: Students raise alarm over encroachment on University of Hyderabad land
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

University of Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Students of University of Hyderabad ( UoH ) raised an alarm over encroachment within the campus on Thursday after an earth mover demolished a university compound wall.

Around 12 pm, an earth mover demolished a compound wall towards near Mushroom rocks area. Students alleged that the demolition work was taken up following orders from a local MLA.

“The demolition work was being undertaken citing an order that the collector had passed to construct a road to CNG Colony. Those involved in demolition stated that the land was promised by a former vice-chancellor,” said Abhishek Nandan, president of UoH students union. Students opposed the demolition as they claimed that persons involved could not produce relevant documents.

UoH authorities have taken up the matter with the district collector.

“In the past, we had to reconstruct the wall twice as some miscreants had demolished them overnight. On Thursday, an earth mover was used to tear down the wall again,” said P Singh, UoH registrar, adding that filed a complaint with Gachibowli police.

“We had even requested the collector to survey the university land to curb such encroachments. We are yet to receive the survey report following which we will decide further course of action,” added Sardar Singh.

Title: Adani Vidya Mandirs win Samagra Shiksha awards
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

(From L) Juuhi Rajput (CEO Arrucus), Ramesh Pokhriyal, Union HRD minister, Rajanikant Sharma (principal, Adani... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Adani Vidya Mandir, Ahmedabad, and Surguja won the ‘Samagra Shiksha – Empowering India Awards’ 2020. Adani Vidya Mandir, Ahmedabad got the award in the category of private school (unaided) from the Gujarat government, while Adani Vidya Mandir, Surguja, won in the category of private school (unaided) from the Chhattisgarh state government. Adani Vidya Mandir, Bhadreshwar (Gujarat) also received a certificate of appreciation.

The awards were presented by HRD minister, Dr Ramesh Pokhriyal in New Delhi on Tuesday. Dr Priti Adani, chairperson Adani Foundation said, ‘Adani Vidya Mandir is preparing children from the underprivileged sections of the society to navigate their future with confidence.”

Title: Hyderabad: Dog beaten up by security guard, critical
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The dog received severe head injuries due to the assault.

HYDERABAD: A community dog near a office in Domalguda was beaten up by a security guard of an apartment when the canine allegedly tried to attack him on Thursday evening. The dog received severe head injuries and is battling for life. The incident came to light after some residents raised an alarm and informed the police as well as animal activists.

“The dog was beaten up by the watchman of an apartment complex. The dog became unconscious after the watchman hit him on the head. The watchman is claiming that the dog came to attack him. The dog received some stitches on his head and is under observation at a private clinic,” said Yashwant Kumar , a resident.

After the animal rights group was informed, they took the dog for treatment and also took photographs of the canine that showed the assault. “We are investigating the case and an FIR has been registered against security guard Sathi Babu . He will be taken into custody soon,” said Prem Kumar, sub-inspector, Chikadpally.

Title: Fund-starved Telangana govt mulls auctioning assigned land
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a massive exercise to prop up revenue mobilisation, the state government is planning to take over thousands of assigned land given to farmers in prime areas — especially Ranga Reddy and Medchal districts — and auction it at market rate. Official sources said that collectors of districts surrounding Hyderabad have been asked to identify assigned land in their respective areas which was lying fallow.

With no major chunks of vacant land available around the city as most of it has already been given to companies, auctioned or encroached, the state was now looking at assigned land allotted to farmers several decades ago for cultivation but without ownership rights. The government has the power to resume such land whenever it wants and, as there was little farming around Hyderabad, it now intends to compensate farmers and then auction the land.

As a precursor, a sample survey was done in five villages of Ranga Reddy district and it was estimated that the assigned land was worth over Rs 3,500 crore if auctioned.

“There are 1,450 acres in five villages — Kongara Khurd, Thummaloor, Raviryal (near Shamshabad airport) villages in Maheshwaram mandal, Madhapur in Kandukur mandal and Rayannaguda in Shamshabad mandal — and it could fetch about Rs 3,580 crore. After paying about Rs 1,220 crore as compensation to farmers, the government would get nearly Rs 2,360 crore,” an official said.

Apart from assigned land, the state government has already indicated its plans to auction government land to raise funds which would be used for executing irrigation projects and welfare schemes.

The Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority (HMDA) is planning to auction about 600 acres in Kokapet and the layout was being developed. The Ranga Reddy administration has reported that there was about 665 acres (including evacuee property) in Puppalaguda but no available assigned land in the area. Of the 665 acres, 188 acres was clear and unassigned land which could be auctioned, official sources said.

“Once the government gets all the land details, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao is likely to take a decision on acquiring assigned land as well as auctioning government land around the city,” said a senior official in the chief minister’s office.

Title: Shaheen Bagh-type protest launched in Vaniyambadi
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vellore: Within hours of the statewide protests demanding that the Tamil Nadu government pass a resolution not to implement Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and National Population Register ( NPR ), Muslim-centric political parties and Islamic organisations launched an indefinite Shaheen Bagh-type protest at Vaniyambadi Aathumedu area in the wee hours of Thursday.

More than 200 Muslim organisation members, including women, held placards and raised slogans demanding that the central government immediately withdraw the CAA, NRC and NPR.

“The protest, which initially began with active participation of 200 members, will reach several thousands in the coming days. We hope that the ruling AIADMK government will soon implement a resolution and pressure the central government to withdraw the CAA, said N Nasir Khan,” a protest organiser.

“All arrangements including safer restrooms for women and children, food and water have been arranged near the protest venue. We will not withdraw the protest untill the state government heeds to our unified demand by passing a resolution,” Nasir Khan said.

Members of DMK, MDMK, SDPI, IUML, TMMK and various other Muslim organisations took part in in the protest in large numbers.

Title: Nirbhaya convict is back in court, this time with mental illness plea
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

New Delhi: A court on Thursday sought a reply from the Tihar Jail authorities on a plea by Vinay Sharma , a death-row convict in the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case, that he be given better treatment due to his mental condition, including schizophrenia, and head and arm injuries. Additional sessions judge Dharmender Rana directed the authorities to file its reply on Saturday.

According to prison officials, Sharma injured himself by banging his head on his solitary cell wall in jail number 3 on Sunday afternoon. He suffered minor injuries and was treated on the Tihar premises, they said.

Advocate A P Singh, appearing for Sharma, told the court that “it was a serious matter” that the convict couldn’t recognise people, including his mother and lawyer. The lawyer claimed that while visiting his client on the family’s request, he had found Sharma had sustained a grievous head injury, had a plaster in his right arm due to a fracture, and was suffering from “insanity, mental illness and schizophrenia”.

Singh also claimed that the jail records would prove that Sharma had attempted suicide thrice in Tihar and was treated for depression.

The prosecution, however, opposed the plea arguing it was not maintainable. It termed the plea as a delaying tactic.

Meanwhile, according to an IANS report, Sharma’s counsel also moved the Election Commission of India challenging the rejection of his mercy petition. The rejection was suggested by Delhi government and signed by deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia when the model code of conduct for the assembly elections was in force. The code made him “ineligible” to do so, Singh said, adding that a WhatsApp screenshot was sent instead of Sisodia’s digital signature while forwarding the plea to the lieutenant governor of Delhi.

After the LG sent it to the Union home ministry, it went to the President of India, who rejected the plea after considering the MHA’s suggestion.

Thursday’s petitions were filed after the court, on February 17, for the third time, issued death warrants for March 3 to execute the four convicts. Besides Sharma, the other convicts are Mukesh Singh, Pawan Gupta and Akshay Thakur.

Any further delay in their execution will be “sacrilegious” to the rights of the victim and for justice, the court had noted while fixing the new date.

Title: ‘Faulty planning, staff crunch hit mining funds utilisation’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Despite a huge collection of funds under the District Mineral Foundation (DMF) and the Odisha Mineral Bearing Area Development Corporation (OMBADC), the utilisation by the state government remains low.

Of the total collection of Rs 9,501.48 crore under the DMF by January-end, only Rs 2,794.19 crore has been spent. Similarly, about Rs 16,520 crore has been generated under the OMBADC of which only Rs 1,143 crore has been utilised. This was informed by state planning and convergence minister Padmanabha Behera in a written reply to a query from BJD MLA Soumya Ranjan Patnaik in the assembly on Thursday.

Both the DMF and OMBADC are meant for infrastructure development in areas where people are affected by mining activities. Drinking water supply, education, healthcare facilities, sanitation, skill development, housing, connectivity, livelihood programmes and environment conservation are some of the priority areas, where the government utilises money from the DMF and the OMBADC funds. The OMBADC was constituted in 2014 with contribution from mining lessees with the amount they paid for diversion of forest land (Rs 7 to 9 lakh per hectare) for mining purpose. The penalties collected from the lessees for illegal mining based on a Supreme Court order delivered on August 2, 2017, is also deposited in the OMBADC fund.

A committee headed by the chief secretary has already sanctioned projects worth Rs 9,084 crore from the DMF fund for various areas. There has been delay in implementation of projects for reasons like lack of adequate professionals at sub-ordinate offices and lack of planning to utilise the amount, said a senior government official, requesting anonymity.

While all the districts have DMF fund, resources from the OMBADC are being utilised only in eight mining-hit districts — Angul, Dhenkanal, Jajpur, Jharsuguda, Keonjhar, Koraput, Mayurbhanj and Sundargarh.

Title: Med college hosp to be apex centre of trauma care, training
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Health minister K K Shailaja has said Medical College Hospital of Thiruvananthapuram will be made into an apex centre of trauma care and training. Since there is space constraint on the college campus, the training centre will be functioning at a new building constructed on the General Hospital campus.

The minister said the centre will provide training on trauma care to the doctors in the health service and medical education department. Apart from this, para medical staff, nurses, ambulance drivers and employees concerned will be trained on trauma care. The centre will also provide training for police personnel, NGOs working in this field and even for the common man.

Tata Trust has given Rs 12 crore for setting up the centre and the work is nearing completion. Apart from this, Rs 12 crore was sanctioned for the centre in the state budget, she said.

The funds sanctioned will be utilised to set up cardiology and angiography simulation trainer, surgical skill trainer and other related equipment. With this, a training centre will be fulfilled under the medical education department.

Shailaja said the government had already entered into an agreement with the Tata Trust for sharing their expertise in this. The centre will be run by the Tata Trust for the first three years and then will be handed over to the health department.

The centre is set up as part of the comprehensive trauma care programme being launched in all medical college hospitals in the state. The programme is planned in the state with the support of University of Warwick, UK, and All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi.

As per the proposal, three levels of trauma-care system will be implemented in the state, apart from the emergency department in all medical college hospitals and the simulation centre.

All medical college hospitals will come under level one trauma-care management. District and general hospitals come under second level, and taluk and community health centres under the third.

Title: IIT-Hyderabad launches artificial intelligence programme-2
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

IIT-Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: The IIT-Hyderabad announced its second edition of professional certification programme in artificial intelligence and emerging technologies for college students and professionals in association with TalentSprint .

Considering that 2020 will be a pivotal year in AI-related employment dynamics, according to Gartner Inc., the six months programme by IIT-H and TalentSprint will bridge the gap and provide IIT edge to non-IIT students in building AI expertise.

Title: It’s drama time, folks!
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Starting today, youth drama clubs from across the state will showcase their talent at a theatre festival in the city. The two-day fest is organised by Kerala state youth welfare board.

The fest titled ‘ Youth theatre festival of Kerala ’ will feature 13 teams who have won first prize at district-level competition. Minister for sports and youth welfare E P Jayarajan will inaugurate the festival at Tagore Theatre at 9am.

Festival co-ordinator Krishnan Balakrishnan said it is for the first time an attempt is being made to showcase emerging talents from the youth in theatre on a common platform. “Teams from across the state who have exposure at national level and those with debutants are coming together for the fest. More than a competition, this is designed as a venue for exchange of ideas and imbibing each other’s presentation,” said Krishnan.

Each drama will be of 30-40 minutes and entry to the fest will be free. The opening day will have 12 hours of plays. Nine plays will be staged on the first day and the second day will showcase five plays.

The festival co-ordinator said it offers one of the biggest cash prizes for the winners. The team that comes first will get a cash award of Rs 1 lakh. Those winning second and third prizes will bag Rs 75,000 and Rs 50,000 respectively. The concluding convention will be inaugurated by minister for tourism and devaswom Kadakampally Surendran.

Actor Prem Kumar, festival director Pramod Payyannur and members of youth welfare board will be present. Dhwani, a theatre group of transgender people under Dwaya transgenders arts and charitable society, will stage a play titled ‘Parayan Maranna Kathakal’ on the final day ahead of the convention.

Except for Wayanad, teams from 13 districts will take part in the fest. They made it to the final round through an initial screening. “Many of the teams are collectives of youth who take drama seriously and this is our initiative to encourage them by giving the ideal platform,” Krishnan said.

Title: NMC ignoring norms for cement roads: Holey
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: Senior corporator Satish Holey accused the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) of violating all guidelines and norms, including those prescribed by the Indian Road Congress, while constructing cement roads. Following the allegations, mayor Sandip Joshi ordered superintending engineer Manoj Talewar to conduct an inquiry and submit a report before the House.

Despite going through a financial crisis, the NMC is constructing over a feet thick roads while the National Highways Authority of India has constructed only six-inch thick road patch from Liberty Square to Mankapur Square, said Holey.

Holey sought to know criteria for selecting any tar road for converting it into cement concrete. When Talewar informed that the NMC is selecting the roads as per traffic density, Holey said that even internal lanes which witness less traffic were being concretized. He also alleged that the administration selects tar roads for concretization only after a nod from the standing committee chairman.

The NMC didn’t even mention about usage of fly-ash in constructing cement roads, he said.

Leader of opposition Tanaji Wanve drew attention of the House to violations of environmental norms by cement road contractors and gave example of ready-mix plants operating in residential areas though they are supposed to be outside city limits.

Title: Venkaiah visit: PU forums to hold black flag demo
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Puducherry: The Students’ Federation of India (SFI) along with other students’ forums in Pondicherry University has decided to hold a black flag demonstration on February 25 , a day before the visit of vice-president Venkaiah Naidu to the university to press the administration to revoke fees hike for all courses from the academic year 2019-20 and to fulfill their other demands.

Naidu, also the chancellor of the university, will visit Pondicherry University on February 26 to award degrees to the students at the convocation ceremony.

The forums appealed to the students to boycott classes and participate in large numbers in the demonstration on Tuesday. They lashed out at the university for hiking the fees steeply. They pointed out that the highest annual fees for any course in JNU is just Rs 500 and the highest annual fees for any course in all the 49 central universities (barring Pondicherry University) is less than Rs 10,000. The fees structure for all courses in Pondicherry University has been fixed exorbitantly high compared to other central universities.

“The total fees for most-sought-after courses like MBA and MCA programmes in Pondicherry University are Rs 1.5 lakh and Rs 1.03 lakh respectively,” said a students’ representative.

The forums also demanded the administration to continue free transportation facility for day scholars. The university extended free transportation facility since its inception, but the present administration has imposed a transportation fee of Rs 4,000 a year for a day scholar.

Meanwhile, the indefinite strike launched by the students’ council against fees hike since February 6 entered the 15th day on Thursday. The fee revision committee formed by the university with representatives of the administration and students, which convened twice, failed to resolve the impasse. The committee came forward to waive 20% fees for economically weaker sections, while the students’ representatives demanded 100% rollback of hike.

On Wednesday, representatives of students’ forums called on chief minister V Narayanasamy in the presence of DMK MLA R Siva and urged him to ask the university administration to revoke the fee hike . The representatives also sought the intervention of the chief minister in securing 25% reservation for Puducherry students in all courses in the university.

However, the university administration in a statement on Thursday justified the fee hike claiming that it did not revise the fees for the last 10 years and hiked it for all courses from 2019-20 by 25% to 50%.

Title: Nirbhaya Case Latest Update: All four Nirbhaya case convicts counselled for anger management
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nirbhaya case convicts

NEW DELHI: The four convicts in the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case are being counselled for anger management in Tihar Jail after two of them, Mukesh Singh and Vinay Sharma, allegedly showed traits of violent behaviour even when prison staff approached them for routine checks. The behaviour of Pawan Gupta and Akshay Thakur is also under scanner, a source said.

In the past one week, Sharma misbehaved with jail officials while being served meals or asked to comply with the prison rules, the source said. Singh has also refused to comply with orders, he added.

Sharma, who has approached a court demanding that he be treated at Institute of Human Behaviour & Allied Sciences, however, didn’t show any sign of being mentally unstable during the tests conducted by counsellors, an official said. In addition to its in-house counsellor, Tihar has tied up with an NGO comprising of mental health experts who keep monitoring both inmates and jail officials.

The convicts can meet family members twice a week. After Sharma met his mother on Monday, his lawyer claimed the convict couldn’t recognise her. Jail officials, however, didn’t find anything unusual during the meeting.

Besides keeping all four convicts on a suicide watch in their solitary cells, the authorities are keeping an eye on their behaviour when they are meeting their family members or lawyers. A close watch is also being kept when they are out of the view of CCTV cameras or are in the bathroom. “A guard is specifically deployed to check on them if they take longer than usual to complete their chores,” said an official. They can meet each other only in the presence of a jail staffer.

To maintain their health, the convicts are kept on a simple diet. They are allowed to keep one set of clothes and only essential personal belongings.

Title: Dalit shooting: Forest staff protest against colleagues’ arrest in MP
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

BHOPAL: Several government employees, including members of MP Forest Employees’ Association, took to the streets on Thursday to protest against the registration of murder case against 14 forest personnel following the shooting of a Dalit in Shivpuri.

The protesters submitted a memorandum to the district collector and SP, saying that the action against forest employees was uncalled for. They argue that the firing was in self-defence and some of the employees who have been charged with murder were not even on the spot at the time of incident. Six of the 14 accused forest personnel have been arrested and all of them are in jail custody.

“We have arrested forest guard Ram Naresh, who had fired the shot from his licensed weapon. As of now, we have not found any evidence to indicate that there was a situation that led him to use his weapon. We have received memorandum from the forest employees and their points will be taken into consideration,” said SP Shivpuri Rajesh Singh Chandel.

On February 16, a Dalit was shot dead in Shivpuri’s Fatehpur village, allegedly by a forest department employee, during an altercation between his family and foresters over filling of water from a hand pump. The family of victim Madan Balmiki alleges that forest personnel humiliated them when they were drawing water from a tube well near the Fatehpur outpost. It triggered an altercation during which Madan was shot dead.

A case was registered against 14 forest department personnel, including a woman, under IPC and SC/ST Prevention of Atrocities Act.

The forest department, on the other hand, claims stones were thrown at them during an anti-encroachment drive and Madan was shot when some villagers were trying to snatch a gun.

Madan’s wife and cousin were washing utensils at the hand pump when ranger Suresh Sharma came to fill his waterbottle and a few drops of water spilled on him. He got angry and hurled casteist remarks at them, says the FIR. Madan’s wife says in the FIR: “My daughter ran over and told him not to abuse us. But a woman forester dragged her by the hair and slapped her. When my husband came running to intervene, he was shot dead,” says the complaint.

Title: Umiya Mata temple stone-laying on February 28-29
Content:
The first phase of the temple, termed as the biggest and tallest temple dedicated to Umiya Mata, deity of Pati... Read More

AHMEDABAD: The stone-laying ceremony for Umiya Mata temple at Vishwa Umiya Foundation (VUF) will take place on February 28 and 29, said the temple trustees on Thursday. The first phase of the temple, termed as the biggest and tallest temple dedicated to Umiya Mata, deity of Patidar community, is likely to be completed by 2025.R P Patel, trustee of VUF, told reporters on Thursday that the temple will be 131 meter (431 feet) high and spread across 100 bighas of land. “There will be three viewing galleries at 82 and 90 and 110 metres height from where the devotees can see the surrounding Ahmedabad. The design is jointly created by an Indian and a German architect,” he said.The idol of the goddess will be installed at the height of 52 feet whereas there will also be other temples including a Shiva lingam made of mercury. “The two-day event is likely to be attended by 2 lakh devotees from across the world. Mahant Swami and Sri Sri Ravishankar will be present along with 21 major sants and mahants,” said a trustee.The project will cost over Rs 800 crore, said trust officials. While Rs 375 crore has been raised by the community, more than Rs 500 crore will be raised over the period of five years, they added. The extended premises will have skill development university, career development centre, hospital, sports facility, NRI bhavan, immigration and employment guidance centres and a space for community court (panch).

Title: Varanasi: School principal, staffer held with 21 solved answersheets
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

VARANASI: Principal and a computer operator of Jagnarain Inter College in Jakhania area, under the limits of Bhudkuda police in Ghazipur district, were arrested by the STF for trying to take 21 solved answer sheets inside the college premises, a UP Boards examination centre, to submit before the end of exam on Thursday.

STF’s Varanasi field unit officials said that the college was on radar as questions papers of many examinees were getting solved outside the college to dodge the authorities monitoring the centre through CCTV network and webcasting.

On Thursday, the STF cops raided the college just before the end of the examination of physics and caught a computer operator Nitishwar Pandey red handed as he was trying to enter the campus with 21 solved answer sheets to deposit. Following further investigation, principal of the college Anil Kumar Pandey was also arrested. Both of them have been handed over to Bhudkuda police after lodging of a case in this connection.

Title: Cong leadership vacuum hurting its state units?
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: That the leadership vacuum in Congress is percolating to state units and hampering their functioning was evident Thursday when Karnataka Congress functionary Dinesh Gundu Rao , who earlier resigned as state party chief, met Sonia Gandhi and urged that his replacement be named soon.

“Our workers and leaders are in a state of confusion. It's been two months since I resigned as state party president. Let's not delay this further because it sends wrong signal,” he told reporters.

There are concerns that AICC has failed to appoint new presidents in key states of Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra, where organisation is witnessing clashes.

While Jyotiraditya Scindia is locked in a war of nerves with chief minister Kamal Nath in MP, a senior leader from Maharashtra said the situation in the state is not comfortable despite formation of coalition government with Shiv Sena and NCP.

“There is an urgency about having a new organisational chief here. But there is a drift here which is reflective of the drift in AICC,” he lamented.

Besides, the leadership is worried about growing dissent in Punjab unit with individual MLAs speaking out against the Amarinder Singh dispensation. Sources said Congress brass recently met Navjot Sidhu , in what was a bid to pacify him. Sidhu resigned from the Punjab Cabinet after a spat with CM Amarinder Singh, and there are rumours that he may go out of the party.

Title: GHMC to conduct 10-day literacy prog
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Hyderabad: After chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao directed officials to achieve 100 per cent literacy in the state, the urban community development wing of the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation is taking up 10-day programme. “Survey will be held under the banner “Each one Teach one” from February 24 to March 4,” said Hyderabad mayor Bonthu Rammohan. TNN

Title: Use recovered land for MG Road expansion project: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Merchants say commercial activities in the area have come down at least by 40% after Metro construction began

KOCHI: Over the past four or five years MG Road has been losing its importance as a major commercial hub. Reason? Traffic snarls and lack of adequate parking facilities.

Though revenue department had recovered more than 80 cents by evicting encroachers on the MG Road in 2007, authorities have not yet moved to use the land for road expansion.

According to details collected as per a RTI reply, 287 encroachments were identified during the eviction drive, which had to be stopped mid-way due to pressure from vested interests and political parties. Had the drive not been stopped abruptly, more encroachments on Jos junction-Thevara stretch also could have been evicted.

The current market value of the 80 cents has been pegged at around Rs160 crore. What is shocking is that encroachers have been reclaiming the evicted holdings again.

“Parking and traffic blocks have been plaguing MG Road for long. Using the 80 cents, Kochi Corporation or Smart City authorities could have constructed bus bays and multilevel carparking facilities,” said president of Ernakulam Vikasana Samithi , K S Dileep Kumar.

“It would have helped MG Road regain its lost glory,” he said.

At many points, there are land parcels, mostly reclaimed from encroachers, where bus bays and car parking facilities can be set up.

“Such facilities can be set up on the lands near Seematti Textiles, Padma Junction, Jayalakshmi Silks and Woodlands Junction. Unfortunately, many of the holdings are being encroached upon again,” Kumar said.

According to experts in urban planning, authorities can explore other options. “Authorities like Kochi Corporation can set up parking facilities under public private partnership model, wherever government land is unavailable. The local body should identify the vacant lands on MG Road and ink pact with the owners of such holdings. Several land owners fear that it will be difficult for them to get back the land once it is given to a public project. The authorities should first allay such fears and give a written assurance to them,” said Elizabeth Philip, urban planning and former chief town planner, Greater Cochin Development Authority .

“As of now, many of the shops on MG Road have converted their parking lots into commercial spaces. The corporation should find a way to make the merchants pay up for the loss without demolishing the structures,” she said.

“Fixed amounts can be charged from such establishments. The funds can be used for providing parking facilities,” she said.

The merchants have also said that they are ready to cooperate with the authorities if there is an action plan to revive MG Road.

“We have created a Facebook page called Save MG Road. Commercial activities have come down at least by 40% after Metro construction began. They had promised to provide parking facilities once the Metro work has been completed. But no one has taken up the issue,” said Rajesh Nair, convener, MG Road Merchants Association.

Title: Coffee House patrons urge UP Governor to save iconic hangout
Content:
Indian Coffee House remained closed on Thursday

LUCKNOW: Patrons and lovers of Indian Coffee House issued an appeal to governor Anandiben Patel on Thursday to save the iconic and popular hangout known to be a favourite of several renowned politicians, writers, artists, intellectuals and journalists for over eight decades.In a joint appeal, several eminent people from Lucknow, including former mayor Dauji Gupta, journalist Pradeep Kapoor, political analyst Ramesh Dixit and Satyadev Tripathi, wrote a letter to governor urging her to take necessary steps to save Coffee House after 10-12 people broke into its premises on February 14 claiming it to be their property and closed it. Arun Prakash Singh, a regular customer, said a group of people led by a man, who claimed to be the owner of the place, broke into the Coffee House in the intervening night of February 13 and 14, closed it and illegally constructed a wall inside it in next three days.When the incident happened, Aruna Singh, secretary of Indian Coffee House Workers’ Cooperative Society that runs the place, was in Delhi. She rushed to Lucknow when she came to know about the incident on Wednesday and lodged a complaint at Hazratganj police station.Ramesh Dixit, former head of political science department, Lucknow University, said, “We have been coming to Coffee House since childhood and have emotional connection with it. The government should take over the place and end the ownership dispute so that this iconic hangout, which is part of Lucknow’s heritage, is preserved.”“The place has been closed down a number of times due to non-payment of electricity bills or others but every time people came forward and saved it. We are taking that legacy forward and we’ll save it,” said journalist Pradeep Kapoor. Aruna Singh said Coffee House will reopen on Friday and will continue operations.

Title: Allahabad: Two held for harassing, shooting at woman
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

ALLAHABAD: Two men were arrested on Thursday, five days after they shot at a woman near Fathua village, under Sarayinayat police station.

The accused were identified as Mohammed Manzoor and Kamal Kumar Bharatiya, both residents of Jhunsi.

Inspector of Sarayinayat police station Surendra Kumar Pandey said the two had shot at Neelu Kushwaha in Fathua village over an old enmity. The accused had been on the run since and a case under sections 307 and 506 of the Indian Penal Code was registered against them.

The inspector said the accused were arrested near Habusa turn on Thursday.

Police said Manzoor had been harassing the woman since a long time. When Neelu threatened to report him to the police, Manzoor and his aide shot at her and fled.

Police also seized a 0.315 bore countrymade pistol from them whihc was used in the attack.

Meanwhile, four men were arrested with 16 cows and a truck on Thursday, under Handia police station. The accused were identified as Mohd Narul Khan, Shabbu, Omar Mohammad and Mansoor Alam — all residents of Gaya in Bihar. The cows were to being taken to Bihar for being slaughtered.

Title: AU honours 9 students at special event
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

ALLAHABAD: Allahabad University ( AU ) felicitated nine meritorious students who had missed the convocation during a special programme on Thursday.

The nine students were awarded 16 medals and were feted by AU officiating vice-chancellor RR Tewari.

“You have earned laurels for yourself and the institution with your hard work and have emerging as inspiration for other students as well,” said Tewari. BA (economics) student Savita was awarded four medals including the Hari Prava silver medal, The other students which were feted with gold medals were Shambhu Nath Shukla, Shyam Bihari Lal and Hari Shankar Shukla. LLB (Hons) students Syed Najam Ullah bagged three medals including the Lumsden Gold Medal, Sir Henry Richards Gold Medal and Ram Mohan De Gold Medal.

AU controller of examination RK Singh said, “AU had organised its convocation on September 5, 2019, but some students weren’t able to attend it. These students were awarded medals at today’s function as we wanted to formally recognize their achievements.”

Title: Ballet on 1857 to remember Wajid Ali Shah
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Lucknow: Come Sunday, a ballet to mark the seventh annual Wajid Ali Shah Festival in the city will be a befitting tribute to the nawab who was known as a great patron of music and dance. Directed by Muzaffar Ali and derived from the poems of Rahi Masoom Raza in the aftermath of India’s first war of independence, the hour-long ballet — Gomti 1857, Krant ka Pehla Sawan — will combine kathak and Sufi qawwal performances by 36 artistes from across Awadh to enthral the audience at Dilkusha Palace on February 23.

“Kaiserbagh was a cultural centre during the time of Wajid Ali Shah. Over the years, our efforts have been the same: to showcase the talent of the man who was so well-versed and also make people aware of places of heritage. Hence, Dilkusha Palace is the venue. It was shelled during the siege,” Ali said.

Title: Chandrapur: Six pilgrims killed, seven injured, in Keslaghat accident
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

CHANDRAPUR: Six people, including a two-year-old, were killed and seven others critically injured as a speeding Scorpio rammed a stationary truck on Mul-Chandrapur road late on Wednesday night.

According to sources, Bhoyar and Zode family from Chandrapur had gone for a pilgrimage at Pratapgarh in Bhandara district. They stayed there during the day and started back home after having dinner. While their vehicle was just 20km from Chandrapur, the driver failed to spot a stationary truck by the roadside at Keslaghat stretch of Mul-Chandrapur road and the vehicle dashed the truck from behind.

The collision was so hard that half of the Scorpio got stuck under the rear hull of the truck.

Six of the occupants of the SUV — Sambhaji Bhoyar (77), Kusum Bhoyar (65), Jiyan Bhoyar (2), Dattu Zode (50), Minakshi Zode (35) and Shashikala Wandhre died on the spot. Seven others — Maroti Patpelliwar, Manisha Bhoyar , Sheela Patil, Rekha Khatekar and three kids Ankita Petkule, 10, Krush Patil, 10 and Soni Patil, 8, suffered critical injuries. The injured were rushed to Mul sub-district hospital. Later, they were referred to Chandrapur Government Medical College and Hospital .

Title: Allahabad: Mahashivratri snan today, Mela police step up patrol
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Labourers busy with preparations on the Mela ground

ALLAHABAD: A posse of 2,000 police personnel, including mounted cops, will turn the Magh Mela premises into a fortress for Mahashivratri snan on Friday, when around 10 lakh devotees are expected to take the holy dip across 10 ghats.

To stem traffic snarls ahead of and during the ritualistic bathing, Mela police have implemented a diversion plan for heavy and commercial vehicles, restricting their entry into the city at nine points.

The restrictions at Bamrauli, Sahson crossing, Haboosa turn, Soraon bypass, Nawabganj bypass, Phaphamau Park trisection, TP Nagar crossing, Rampur crossing and Ghurpur Gate will remain effective till Friday night. Additional police pickets have been set up to manage parking along different routes leading to Sangam.

To ensure smooth final rituals, Mela officials have, on the other hand, inspected sanitation facilities, power arrangements and amenities at ghats.

IG (Prayagraj range) KP Singh said that frisking people and checking vehicles were also part of the security arrangements made for the Mahashivratri snan. “Police teams are frisking individuals and checking cars on the eve of Mahashivratri at various locations. A comprehensive traffic management plan is in place,” Singh said.

With devotees pouring in from neighbouring districts like Pratapgarh, Kaushambi and Chitrakoot in UP, and Satna and Rewa in Madhya Pradesh, Mela police are conducting frequent patrolling on foot and otherwise. Senior officers are reviewing arrangements.

Security has been reviewed at prominent city shrines including Mankameshwar, Padila Mahadeo, Dashashwamedh temple (Daraganj), Shivkoteshwar, Someshwar Mahadeo (Naini), Shivala (Katra), Shiva temple (Civil Lines) and Nagbasuki. Duties of magistrates and DSPs have been assigned to regulate the flow of devotees who are also expected to throng the special aarti and abhishek.

Title: Bhopal: Gandhian padyatris on 14 thousand world march arrive in Armenia
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The journey that started from Raj Ghat in New Delhi will end in Geneva, Switzerland. Several of the participan... Read More

BHOPAL: A year-long march called ‘Jai Jagat 2020’, carrying Mahatma Gandhi ’s message of non-violence, reached Armenia on its 14,000km-long journey on Thursday, walking in minus-16-degree freeze. Several of the participants are from Gwalior-Chambal region and Bhopal.

The journey that started from Raj Ghat in New Delhi will end in Geneva, Switzerland, where a dialogue will take place with UN agencies on implementation of UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The rallyists had to cancel the Pakistan and Nepal legs of the route following visa issues. The journey is being covered on foot and by train, plane and ferry.

The Bhopal-headquartered Gandhian organisation Ekta Parishad is organizing the march. Its national president, Morena resident Ran Singh Parmar, is leading the first batch that arrived in Armenia on Thursday. According to official sources, this team walked through snow on the mountains of Armenia at close to minus-16 degrees Celsius, carrying Gandhian principles of non-violence and peace.

“The Parliament of Armenia actually took a break during their discussion to acknowledge and welcome the Jai Jagat march, and emphasized that the world needs a Gandhian path of compassion and justice,” said a press release.

“While our team largely comprises Indians who are not acclimatized to this weather, we are all filled with optimism and enthusiasm for the challenge ahead,” said Pravin Jha, communication coordinator-Regional Building Domestic Resource Mobilization Capacities of CSOs (Co-funded by European Union & Supported by Welthungerhilfe) Mahatma Gandhi Seva Ashram.

The Yatra started on October 2, 2019 — Gandhi’s 150th birth anniversary — and comprises 50 walkers, led by P V Rajagopal ji and Jill Carl Harris. “The march has completed its main India chapter, spanning 2,000 kilometres in 125 days, and a part of the team is now in Armenia. There are 35 Indian and 15 international team members in the march,” Jha added. Eight to 10 of the padyatris are from Bhopal.

The rest of the team is now moving through Iran and UAE. There are marchers across the world, including North Africa and Europe, walking in solidarity with Jai Jagat Yatra, said Jha. The four key objectives of the march are eradicating poverty, eliminating social exclusion, battling climate crisis and halting conflict and violence.

“We started our march in Armenia from Meghri, which is on the Armenia-Iran border. We had informed both governments about the march, and they were both very positive about the idea of invoking Gandhi during these troubled times for the world,” said Jha.

This team interacted with students and teachers in schools and visited the National Medical University in capital Yerevan. Since Armenians had used Gandhian ideals for a nonviolent revolution in 2018, the Mahatma holds aspecial place in their hearts.

Title: Swine Flu in Delhi: Delhi records 152 swine flu cases so far this year
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: At least 152 people have been confirmed positive for swine flu in Delhi as on February 16, a data released by National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), a central health body, shows.

While no death has been reported from the capital yet, hospitals said there have been a few admissions among patients suffering from the viral illness .

“Admission is required in cases involving bilateral pneumonia and other severe symptoms. It is rare and happens mostly in elderly persons and those with pre-existing chronic illnesses such as diabetes and heart disease,” said Dr Atul Gogia, senior consultant, internal medicine, Sir Ganga Ram Hospital. He, however, added that similar symptoms were exhibited even among persons suffering from seasonal influenza virus.

“Swine flu or H1N1 exists since 2009. It is a seasonal influenza only and people with milder symptoms like common cold, cough or fever need not undergo tests to confirm the strain of virus causing illness because these diseases are self-limiting,” said Dr Mukesh Mehra, senior consultant, internal medicine, Max Patparganj.

Last year, Delhi had reported 3,627 cases of H1N1 of which 31 persons had died. The death toll across the country was 1,218 in 2019, the NCDC data revealed.

The latest update on H1N1 situation in the country shows 884 persons have been diagnosed positive for H1N1 over the last one-and-a half-months and there have been 14 deaths . Tamil Nadu reported the maximum cases (172), followed by Delhi (152), Karnataka (151) and Telangana (148).

Swine flu is a contagious respiratory disease caused by type A strain of the influenza virus. It enters the body through inhalation of contaminated droplets, or is transferred from a contaminated surface to the eyes, nose or mouth of a person. “The symptoms of swine flu are similar to common viral illnesses. Patients feel lethargic, have high-grade fever and sore throat, among other symptoms. The treatment is mostly symptomatic,” said a doctor .

He added that maintaining hygiene was the most important. “People should wash their hands at regular intervals with disinfectants. If there is prolonged fever, one must see a doctor and not ignore symptoms such as difficulty in breathing,” he said.

Title: Delhi: Rare turtles found in a cardboard box near Mori Gate parking lot
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Three of the rescued reptiles are Indian tent turtles, a rare species found in northeast India.

NEW DELHI: Crime Branch has rescued four endangered tent turtles from the Kashmere Gate ISBT . It is a rare breed that comes under Schedule1 of the Wildlife Act. Police suspect the role of an interstate gang operating from north-east India that deals in trade of illegal wildlife.

Police said that a team led a search near Mori Gate on Wednesday night and found the turtles kept in a cardboard box. It seemed that someone had hurriedly left the box at the municipal corporation parking and fled. On inspection, it was found that three of the four turtles were Indian tent turtles that are a rare species of the reptiles found in Northeast India.

The turtles were inspected by the Wildlife Crime Control Bureau (WCCB) and shifted to the Delhi zoo for medical check-up. The reptiles would be kept in captivity till a clearance is received to release them in the wild.

Police are scanning the CCTV footage from the parking to identify the people who were transporting the turtles. The reptiles are usually slaughtered for meat or sold as exotic creatures in foreign countries.

A Delhi zoo official confirmed the rescue, stating the turtles were handed over to them by WCCB on Thursday afternoon. “They will be monitored for the next 15-20 days. After that, we may release them into ponds or they may become a part of the reptile house,” said the official.

Title: Telangana: Rag picker held for raping minor
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

Title: Rights panel probes missing kids case
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state commission for protection of child rights has launched a probe into the mysterious disappearances of two schoolboys, Rahul, 15, and Abhijith, 16, from their homes in the city. Rahul had gone missing on Saturday night and Abhijith on Sunday afternoon. While Rahul, who went missing from his residence at Kannammoola, is yet to be traced, Abhijith was found dead in the Karamana river not far away from his residence at Nedumcaud near Karamana.

The commission has also demanded police to transfer the investigations from the local police to a special team. A senior officer not less than the rank of superintendent of police must conduct the investigation and an inspector general must supervise the probes, the commission demanded.

Commission chairperson P Suresh said on Thursday that he visited the parents of both boys and recorded their statements as part of the inquiry. “In Abhijith’s case, his parents have a doubt that his death could be owing to murder. He was stark naked when the body was found. The police are yet to recover clothes, adding mystery to the case,’’ Suresh said.

According to Rahul’s parents, he left home because they seized his secret mobile phone, the chairperson added. “His parents found out that he was using a mobile phone costing around Rs 2,500 and they seized it. It was after this he left home, allegedly stealing Rs 4,000 in cash from the house,’’ he said. In both the cases, the investigations by local police at Karamana and Medical College are yet to make any breakthrough. The city police are likely to issue a lookout notice in the name of Rahul in a bid to seek the help of the public in tracing the boy.

Title: Smart Schools to be ready by May-end
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Mangaluru: Nireshwalya Government School in the city will soon be declared as the first Smart School under the Smart City Mission .

The Mangaluru Smart City Limited (MSCL) had commenced the Smart School project in 13 schools. The MSCL had earmarked Rs 11 crore for the purpose. The project has been completed at the government school in Nireshwalya in the city by providing smart classes and other infrastructure. By the end of May, all 13 identified schools will be made smart schools, said MSCL managing director Mohammed Nazeer .

The Smart School project is being implemented in 13 schools of eight wards that come under the Area Based Development scheme of the MSCL. Schools are being provided with information and communication technology solutions and other infrastructure through the project. While the project is complete in Nireshwalya school, the work is nearing completion at the government school in Pandeshwara in the city, Nazeer said, adding that the project will be completed in all the 13 schools by the end of May.

Work is under progress at other Government Higher Primary School (GHPS),Car Street, GHPS, Basti Garden, GHPS, Hoige Bazaar, Govt Practising High School, GHPS, Balmatta, Government Secondary School, Balmatta, GHPS, Bunder, GHS, Bolar, GHPS, Bolar and GHPS Bolar West. Works including repair of school buildings, construction of compound walls, playground, water supply facilities, and building toilets are also being taken up through the project.

Title: Kerala governor lauds state’s nutrition schemes
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With its efforts in ensuring child nutrition and in the process of ending hidden hunger , the state will soon script a success story at par with most advanced societies not just in the country alone, but in whole world, governor Arif Mohammed Khan has said.

Inaugurating a nutrition conference with the theme ‘hidden hunger — challenges and way forward’ organized by the department of women and child development here on Thursday, the governor said the Sampoorna Thalika programme highlighted the need for a balanced, healthy and poison-free nutrition, right from childhood. “What is important is that Kerala’s internalization of the significance of mother and child welfare has yielded good results. These efforts have endowed Kerala with one of the lowest infant and maternal mortality rates. If our school education has been rated by Niti Aayog as the best in the country, it is partly due to the improved health of our children,” Khan said.

He lauded the efforts of health minister K K Shailaja and said the alertness, prompt action and the maternal concern of the minister for the health of women and children have given a new direction to health and nutrition in the state. He also appreciated the minister for leading the fight against Nipah and coronavirus (Covid-19).

The governor said if the country needs to end hunger in all its forms, “we need to begin with a broad definition of hunger”, which would include calorie deficiencies or chronic hunger, micro-nutrient deficiencies or hidden hunger and related health problems. “The provision of adequate nutrition has been seen as a key factor in our mission to reduce poverty and hunger. It is here that flagship schemes like National Nutrition Mission , better known as Poshan Abhiyaan, launched to prevent and reduce under-nutrition, gains relevance. This scheme covered adolescent girls, pregnant women, lactating mothers and children below six years, benefiting over 10 crore people,” he said.

The biggest challenges that the state is facing is the lifestyle diseases and communicable diseases, Shylaja said.

Title: Anil Deshmukh sets up team to prepare Disha Act like law for Maharashtra
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

State home minister Anil Deshmukh

NAGPUR: State home minister Anil Deshmukh, who was in Andhra Pradesh (AP) on February 20 to study the newly implemented Disha Act, said on Thursday he had constituted a five-member team for having a similar law in the state. The panel will submit its report in a week after which it may be tabled before the cabinet. Deshmukh sounded hopeful to present the Bill as soon as possible in the assembly.

The team will be headed by IG Aswathi Dorje, an IPS officer of 2000-batch, now posted as director of Maharashtra Police Academy (MPA). The team was with Deshmukh on his tour of AP during which they met the CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy, home minister Mekatoti Sucharita and also woman and child development minister Taneti Vanitha. They discussed in detail the law that mandates capital punishment for rape and gang rape within 21 days which include seven days for investigation and remaining for trial in lower court.

AP government had formulated the Disha Act (Andhra Pradesh Criminal Law Amendment Act, 2019) following the gang rape and murder of the Hyderabad veterinarian in November last year. Following the national outrage, AP government had drafted the bill and passed it in their assembly within a month.

Deshmukh extolled the efforts of AP government that enforced the law just some time back. “The details of the enactment sounded strong,” he said. “We will see how our report on it shapes out,” said Deshmukh. He said express justice was possible in cases where accused are known and evidence is adequate.
