Though the demand of having such an enactment in Maharashtra had been raised during the last winter session in the city, Deshmukh had reiterated the promise to expedite the process after his active intervention in the Ankita Pisudde case in which the contributory lecturer from Wardha was set afire near her college at Hinganghat on February 3.

Deshmukh had also promised Pisudde’s case would be also tried in a fast track court which is one of the highlights of the Disha Act. In the past, MVA’s first home minister Eknath Shinde, replying to calling attention motion of MLC Manisha Kayande in the Upper House, had underlined the significance of a Disha Act-like enactment in the state as a deterrent for atrocities against women and children.

Shiv Sena MLA Pratap Sarnaik too had moved a private member bill in the assembly for such an enactment. Shinde had then informed that chief minister Uddhav Thackeray had taken up the issue with the director general of police (DGP). He was to take suggestions from the state law and justice department into consideration. He had also stated that 25 special and 27 fast track courts were created for expediting trials in such cases.

Title: Telangana chief secretary reviews Pattana Pragati prep, orders special survey
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Telangana chief secretary Somesh Kumar

HYDERABAD: Chief secretary Somesh Kumar on Thursday directed officials to appoint a nodal officer for each ward and constitute a team to participate and take up ‘ Pattana Pragati ’ being taken up in all 141 urban local bodies in the state from February 24.

Speaking at a review meeting at BRKR Bhavan on Thursday, Kumar asked officials to collect details of the wards, municipality and form four committees with 15 members in each ward.

The municipal administration department has developed software for entry of details regarding the programme. Kumar reviewed the software and suggested to simplify it. Pattana Pragathi will focus on sanitation, Haritha Haram, plan for community toilets, integrated vegetable and non-veg markets and parks etc.

“A special survey to identify illiterate has to be conducted in GHMC and Cantonment ,” he added. The finance department has released Rs 156 crores to GHMC and Rs 140 crores to municipalities under 14th Finance Commission grants for February and March.

Title: Lucknow: Police detain father in girl’s mystery death
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

LUCKNOW: After lodging an FIR for murder in connection with the mysterious death of a 15-year-old girl in Vikasnagar, police on Thursday detained her father, a head constable in security department.

After the girl’s death on Monday, the family had claimed that she had shot herself with the licensed pistol of her father after being scolded for not studying.

After the post-mortem examination ruled out gunshot injury and said that she died of head injuries, police registered a case of murder.

Title: Cops permit dharna at Indira Park, albeit with conditions
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

HYDERABAD: The decision of professor Haragopal to approach the high court for police permission to hold a dharna at Indira Park yielded results even before the plea was adjudicated by the HC.

Justice T Vinod Kumar on Thursday began hearing the writ petition filed by Haragopal, convener, Forum Against Repression seeking direction to Hyderabad police commissioner to for permission for a dharna with 500 persons at Dharna Chowk , Indira Park on February 25 from 10am to 4pm.

As the adjudication was about to begin, Telangana special counsel, Sharat Kumar, informed the court that joint commissioner of police, Central Zone, has given permission to the petitioner to hold the Dharna on certain conditions.

Though the petitioner sought permission to hold the Dharna with 500 persons between 10am and 4pm, the police cut down the number of participants to 300 and trimmed the timings to 10am to 2pm.

Few other conditions were also imposed by the police.

The police said the petitioner or any other organisers should plan for parking for participants. They will furnish to the police in advance the particulars of six speakers who will address the gathering. Also, they should ensure that no one, other than the specified speakers mentioned in the list, address the people.

Title: NLC contract staff can’t go on strike: Madras HC
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

CUDDALORE: The Madras high court has passed an order restraining the seven trade unions representing the contract workers of NLC India Limited from launching a strike against the company.

The trade unions issued a strike notice on February 11 demanding that the management fulfil their demands. Assistant labour commissioner (central) invited the representatives of the management and unions for a tripartite meeting at the Puducherry office on Wednesday.

However, the meeting failed to arrive at an amicable solution and the assistant labour commissioner decided to convene a meeting again soon. He appealed to the unions to desist from launching the strike and participate in the conciliatory meetings to settle the issue in an amicable manner.

Title: Why shouldn’t honeytrap case be given to CBI, Madhya Pradesh HC asks state
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

INDORE: The Indore bench of MP high court has observed that state government is reluctant to share information on the honeytrap case with the Centre and asked it to explain why it should not be handed over to the CBI for investigation.

The observations were made by a division bench of Justice S C Sharma and Justice Shailendra Shukla on February 10 while rejecting an application of the state government that sought modifications in an earlier court order to hand over documents of the case to income tax department.

“In the present case, there is a reluctance on the part of the state government in giving documents to the Union of India for reasons best known to the state government. Therefore, the state government shall file a reply on the point of transferring the matter to Central Bureau of Investigation,” the bench said.

The court passed an interim order to the state to provide all details of the case to the Centre, following petition filed by income tax department for information in the honeytrap case. The HC set a deadline of 10 days for the state government to hand over documents related to the case to the centre. The state then filed an interlocutory petition, seeking modification in the order.

“This court really fails to understand why information is being withheld from Union of India, especially in light of the facts that there are a large number of cash transactions in the honeytrap case,” the judges observed, adding that the income tax department is “certainly competent to seek information” keeping in view Section 131(1A) of Income Tax Act, 1961.

Title: GMR Airports sells 49% stake for Rs 10,700 crore to Paris airport developer
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: The GMR Group — India’s biggest private airport infra player — has picked Groupe ADP, formerly Aéroports de Paris, over a Tata Group-headed consortium to sell 49% stake in GMR Airports Limited (GAL) for Rs 10,780 crore. The deal, which values GMR Airports at Rs 22,000 crore, will see GAL getting Rs 5,248 crore immediately. Groupe ADP develops and manages airports, including Paris’s Charles de Gaulle, Orly and Le Bourget.

Last March, GIL had announced that a consortium of Tatas, GIC and SSG Capital Management will invest Rs 8,000 crore in GAL, valuing GMR Airports at almost Rs 22,500 crore. However, since Tata Group operates two airlines — Vistara and AirAsia India — airlines had been opposing its entry into the airport business.

In fact, now both the existing and upcoming airports of Delhi will have a strong European connection — ADP for Delhi and Flughafen Zurich, which is developing Greater Noida . Based on 2019 passenger statistics, the combined passengers handled by GMR Airports and Groupe ADP was 33.6 crore, the highest in the world.

Groupe ADP’s Rs 10,780-crore equity consideration, GMR Infra Limited said in a BSE filing, comprises of Rs 9,780 crore towards secondary sale of shares by GMR Group and Rs 1,000 crore equity infusion in GAL.

“Groupe ADP has also pegged earn-outs up to Rs 4,475 crore linked to achievement of certain agreed operating performance metrics as well as on receipt of certain regulatory clarifications over the next five years. Thereby, total valuation, assuming all above earn-outs are successfully consummated, may reach Rs 26,475 crore on post-money basis. The first tranche of Rs. 5,248 crore will be received by GMR Group immediately. This money will help deleverage the group further and result in improved cash flows and profitability,” the GIL regulatory filing said.

It added that “as part of the terms of transaction, GMR will retain management control over the airports business with Groupe ADP having the customary rights and board representation at GAL and its key subsidiaries”.

GMR Group chairman G M Rao said: “The partnership with Groupe ADP is in line with GMR’s business direction to become a global airport developer and operator. We have been on a journey of defining airports of the future with key focus on passenger experience by leveraging enhanced technology and offering superior amenities. With Groupe ADP, GMR will have smoother access to global markets, opening up newer avenues of business growth.”

Aéroports de Paris SA-Groupe ADP chairman and CEO Augustin de Romanet said: “The acquisition of a 49% stake in GMR Airports fits within Groupe ADP’s strategy. It sets a robust industrial partnership and enables Groupe ADP to build, only two years after taking control of TAV Airports, a unique worldwide network of airports with a solid industrial expertise and strong development capacities. This acquisition will constitute a growth driver in the medium term, and also a transforming position for the group in one of Asia’s and the world’s most dynamic and promising countries.”

Title: Odia engineer on board Diamond Princess ‘desperate’ to return: Kin
Content: Berhampur: The family of a software engineer from Berhampur, who is on the coronavirus-hit cruise liner Diamond Princess anchored off the coast of Japan since February 3, said they did not know when he would be getting off the ship. Passengers began disembarking from the ship, which was quarantined for a fortnight, on Wednesday.The family’s worry has been exacerbated by the fact that two persons who contracted the virus on the ship died on Thursday, and one more Indian crew member tested positive for the disease. There are 138 Indians — 132 crew and six passengers — on board the ship. Of them, eight crew have tested positive for coronavirus . Sibasish Nayak (27) of Pandara Sahi here is a passenger on the liner.Sibashis’s father, Lingaraj Nayak, said he had spoken to his son on Thursday. “He is okay but desperate to return to India. One of my relatives has gotten in touch with the Indian embassy. Though Japan as allowed coronavirus-free passengers to leave the ship, we don’t know when the Indians on board will be allowed to move out,” he said.On Thursday, the Indian embassy in Tokyo tweeted, “1 Indian crew who tested positive for #COVID19 among 79 new cases on #DiamondPrincess yesterday, has been shifted to hospital for treatment. All 8 Indians receiving treatment are responding well. Rest all Indians on-board are braving out the trying circumstances.”Sibashis was part of a six-member team of software engineers who visited southeast Asia on January 10 and later went on to board the Diamond Princess, which was quarantined after one of its passengers, who had gotten off at Hong Kong, tested positive for the disease.Lingaraj, a businessman, had on Wednesday requested chief minister Naveen Patnaik to secure the rescue of his son. “Sibashis tested negative for the disease when a routine check was carried out,” he said.MP (Berhampur) Chandra Sekhar Shau visited the Nayaks’ house on Thursday and assured the family of all help to get Sibashis back.

Title: Kochi airport-Aluva Metro station bus service begins
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The buses will be available from Aluva Metro station and Cial every 40 minutes

KOCHI: Pavan Doot electric bus service, an initiative to provide connectivity between airport and Aluva Metro station, was flagged off on Thursday by Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial) managing director VJ Kurien and Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL) managing director Alkesh Kumar Sharma.

The fare is fixed as Rs 50 for a single journey ticket. The buses will be available from both Aluva Metro station and Cial every 40 minutes. The first service to Aluva Metro station will begin at 5am and the first service to Cial will begin at 5.40am. The last service to Aluva Metro station will be at 10.30pm and the last bus heading to Cial will be at 11.10pm.

“It is a great start to a much-awaited partnership. Within a short time, KMRL signed an agreement with KSRTC to operate e-buses. With the introduction of these buses, it will be possible to find out how many commuters will take the Metro to reach the airport,” said Sharma, adding that the launch of these services was possible because of support from Cochin International Airport.

KMRL has planned airport connectivity as part of its its phase-three extension. The introduction of feeder services is viewed as the first step towards achieving the goal. “There are 12,000 people working at the airport. They will also benefit from the project,” said Kurien.

However, there has been an apprehension regarding extension of Metro to the airport as there are doubts about its viability. Passengers travelling to or from the airport generally carry huge luggage and Metro has restrictions on luggage sizes.

Shuttle services between Aluva Metro station and Cial have always been considered as a more viable option.

Title: Kerala: Court seeks action taken report
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: The high court on Thursday asked the state government to inform what action has been taken regarding the alleged missing of 25 rifles and 12,061 live cartridges from Kerala Police .

A division bench comprising Chief Justice S Manikumar and Justice Shaji P Chaly asked the steps taken on the basis of the report by Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) while considering during admission hearing a public interest litigation (PIL) by P P Ramachandra Kaimal of Changanassery through advocate R Krishna Raj. A probe by CBI or NIA has been sought by the petitioner.

A day ago, the court had dismissed another PIL seeking a CBI probe citing lack of materials to substantiate the allegation of an improper probe.

Considering the new PIL, the court has asked the state government to file an affidavit and has posted the case for a hearing on March 2. Opposite parties named in the PIL are the state government, state police chief, accountant general (general and social sector audit), comptroller and auditor general of India, and the Union government.

It is alleged in the PIL that no steps have been taken by the authorities yet to trace and recover the missing rifles and bullets. According to the PIL, the report by the CAG had mentioned a shortage of 25 5.56mm Insas rifles and 12,061 live cartridges, which includes 1,835 cartridges for Insas rifles and 1,578 cartridges for AK-47 rifles. It was also found out that out of the missing cartridges, 250 9mm drill cartridges were replaced by dummy bullets. The shortage of bullets started to happen from 2000 onwards, the petition said citing the report.

The CAG report had recommended for steps to immediately recover the missing rifles and bullets as well as taking stock of arms and ammunition of the entire police force in the state, the petitioner pointed out.

Though the crime branch team conducting the investigation at present has given a statement that no rifles are missing, there is serious suspicion regarding the actual situation, the PIL said. While the claims in the CAG report and that of the crime branch team are contradictory, the fact remains that missing of arms and ammunition is a serious security breach involving the security of the nation and the people of the state. Therefore, it is highly necessary to find out the veracity of the allegation so as to ensure physical safety of the people, the PIL stated while seeking a probe by the CBI or the NIA.

Title: Make green fight a mass movement: Delhi environment minister Gopal Rai
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Delhi environment minister Gopal Rai. (ANI photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi’s newly appointed environment minister, Gopal Rai , held a high-level meeting with officials of Delhi Pollution Control Committee and Delhi government’s environment and forest departments on Thursday.

The meeting was intended to impress on the officials the need to make environment a mass movement so that the promises made in Arvind Kejriwal’s pre-election ‘Guarantee Card’ could be fulfilled. These include planting two crore saplings, cleaning the Yamuna and reducing pollution levels by a third.

Track the pollution level in your city

At Thursday’s meeting, the government decided on four immediate steps. “Obtaining real-time data is the first priority,” Rai said. “For this, I will visit the office of Washington University near India Gate on Friday to understand the process of obtaining real-time data.” The second priority is sewage treatment plants created by Delhi Jal Board to detect, treat and monitor pollution in the Yamuna. “I will be visiting an STP at Delhi Gate to see its functioning," the minister said.

The meeting proposed a roundtable meeting on February 27, where experts, NGOs and environmentalists would discuss air pollution. There, Rai said, he would invite suggestions for Delhi government to consider when it is formulating a long-term action plan to clear the city’s air. The fourth step will be an interaction with greening agencies on February 28 to help determine how 40 lakh trees can be planted each year for five years.

“During the Delhi Assembly elections, CM Arvind Kejriwal ji had made a significant promise to reduce by one-third the pollution in Delhi and another to plant two crore trees in the city over five years,” Rai said. “To achieve this, we cannot rely solely on the government. We need the help of the people. Environment needs to be made into a mass movement in which every individual is a contributor. We will hold meetings with various departments to come up with a long-term action plan on how we can create this movement and involve the people.”

Rai said an action team needed to be formulated to oversee the effort. “In Delhi, the coordination of several agencies is important, and an action team can guide such a coordination,” he explained.

The environment minister conceded that people complied with but did not accept the rationale for the odd-even road rationing exercise because they felt that vehicular emissions was not a major component of Delhi’s air pollution. “Many felt dust and stubble-burning were the biggest contributors to dirty air,” he said. “The problem is we need real-time data to identify exactly what the biggest sources of pollution at any given time are to enable us to tackle them accordingly. Our tie-up with Washington University for real-time data will provide us a report by March this year and we can then measure our actions as well as the impact of each action.”

Rai claimed that various measures undertaken in the last five years, such as 24-hour power supply, increased greenery and the construction of the Eastern-Western Peripheral Expressway had helped Delhi. He also opined that the odd-even measure had sensitised people and impacted thinking.

Title: Lucknow: Wave of shock & anger at Gomtinagar Extension building
Content:
Alaknanda Apartment

LUCKNOW: A knife gang pouncing on a youth inside an SUV, stabbing him multiple times and leaving unchallenged — the gruesome attack may seem like a scene from some violent movie in the league of Gangs of Wasseypur. But, for residents of Alaknanda Apartment, it is brutal reality that left an indelible imprint on their collective psyche.A 20-year-old man, Prashant Singh, who had come to the elite residential complex in Gomtinagar extension to invite a friend to a birthday party was fatally attacked by a group of outsiders in front of at least three security guards and several bystanders.“We are shocked at how unsafe our city has become that murders like this are happening in broad daylight. We are infuriated at the security arrangements in posh apartments like ours,” said a resident, not willing to be named. Many Alaknanda Apartment residents stayed away from the crime scene. Those who assembled near the front gate swarming with policemen and forensic experts vented their anger at private security guards.“We pay Rs 2,000 per flat monthly for maintenance and security, but the incident today has instilled fear in us. Are we safe here,” asked Anurag Anand, a dentist.Poonam Tiwari, a dietician, said, “I am shocked to know that CCTV cameras at the gate are not working. The guards didn’t even try to confront the attackers.”Durgesh Shukla, the security supervisor, said the attack happened too quickly for anyone to react. “The victim came out of SUV and ran inside, but fell before reaching the elevator. The attackers zipped away on bikes. It was all over in minutes,” he added.In Video: Caught on camera: 20-year-old youth stabbed to death in Lucknow’s Gomtinagar

Title: 14 students skip CBSE class 10, 12 exams in Kanpur
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representational Photo

KANPUR: At least 14 students skipped class 10 and 12 examinations of CBSE Board in the city on Thursday, officials said.

City coordinator of CBSE Balvinder Singh said, “Nine students of class 10 did not appear for information technology paper on Thursday. Out of 326 students of class 12 who were to appear for painting paper, five skipped the examination.”

He said the question paper was moderate and students could have managed to answer questions with ease.

Schools are abuzz with activities in view of the ongoing examinations. Teachers are busy motivating students and helping them to cope with the examination stress.

Meanwhile, to ensure copying-free examinations of UP Board, CCTV cameras have been installed at examination centres.

District authorities are on their toes to ensure that the Board examinations are conducted peacefully.

Title: Ahmedabad: Society awaits redevelopment nod
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

There are 6,714 housing co-operatives in Ahmedabad

AHMEDABAD: Over the past few weeks, each time chunks of concrete fall off from the 59-year-old posh Nirmalkunj Society on the central business district (CBD) riverfront, residents — most of whom are elderly — have been hit by anxiety. In 2018, the residents had resolved to have the society redeveloped, but they have been waiting for an answer from the state government on whether a co-operative housing society is eligible for redevelopment . There are 6,714 housing co-operatives in Ahmedabad.

Officials at the registrar of co-operatives (housing) in Paldi have already communicated Nirmalkunj residents that an order or a resolution from the commissioner of co-operatives in this respect is yet to be received.

Time is running out for the eight families of the 18 members who live in Nirmalkunj. In one building, Block-C, deflection (bent) in the beam was observed, such that the building has slanted towards a slum area, adjacent to the society’s wall. Also February 2019 structural engineers report has pointed out “settlement of foundation in few blocks due to seepage.”

Town development officer for west zone, Chaitanya Shah said, “Till June last year, we have already issued Nirmalkunj Society members two notices to vacate the building immediately. If any tragedy occurs members living within the society or outside will be held responsible,” said Shah.

He added that the members have also been communicated that as per road width, only six floors will be allowed and no access will be provided from the riverfront.

Registrar of co-operatives (housing) for Ahmedabad, Chetan Parmar, said, “Re-development is allowed in housing which are under Gujarat Flat Owners Act. We cannot allow co-operative housing society permission for redevelopment as subsequent government order in this respect has not been be received by our department. Co-operatives are governed under Gujarat Co-operatives Act. It’s a different law,” says Parmar.

But state secretary for co-operation Manish Bhardwaj , said, “Redevelopment permissions are applicable to co-operative housings societies and for any new work, housing or any other kind of repairs. The society needs to have consent of 70% of the members and submit the resolution to the registrar. Housing societies can also get consent of 70% members for any change or initiating redevelopment work.''

When TOI visited the premises, the members were reluctant to comment. Recently the society’s accounts were frozen as a new committee is yet to be approved by the registrar. Chairman of the society Alka Tripathi said, “We have applied for redevelopment right now. We are yet to receive an answer from authorities. We are worried as the building is dilapidated and we have nowhere to go.”

Title: CM Kamal Nath attends mass marriage in Chhindwara
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

CM Kamal Nath attended a multi-faith mass marriage ceremony in Chhindwara

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Thursday asked the younger generation to imbibe Indian values and culture by eliminating social evils. “It is necessary for the existence of our country,” he said while addressing a mass marriage function of all religions and physically challenged couples in Chhindwara.

The event found a place in the Golden Book of World Records with 3,353 couples married together in a single function. The CM said that the event was a symbol of India’s diverse culture where Hindus, Muslims, Buddhists and disables couples tied the knot.

Nath said India’s culture is our greatest power, which makes this a great nation in the world. He argued it is the responsibility of younger generation to ensure that this characteristic of unity among people of different religions, castes, languages with the spirit of brotherhood is maintained.

Nath said that the state has a major challenge before it to make it a leader in the field of education and health. He said quality is essential in education and without it, the future of youths will be bleak. He said there is also a need for improvement in health facilities. “In these two fields, we should move forward towards excellence. The youth will need to play an important role in this regard,” he added.

Nath also said that the state government has taken important decisions including loan waiver for economic upliftment of farmers. “Economy of the state will not strengthen if purchasing power of farmers does not increase”, he said. He mentioned that his government is working with an aim to ensure fair prices to farmers for their produce.

“We are striving to bring a new revolution in the agriculture sector,” Nath said. By reducing electricity bills, the state has taken an initiative to provide relief to general consumers, he said.

Title: Madras HC permits abortion of minor girl’s pregnancy
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

Title: Marine enforcement wing to add more teeth to fisheries dept
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Madurai: To help the fisheries department regulating marine fishing activities, contain illegal fishing, maintain law and order problems at sea and to manage inter-sector conflicts, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami inaugurated marine enforcement wing on Wednesday.

According to a statement, the fisheries department is taking serious steps for the effective implementation of Tamil Nadu Marine Fishing Regulation Act, 1983. However, inadequate infrastructure, patrolling vessels and manpower are major hurdles in maintaining the law and order situation at sea besides preventing illegal fishing and conserving resources.

The newly-created wing will have 112 posts, which include a superintendent of police, a deputy superintendent of police, and 10 inspectors. The wing will also have 19 vehicles and provisions for patrol boat. The wing will conduct regular patrolling along the coast, fishing harbours, fish landing centres and other vulnerable areas to contain banned fishing practices.

The CM, who unveiled the emblem for the wing, also affixed the newly-designed badges to police personnel who are part of the wing.

A scheme was launched by the central and state governments for the conversion of 2,000 trawling boats in the Palk Bay region into deep sea fishing boats. During 2017-18, governments had allotted Rs 286 crore for the scheme for converting 500 trawl fishing boats in the first phase. Eight such boats were constructed spending Rs 6.40 crore for fishermen in Ramanathapuram district. The CM has handed over keys of the deep sea fishing boats to seven fishermen.

The CM has also inaugurated several buildings under the Tamil Nadu Dr J Jayalalithaa Fisheries University for Rs 27.65crore at Nagapattinam, Ramanathapuram and Chengalpattu districts.

Title: Melavalavu massacre victims’ kin challenge release of convicts
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Madras high court

MADURAI: Family members of the Melavalavu massacre victims have moved the Madras high court challenging the premature release of the 13 convicts.

The case involves the massacre of six dalits at Melavalavu on June 30, 1997, by members of another caste following the election of a dalit as the village council president. The state government released all the 13 convicts citing good conduct in November 2019.

Five women – Manimegala, Vasanthi, Kaali, Pachaiyammal and Kattachi – who are family members of the deceased moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to quash the orders passed by the state government for the premature release of these convicts and sought to detain them back in prison.

When the case was taken up for hearing on Thursday, justice A D Jagadish Chandira tagged this petition to be heard along with similar petitions which were filed earlier.

It maybe recalled that, recently, while hearing two petitions with similar prayers, a division bench withdrew the interim order which directed all the convicts to stay in Vellore district after the litigant who challenged the release of 13 life convicts in Melavalavu massacre case failed to appear before the court for the hearing.

Title: Kanpur: Man sends obscene photos to ex-lover’s groom, booked
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

KANPUR: A woman’s marriage was called off after her ex-boyfriend allegedly uploaded her obscene videos and pictures on social media and also forwarded them to her fiancé and his family in Chakeri area of the city.

The woman approached the police on Wednesday and lodged a complaint against the accused, identified as Vikas Jaiswal of Chakeri.

Police have launched a search to nab the accused who is on the run. according to cops, the marriage was scheduled to take place next month.

In her complaint, the woman said she developed relationship with her one-time classmate, Vikas Jaiswal, after meeting him on social media about a year ago.

Jaiswal, however, exploited her sexually on several occasions on the pretext of marriage.

Later, Jaiswal refused to marry her on the ground that she came from a lower caste, police said.

However, when the accused came to know about the woman’s marriage with someone else, he uploaded her inappropriate videos and pictures on social media and sent them to her fiancé and his family following which the marriage was called off.

Jaiswal has been booked under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) including 376 (rape) of IPC and Section 67 A (publishing or transmitting of material containing sexually explicit act) of the Information Technology Act.

“An FIR has been lodged against the accused following a complaint by the woman on Wednesday. We are conducting raids to arrest him,” said inspector, Chakeri, Ranjit Rai.

Title: 4 cops, including 2 S-Is, suspended
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Lucknow: Hours after the Pandeyganj loot and murder, police commissioner suspended four cops, including two sub-inspectors, for laxity. “In charges of Yahiyaganj and Pandeyganj outposts, Achyutanand Rai and Mahesh Sharma, and constables Ravindra Kumar and Dinesh Kumar have been suspended,” said police spokesman Nitin Kumar said. Nine patrol vehicles were in the area at the time of crime.

Title: Hyderabad: Activists raise concern over lack of identity proof for trafficking victims
Content:
(From left) IG women of safety wing Swati Lakra, director general of Aeronautical Systems at DRDO Tessy Thomas... Read More

HYDERABAD: Amid nationwide protests against the implementation of National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ), activists are raising concerns regarding the lack of identity proof in possession of marginalised sections like victims of human trafficking .“There are a substantial number of Muslim women victims who are rescued from the clutches of the traffickers. Most of them hardly have any identity proof. Even if they do, it is very hard to trace those documents. Some were sold by their own family or relatives. They do not have any documentation,” said Sunitha Krishnan, social activist and co-founder of Prajwala. Krishnan attended the She M Power event organised by the Cyberabad police andSociety for Cyberabad Security Council.“We work towards getting them Aadhaar card and identity proof, but that is not a citizenship proof either. How are these women going to prove they are citizens of the country, or what documents will they show?” added Krishnan.Some of the rescued women are Rohingya Muslims who are scared to talk about where are they from, lest they get deported or detained. “The Government needs to consider these issues before implementing CAA-NRC-NPR,” said Krishnan.

Title: State-of-the-art amphitheatre at Khajuraho soon, says MP culture minister
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

POETRY IN MOTION: Kathak dancers at the Khajuraho dance fest

BHOPAL: The ancient murals of Khajuraho came alive with light breeze adding to the romance of a sublime evening as the 47th Khajuraho Dance Festival began on Thursday with politicians, bureaucrats and several tourists in attendance.

The much-awaited event was inaugurated by culture minister Vijayalaxmi Sadho, with senior IAS officer Pankaj Raag in attendance. Chhatarpur collector Mohit Bundas was also present on the occasion.

The high point of the evening was the felicitation of internationally acclaimed dancers — Jatin Goswami and Uma Sharma - with Kalidas Samman. While giving the awards, Sadho said, “Madhya Pradesh is a culturally rich and diversified state. We have a long and illustrious legacy, but the onus lies on each one of us to nurture this heritage. It is a pleasure to award Kalidas Samman to brilliant artistes like Jatin Goswami and Uma Sharma who have made us proud.” A cash award of Rs2 lakh was given to each awardee, along with a citation.

Sadho also made a special announcement on the occasion, which is expected to give fillip to tourism in the region. “We will soon make a state-of-the-art amphitheatre in Khajuraho, which will attract more tourists to this thriving hub of culture,” she said.

The event began with a dance drama by Kathak guru Uma Sharma and her troupe. The act saw Uma’s team captivate the audience as Krishna, Radha and gopikas with their divine raas leela. Later, living legend of Sattriya, Goswami enthralled everyone with his performance. Odissi artiste Meera Das was a joy to watch on stage with her brilliant footwork, abhinaya and lyrical moves.

Khajuraho fest is one of the most prestigious dance festivals in the world, attended by connoisseurs from across the globe. The week-long dance extravaganza will see a perfect blend of youth and experience mesmerising the audience in the backdrop of the ethereal Khajuraho temples, a UNESCO World Heritage site, with their mastery over various classical dance forms, including Kathak, Bharatanatyam, Odissi, Kuchipudi, Mohiniattam and Sattriya.

Organised by Ustad Allauddin Khan Sangeet Evam Kala Academy and the department of culture, the festival will have dancers like Pujita Krishnan, Krishna Mohan Mishra, Lata Singh Munshi, Shobhana Pillai, Suprva Mishra, Anand Shankar Jayant, Y Asha Kumari, Kshitija Barve, Ragini Makkhar, N Srikanth, Ashwini Srikanth, Nair sisters, Nartaki Natraj, Bhadra Sinha, Gayatri Verma, Richa Joshi, Deepak Gangani, Mohika Saxena, Sri Vidya, Inakshi Sinha, Vasu Sinam, Amita Khare mesmerise the eclectic audience.

Title: CPR could have saved DMart victim: Doctors
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Teenagers who have undiagnosed heart diseases can have sudden heart attacks, but many lives can be saved by cardiopulmonary resuscitation , said experts.Four days after 18-year-old Intermediate student, Lavudya Sathish, died of suspected heart attack, when he was confronted by DMart staff in Vanasthalipuram for stealing chocolates, health experts said Satish’s life may have been saved if someone knew CPR at the mall.“When there is a death due to cardiac arrest, the heart is generally to blame. But even more to blame is the fact that we don’t have enough experts to handle emergencies with CPR, or cardiopulmonary resuscitation, which can possibly save a life in such circumstances,” said Dr Sivaranjani Santosh , a leading paediatrician who works extensively on CPR and administering first-aid.Experts say hypertrophied cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the leading cause of sudden cardiac death (SCD) in youngsters.“In HCM, the heart muscle thickens abnormally, and this can make it harder for the heart to pump blood. This is also a genetic disease. HCM can trigger arrhythmia, which can be described as irregular heartbeat, which in turn leads to sudden cardiac death,” said Dr Sai Ravi Shankar, senior consultant interventional cardiologist, Continental Hospitals.According to available statistical data, awareness of CPR in the Indian population is less than 1%. Calling for more awareness on CPR and the importance of going for regular health check-ups involving ECG and echo tests, Dr Shankar said that there are 100% chances of survival in cases of arrhythmia if CPR is performed immediately, in the right way. “It is extremely crucial to have some knowledge of handling medical emergencies. Also, families that have a history of SCD must go for heart screenings to prevent such incidents from occurring. In last two years, I have witnessed nearly 6 SCD cases among youngsters, ” adding, “Unlike the US, UK and Canada, where training is imparted in schools, colleges and communities, we have still not incorporated training in life support in our curriculum,” he said.Dr Vijay Rao, faculty member of American Health Association for basic life support, said that in Sathish’s case, the death was most likely a result of shock, which caused a surge in release of catecholamines (neurotransmitters), which causes more dangerous arrhythmia that leads to cardiac arrest and, if untreated, sudden death. “Had CPR been performed on the boy in the first five minutes, chances of him surviving would have increased. Every 90 seconds, there is death due to cardiac arrest, which is more than deaths due to all the cancers,” he said.

Title: Shaheen Bagh road closure: Cops have their reasons
Content:
Protesters protesting against CAA for over two months at Shaheen Bagh (File photo)

NEW DELHI: While the talk till now has been about the commuting woes due to the blockade of the Kalindi Kunj road by protesters at Shaheen Bagh , the new dispute is about the barricades placed on the stretch there to stop vehicles from using the roads in the area.At a time when the DND Flyway, the major point of entry into Delhi from Noida, is choked, barricades (B1) placed on the six-lane Okhla Barrage Road at a point where the Mahamaya Flyover descends appears misdirected. However, they actually prevent chaos on the two smaller roads flanking Madanpur Khadar, as do the barricades (B2) manned by Uttar Pradesh Police near the new Kalindi Kunj bridge.The 150-metre protest site at Shaheen Bagh comprises tents on one carriageway of GD Birla Road, protest installations and uprooted grills on the other. Between Jasola at one end and Kalindi Kunj park on the other, the 900 metres has a series of barricades (B3, B4, B5), those closest to the sit-in side manned by protesters and those at the extreme ends by police.The placement of police barricades (B2) near the Supertech Supernova building at a fair distance from Shaheen Bagh has received flak. But what this achieves is visible 1.5km down the stretch. Dinesh Kumar, a traffic policeman at the barricade, described such criticism as “specious”. He asked, “Why would we want to close the roads simply to inconvenience people? Is it not clear that if we remove the barricades, with the main carriageways blocked, the two smaller Khadar Road and Mithapur-Molarband Road will not be able to take the traffic load?”Another officer caustically observed, "The removal of these barricade will induce a heart attack in the arterial road network several kilometres away.” When TOI visited the barricades on Thursday, police were allowing smaller vehicles to run via the sector road, but even this small trickle was creating significant chaos further down.After crossing the Kalindi Kunj bridge, commuters encounter barricades (B3) handled by CRPF and Delhi Police at the right turn toward Atlantic Water World park. “We allow ambulances and school buses through because the next barricade on GD Birla Marg is managed by the protesters, who let them pass too,” a CRPF personnel said. The protestors do not permit other vehicles, either here or on the road from Kalindi Kunj to Abul Fazal Enclave and Okhla Bird Sanctuary.Executives of the private toll collector at Kalindi Kunj have been idling since the protest began over two months ago. More than 1.5 lakh vehicles crossed the border every day. One of them recalled how for the first couple of days there were jams for up to 10 hours until the barricades stopped the entry of vehicles from Noida. “There is no way the smaller roads in the area can handle such a volume,” he noted.TOI realised on Thursday that even the limited number of vehicles being allowed to reach the toll point were causing chaos on the two-lane Khadar Road and Mithapur-Molarband Road branching off from the Kalindi Kunj bridge. The latter has a small bridge where traffic bunches up. Pradeep Chauhan, a contractor who uses the road every day, grumbled about being stuck there for up to an hour. “It takes me five minutes on normal days, but traffic has burgeoned,” he said. Mohammed Illyas, a broom seller who rides a two-wheeler, had a dire warning: “This bridge can collapse any day.”At Shaheen Bagh, it has been suggested that one carriageway could be opened for traffic while the sit-in continues on the other. Police, however, are sceptical about the half-road solution. An officer explained that the purpose of blocking both carriageways was to ensure the safety of the protesters. “Heavy commercial vehicles cross the UP border and they are bound to cause chaos among the floating population congregating at the protest site,” he said, adding that there was also the risk of “violent elements” approaching the protest site in large numbers if traffic was allowed on the road. “Who will be accountable for any law and order problem that could arise if such mischief makers managed to access the protest site?” he asked.

Title: Avinashi accident shatters dreams of six families in Thrissur
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

AC Moideen pay tributes to the mortal remains of Anu KV of Vazhappally near Erumappetty

THRISSUR: The tragic bus accident at Avinashi in Tamil Nadu on Thursday morning also shattered the dreams of many families in the district.

Anu K V, 24, wife of Snijo, a resident of Vazhappally near Erumappetty , was coming home from Bengaluru, where she was working, to meet her husband who was planning to go back to Qatar. “The couple had got married only a month ago. Snijo, who works in Qatar, was going back on Sunday. Anu was coming to meet him. It’s a big loss to our family,” Johnson, Anu’s relative, said.

For another victim, Jofi Paul, it was his long-pending dream of visiting the Velankanni shrine with family, that has gone unfulfilled. Jofi’s colleagues at Joy Alukkas in Bengaluru, where he is the manager, remember him as a man with ever-smiling face. “Jofi was always identified by his iconic smile. He had taken leave from work to visit Velankanni Church with family,” his colleague Anish said.

Another victim from Thrissur , Igni Raphel, 39, a resident of Ollur, was working at an oil rig in Saudi for several years. He had come home to take his wife to Saudi. “Raphel had decided to arrange a job to wife Bincy in Saudi. As part of this, the couple had gone to Bengaluru to collect Bincy’s college certificate. The couple, who got married four years ago, was planing to complete the paper works after collecting the certificates. But the accident destroyed all their hopes,” said a relative of the family.

For Manikandan, his 25-year-old son Kuranjiyoor Valappil Haneesh was everything. A resident of Chittilappally near Thrissur, Haneesh had got married on October 25, 2019, and he was the sole bread winner of his family. He had completed his polytechnic course and was working in an engineering firm in Bengaluru. The family was staying in a rented premises at Adat and Chittilappilli areas for several years. With the death of their sole breadwinner, Manikandan, has no answers about his family’s future.

Title: Kanpur: Homeguard run over by train, probe on
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

KANPUR: A 46-year-old homeguard died after he was run over by a train near 9 no. crossing in Kalyanpur area of the city on Thursday.

The police have identified the deceased as Rajesh Kumar Shukla. According to inspector Kalyanpur, Shukla was attached with Chamanganj police station of the city.

According to reports, on Thursday afternoon Shukla was crossing the railway tracks when he was run over by a speeding train near 9 no: crossing in Kalyanpur said the inspector. The body was recovered from the tracks and shifted to mortuary for postmortem examination.

“It is still not clear whether the homeguard committed suicide or he died accidentally, investigations are underway in this regard,” added an official privy to the investigation.

Title: Payal Tadvi suicide case: Bombay HC asks B Y L Nair Hospital dean if accused doctors on bail can do PG
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Payal Tadvi

MUMBAI: Six months after they were released on bail in the Dr Payal Tadvi suicide case , the Bombay high court has sought B Y L Nair Hospital dean’s assistance to figure whether the three accused doctors can pursue their post-graduation in a different unit there. The HC directed the hospital’s gynaecology head to remain present on Friday to enable it to pass orders.

Last October, the accused doctor trio—Hema Ahuja, Bhakti Mehare and Ankita Khandelwal— had approached the HC to drop certain strict bail conditions and be permitted to enter Nair college and practise again.

On Wednesday, at a hearing of their plea before Justice Sadhana Jadhav, Aabad Ponda, senior counsel for the doctors, submitted that their right to complete their post-graduation from the same college be protected. Senior counsel Raja Thakare appearing as special public prosecutor, though, said while relaxing the bail conditions, the court must also keep in mind that witnesses in the case work in the same college. They would all be working together and, therefore, the remotest possibility of tampering of witnesses will have to be ruled out first, it was submitted.

The accused are pursuing post-graduation in gynaecology. The prosecution said it would ask the college if they can pursue their PG in a unit different than the one they were attached to before the FIR was registered against them. The gynaecology department head will give appropriate instructions to the dean and the prosecution, said the HC.

The dean, too, will assist the prosecution, said the judge and posted the matter to Friday for orders. Barun Kumar, counsel for the complainant, objected to any relaxation in bail conditions, arguing that tampering of witnesses cannot be ruled out.

Tadvi, a junior doctor pursuing her PG at Nair College, ended her life on May 22. Her family alleged the accused doctors taunted her and hurled casteist abuses at her. Police filed a chargesheet against the trio for abetment to suicide and under the SC/ST Act. They were in judicial custody for over two months.

In an oral observation, the judge, “The social impact of the case was so much that they (accused) should not face wrath. From whatever they have done, we cannot take away their right to education.”

Title: Brain booster: UP’s 1st advanced neuro unit at RML institute
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

LUCKNOW: For all patient needs under neuro science, Dr Ram Manohar Lohia Institute of Medical Sciences (RMLIMS) will soon be the one-stop medical centre. The institute is setting up the state’s first advanced neuro science centre. It is also going to be the first institute in the state to have the gamma knife procedure for burning out brain tumours without opening up a patient’s head.

The two decisions were taken by the institute on Thursday in its 32nd general body meeting presided over by principal secretary medical education Dr Rajneesh Dubey.

The centre will provide neuro trauma and neuro emergency treatment under a single roof at the centre. In the first phase, 90 beds and three modular operation theatres will be constructed on three floors of the institute’s new block. By bringing gamma knife procedure to the state, RMLIMS will make complex brain tumour surgeries more likely to be successful. Under this procedure, gamma rays will be used to burn the tumour without cutting through the head. Even complex tumours really close to brain nerves can be burnt with the gamma knife.

The facility, the institute said in a statement, will allow discharge of a patient from the hospital within four hours of surgery, unlike weeks of stay after regular brain tumour surgeries.

With the procedure, RMLIMS expects to treat around 1,000 patients every year for not just brain tumour but other diseases like acoustic neuroma, vascular malformation and epilepsy.

Title: I am committed to change the face of MP, says CM
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Chief minister Kamal Nath has said that when he took over the reins of Madhya Pradesh, he could realise that the state was stuck in an economic mess due to “unwise” financial policies of the Union government and the previous BJP government in MP.

In a blog on Thursday, the CM said, “Huge resources were spent to project just one person and fake propaganda was carried out to keep him in focus at an expenditure of crores, but no attention was paid towards “inclusive” development of MP, which kept sliding during the previous regime. Several schemes were announced without allocating necessary funds for them in the budget, and this too is weighing heavily on the finances available with the incumbent Congress government in the state”.

He said, “Mahatma Gandhi had said that whenever a government formulates a scheme, its focus should be the last man in the queue and whenever it has to evaluate its performance, it should look at the condition of villages and farmers”. The chief minister said he is happy that his government has been able to do what Gandhiji wanted. “Electricity bills of 87% power consumers has come down by 50-60% following implementation of the Indira Grih Jyoti Yojana and farmers are happy as their farm debts are being waived. We are realizing Mahatma Gandhi’s dream with many such schemes”, he said.

He said that there is a special reason why he wants to interact with people of the state through his blog. “The recent Union budget clearly indicates that “immature” economic decisions of the Union government have put the nation in a grim economic situation and Madhya Pradesh is also suffering on this count. There has been a drop in GDP growth rate as the Union government is neglecting inclusive growth of the nation. With huge unemployment among youths and fall in net tax revenue collection, the country is heading towards serious economic condition”, he said.

The chief minister said that he is also concerned over “back-stabbing” by the Union government, which is not giving its share for the schemes being implemented in MP. Even in “Swachh Bharat Mission” (urban), the Union government has given only 20% of its share, he said.

“The Union government, in its revised estimate, has reduced the share of MP by Rs 14,233 crore. It is for the first time in 50 years that the state’s share in central taxes has been so low. People of MP have elected 28 BJP MPs, but no one raises his voice in the interest of the state,” Nath said.

The chief minister, however, said that he is committed to change every social and economic challenges into an opportunity and nobody can stop Madhya Pradesh from becoming one of the most developed states of the country.

(The blogger is the chief minister of MP)

Title: Coimbatore bus accident: 19 killed, 25 injured as truck rams bus in Tamil Nadu
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

COIMBATORE/KOCHI: Kerala woke up on Thursday to the tragedy of a horrific road crash, involving a state transport (KSRTC) bus and a floor tiles-laden container truck near Avinashi on Tirupur-Salem bypass in Tamil Nadu around 3.40am, that claimed the lives of 19 people and left 25 injured. The deceased included five women and the two driver-cum-conductors of the multi-axle luxury bus.

The bus was going to Ernakulam from Bengaluru with 48 passengers. The container truck, laden with over 25 tonnes of floor tiles, was heading towards Bengaluru from Kochi. Police said the truck driver, K A Hemaraj (37), might have fallen asleep at the wheel and lost control of the vehicle. The speeding truck hit the 15-cm high median, entered the other side of the lane and rammed the bus head-on.

The right side of the bus was completely torn off till near its middle. Most passengers sitting on the left side of the bus were stuck inside for hours as the front portion was completely mangled. Rescue works lasted till around 8.30am.

The post-mortem of bodies was conducted at Tirupur government hospital before handing them over to relatives while the injured were rushed to nearby hospitals.

Tirupur city police commissioner Sanjay Kumar said that the truck driver had been arrested and booked under IPC sections 279 (rash driving), 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) and 304A (causing death by negligence).

“The autopsy of 18 persons was completed by evening and the bodies handed over to relatives. All of them are Keralites. The remaining is that of a Thumkoor native. The condition of one of the injured, Bincy, is a bit serious, for whom medical care is being given,” Kerala transport minister A K Saseendran said.

The Kerala state government will bear the treatment expenses of the injured.

Title: HC slaps fine on IAS for delay in appearing
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Lucknow: The Lucknow bench of Allahabad high court imposed a fine of Rs 25,000 on principal secretary, forests, for default on framing of UP Special Tiger Protection Service Rules and for keeping the court waiting for hearing.

A bench of Justice MN Bhandari and Justice Manish Kumar passed the order on a pending PIL moved in 2016 for protection of tigers. A tiger protection force was constituted way back in 2013 but the rules have not been framed till date.

On January 7, the court had directed the officials to frame the rules or else the principal secretary (forest) and chief conservator of forests/field director of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve (Kheri) would have to appear before it on February 17.

On the day of hearing, the chief conservator appeared and said the rules could not be framed.

The principal secretary (forest), however, was busy in the assembly session, his counsel said.

While the court was about to issue a contempt notice, the counsel said the secretary was on his way.

The court granted half an hour to the secretary while imposing fine of Rs 25,000 for wasting its time.

The secretary informed the court that the process of framing rules was taking time due to other departments and sought three months for completion, which the court granted.

Title: Coronavirus: Indians may be airlifted on Friday, Trichy collector tells ship crew over phone
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI/TRICHY: Japanese health authorities on Thursday started collecting swabs from the crew members of the ship Diamond Princess which has been quarantined off Yokohama due to the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) which infected them. Meanwhile, an assurance given by Trichy district collector S Sivarasu to one of the Indian crew members on board the ship that they will be airlifted on a special plane in a day or two has given a new lease of life to the worried men.“As the quarantine period for passengers came to end on Wednesday, hundreds of them were evacuated over the last two days. Swabs were collected from us on Thursday and we were told that the results will be known in two to three days. The captain also made an announcement that a Philippines crew member who had earlier tested positive for COVID-19 has recovered and returned home,” Anbalagan, a crew member from Madurai, told TOI.Devipriya, the wife of Muthu Ponnusamy, 42, of Trichy, who is among the five crew members from Tamil Nadu on the ship, petitioned the Trichy collector on Thursday. She appealed to the government through him to bring back the Indians including her husband who are on the quarantined ship. The chef who is a colleague of Anbalagan used to come home once in six months.“My wife is a homemaker. My son and daughter are in class VI and V. They are worried over the undue delay in evacuating us from the ship. So she petitioned the collector. I spoke to the collector on a WhatsApp call through my wife’s phone and explained our plight. We want to be disembarked from the infected ship on priority,” Muthu said. The collector told his wife and the crew over phone that he is aware of the issue and also enquired about his health. “I spoke with him. He tested negative. He and other Indians are likely to be airlifted from the ship tomorrow,” the collector told TOI.Meanwhile, the Indian Embassy in Tokyo stated that one Indian crew member is among the 79 new cases who had tested positive for COVID-19 on board Diamond Princess on Wednesday. In their tweet on Thursday, the embassy added that this takes the number of Indians on board who tested positive for COVID-19 to eight. Stating that they have been shifted to a hospital for treatment, it added that all eight Indians receiving treatment are responding well. “All other Indians on board are braving out the trying circumstances,” it added. However, the crew members on board are worried over the delay in getting a confirmation from the embassy in flying them to India.

Title: Avinashi bus accident: Relief as per KSRTC’s revised policy
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Rescue operation in full flow early on Thursday

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With proper insurance coverage and revised policy, KSRTC will be able to offer a decent sum as insurance amount to the families of the Avinashi accident victims. An amount of Rs 10 lakh each will be paid to the relatives, said transport minister A K Saseendran.

KSRTC CMD M P Dinesh convened a meeting with representatives of New India Assurance company on Thursday to expedite the disbursal of insurance amount.

Saseendran said it is the first time that KSRTC will be disbursing such a huge amount of insurance to the kin of accident victims. “A first instalment amount of Rs 2 lakh each will be disbursed to the relatives on an urgent basis without procedural delay. The remaining amount will be paid in a month. Families of the bus crew members who died in the accident will be given an amount of Rs 30 lakh as insurance amount.

“The treatment expenses of the injured will be paid by KSRTC from passenger insurance. Overcoming several challenges, introducing passenger insurance cess and regular payment of premium amount led KSRTC to pay the insurance,” the minister said.

Also, financial aid up to Rs 3 lakh will be provided to people injured in the accident.

The insurance policy was revised by KSRTC last year, when an employee P Prakash died for burn injuries sustained during an accident involving KSRTC bus and concrete mixer vehicle at Vayakkal , near Ayoor. The insurance amount was found to be insufficient to meet the treatment expenses of the person. Then, KSRTC came into an agreement with New India Assurance company for insurance coverage for passengers.

The minister also said KSRTC will conduct an inquiry into the accident in which 19 people were killed and more than 20 people were grievously injured at Avinashi, Tamil Nadu . “I have ordered an inquiry. And KSRTC managing director will probe and submit a report,” said Saseendran.

Title: Discard home secretary’s clean chit: Ramesh Chennithala
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Ramesh Chennithala

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala has demanded that the report of additional chief secretary (home and vigilance) Vishwas Mehta , giving clean chit to the police, should be immediately discarded as the crime branch has already seized fake cartridge shells from special armed police battalion.

“After the crime branch seized fake cartridge shells, the report of the home secretary itself has become a sham. The report is only an attempt to rescue the government from the crisis it has fallen into, and the report is nothing but tailor-made for how the chief minister asked him to write such a report,” Chennithala said. He said that the comptroller and auditor general (CAG) had sought explanation from the home department over the irregularities in the purchases and missing guns and cartridges before finalising the audit report. The home secretary’s report is the same justification that CAG had examined earlier and discarded after finding them baseless.

The home secretary is also responsible for the findings of the CAG’s report. It is strange that the same person who is one of the culprits is preparing a report that has now given clean chit to all the irregularities, Chennithala said.

A report by Mehta, on the adverse remarks on the police, had given clean chit to the police, completely brushing away the observations of the CAG. The home secretary had given explanation on each of the major observations of the CAG report.

Title: Intense lobbying on to up retirement age of doctors
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Intense lobbying at different levels is on to raise the retirement age of medical college doctors since about 60 doctors are due for retirement this April-end.

The retirement age of doctors was increased to 62 from 60 in 2017 when a bunch of senior doctors were due for retirement that year. Now the same set of doctors will be retiring this April. Hence, they have again started lobbying for raising the retirement age to 65 from 62. The retirement of medical college doctors takes place only at the end of the academic year.

According to sources, the proposal for increasing the retirement age along with pay revision is awaiting approval at the chief minister’s office.

However, this proposal has been vehemently opposed by the finance department. “There is no need for increasing the retirement age presently. It was raised two years ago. Moreover, it would affect prospects of several junior doctors,” said a senior finance department official. The health department has also taken a similar stand on the issue. But now the doctors have approached the chief minister’s office with the request.

The Kerala Government Medical College Teachers Association (KGMCTA) is also against raising the retirement age. But the doctors who are due for retirement this year are lobbying citing that the cream of senior doctors will be leaving the medical education service with this retirement.

“We have not demanded the increase in the retirement age since it would affect the prospects of the several junior colleagues and also those who are in the list seeking recruitment to the medical education service. The only demand of the association was to implement the pay revision since the last revision was done in 2006,” said Dr Nirmal Bhaskar, state secretary of KGMCTA.

When P K Sreemathi was the health minister in the V S Achuthanandan government, the pay revision was implemented in 2006. The retirement age of the medical college doctors was increased to 60 from 55 in 2009.

Title: Government museum launches heritage awareness programme for students
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Students of history from the NMSVN College Nagamalai Pudukottai, had an opportunity to go around the museum an... Read More

MADURAI: As part of efforts to spread awareness among the students on the importance of maintaining heritage structures and ancient sites, the government museum in Madurai conducted a workshop here on Thursday.

Curator of the museum, Dr M Marudhupandiyan , who delivered the special address, explained the various acts that played an important role in protecting and preserving ancient, heritage structures. He said that the Indian Treasure Trove Act of 1878, the Ancient Monument Act of 1904 and the Ancient Monument and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act of 1966 and their rules in 1977 go a long way in helping to preserve ancient structures.

A latest finding by the museum, a 12th century stone script which brought to light that two later Pandya kings ruled simultaneously was shown to the students, and its significance explained.

Marudhupandiayan also explained the importance of the excavation at Keeladi which has brought to light the existence of a civilization which was unknown till about eight years ago,.

Students of history from the NMSVN College Nagamalai Pudukottai, had an opportunity to go around the museum and later distributed awareness pamphlets to people at important places like Rajaji Park, Government Medical College and others.
