Title: 'She M Power' conclave held in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

HYDERABAD: A women’s conclave with the theme ‘Respect-Reach-Rise’ was held at Hyderabad International Convention Centre on Thursday.

The conclave, named ' She M Power ', was jointly conducted by the Cyberabad police and Society for Cyberabad Security Council.

Addressing the gathering, Swati Lakra, IG (Law and Order) and In Charge of Women Safety Wing, Telangana Police said that punishing the violators of law is not a corrective measure.

The chief guest of the event, Dr Tessy Thomas, Director General of Aeronautical Systems at DRDO, said that women should take criticism as an opportunity to learn. “Take criticism into your stride and develop, improve your performance,” she said.

Title: Gas tragedy: MHA official attends court hearing but case transferred
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bhopal: Undersecretary in the ministry of home affairs (MHA), M K Chahar, appeared in the court of judicial magistrate first-class Hiralal Alawa in Bhopal on Thursday to explain the delay in delivery of court summons to Dow Chemical at its headquarters in USA.

Alawa, however, refused to hear the case any further in compliance with a notification that all cases pending in the court of magistrates, where CBI is the prosecuting agency, will be heard by the court of additional chief judicial magistrate (ACJM). The case now stands transferred to the court of ACJM Ashish Parsai, the applicant was told.

The court has issued summons to be delivered to Dow Chemical half a dozen times in response to an application filed by the NGO Bhopal Group for Information & Action (BGIA), seeking a reply on why Dow should not be made a party in the litigation against Union Carbide Corporation (UCC) and its officials for the Bhopal gas disaster since it took over UCC in 2001. BGIA, which was one of the interveners in the criminal proceedings against UCC, its subsidiaries and officials, contends that Dow Chemical, by taking over UCC, not only inherited its assets but also its liabilities and therefore, it should also face trial for the Bhopal gas disaster, which killed hundreds of people and maimed many more.

BGIA co-convener Rachna Dhingra prayed to the judge, Ashish Parsai, to hear the case on Wednesday itself since the MHA undersecretary was present in court in compliance with a court order, but the judge said he needed time to examine the case. The court has posted the case for February 26.

Title: Man sets self afire at dad’s clinic, critical
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Kanpur: A man tried to commit suicide by setting himself afire in his father’s clinic in Meerpur Cantt under Rail Bazaar police station area of the city on Thursday.

Sandeep Singh, son of Indrajeet Singh and a resident of Lal Bangla area, was admitted to hospital with serious burns.

According to the police, “Sandeep used to assist his father, who runs a homeopathy clinic in Meerpur Cantt area. On Thursday afternoon, he set himself on fire inside his father’s clinic and then ran outside on the street. Locals tried to rescue him by pouring water and then informed the police. By the time, the police arrived, his family members rushed him to a private hospital. He had sustained 60 percent burns,” said a senior police officer. His condition is stated to be serious, he added.

“Police are trying to ascertain the reason behind the extreme step,” said inspector Rail Bazar police station Dadhibal Tiwari.

Sources, however, said Sandeep took the step owing to some kind of financial constraint.

Title: Uddhav Thackeray: Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray to meet Sonia Gandhi as Congress, NCP firm on not allowing NPR
Content:
Uddhav Thackeray

MUMBAI: CM Uddhav Thackeray will be in New Delhi on Friday to meet PM Narendra Modi and Congress president Sonia Gandhi , even as Congress and NCP appear to have further piled on pressure on the Shiv Sena to reject the National Population Register, which the Sena is in favour of implementing.A senior Congress minister told TOI that CAA, NRC and NPR may figure in the meeting between Thackeray and Sonia given the divide in the Maha Vikas Aghadi over the issues. Both Congress and NCP want the MVA to take the position adopted by non-BJP states, and state Congress chief Balasaheb Thorat reiterated on Thursday that his party would urge Thackeray to reconsider the Sena’s stand that NPR updation—set to begin in the state from May 1— was in the national interest.This will be Uddhav’s first meeting with Sonia after becoming CM. His son Aaditya had met her in Delhi to invite her for his swearing-in ceremony in November 2019, but she did not attend. Aaditya will accompany Uddhav on Friday as minister for tourism and protocol.Sena MP and parliamentary party leader Sanjay Raut tweeted that the meeting with the PM would be a “courtesy call,” though Uddhav and Modi had met at a police conference in Pune soon after the former was sworn in as CM. Raut stated, “There is no need to dig further, Jai Maharashtra .” However, sources said issues such as streamlining of payment of Maharashtra’s GST share and topics such as CAA-NRC-NPR may also be discussed.Sources said Thackeray may congratulate Modi for announcing formation of a trust to construct the Ram mandir in Ayodhya. Uddhav had been pushing for the temple as part of the NDA before BJP and Sena ended their alliance after the state poll results. Even after he became CM, Uddhav said he would visit Ayodhya on March 7.The Sena president had last year gone to Varanasi when PM Modi had filed his nomination papers for the April-May Lok Sabha elections, and Uddhav was in Gandhinagar as well to accompany then BJP chief Amit Shah for filing of his papers.In a recent interview to Sena mouthpiece Saamna, Uddhav had said, when asked if he would go to Delhi, “It is not mandatory to visit Delhi, but I do not hate Delhi. Whenever required, I will visit.”Asked if he would meet PM Modi and Sonia Gandhi, he had said, “Why I should not meet them? Will meet Modi, Soniaji, (LK) Advani.”A Sena leader said chief ministers have to maintain a good rapport with the Centre for funds to be released smoothly and on time and for coordination on various issues.On the even of Uddhav’s visit, NCP spokesperson and state minister Nawab Malik again spoke out against the NPR and said the MVA must examine the response of non-BJP states before taking a final stand on the matter. “Besides Congress-ruled Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Rajasthan, several other non-BJP states too have opposed NPR,” Malik said.

Title: Two women among seven Ernakulam natives dead
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Kochi: Angamaly town on Thursday was grieving for two youths hailing from the region, who lost their lives in the Avinashi accident, in which 19 were killed.

Jissmon Shaju, a 24-year-old B Tech student was traveling from Bengaluru to his home at Angamaly, when the accident tok place. Jissmon is the elder son of Shaju and Shiny of Thuravoor in Angamaly. He was enroute his home after visiting Bengaluru for job requirements when the incident happened.

Jissmon’s cousin said he had sent a WhatsApp message to him on Wednesday evening before boarding the bus.

“He had left on February 14. On Wednesday evening, he sent a message asking me if I had gone back to Australia, where I work. He had told me on WhatsApp that he would meet me on Thursday,” said Dinto Puthussery, Jissmon’s cousin, adding that the body was brought to Kochi on Thursday night.

Jissmon’s yonger brother is working in Mali and Dinto said that they were waiting for his arrival to fix the time for the cremation.

Emcy Mathew, 34, another Angamaly native was an IT professional based in Bengaluru. Emcy was the son of Sunny Mathew and Celin Sunny. Emcy’s wife Seethu works as a lecturer at Bharata Mata College in Kochi. They have a two-year-old son, Neel. Mathew has been working in the IT field for more than five years and it has been only four months since he had shifted to his new job in Bengaluru.

Apart from the deaths in Angamaly, Gopika Gokulanath, a 24-year-old software engineer who was working at Bengaluru, was also among the deceased. Gopika was on her way home to Tripunithura for holidays.

Gopika’s father, Gokulanatha Kaimal works at ESI Ernakulam Branch and her mother Varadha Devi, is the personal assistant to a judge at the high court. Relatives said that the body will be brought to Tripunithura Government Hospital by Thursday night and they are planning the cremation on Friday morning.

Sivasankar P, a 30-year-old professional, was travelling to his home at Thiruvaniyoor in Ernakulam for the Shivaratri holidays. He has been working in IT field for past few years. He is the son of Purushothaman and Usha purushothaman. He has a sister named Radhika.

In total, including Aiswarya and the two KSRTC employees, seven hailing from Ernakulam died in Thursday’s tragedy.

Title: Coimbatore KSRTC bus accident: Aiswarya Gopakumar got married last year
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Arrangements under way at Aiswarya Gopakumar’s house at Ponekkara

KOCHI: Two weeks before boarding the fateful bus as passenger number one on Wednesday, Aiswarya Gopakumar, a young professional working in Bengaluru, had celebrated her first wedding anniversary. Aiswarya’s parental home at Ponekkara in the city, where her wedding celebrations took place about a year ago, now has another tent and the relatives are grieving, awaiting the arrival of her body.

Aiswarya was a Learning and Development Consultant at Earnest & Young in Bengaluru while her husband Ashin Uday, is a software engineer in Bengaluru.

Her mother, Rajashree, a retired executive engineer with the KSEB, was at the house in the city on Thursday. She remained inconsolable though out the day. And why wouldn’t she? She may not even get a final glimpse of her beloved daughter whose body got shattered in the horrific accident at Avinashi. Her husband, Gopakumar and her son-in-law Ashin was at Avinashi for the procedures that was left to be done.

Aiswarya took an engineering degree at Adi Shankara Institute of Engineering Technolody at Kalady and went on to take an MBA from the Amrita School of Business in Bengaluru. Her schooling was at Bhavans Adarsha Vidyalaya, Kakkanad. “She was an exceptionally efficient persona and there were no problems that Achu, didn’t have a solution for,” recalls her uncle M Sreekumar. “Her mother dances well, she retired from the KSEB in January and the mother and daughter were dancing and singing at the send-off celebration. It is hard to believe, that a smart, young successful woman like her is no more,” said Sreekumar.

Aiswarya’s father is also an engineer, specialised in lift consultancy and her brother Aswin is a student. The family which has been long settled in a two-storied house, Saarang, at Ponekkara have their roots in Pathanamthitta .

Relatives said they are expecting the body to arrive at Kochi by night after which further plans would be made.

Title: K Chandrashekar Rao must respond on Aadhaar issue, says BJP
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Telangana chief minister K Chandrashekar Rao

HYDERABAD: BJP state unit on Thursday demanded chief minister K Chandrashekar Rao to respond and explain the UIDAI notification on Aadhaar fraud and irregularities noted in Telangana. In a statement issues to the mediam, BJP chief spokesman Krishna Sagar Rao said UIDAI recommending 400 Aadhaar cards for deactivation in Telangana is an indication that cards were obtained in fraudulent manner in the state.

“It is evident that for electoral appeasement of Muslim minorities, KCR has handed over reins of Old City to AIMIM and Owasi brothers. It is no wonder that Telangana is infamous for fraudulent procurement of Aadhar cards,” he said.

Title: Locals try to stall demolition drive for widening of road at Raoji Bazaar
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Indore: Continuing its removal drive at Raoji Bazaar area, Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) on Thursday demolished portions of five residential structures near Hathipala Bridge as they were coming in the way of an ongoing road widening project.

The corporation also razed three temporary sheds in the area. Two of these sheds were demolished by IMC earlier but locals were found to have made constructions again. A team of some 50 workers and officials from IMC’s removal wing reached the area at around 11.30am and started the removal action. As soon as the drive started, locals whose constructions were getting affected came out of their houses and started protesting.

The occupants including women also held demonstration alleging officials of causing extra damage on their constructions. “This action has caused additional damage to our constructions. Who is going to pay for it?” they said.

IMC’s removal wing in charge MS Chouhan said that the drive was meant to remove constructions that were posing as hurdles in road widening project.

“We had already issued notices to all occupants with instructions to cooperate. But when they failed to do it, we had to take action,” he said.

The corporation has proposed to increase width of this stretch up to 80ft as part of road widening project between Sarwate and Gangwal bus stand. Around 60 per cent of this stretch is being developed under Smart City project while the remaining will be done as civic project.

Civic body’s enforcement wing staff had to face strong opposition from locals of Kanadia Road during a drive against vehicles parked on roadsides.

Some locals also entered into a scuffle with IMC workers while protesting the action near a dairy shop of the area.

Title: City selected for pilot project of river mgmt plan
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Kanpur: Kanpur has been selected as a pilot project for Urban River Management Plan and exercises have already been started to execute the plan to keep the river banks pollution-free.

National Institute of Urban Affairs on Friday conducted a workshop at municipal corporation headquarter in which as many as 35 departments took part. Municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi along with other officials shared the plan. Team leader of National Institute of Urban Affairs Victor Shinde presented the project. He stated that the growing population was the cause of pollution on banks of the river.

The project would cover not only the Ganga but also its tributaries. Addressing the participants, Shinde said the main focus was on keeping the banks of river pollution free but efforts would also be made to earn through faith and belief.

Under this project, 97 cities situated on the bank of the river have been selected while Kanpur has been selected for the pilot project. All work for urban river management would be performed under the pilot project in the city, Shinde added.

Title: Luck sided with them
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

For them, it was the usual journey home. Their bus left Bengaluru at night and all of them were fast asleep when a container truck collided with their KSRTC bus near Avinashi around 3.30am. The truck’s container unit almost ripped out the right side of the bus even before the passengers could sense what was happening and it was over within seconds.

Sreelakshmi Menon (25) from Thrissur, who works as a manager at Flipkart in Bengaluru, said most passengers were fast asleep when the mishap occurred. “The bus left Bengaluru around 9pm. My seat was on the left side and I remember waking up on hearing a loud noise around 3.30am. I saw that some passengers, including kids, fall inside the bus and the road. For me, it was a miraculous escape,” she said.

“I managed to get out of the bus and saw that a major portion was destroyed on the other side. Visibility was low in the area. An ambulance reached the spot and we were shifted to nearby Revathi Medical Centre. After being kept under observation for some time in the hospital, I was allowed to go home,” she said.

Chirakkekkara Christo Francis (25) and his two colleagues escaped with minor injuries. Christo, who works at SFO Technologies in Kakkanad, injured his right leg. “Christo and his colleagues visited Bengaluru for official purpose. They were supposed to take a train home. But train was cancelled and they chose the bus. The trio were sleeping in the backseats when the accident happened. Christo’s leg injury is a minor fracture, he was taken to a private hospital for treatment. He is on his way home,” said Christo’s father Francis.

Another passenger Madhusoodhana Varma, who spoke over the phone from Deepa Hospital at Tirupur, is yet to overcome the shock. Varma, a techie settled in Bengaluru, was on his way to meet his father in Thrissur. Varma said he woke up on hearing a loud noise. He was sitting on the left side of the bus and his legs were stuck between seats and his right arm was fractured. Varma was stuck for 90 minutes, until rescue workers managed to get him out.

His cousin had reached the hospital in Tirupur on hearing about the accident. Varma, after treating his fractured hand and leg wounds, returned to Thrissur with his cousin in the afternoon in a car. He is planning to continue treatment at a private hospital in Thrissur and his family is expected to arrive here soon.

Design engineer Santhosh Kumar, who travels every week from Bengaluru to Palakkad, felt he was lucky to escape with minor injuries. “I have a cut on my lips and some bruises on my legs. The person beside me fractured his leg. Residents rushed to help us. I remember flames and fumes rising from the bus. Within a short time, fire and rescue personnel came to our rescue. I was taken to a hospital,” he said.

R Devi Durga was on her way to meet her husband. “I am still in shock and don’t remember anything but rescue teams helping us,” she said.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: HC nixes panel’s decision on donor, allows liver transplant
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

LUCKNOW: Considering a patient’s request in a transplant case, the high court on Wednesday allowed a man to donate his liver to a woman suffering from liver cirrhosis.

The petitioner had challenged the order passed by the State Authorization Committee of February 9, 2020, and an order passed by district authorization committee on December 23, 2019. These committees approve live organ transplants based on a number of factors and also help check illegal transplants motivated by commercial dealings.

These authorities had rejected the woman’s application saying the donor was not a close relative of the recipient and that there was disparity in their financial status. Satisfied that the consent for donation was bonafide, the court set aside reports of the authorities and directed doctors to take care of the donor during hospitalization and in recovery.

A bench of Justice MN Bhandari and Justice Manish Kumar passed the order on a writ petition moved by the woman patient.

Taking into consideration that the donor was known to the patient from childhood and frequently visited her house, the court called him in court and questioned him.

The court also noted that there was no evidence of any commercial dealing between the patient and the donor.

Title: In a month, Delhi to get pollution data even as you speak
Content:
Delhi environment minister Gopal Rai held an important meeting with officials related to the evironment depart... Read More

NEW DELHI: In a month, Delhi will start getting detailed reports on the composition and contribution of different sources of air pollution, Delhi’s environment minister Gopal Rai said on Thursday.The real-time source apportionment set-up, which has been installed by Delhi government in association with Washington University , is likely to be functional soon, and its first report will be presented by March, Rai said.Track the pollution level in your cityThe newly-appointed minister said he would be visiting the headquarters of Washington University in Delhi near Major Dhyanchand stadium on Friday to meet the scientists and understand how the data could be utilised. “We had a number of studies on source-apportionment carried out in the past, but these are old studies now. A lot has changed in Delhi since. Not only do we need to know the highest source of pollution, but also how this changes every few months,” said Rai.Meanwhile, DPCC officials said the project would be able to provide an accurate data on the contribution of each sector in both summer and winter, allowing them to act on the sources of pollution. “The real-time data is important to see the improvement in each sector. If the contribution from the transport sector will be high, we can aim at reducing congestion on roads. If it is from industries, our teams can specifically target them and check for clean fuel usage,” said a DPCC official.While the first report will be made available in March, DPCC officials said a decision was yet to be taken on how often the subsequent reports would be released. “We have organised several meetings over the past few months. After the final calibration, data will be available from April. It will also be provided to our teams for further action,” added the official.The real-time source apportionment will be done using analysers installed at one location initially. Particulate matter will be taken into consideration from 26 air quality monitoring stations. Real-time monitoring and sampling of PM1, 2.5 and 10 will be carried out in addition to the various aerosols and compounds, the official said. As part of the study, an algorithm is also being developed to help DPCC analyse long-term data, he added.In January 2019, the government had signed an MoU with the Washington University to determine real-time sources of pollution through the year. A long-term source apportionment study, however, may take 1-2 years to complete.

Title: Kanpur: Couple consumes poison on wedding eve after argument
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative Image

KANPUR: Two lovers, who were about to get married on Wednesday, allegedly attempted suicide by consuming poison, police said.

The man tried to end life on Tuesday after which the woman also consumed poison on Thursday evening.

Police said they were yet to ascertain why the couple took the extreme step.

They both are undergoing treatment at LLR hospital where their condition is stated to be critical.

Both of them were found unconscious in their respective houses.

According to police, the 23-year-old woman of Harsh Nagar locality, and 25-year-old man of Kamla Tower were having an affair. “The two came in contact through Facebook and developed an affair. Thereafter, they decided to get married and apprised their parents about their decision,” a police officer said.

Subsequently, the two got engaged in April last year. Later, when the youth and his family members allegedly demanded dowry, the girl’s family lodged an FIR against the youth and his family following which the marriage was called off. However, following intervention of elders from both the sides, the matter was solved and the two sides decided to solemnise the marriage in court on February 19.

“However, on Wednesday, it came to fore that the youth had attempted suicide by consuming poison in his house on Tuesday and was undergoing treatment at Lala Lajpat Rai hospital.

The girl went to meet him in the hospital on Thursday evening and consumed poison after returning home.

Inspector, Pheelkhana, Satish Chandra said prima facie it appeared that they had an argument before attempting suicide, but the exact reason would only be ascertained after they give their statement to police on regaining consciousness.

Further investigations are on in this connection, the inspector said.

Title: Kerala: Vigilance raids ex-minister VS Sivakumar’s residence
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vigilance officers conducting a raid at former health minister VS Sivakumar’s house in Thiruvananthapuram on T... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A team from special cell of the vigilance and anti-corruption bureau on Thursday conducted raids at the residence of former health and devaswom minister V S Sivakumar and his close associates in the capital. The action is in connection with the probe into allegations of amassment of disproportionate assets . The vigilance team conducted raids at the residence of Sivakumar and N S Harikumar who has been named the seventh accused in the first information report. The raids began at 8am.

The government had given sanction to the vigilance and anti-corruption bureau to register a case against Sivakumar and his close associates, on the basis of a preliminary inquiry conducted earlier. Following the government giving permission, the vigilance had registered a case against Sivakumar and three of his close associates –– M Rajendran, H Shyjuharan and N S Harikumar.

Even though the vigilance inquiry could not prove that Sivakumar amassed assets disproportionate to the known source of income during his tenure as health and devaswom minister in the former UDF ministry from May 18, 2011 to May 20, 2016, the assets of his three aides were found to have grown during the period. This, vigilance suspects, is because they acted as Sivakumar’s benamis.

Upon interrogating them, they could not give satisfactory explanations regarding the increase in wealth, the vigilance FIR said.

“The suspects 5 to 7 (the three other accused other than Sivakumar) had acquired huge assents disproportionate to their known sources of income. Since they are close associates of Sivakumar, it has to be rightly presumed that V S Sivakumar had acquired those assets possessed by them, as benami to him,” the FIR statement said.

The vigilance charged case against Sivakumar and others under Sections 13 (2) read with Section 13 (1) (d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, and Section 120 of IPC. As per Section 13 (2), any public servant who commits criminal misconduct shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which shall be not less than one year but which may extend to seven years and shall also be liable to fine. Section 13 (1) (d) says that a public servant is said to have committed criminal offence if he makes pecuniary advantage by corrupt means and by way of using his position while holding a public office. The FIR was submitted to the vigilance court here on Tuesday.

Title: Telangana Congress slams K Chandrasekhar Rao, Asaduddin Owaisi
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

HYDERABAD: TPCC senior leader and former minister Shabbir Ali on Thursday said that while Rohingya Muslims are being served notices by the Union government, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao and AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi are “fooling people of the state”.

Laxman said, KCR is just playing with Muslims by saying that he will provide 12% reservations, and Owaisi on the other hand is responsible for the cases against Muslim women in Old City.

Addressing a press conference at Gandhi Bhavan, he said that in Telangana, NPR is being implemented in the name of Census. “Chief minister KCR, after passing the resolution in the cabinet, said he will take a decision on CAA,” he said.

Title: NMC razes 45 unauthorised huts along Aurangabad Road
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nashik: The encroachment department of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Thursday razed 45 unauthorised huts along the Aurangabad Road in the Panchavati areas of the city.

There were 45 unauthorised huts that had come up near Nilgiri Bag area along the Aurangabad Road. Several notices were served to the occupants, but they did not budge. We razed these huts with police security, said NMC officials.

NMC has already started a series of anti-encroachment demolition drived in all the six divisions of the municipal corporation — Nashik East, Nashik West, Nashik Road, Panchavati, Satpur and Cidco — over the past few months after instructions from civic chief Radhakrishna Game.

The NMC has warned people, including hawkers and vegetable vendors, to refrain from encroaching footpaths, roads and squares in the city. It is an inconvenience for the pedestrians and motorists.

NMC has cautioned that it would continue to take action against encroachments along the city roads and footpath.

Title: Wading through sewage on Vaigai bank road a challenge for public
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Sewage water has been overflowing from manholes on the Vaigai river Bank Road in Alwarpuram for the last two d... Read More

MADURAI: Sewage water has been overflowing from manholes on the Vaigai river Bank Road in Alwarpuram for the last two days. As a result, commuters have been finding it very difficult to use the road as it is inundated with water. Residents said they have taken the issue to the notice of the Madurai corporation several times, but to no avail.

“The force of the flowing water is more during the day time, especially mornings, and apart from having to wade through it, we also get splashed by this stinky water when vehicles pass with speed on this road,” said Shenbagaraman a resident.

School children, who use the road, also suffer as they have slipped and fallen at times on the slimy road. “This seems to be a never-ending problem as we have a history of seeking solution for this same problem for many years, but we never get permanent relief,” said Abudahir of Sellur, who uses this road regularly.

The same problem persists in the Southern Bank Road also where the beautification works have been taken up by the corporation under the Smart City project. Even after the workers fix the manhole, water starts gushing out within two days of repair work, the residents said. Ismailpuram near the southern bank of Vaigai river has water overflowing from four manholes.

It is the stench that is really unbearable and the water has started running over a wide stretch and entering the river once again polluting it, said Pandian of Alwarpuram. “We also suspect that sewage from the government Rajaji hospital also overflows from this manhole, which is why it is so smelly,” said Thangaraj T, another resident.

Now, the corporation is constructing a sewage treatment plant near the Meenakshi Government Arts College and the residents said that the civic body should come forward to explain if it is going to help them.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said that a block at the other end of the underground drainage (UGD) system was the reason behind these manholes overflowing. “It is also due to overloading and I have asked my personnel to clean it and set it right,” he said.

Title: Kanpur: 7-yr-old boy loses two fingers as cracker explodes in his hand
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The injured boy

JHANSI: A seven-year-old boy sustained grievous injuries on both his hands and lost two fingers after a cracker bomb exploded in his hands in Barwar village area of Jhansi on Tuesday.

According to police, the boy found a bomb on the campus of government primary school where it was abandoned by revelers after a marriage function on Sunday.

On getting information, Mauranipur circle officer Pradeep Kumar and tehsildar Laxminarayan visited the injured boy’s house. The boy’s family has not filed any complaint yet.

According to police, a marriage function was organised at government primary school campus in violation of rules on Sunday where revelers exploded crackers.

On Tuesday, when the school reopened, Abhishek (7) of class 2, found a cracker bomb and brought it home.

While Abhishek was trying to adjust the bomb to burn it, it exploded causing serious injuries on his hands and legs. He lost two of his fingers in the incident.

Abhishek was admitted to a private hospital where he is still undergoing treatment.

Circle officer Pradeep Kumar said, “The matter came to our notice today (Thursday). We have ordered an internal enquiry. The victim’s parents have not lodged an FIR yet.”

Tehsildar Laxminarayan also went to the primary school to inquire as to how the school administration allowed a marriage function on its premises. He said he would submit his report to the district magistrate.

Title: To save Taj from pollution, UPMRC to revise construction plan
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Agra: To protect the Taj Mahal from pollution generated by construction, the Uttar Pradesh Metro Rail Corporation (UPMRC) is working on another action plan to start work on Agra Metro.

On Thursday, the Supreme Court asked the corporation to come up with a better plan to ensure lesser pollution near the heritage sites in Taj Trapezium Zone (TTZ) in Agra.

In its previous action plan submitted to the apex court, UPMRC had stated that apart from conducting regular water sprinkling near the construction site for settling dust particles, UPMRC will also cover the periphery with green net to ensure that dust does not get mixed with the environment. TNN

Title: MP govt to place anti-CAA resolution in assembly: Diggy
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bhopal: The Madhya Pradesh government will table a proposal against CAA, NRC and NPR and in the upcoming budget session of assembly, said Congress Rajya Sabha MP Digvijaya Singh said in Gwalior on Thursday.

Taking part in an anti-CAA protest, he said: “I had a talk with chief minister Kamal Nath about it and the proposal against CAA, NPR and NRC will come up in the assembly session for clearance. The Congress working committee opposes CAA, NPR and NRC nationwide. The MP cabinet has already passed a resolution against CAA. Now, it will be tabled in the assembly.”

Questions that were not part of NPR-2010 have been included in it now, Singh said. “Questions on the birthplace and birth date of parents figure on the NPR form now, and those who fail to provide these details will be considered as doubtful citizens,” the former CM said.

Replying to a question on notices being sent to people in Hyderabad for allegedly obtaining Aadhaar numbers on false documentation, Singh expressed the fear that Muslims will be “sent to detention centres in the future”. “This is going to affect India's 130-crore population. The NDA government has brought about CAA, NPR and NRC to divert people’s attention from the deteriorating economic condition,” he added.

Title: Jamia Millia Islamia to begin admissions, portal up for applications
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Jamia Millia Islamia

NEW DELHI: Amid protests and police investigation, Jamia Millia Islamia has announced admissions for the 2020-21 session, as vice-chancellor Najma Akhtar launched the admission web portal for receiving application forms on Thursday. The online forms for admission will be available from Friday and the last date will be March 25. The university has also released its prospectus.

Online admission forms are open for all undergraduate, postgraduate, PG diploma, advance diploma, diploma, MPhil/PhD programmes.

Admission test for Jamia will start from April 18 and the forms are available on the university’s website.

In their admission portal, the controller of examination Nazim Husain Jafri said that “admission and examination are the two faces of any university. It is our responsibility to keep both the processes efficient and transparent. The number of applicants to take admission is increasing exponentially every year. The new CBCS structure is opted by the university. These are welcoming signs and generate new challenges for the office of controller of examination. The university administration has started the automation of admission and examination system to meet these challenges and to provide better connectivity with students and teachers.” Those willing to apply can also call on the technical helpdesk from 10am to 6pm on the phone number provided on the website.

Title: Coimbatore KSRTC bus accident: Government to bear all expenses, say ministers
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Kerala ministers at Tiruppur hospital

KOCHI: The government machinery swung into action soon after the news of the bus accident was reported from Avinashi on Thursday. Two ministers were sent to the spot to coordinate government effort in Tamil Nadu while Palakkad SP and collector camped at Avinashi to assist the families of the deceased and the injured.

KSRTC declared Rs 10 lakh as emergency relief to those who died in the accident and government announced that it would take care of the medical expenses of those injured in the accident.

A press note issued said that KSRTC would give Rs 10 lakh each to the families of the deceased. Employees, who died in the accident, would get Rs 30 lakh as the insurance amount. This amount would be handed over soon, said transport minister A K Saseendran.

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan termed the accident a shocking incident. “The chief secretary-level coordination is being done between both states and if needed, a medical team will also be sent,” he said.

“Two MPS, one MLA have come here to coordinate relief activities. Transport minister would reach by evening. Our ambulances are ready. Some bodies are being transported using Tamil Nadu’s ambulances,” said minister for agriculture VS Sunilkumar, adding procedures like autopsy are expected to be completed by Thursday evening.

Health minister K K Shailaja said 20 ambulances were sent to Tamil Nadu. “As many as 10 Kaniv Ambulances and 10 other ambulances were sent. We are trying to bring the injured back to the state and treat them here,” she said.

Also, five more ambulances are kept ready at Palakkad and Thrissur. State police had released phone numbers (9497996977, 9497990090 and 9497962891) for relatives of passengers to contact Palakkad SP G Siva Vikram who was leading Kerala police team at Avinashi.

Title: Medical team to urge Kerala government for detailed study
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

MALAPPURAM: District administration of Malappuram has stepped in to find the medical reasons behind the deaths of six children of a family in a span of nine years at Tirur , in the backdrop of revelations that hereditary disease caused the infant deaths .

The district medical administration which has examined the medical documents regarding the babies who died during between 2011 and February 2020, has decided to demand the state government to appoint an expert medical team for a detailed study on the phenomenon. The medical administration received the forensic test results of the body samples of 3-month-old baby who died on Tuesday morning.

On Tuesday, Tirur police registered a suo motu case for the death of children, after residents raised suspicion over the death of six children, four girls and two boys, of Rafeeque and Sabna, natives of Chembra near Tirur. Police had exhumed the body of the 3-month-old baby who died on Tuesday morning and postmortem examination was conducted. But the preliminary postmortem reports had ruled out any ‘unnatural’ elements in the death of the baby. Later, doctors who treated the children, had raised doubts of genetic disorder sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) causing deaths of the children.

A senior official of medical department said that the district administration had collected details of each child’s death from the family earlier as part of data collection for infant deaths across the district. The administration has now examined them in detail once again in the backdrop of the latest incidents, including police probe into the death of the 3-month-old.

Title: Fisherman injured’ in Sri Lankan navy ‘firing’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

MADURAI: A fisherman from Rameswaram allegedly sustained an eye injury when the Sri Lankan navy attacked their fishing boat near the IMBL late on Wednesday. The fisherman, identified as Jesu Alangaram has been admitted to the Aravind Eye Hospitals in Madurai on Thursday.

President of the Rameswaram Fishermen ’s Co-operative, N Devadoss, said that about 500 mechanised boats had been fishing near the IMBL on Wednesday night, when a Sri Lankan naval vessel which came there started shooting indiscriminately at the boats with rubber pellets. One of the fibre boats was badly damaged and Alangaram, who was in one of the boats, sustained injury in the eye and cheek, when the splinters from the shattered glass in the boat hit him.

His fellow fishermen brought him back to the shore and he was first rushed to the Government Rajaji Hospital in Madurai, and later referred to the Aravind Eye Hospital. Sources from the hospital said the fisherman had suffered a corneal tear which was sutured and it was suspected that a foreign body may have entered his retina in the impact and it would be removed in a surgery soon. Devadoss said the incident is proof that the Sri Lankan navy was not going to stop antagonising the innocent fishermen. “Union minister of state for shipping, Mansukh Mandaviya had said the Indian fishermen were safe under BJP rule, but this incident proves otherwise,” he said.

Title: In 2019, MP saw highest no of ragging complaints in a decade
Content:
Representative Image

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh seems to have failed when it comes to tackling ragging on campus. According to the UGC anti-ragging helpline data, MP stood second in the country in ragging complaints filed in 2019. Uttar Pradesh tops the list. Also, in 2019 , the highest number of ragging complaints in the past one decade were registered in Madhya Pradesh.The data revealed that 132 ragging complaints were filed in MP in 2019. This is the highest number of complaints filed from MP ever since the UGC started the online complaint facility in 2009. UP topped the list with 152 complaints.Before this, 104 and 100 complaints were filed from MP in 2018 and 2017 respectively. In the past three years, ragging complaints have been on the rise. Only in 2012, MP had 32 ragging complaints, the lowest number of complaints. So far in 2020, MP has seen 10 ragging complaints filed in different colleges across the state.One more pattern the data revealed In MP was that male students registered more complaints than their female counterparts. In the past 10 years, 735 complaints were filed against boys while only 57 complaints were against girl students.Experts said that the time has come for the state to have its own legislation against ragging like other states have done. The neighbouring state of Maharashtra, where the number of ragging incidents had gone up in the late 90s, had introduced the Maharashtra Prohibition of Ragging Act 1999 to check the menace.Bhopal district court lawyer, Deepak Gour, said in the absence of legislation, there is no fear among the perpetrators. “There is no deterrence in this situation. It is tough to handle the situation in the absence of the state legislation,” said Gour. He added that there is a need to have a state legislation on ragging. “Ragging is rampant in colleges and there should be a state legislation,” he said.“Despite several incidents in the recent past, we are unable to register ragging cases,” said a cop, adding that the most severe punishment available in Madhya Pradesh for ragging is a mere suspension from the institute for a couple of days. A senior faculty said in this situation, the college also starts claiming that it was not ragging, but a fight among two groups of students.On the contrary, states where such anti-ragging laws are available have managed to tackle the situation.“A state like Andhra Pradesh has its own state anti-ragging law. It is called Andhra Pradesh Prohibition Act 1997. Last year, MP had witnessed 132 cases, while Andhra had seen only 29 cases. There is a need to have a state anti-ragging law,” said a senior faculty. Still, hardly any student from Madhya Pradesh was given strong punishment. In most cases, the accused either escaped unpunished or was awarded nominal monetary penalty and suspension from hostel.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Man, 47, in isolation ward at GRH
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A 47-year-old man from Sivaganga district, who returned from Singapore a week ago, has been admitted to the special isolation ward at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) on Wednesday evening. Though doctors and health department officials have said on Thursday that there is no cause for any worry, his sample has been sent for testing for COVID-19 The man was initially admitted to a private hospital in Madurai on February 18 with symptoms of respiratory illness. Soon after the hospital notified the health department about the man’s arrival from Singapore, he was shifted to the GRH on Wednesday evening. “He did not have fever, sore throat, running nose or any other symptom of upper respiratory tract infection. He was suffering from wheezing which usually indicates asthma,” said a senior doctor. Hospital staff said that he was admitted to the isolation ward as a precautionary measure.The doctor said the patient was treated mainly for dehydration and had minimal support for breathing. “He showed symptoms that were more like asthma exacerbation rather than viral infection. He has so far remained conscious. If his condition improves, we will remove him from non-invasive ventilation on Friday,” the doctor said. After initial diagnosis which pointed towards pneumonia or allergy, samples have been sent for testing for H1N1 and COVID-19.Meanwhile, a 28-year-old man from Virudhunagar district was treated at the isolation ward with symptoms of running nose and sneezing and a history of travel to China around 14 days ago. “He had no symptoms of COVID-19. His complaints were more of an allergic reaction. He had already completed his quarantine period. We alerted health officials to monitor him and sent him away,” said a doctor.District health officials have requested the public not to panic and asserted that all measures are in place. In Madurai, around 85 people are under home quarantine for COVID-19. So far, no person in Tamil Nadu has tested positive for COVID-19.

Title: KSRTC loses two model employees
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Kavitha, wife of VR Biju, who was killed in the road accident at Avinashi was inconsolable as his body was bro... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The death of KSRTC’s employees V D Gireesh and V R Baiju came as a shock to their friends and colleagues who considered them as role models. Ernakulam transport officer Thajudeen Sahib V M, who rushed to Avinashi, said nobody had complained against his two best men and not a single accident case was registered against them since they joined in 2008. He recalled how they had agreed to operate additional services to Bengaluru during a private bus strike last year as many passengers were stranded at bus depots in Kerala and Bengaluru.

KSRTC had feted them on June 26, 2018 for helping a passenger Dr Kavitha Warrier who had an epileptic seizure during a bus journey from Ernakulam to Bengaluru. The appreciation letter states how the driver Gireesh and helped Dr Kavitha by taking her to a private hospital in Hosur . Baiju, after seeking permission from higher officials, stayed back with her till her relatives reached the hospital, while Gireesh continued the bus service to Ernakulam. The appreciation letter was given by Tomin J Thachankary, who was then CMD of KSRTC. “The bus crew V R Baiju and V D Gireesh were lauded by media and passengers for their initiative to take the passenger to the hospital. I congratulate Gireesh and Baiju, whose timely act has brought laurels to KSRTC,” reads the letter from the CMD.

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan condoled their death. “They were the best employees of KSRTC and more than that they were role models. Their effort to provide treatment to the passenger shows their love towards people,” he said.

Title: NRI family from New Zealand performs ‘pind daan’ for pet dog in Gaya
Content:
The story of an NRI family from Purnia and their pet Labrador Liken shows just how special the bonding is.

PATNA: We’ve all heard the old saying that a dog is a man’s best friend. It may be a cliché for some, but for dog lovers their furry friends are a part of the family and their loss is as painful as that of a family member.The story of an NRI family from Purnia — now settled in New Zealand— and their pet Labrador Liken shows just how special the bonding is.Pramod Chauhan and his wife Rekha, both in their early fifties, flew into Patna with their daughter Vishnupriya from Auckland last week after their beloved pet died of cancer. They wanted to immerse the ashes of their beloved Liken in Ganga and perform the rituals, including ‘pinddaan’ in Gaya .The grief-stricken Chauhans, who belong to a landed family of Purnia, arrived in Patna on February 13.The next day they hired a boat to immerse the ashes in Ganga and left for Gaya on February 15 to perform the ‘pind daan’ rituals that, according to Hindu traditions, is done to appease the soul of the departed.Chauhan, who runs a flourishing business in Auckland and supports a voluntary organization that works with cancer patiens, is now at his ancestral house in Sipahi Tola in Madhubani Mohalla in Purnia where the family is preparing for a bhandara to be held in the memory of Liken on February 23.“Pramod came with his family covering a distance of 12,000km to perform the rituals for their pet. Liken was like a family member to them and was cremated in Auckland following Hindu rituals,” said his childhood friend Himkar Mishra.“The family had kept his ashes to be immersed in river Ganga. After reaching Patna, they hired a boat and with a priest went on the Sonepur side to immerse the ashes,” he added.Pramod told a TV channel, “Liken was brought up in a Hindu culture and participated in Hindu festivals with us. All our relatives will come for his Shraddha.”

Title: Hyderabad: Old City residents condemn UIDAI
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Old City residents on Thursday condemned Unique Identification Authority of India ( UIDAI ) notices questioning their citizenship and demanded it to rectify its flaws.

Locals complained that they face immense difficulties in getting their Aadhaar cards made or making corrections to existing ones.

“Lack of Adhaar card enrollment centers in Old City areas has become a matter of concern for the applicants. The residents in need to apply for new cards or update old ones have to leave home early and stand in long queues to get their tokens,” said a resident, Syed Ghulam Mahmood Hussain.

The UIDAI has served notices to some locals, stating that they had obtained their Aadhaar cards by submitting false documents.

However, residents claimed that UIDAI makes deliberate mistakes despite details being clearly mentioned in the enrolment forms..

“It seems like UIDAI is not serious about its work. Syed is being printed as Sayd although correct spelling is written in the form. Instead of D/O, S/O, W/ O being carried, C/O is being mentioned,” Mohammed Abdul Moin, a local, told TOI.

Title: 27-year-old man who murdered trader surrenders
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A 27-year-old man was arrested by the Kalugumalai police in Kovilpatti on Thursday for murdering a smalltime trader from Tenkasi district who warned him to end his relationship with a married woman.

The victim has been identified as A Alagurajan, 40, a small trader from Alangulam village in Tenkasi district. On Thursday, as usual for his business, when Alagurajan was returning to Alangulam from Kalugumalai in Kovilpatti, he was murdered by a man with a sickle. Kalugumalai police who reached the spot sent the body for autopsy to Kovilpatti Government Hospital.

Later, a man identified as P Mahendran confessed to the murder and surrendered before the police. He said he had killed Alagurajan “out of anger” for being against his relationship with a married woman from Alangulam. During the investigation, it came to light that Alagurajan and Mahendran had had an argument on tis a few days ago and had to be calmed by passers-by. The police said that they were also checking CCTV footage near the crime scene.

Meanwhile, angry kin of Alagurajan held a road roko at Kalugumalai Sanakarankovil Main Road demanding strict action against the accused. Despite talks with Tuticorin SP, Arun Balagopalan, Kovipatti DSP M Jebaraj and other officials, the protestors did not disperse. They also approached Tenkasi district collector GK Arun Sundar Dhayalan and submitted a plea. It was only on the collector’s assurance that they gave up their protest. Traffic was affected in the area for a few hours.

Title: Rs 2 lakh penalty on firm for irregular cleaning of Ganga ghats in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

A surprise inspection on Wednesday, civic officials said, revealed that the ghats were not being maintained pr... Read More

HARIDWAR: The Haridwar Municipal Corporation has imposed a Rs 2 lakh penalty on a firm, Akanksha Enterprises — mandated to clean the ghats along the Ganga — for doing an irregular job. According to municipal corporation officials, 72 ghats along the river were handed over to the company last year in February for maintenance at a cost of Rs 15 crore for three years under the Namami Gange programme.

A surprise inspection on Wednesday, civic officials said, revealed that the ghats were not being maintained properly. However, officials of Akanksha Enterprises refuted the charges and said that they have deployed people round-the-clock to clean the ghats. “The corporation may have found the ghats unclean during rush hours and imposed the penalty. But I want to reiterate that adequate staff has been deployed for regular cleanliness of the ghats,” said Anil Tripathi, an official of the company. He added that 385 workers had been deputed to maintain the ghats and cleaning work was being done throughout the day in three shifts.

Notwithstanding the organisation’s claims, several social activists had been time and again raising the issue of improper cleaning of Ganga ghats, claiming that cleaning of the ghats was being done only on paper.

Social activist JP Badoni told TOI, “Government is spending huge amounts of money to clean the Ganga banks but no work is being done on the ground. Anybody can visit any ghat and check the sanitation conditions. In fact, a serious inquiry should be done on all works under the Namami Gange project in Haridwar. First, Rs 60 crore was claimed to have been spent in planting 50 lakh saplings and now Rs 15 crore is being spent on cleaning ghats but the cleanliness has not been happening.”

In response to residents’ concerns, a surprise inspection was ordered on Wednesday by commissioner of Haridwar Municipal Corporation Narendra Singh Bhandari who said that severe irregularities were found in cleaning the ghats after which the Rs 2 lakh penalty was imposed. “Sanitation inspectors of all the areas have been asked to conduct inspection regularly,” he said. Bhandari also conducted an inspection of the doo-to-door garbage collection service in the city on Thursday and ordered it to be streamlined.

Meanwhile, social organisations in the town claimed that prominent ghats were actually being cleaned by private sanitation workers hired by them, and not by the company mandated to do the work. General secretary of Ganga Sabha, Tanmay Vashisht told TOI, “We have hired sanitation workers to clean the Har-ki-Pauri and Malviya ghat. We don’t know about the work that is supposedly being done by Akanksha Enterprises. If they have been mandated to clean 72 ghats, their work should be monitored and assessed by relevant authorities.”

Title: Bhopal: Corona scare fades Holi spirit
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Traders worry that people will be less inclined to buy Chinese goods because of the rumours

BHOPAL: The ongoing “boycott” of Chinese goods in the wake of coronavirus scare might hamper Holi market adversely, worry vendors. Traders say that rumormongering and fake news on social media are hurting the consumer sentiment and scaring away people from markets with Chinese goods.

There were initial reports of stock shortage, but wholesalers say that they are ready for the festival of colours as they start stocking two-three months ago. Every year, fancy products like pichkari, water guns, magic balloons, masks and colour capsules come to India from China for the Holi season. Traders worry that people will be less inclined to buy Chinese goods because of the rumours.

“Chinese products are quite attractive and usually children make their parents buy them the products. They account for a good portion of our income…we already have stocks of Chinese waterguns and there is a slight worry in the market that they won’t sell this year,” said Manoj Kumar, a retailer in New Market. Bhopal gets most of its Holi paraphernalia from Indore and the remaining from Mumbai and New Delhi, said wholesaler Ashish Jain.

Nandu Bhai, a trader of water guns in Ranipura market, a leading wholesale market of Indore said, “China is not accepting any fresh order and the pace of goods committed to be dispatched in coming weeks has also slowed down.”

Traders say that Chinese factory manufacturing plastic products shut down during New Year which is why the Holi products are usually shipped earlier — way before the outbreak of the disease. In addition, there has been no new consignment from China for over a month.

But wholesale suppliers say there is little to worry about as they start stocking for festivals two-three months in advance. The stocks for Holi should not be a problem, but traders have no way to replenish their stocks as there will be no fresh stocks from China for the next few months, say wholesalers.

All Holi products are already in Indian warehouses a month ahead of the festival. Businessman Anand Taran said, “There will be no change in the market this year. Coronavirus will not affect business in Bhopal.”

The only problem is that there is a disagreeable sentiment towards China-made products at the moment, which might affect prices, said Jain.

Hoax messages have been circulating on social media, but experts say that these fears are unwarranted. Experts say, that no virus can survive so long inside a packet of Holi toys during the entire shipping process. Talking to TOI, Dr Saurabh Atulya said, “The rumours that Chinese goods are affected are baseless … There is no question of the virus being transmitted through Chinese goods like pichkaris, and even if it were a possibility, the climate of China and India is very different, and it is not possible for the virus to survive without a host. People should think rationally at this time.”

Title: Curtains for IPS meet after an evening of dance, music & masti
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bhopal: The two-day IPS meet concluded with individual and group cultural performances at the Police Officers Mess on Thursday.

IPS officers from different districts showcased their talents and won additional points for their four zones — Mahakaushal zone, Chambal zone, Bhopal zone and Malwa zone. From performing contemporary to semi classical and zumba dances, the IPS officers left no stone unturned to put their best foot forward. Many officers also recited poems and sang songs at the meet and received a lot of applause.

DIG Shahdol Range, Pritam Uikey and Dr Mohan Rao sang old Bollywood songs that made the officers nostalgic. DIG (Indore Rural) Sushant Saxena recited Harivansh Rai Bachchan’s poem ‘Madhushala’. SSP Indore Ruchi Vardhan and Darshita Shrivastav won the hearts of the audience with their melodies.

“It was a great event. We all were overwhelmed to see such a lot of talent in the officers as well as among the children of the IPS officers who just stole our hearts. The energy and vibe of the place was so positive that we were filled with a new energy to get back to duty”, said IPS officer and secretary of the IPS Association Simala Prasad.

Semi classical dance on Afreen Afreen by Divyashri Sagar and solo dance performance by Radhika Tiwari, daughter of IPS Shradha Tiwari and Dia Iqbal, daughter of IPS Riyaz Iqbal were loved by the audience.

Zumba dance performance by Tanmay Rao, Nidhi Singh and contemporary dance by Madhur and Ojas Shayawar filled the audience with enthusiasm.

After the individual performances, teams of the four zones also participated in group performances, winning points for their zones.

Title: Four youths arrested for tourist guide’s murder in Udaipur
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Udaipur: In a major breakthrough, Udaipur police has arrested four youths for murdering a 30-year-old tourist guide.

Anurag Patwa alias Janu worked as a tourist guide in Delhi while his family resided in Udaipur.

On Wednesday morning, his body was found at a secluded spot on Kodiyat road under Nai police station area.

Police could not identify the body since the killers had taken away his mobile, purse and other belongings.

Later, when his picture was posted on social media, the body was identified by some of his acquaintances and the family was informed.

“The deceased’s father told us that Janu came to Udaipur two days ago. On Tuesday night, he was sitting inside his car till late night and listening music. Thereafter, he went missing. The family also told us that Janu had been threatened by some persons in connection with a loan taken long ago,” additional SP Anant Kumar told reporters.

Police interrogated all the suspects, however, none was found to be involved in the crime.

A special team lead by dySP Prem Dhande, Girva Circle, Nai SHO Mukesh Soni, Surajpole SHO Ram Sumer was constituted who rounded up the all history-sheeters in the city.

During interrogation, one Alfez Mohammed (20), resident of Malla Talai area, confessed to the killing along with his friends Soyal (19) and Pratap Bhati (19), both residents of Ambamata, and Gaurav Jeengar (20) from Nai area.

“The accused said they were addicted to drugs and had planned to loot someone on Kodiyat road. They were wandering in the area when they spotted Janu inside his car. One of them went up to him and asked for a cigarette, meanwhile, others stabbed him several times in the chest and neck,” the ASP said.

The accused shifted the body to the back seat and drove to the secluded area where they dumped the body and escaped with all his belongings and the car.

Title: Vaiko expresses solidarity with anti-CAA protesters in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

MDMK leader Vaiko addresses a protest against CAA at Mahaboopalayam in Madurai (PTI Photo)

MADURAI: MDMK general secretary Vaiko on Thursday met members of the Muslim community protesting against the CAA and NRC in Mehaboopalayam in Madurai and expressed solidarity with them.

Speaking at the venue, Vaiko said the Muslim community members, including the women had set an example on how to protest peacefully. “You have made Mahatma Gandhi’s dream come true through this peaceful protest. The CAA has come to destroy the nation,” he said. It is an Act that has to be defeated, he added.

BJP leaders Narendra Modi and Amit Shah are trying to deprive the rights of the Muslims through these acts. Vaiko lauded the women, most of whom never came out on the roads to protest, for continuing their protest for the seventh day in succession. “We should continue till the Act is withdrawn,” he added. Earlier, speaking at a marriage function in Madurai, he said that the DMK had obtained two crore signatures against the Act and submitted it to the President of India. The people’s anger against the BJP is intensifying and it will go against them, he said.

Title: MKU-SBI smart card enables students to mark attendance, withdraw money
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU) and State Bank of India (SBI) on Thursday launched a multi-purpose identity card which will enable students to get access to various department buildings, mark attendance and be used as a regular debit card.

“Ever since noticing that many rural families are still far from digitalisation, I wanted to introduce this card at our university which mainly caters to students in rural and remote areas. This card has been issued free of cost to the students. We would also be able to collect and document data of students and the university’s activities more easily,” said MKU vice-chancellor Dr M Krishnan . The university is currently in the process of achieving complete automation of its academic and administrative activities. It had recently introduced MKU-Mobile app / Web app as a platform for digital learning management system.

The MKU VC and the deputy managing director, SBI, J Swaminathan, launched the smart combo ID card and distributed it to students. About 1,500 PG students will first be making use of the cards. An MoU was signed for five years between the university and the bank to implement the project with SBI investing a total of Rs 20 lakh initially. “We are trying to promote electronic system of recording and reduce cash. We don’t see it as expenditure but rather an investment whenever we are working with educational institutions,” Swaminathan told the students. MKU is the fourth educational institution in the country to collaborate with SBI for issuing such combo cards.

MKU students availing of the card will get a zero balance savings bank account in SBI, MKU Branch . The card will then be issued free and the annual maintenance charge will also be waived until the students complete their course at MKU. The card will have a magnetic strip and EMV chip and can be used like a normal SBI ATM card. It will also have an additional chip for access control with multiple functions. The card will have the photograph of the student, university registration number, the programme and duration of the study. The smart combo ID card will operate as access card through which the student can attend class, use library, enter hostel premises and use common facilities like auditorium, language lab, various science labs, etc. When the students finish their course, the card can still be used as an ATM card but the data would be stored as alumni data.

Title: High court cracks whip on medical college for not refunding extra fee of Rs 80 crore to 1,ooo students
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Uttrakhand high court

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Thursday ordered the principal of Dehradun-based Himalayan Ayurvedic Medical College , Anil Kumar Jha, to be personally present in court and explain why contempt proceedings should not be initiated against him.

The Bench of Justice Sharad Kumar Sharma was hearing the contempt petition against the college filed by several students after the college failed to return the increased fee it had charged from students after a Government Order (GO) increased the fee from Rs 80,000 to over Rs 2.15 lakh.

The fee was increased retrospectively and even the students who were studying in senior years were made to pay the increased fee. “The state government, through a GO had in October 2015 increased the fee of Bachelor of Ayurvedic Medical Sciences (BAMS) by almost Rs 1.4 lakh. The fee was increased retrospectively. However, after a petition was filed, the court quashed the GO and ordered all the colleges to return the extra fee that had been charged from the students,” said Vinod Tiwari, the counsellor appearing for the students who have approached the court.

Tiwari added that despite the court’s order, several colleges did not comply and in fact filed a special appeal before the division bench. “That appeal was also dismissed by the court and they were again ordered to return the fee. However, as the colleges did not return the amount again, students approached the court and filed a contempt petition against the college,” he said.

“The court has now ordered the principal to be personally present in the court on March 2 and explain why contempt proceedings should not be initiated against him under the Contempt of Courts Act,” Tiwari said, adding that around 1,000 students are to be issued refund amounting to around Rs 80 crore from 13 colleges in the state that provide the course.

As reported by TOI earlier, several colleges had charged the increased amount, however, even after around two years since the HC order many students are still awaiting refund.

Meanwhile, Bal Krishna Chamoli, secretary of Himalayan Ayurvedic Medical College, said that the college has complied with court orders earlier and will follow whatever directions the court gives even now. “However, the thing that has to be kept in mind is that the fee for BAMS courses have not been hiked since 2004 even though the input costs have increased many a times. The cap on fee is stressing on our financial situation,” Chamoli said.

Title: Blasting for Mumbai coastal road near Nepean Sea Road alarms locals
Content:
Tunnelling work is expected to begin once the boring machine arrives from China

MUMBAI: Several residents of Nepean Sea Road were taken aback this past week on hearing a thumping sound emanate from the Mumbai coastal road work site.Worried, they made inquiries with the local site supervisor and found the contractor was undertaking tests for controlled blasting of rocks to make space for a launching shaft.Gita Mirchandani, chairperson of Napean Sea Road Citizens Forum, said, “There are a lot of old buildings in the area and with such kind of blasting work being carried out, we got worried our walls might develop cracks. We spoke to the contractor to know what studies were conducted and precautions taken to ensure there is no untoward incident,” she said.On Thursday, the official Twitter handle of the forum read: “EXPLOSIVES WARNING. We have been informed by L&T, that it intends to carry out rock blasting using explosives.@mybmcCoastalRd @NepeanSeaRoad site, between 1 pm and 2 pm today. Kindly spread the word to fellow residents to not be alarmed during he blasting activity. If you notice any structural cracks/defects or experience vibration caused during or after the blasting, keep calm and reach out to the MCGM helpline 1916 and also @mybmcWardD.”Tunnelling work is expected to begin once the boring machine arrives from China. The BMC needs to ensure the launching shaft is ready beforei it arrives.Mukul Mehra, secretary of Nepean Sea Road Citizens Forum, said they should have been informed of the plan. “We do not know how long the blasting will continue.”Susieben Shah, general secretary of Malabar Hill Citizens’ Forum, said there are not just old buildings but also senior citizens in the area.BMC officials said they secured all permissions from the collector and police authorities. “All precautions will be taken at the launching shaft site near Priyadarshani Park and near Chota Chowpathy at the retrieval site. Residents don’t need to worry,” said an official.When contacted, a spokesperson for L&T, which had undertaken the work at the site, refused to comment.

Title: Rajasthan: Woman’s half-burnt body found in Amber
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Partially burnt body of a woman was found in Langadiyawas of Amber area on Thursday. The police are yet to ascertain the woman’s identity.

The police suspect that after murdering the woman, the unidentified persons dumped the body on Amber-Langadiyawas Road. “Prima facie, it appears to be a case of murder. However, anything concrete could be said only after the body is identified. We have sent the photographs of the charred body to the nearby police stations and are also checking the missing report registers across the state for identification,” said a senior police officer of Amber police station.

Control room and other police stations have also been intimated for any information on the woman. “As the body is charred and was put in a sack, it appears that the miscreants wanted to conceal her identity, in order to go scot-free. However, we will identify the body to solve the mystery,” the officer added.

From the appearance of the body, it seems that the deceased woman may have been aged between 30 and 35 years.

A black thread has been found tied on her ankle. The police have also found an amulet.

The police are quizzing people in the nearby areas like shopkeepers, tea shop owners and pan wallahs to find any clue. Also, they are scouring CCTVs, which could provide them some clue about the identity of the woman.

Title: Trichy: Man on all-India bicycle tour to raise awareness on hygiene
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Luis Das who hails from Morigaon district in Assam is employed as a helper in an ashram in Haridwar

TRICHY: A 29-year-old cyclist from Assam on a pan-India mission to spread awareness on public hygiene reached Trichy on Thursday. Sensitising people to dump their waste only in dustbins, the man has so far covered 18 states and Union territories on his bicycle with the support of people he never knew.

Luis Das who hails from Morigaon district in Assam is employed as a helper in an ashram in Haridwar. He says his journey is inspired by the Swachh Bharat mission envisaged at keeping India clean and litter-free. He wanted to contribute his mite to the mission and hence embarked on ‘Bharat Yatra’ on his mountain bicycle on October 30 last year from Haridwar, Uttarakhand. Passing through 18 states and union territories including Sikkim, Assam, West Bengal, Bihar, Jharkhand and Odisha, Das reached Chennai last week from where he cycled to Trichy via Puducherry. “During my nationwide trip, I have been sensitising school students on disposing waste only in bins. Absence of public hygiene is the major cause of diseases,” Das told TOI. He also spoke about the importance of using toilets. In Trichy where public garbage bins were removed as a part of Swachh Bharat Mission (SBM) guidelines, Das told the public to dump waste where bins are available, or else in the bins available at houses.

The bicycle is fitted with boards promoting awareness on cleanliness and speakers for spreading messages on cleanliness. Das managed to purchase the bicycle worth Rs 9,000 with his money, but now relies completely on strangers for money, food and even to charge his mobile phone for GPS needs during his journey. “I spend nights at petrol bunks, eateries, temples and hospital campuses — wherever they permit and I feel safe. Having made friends in all the states I visited, I will use the contacts constructively to promote cleanliness,” Das added. With Kochi in Kerala as his next pit stop, Das plans to cover all the states and Union territories with his awareness messages in the next three months.
