Title: For clarity, NHRC asks govt to define ‘human rights offences’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: The national human rights commission and its autonomous counterparts in states have unanimously demanded that the government should define “human rights offences” in the NHRC legislation in order to give the commission greater clarity and teeth. They also dwelt on the need for clarity in the scope of offences being tried at the human rights courts established in the country.

Addressing issues that pertain to the running of NHRCs and SHRCs during a day-long meeting convened by NHRC, chairs and members of the rights commission stressed on the need for clarity on the nature of offences that can be tried and the procedure to be followed to try such offences.

While members acknowledged that the Supreme Court may fill the lacuna by making guidelines to ensure that human rights courts are guided on which cases to try and how, in the absence of the judgement, they called for the need for clarity.

On Thursday, NHRC chairman Justice H L Dattu also asked all state human rights commissions to join its common portal to avoid duplication of complaint registration. Dattu said that in order to expand its outreach, the commission had integrated its online complaint filing system with common service portal of the centre and was encouraging SHRCs to join the HRCNET portal.

“Most of the state commissions have joined this portal. I take this opportunity to urge state commissions which are yet to join the portal to do the same at the earliest to avoid duplication of complaint registration on the same issue,” he said.

According to another NHRC official, 22 states have joined the portal so far.

On Thursday, the members in attendance also said NHRC will recommend to the home ministry to consider amendments to the NHRC Act to clarify the issues raised by the rights commissions through their discussions.

Title: Police file FIR to probe acid attack on stray dog in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Police registered an FIR for mischief by killing or maiming animals (429 IPC) and Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to probe a case of acid attack on a dog in Paharganj.

In an incident that occurred earlier this month, a woman resident of Mantola lodged a complaint after a man in the locality allegedly poured acid on a street dog. An animal rights activist from the area, too, submitted a complaint against the man who had allegedly threatened to maim the rest of the strays dogs if they barked at him.

On February 7, the complainant heard the wails of a dog outside her house and found the animal with severe burns on its face and back. She and other residents then got the canine treated.

“This was not the first time that a dog had been attacked in the locality,” said Megha Arora, an activist and a resident of the area. The residents decided to register a complaint against the suspect at Pahargunj police station.

“We told police that many other dogs had suffered injuries after being hit by nails sticking out of wooden planks or by acid-like substances,” she said. Arora said that so far no one had been arrested in this case.

“We are probing the role of a person who has been identified as a suspect and will take appropriate action,” an officer said.

Title: Mussoorie Dehradun Development Authority holds its 98th board meeting
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

DEHRADUN: The Mussoorie Dehradun Development Authority (MDDA) held its 98th board meeting at the MDDA office in Dehradun on Thursday. The meeting was chaired by MDDA chairman Ravinath Raman and was attended by various other officials including MDDA V-C and incumbent Dehradun district magistrate Ashish Shrivastava.

In order to help out the people from the lower-income groups to achieve their dream of buying a flat, the MDDA has decided to come up with a scheme in which people can avail of LIG flats at Transport Nagar Phase 2 by paying easy EMIs over a period of 15 years.

The agency has also decided to invite architects to submit their designs for making the facades of government buildings as per traditional architecture of Uttarakhand.

A proposal to grant cash prizes of best design was also passed. The best design would be given Rs 1 lakh, second Rs 75,000 and third Rs 50,000, a communique from MDDA said.

An official of the agency said that decisions were alsotaken pertaining to Rishikesh as the registry of land in Rishikesh comes under the MDDA as well.

A total of 43 points came up for discussion during the meeting in which decisions were taken, the official added.

Title: Oil companies must spell out duration of ongoing exploration: Farmers
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Farmers have raised apprehensions about the duration of the ongoing hydrocarbon exploration projects

TRICHY: Delta farmers have raised apprehensions about the duration of the ongoing hydrocarbon exploration projects even while hailing chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami for introducing the Protected Agriculture Zone Development Bill 2020 in the assembly on Thursday.

When ongoing projects have already made the entire agriculture land in the delta region unproductive, allowing companies more years to explore would only harm the very purpose of announcing the districts as protected zone, they opined. Cauvery Delta Farmers Association president Cauvery S Dhanapalan said the farmers’ prime demand was to close down existing oil wells dug by ONGC in the delta region. But chief minister has announced that the ongoing processes would continue, thereby creating confusion and apprehensions among the farmers. “State government should ask oil companies to declare how long they would take to complete the ongoing extraction. Otherwise, they may continue the process for years stating that the contract period is not over”, he opined.

If the existing exploration projects continued and newly announced ones would not be revoked, what is the purpose of announcing the delta as protected zone, asked the secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association, Swamimalai S Vimalnathan. “Already oil companies have damaged our entire resources. Now the state government has given them more time to exploit it further”, he said. Coordinator of Cauvery Rights Retrieval Committee P Maniarasan wondered what was the urgency in passing the bill on a single day without holding discussions. “The bill should have been referred to select committee for further clarification and to get a proper shape so that it would not be struck down by courts”, he stressed.

State secretary of Tamil Nadu Vivasayigal Sangam P S Masilamani sid in Tiruvarur that the bill has been passed in a hasty manner without examining how to strengthen it, just for political mileage. President of All Farmers Associations’ Coordination Committee P R Pandian urged opposition parties to support the state government’s efforts to get the bill included in the Union government’s gazette and for getting the Presidential assent.

“The state government should insist that the Union government give up the recently announced hydrocarbon projects. Besides ONGC, new contracts handed over to Reliance and Vedanta should also be withdrawn”, he added.

Title: ‘Make it mandatory for each student to plant 10 trees in order to pass final exam’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Licypriya Kangujam, at 8 years, is one of the youngest environmental activists in the country.

Title: PG ayurveda student hangs self in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Jaipur: A 26-year-old woman pursuing post-graduation in ayurveda ended her life by hanging from the ceiling fan at Govind Nagarpur locality under Brahmpuri police station area on Thursday.

The matter came to light when friends of the deceased informed police on not getting any response from her.

Rekha Karir’s friends were trying to reach her on phone on Thursday afternoon, but got no response.

“Her friends were trying to contact her. When they failed to get any response, expecting the worst they visited her house. Her room was locked from inside, thus, they intimated the police,” said a senior police officer of Brahmpuri.

A team of police officers rushed to the spot to take stock of the situation at 1.30pm on Thursday. “It was a rented room and was locked from inside. After the door was unlocked, the woman was found hanging from the ceiling fan,” the officer added.

Rekha hails from Indoka village near Makrana in Nagaur district.

“Her relatives arrived in the city in the evening. The reason why the woman committed suicide is yet to be ascertained as no suicide note was recovered from the spot. We will also have a word with the family members and friends to know the cause of death, if any,” the officer added.

Title: Drug department bans sale of Cold Best PC syrup
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: The state drug department has banned the purchase, sale and distribution of Cold Best PC syrup manufactured by a Himachal Pradesh-based pharmaceuticals company, which has allegedly caused infant mortality in the state of Haryana.

Talking to TOI, Tajber Singh, drug controller, Uttarakhand said that the state drug department has received a notification from Drugs Controller General of India, New Delhi (DCGI) which maintained that the cough syrup has claimed the lives of infants in Haryana last in the past several weeks.

“As per DCGI’s letter, the Cold Best PC syrup contains diethylene glycol which the doctors at Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research (PGIMER), Chandigarh believe to be the reason of the deaths of infants in Haryana. This syrup is manufactured by M/s Digital Vision, a pharmaceutical company based in Sirmaur district in Himachal Pradesh,” he added. The drug department of Uttarakhand has already initiated to check the sale and consumption of Cold Best PC syrup. An advisory has been issued to all the doctors, medical store owners and to the concerned departments to check the sale of the drug to avoid any further fatalities.

“Locals are also requested to alert the health and drug department in case they come to know about the sale or consumption of the drug,” added Singh.

Title: Promotion in jobs: Thousands of government staff members hit streets in Dehradun
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The protesters also had a altercation with police teams as the route of their proposed march was changed at th... Read More

DEHRADUN: Thousands of government employees under the umbrella of General-OBC Employees’ Federation staged a march from Parade Ground towards the chief minister’s residence on Thursday. The protesters also had a heated altercation with police teams as the route of their proposed march was changed at the last minute.

The government employees are demanding lifting of ban on departmental promotion saying that even the Supreme Court (SC) has taken a decision in their favour and the government should now implement the SC decision.

As per the initial plan, the march was to move from Darshanlal Chowk to Clock Tower and thereafter move towards the CM’s residence. However, the protesters were directed towards the Astley Hall crossing, which led to a scuffle between the employees and the police team. The police team deployed near the Hathibarkala barricade stopped the protesters. The employees thereafter sat on the ground and raised slogans against the state government.

This was the second major protest in a short span of a week, the first being on February 14. The employees have threatened to go on an indefinite work boycott if their demands are not met.

“We are ready for a do-or-die battle. The employees should not be deprived of their rights. Several employees have retired without getting promotion and with even the Supreme Court order now, there is no reason why the ban on departmental promotion committee meeting is continuing. It should be lifted to pave way for promotion of employees,” Deepak Joshi, who heads the association of secretariat employees and is also the chairperson of Uttarakhand General-OBC Employees Association, said.

He added, “Despite the Supreme Court order on the issue of reservation in promotion on February 7 this year, the state government has not yet revoked its order of September 11, 2019, through which it had stopped promotion in government jobs.”

Virendra Singh Gosain, the general secretary of Uttarakhand General-OBC Employees Association, said that the state government needs to stick to the new reservation roster in government jobs. “We are against any sort of change in the roster,” he added.

Meanwhile, CM Trivendra Rawat when queried about the issue on Thursday, said that talks will be held with those who are protesting. “We will find out a solution by holding talks,” he added.

Title: Mum man uses crowdfunding to help Nain Singh Rawat’s descendants
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Dehradun: A Mumbai-based man hailing from Uttarakhand has launched a crowdfunding campaign to collect money for paying back outstanding bank loan of the family of legendary surveyor Nain Singh Rawat , who worked in Survey of India during the British era in Dehradun, and who is believed to have determined for the first time the location and altitude of Tibet’s capital Lhasa, and surveyed a large section of the Brahmaputra.

Speaking with TOI over the phone, Prayag Rawat, who hails from the same area in Kumaon as Nain Singh, said that he came to know about the financial crisis faced by the famous surveyor’s descendants, and decided to chip in. “It was very disheartening to know that one of Nain Singhji’s descendants, Kavindra Singh Rawat died in a road accident in August last year and the family is struggling to pay back a loan of Rs 19 lakh,” he told TOI, adding that when he came to know of Kavindra’s death, he contacted the family to find out how he can help. “I came to know that the family has to pay Rs 9 lakh as the final settlement amount for the loan taken by Kavindra Singh Rawat in 2015. The family lives in Madot village in the Pithoragarh district. Kavindra used to run a taxi and after his death, there is no one to look after the family.”

Rawat said that he decided to start a crowdfunding campaigning to help them and so far, has collected Rs 2 lakh from people in Mumbai. “Since my childhood, I had a great fascination for the work of Nain Singh Rawat. I am happy that people have been so forthcoming to help the family financially.” Meanwhile, speaking to TOI, Kavindra Singh Rawat’s wife Kamla, said, “Prayagji’s offer to help has come as a big boon to us since we have been struggling to make ends meet after my husband’s death.”

Title: Maharashtra: Power consumption hits record high on rising heat
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose

PUNE: The Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited met the record power demand of 21,570 MW on Wednesday, with rising temperature and increased consumption in the agriculture sector being the primary triggers.A statement issued by the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL) stated that the previous highest demand for electricity was recorded in the state on October 23, 2018, when the company had supplied 20,745 MW power. The demand recorded on Wednesday was 3,320 MW or 18% more than the maximum demand recorded in February last year, the statement said.It said the merit order dispatch mandated that last preference should be given to buying costly power. “The distribution company did not opt for around 2,350 MW costly power from Ratan India (1,080 MW), Mahagenco (630 MW) and NTPC, Solapur (640 MW), but still met the high demand, “ the statement added.The distribution company said it was anticipating higher demand in March and April months and had already made arrangements to this effect.As for the rising mercury, the maximum temperature at Shivajinagar rose to 34.5°C on Thursday.

Title: Govt submits status report of Viveka murder case to HC
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The state government on Thursday submitted the status report of the investigation into the YS Vivekananda Reddy murder case by the special investigation team ( SIT ) to the high court in a sealed cover. Advocate general S Sriram told the high court that the petitioners did not satisfy the tests laid down by the Supreme Court guidelines to transfer the investigation of the case to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI).

Sriram further argued that the petitioners are making allegations against each other. While Adinarayana Reddy said Prasad is continuing as the family’s driver, Vivekananda Reddy’s wife Sowbhagyamma and daughter Sunitha named Adinarayana Reddy and B Tech Ravi. This indicates that the police are doing a neutral job, he argued.

The advocate general further said that the SIT has examined 1,461 suspects, seven gangs, 31 high-profile offenders and gangs of hired assassins. Due to the fact that there was screening of evidence, the police have had to rely on forensic evidence, Narco and brain mapping. He said a few applications for Narco tests were rejected.

Justifying the stand of the state government not to hand over the case to the CBI, the advocate general said the subjective anxiety and self-serving pleas of the petitioners cannot be enough to lay a basis for disbelieving the state police. He said the high court is not the place for mini trial of the case which is what the petitioners want in contrary to the jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Indian Constitution. Vague pleadings and unsubstantiated contentions cannot form the basis of a writ petition to transfer the case to CBI, he argued.

As the investigation is at an advanced stage and likely to conclude in the next two months, there is no need for a CBI probe at this stage, said the advocate general. After hearing his arguments, the high court directed him to submit the case dairies and general dairies of the case and posted the matter for further hearing to Monday.

Title: Fraudsters dupe woman of Rs 87k with lottery bait
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pune: A 35-year-old homemaker from Khadki lost Rs87,000 to unidentified telecallers, who claimed to be representatives of “Kaun Banega Crorepati” and told her to pay the money towards GST and income tax for redeeming a Rs25 lakh “KBC” lottery she had won.

The Yerawada police on Wednesday lodged an FIR in this connection after their cybercrime counterparts did the initial verification of the woman’s complaint application regarding the incident that occurred on October 7, 2019. Inspector Ajay Waghmare of the Yerawada police told TOI that the woman worked as a domestic help in housing societies, while her husband worked as a gardener in these societies after leaving his job with a private company.

In her statement with the police, the woman said she received four calls between 9am and 2pm on October 7, 2019 from telecallers who claimed to be “KBC” representatives. In the first call, the caller told her that she had won a Rs25 lakh “KBC lottery” and that she should check her WhatsApp account. On checking her WhatsApp account, she found the ticket and consulted her husband.

Around 12 noon, she received another call. This time the caller told her to pay Rs12,200 towards GST to redeem the ticket. She then went to her bank at Parnakuti Chowk around 1.30pm for depositing the money in the account the caller had provided. Around 2pm, she got the third call and this time the caller told her to deposit another Rs75,000 towards Income Tax and provide her bank account details for depositing the lottery amount.

After making the second deposit, she received another call. This time, the caller started asking for more money. An offence under section 420 (cheating) of IPC and under the provisions of the Information Technology Act has been registered.

Title: Notorious criminal named in 21 cases in UP, Maharashtra arrested in Dehradun
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Manoj Singh Thakur has escaped from police custody when he was brought for a court hearing in Azamgarh

DEHRADUN: The Dehradun police on Thursday arrested Manoj Singh Thakur, a notorious criminal accused in 21 cases of fraud, loot and attempt to murder at Azamgarh, Varanasi and Mumbai.

Singh, who had a reward of Rs 25,000 on his head, had escaped from police custody when he was brought for a court hearing in Azamgarh this year.

Dehradun senior superintendent of police (SSP) Arun Mohan Joshi said that Thakur, 41, had allegedly sold a flat in Mussoorie using forged documents and a police team was searching for him. He said, “During investigation, we found that Thakur had 20 cases against him in Uttar Pradesh and Maharashtra . Of which, five were registered in Mumbai and remaining 15 in Azamgarh and Varanasi districts of Uttar Pradesh.”

Earlier, Thakur was arrested by Mumbai police and Azamgarh police. “He was arrested by Mumbai police in September 2019 and in February this year, he was brought to Varanasi in connection with a court hearing in a matter related to fraud but he had escaped,” the SSP said.

Thakur told policemen that he wanted to meet his mother, who was in Azamgarh and was unwell. The Mumbai police team agreed and reached Azamgarh on February 11 but Thakur had escaped by then.

Since then he was on the run. Following which, the Azamgarh police had announced a Rs 25,000 reward for his arrest.

“We collected information that his wife and children were based in Dehradun. We traced his house and a team of Rajpur police and Special Operation Group was formed to nab him,” Joshi said.

While checking near Johri Tiraha area, police team intercepted the vehicle in which Thakur was travelling and he was arrested.

A country-made pistol of .315 bore and two live cartridges were recovered from him.

During questioning, Thakur told police that he belongs to Azamgarh but had studied in Mumbai as his father, who was a railway officer, was posted there. After completing graduation from Mumbai University in 2002, he got his diploma in journalism.

Title: Maharashtra: Errors spotted in school scholarship exam papers
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Students and teachers have alleged that the question papers for the scholarship exam conducted for Standard V and VIII on February 16 were fraught with errors .

The mistakes included misprints, missing key words and the mention of ‘square’ in a question, for which a diagram of triangle was printed. The students and teachers claimed that in the first paper of the middle school scholarship exam (Standard V), there were as many as 11 errors.

The allegation follows detection of several mistakes in last month’s Teacher Eligibility Test.

The Maharashtra State Council of Examination (MSCE) had received 3,847 objections to the TET, which was conducted on January 19. The MSCE said the answer key to the question papers would be published soon. Students, parents and teachers can submit their objections regarding the questions and a fair decision will be taken, the council stated.

Scholarship guide Santosh Gurav said, “Students put in efforts throughout the year to to appear for this exam. But, every year, there are several mistakes in Marathi and math papers, which leave the students confused.”

A Zilla Parishad teacher from Indapur, Satish Bhong, said for one of the questions, wrong options were provided.

“Apart from students, even parents get disappointed with such mistakes in the scholarship paper. Parents also put in a lot of efforts to prepare their wards for the examination,” he said.

Tukaram Supe, the MSCE commissioner, said, “We will publish the answer keys for the entire paper for both middle and high school once they are ready. The teachers, students and parents can submit their objections regarding the questions once the answer key is announced so that the expert panel can study them and take the decision on each objection raised.”

Title: ‘Innovation essential for development’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Trichy: Saying that innovation and creativity in rural economy is essential for development, deputy advisor, national assessment and accreditation council (NAAC) New Delhi, Devender S Kawday said if enough output is created in rural economy, through agriculture or cottage industry, we can bring about a revolution.

He was addressing students on the concluding day of Gyanotsav 2020 at National College Trichy on Thursday. The country should focus on rural economy as we are diverting ourselves from rural economy to urban economy, he said. Only 2.3% of our population is skillful, but we have excellent minds here, and we are unable to push them towards innovation.

Educational institutions should ignite the minds of rural people for the sake of developing their skills. We have 37.4 million, which is the highest student population in the world. Even if one percent of population starts thinking in this area, there will be a big change. Agriculture is going to be very important in future, he said.

Agriculture is not profitable in the country, but 60% of population depends on agriculture. He said India’s contribution to world GDP was more than 25% two centuries back. Now that we have about 18% of the world’s population, but the contribution to the world economy came down to 2.3%.

P Kanagasabapathi from Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR) stressed on the need to have basic education in mother tongue to effective learning.

Title: Maharashtra: Four steal 140 smartphones, sit by bonfire before fleeing
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Four men stole at least 140 smartphones and Rs1.47 lakh, totally worth Rs17.72 lakh, from a store in Bhosari around 3am on Wednesday, put the gadgets in two backpacks and spent some time next to a bonfire to beat the pre-dawn chill barely two stores away before fleeing.

Police said the bonfire was on in front of a jewellery store and the four men shared its warmth along with two persons, including the watchman of one of the shops in the area. The police said the duo did not even realize that the four men were sitting next to them and having a hearty chat after committing a theft.

The crime came to light around 10am when two employees of Shri Sai Enterprises opened the shutter of the store and found the empty boxes of cellphones lying all over. They alerted shop owner Visham Nimse (32), who lodged an FIR with the police.

Nimse told TOI that the shop had eight CCTV cameras, but the thieves had made off with their digital video recorder as well. “We obtained CCTV footage from the neighbouring shop and found that four persons were involved in the crime,” he said.

The shop owner said the footage revealed that the four men had entered the store around 3am by breaking the locks of its shutter. He said, “They took the smart phone boxes from the display rack. They took away nearly 140 handsets, each worth around Rs10,000, but left the chargers behind. They also stole Rs1.47 lakh from the cash counter inside the store.”

Nimse said the CCTV footage also showed the four men coming out of the store with two backpacks and then halting near the bonfire in front of the jewellery store. “One person was sitting near the bonfire. They had a talk with him for quite some time. The watchman of the shop was also there. But they apparently did not suspect anything unusual,” he said.

An officer from the Bhosari police said, “We have shared the CCTV footage showing the four men with our informers. We are working on some clues to arrest them.”

Title: Kids spot wounded tiger in Pauri Garhwal; forest officials say this is first sighting of a tiger in area
Content: Dehradun: Forest department officials expressed excitement after a recent sighting of a tiger in Dabrisain village of Rikhnikhal block of Pauri Garhwal district by school children. According to them, it could be a 'new habitat' for tigers apart from their regular homes – Corbett and Rajaji Tiger reserves.On Wednesday, some students on their way to school had spotted the big cat, which was unable to move. They informed the forest department about it. The four-year-old male tiger was tranquilised by a team of four veterinary doctors and experts from Wildlife Institute of India. On Thursday morning, the big cat was moved to Chidiyapur Rescue Centre of forest department where it is now being given preliminary treatment.The doctors treating the tiger said that the wild cat is unable to move due to weak muscles in its hind legs. Samples are being sent to IVRI for further tests. “We are keeping the tiger under observation and it is being administered drips as it was dehydrated. The next course of treatment would depend on the reports,” said Dr Amit Dhyani, veterinary officer of forest department. Poaching is ruled out from the scene as per the DFO of Pauri, Sant Ram.“Tigers are certainly moving uphill, as this one was spotted 20km north of Rajaji and Corbett Tiger reserves. Pauri Garhwal, therefore, is emerging as a new habitat for tigers. Last year we saw a camera footage of a tigress in Yamkeshwar block. From the past one month, villagers said that have felt the presence of tigers here. Now we are certain," said Vaibhav Singh, DFO Rudraprayag.Experts have indicated tigers’ presence in Kedarnath and in areas as high as Askot in Pithoragarh at 12,000 feet. “Tigers are extremely resilient animals. They travel a lot when it is required. Their movement in search of new territory can be seen as a mark of rising population as well as seasonal migration,” added Sant Ram. Harak Singh Rawat, forest minister of the state, had also stated after the release of tiger census last year that Uttarakhand is the only state where the presence of tigers is witnessed almost all over the state.

Title: Pune: Minors bend rules to hop on two-wheelers for ‘convenience’
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose

PUNE: If your are under 18, you cannot be riding a motorised vehicle. But, many college going students who are still under age, ride two-wheelers with utter impunity.A 17-year-old student from a college in the Deccan area said, “I have been using a two-wheeler for commute ever since I joined college. The public transport in the city is erratic and the autorickshaws are expensive. Having a two-wheeler at my disposal is convenient.”Another student (17) from the area said she had to travel to college and various tuition classes.“My home, college and classes are located in different areas and using a two-wheeler is the most reliable form of commute for me to reach on time,” she said.The death of a 16-year-old rider in the city in January has once again highlighted the dangers of underage driving. In that incident, the 15-year-old pillion rider had sustained serious injuries.A casual glance at any busy road in Pune shows that there is no dearth of minors riding in a way that puts their — and others’ — lives at risk.A 16-year-old student from Wanowrie said, “The public transport connectivity in our area is not up to the mark. I have to change buses at either Swargate or Pune station. The buses mostly aren’t on time either. If not a two-wheeler, what other options am I left with?”Devendra Mehta, a businessman, said he knew a 15-year-old student who rode a Royal Enfield motorcycle. “On a daily basis, I also see children between 15 and 18 years riding two-wheelers and flouting rules — riding triple seat, not wearing helmets or riding in a no-entry zone.,” he said.Harshad Abhyankar, director of Save Pune Traffic Movement, said there were many reasons for minors using vehicles. “Not too long ago, licences were easy for even 16-year-olds. Many have seen their elder siblings use a vehicle at that age and want the same. Children attend several classes and using a two-wheeler seems convenient. But, none of this justifies underage driving,” Abhyankar said, adding road safety should become a part of school and college curriculum.According to the police, 285 cases were registered and Rs1.42 lakh in fines was collected from offenders last year.Samaiirah from Safe Roads Foundation said, “All too often, parents themselves let their children use two-wheelers to run errands, but they need to understand the consequences of this.”Under the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019, in cases of underage driving, parents or the vehicle’s owner will be held responsible.Sujit Patwardhan, the founder of local NGO Parisar, which works towards road safety, said his granddaughter used to ride a two-wheeler to buy things from nearby shops. “We explained the consequences to her. she understood and stopped. But, her underage friends continue to ride vehicles. Parents should step in,” he said.Patwardhan said it was incumbent upon the traffic police to nip this problem in the bud. “Confiscating the vehicle from a minor and handing it over to his/her parents is one way. The police could also force offenders to do social work as a deterrent,” he said.Pune police commissioner K Venkatesham said a softer approach was needed. “We need to apply a reformative approach, rather than punishment, for this age group,” he said. “Accordingly, we are focusing on counselling, under which 35,000 students have been made aware about the dangers of underage driving in more than 287 counselling sessions,” he added.

Title: Three killed in Tamhini Ghat accident
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pune: The plan of five friends from Bopkhel to go for a picnic to Diveagar in Konkan turned tragic as the car they were travelling in crashed into a tree in the Tamhini Ghat section in the early hours of Thursday, killing three of them on the spot.

The two others suffered severe injuries in the accident around 1.45am at Kondeshwar village on Pune-Mangaon Road, about 55km from the city. The Mangaon police identified the deceased as Nikhil Chandrakant Ghule (26), Chandrakant Shrikant Nikam (26) and Vikram Singh (31). “The injured persons, Vijay Gorakh Patil (28) and Sunil Balaji Telange (27) are being treated in a private hospital,” said inspector Ramesh Ingwale of the Mangaon police station.

Assistant police sub-inspector S S Chavan said, “Ghule was driving the car. He lost control at a sharp turn in the Tamhini Ghat section and crashed into the tree along the road.”

“Patil somehow came out of the vehicle and alerted the PCR. A police team reached the spot and took them to a hospital,” Chavan said.

Title: ‘All-party delegation should press for SCS’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Exert pressure on Centre: CPI state secretary K Ramakrishna addresses the round-table meeting in Guntur on Thu... Read More

Guntur: CPI state secretary K Ramakrishna has demanded that the state government take an all-party delegation to New Delhi to press the Centre to grant special category status ( SCS ) to Andhra Pradesh.

Addressing a round-table meeting here on Thursday, Ramakrishna criticised chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy for not being able to exert pressure on the Centre despite winning 22 Lok Sabha seats from the state. “Jagan promised to achieve SCS had people given him 25 Lok Sabha seats. People trusted him and handed him 22 seats. He has thoroughly disappointed the people in the last nine months,” said Ramakrishna.

The constitution of an all-party delegation, he said, would help put pressure on the BJP as all parties at the national level, except BJP, were in favour of granting SCS to AP.

Aam Admi Party (AAP) leader and vice-president of Pratyeka Hoda Atma Gaurava Porata Committee, Dr Seva Kumar, said people would lose trust in the democratic system if the Centre did not honour promises made in Parliament. He said Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu had demanded granting SCS for 10 years while former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh promised to give SCS to AP for five years.

Seva Kumar said they would chalk out a plan to intensify the agitation for SCS.

Title: Flash sales prompt 20-30 per cent growth in air travel bookings for some sectors
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The recent airline flash sales offered by two carriers caused a 20-30% increase in travel bookings for some national and international sectors, travel firms told TOI on Thursday.An IndiGo airline sale that ends on February 21 is offering cheap one-way fares for the upcoming travel period. For instance, a Pune-Singapore one-way ticket is priced at Rs8,886, per person, a Pune-Dubai one-way ticket is at approximately Rs8,700, as per travel firms. From Mumbai to Abu Dhabi, the fare is Rs6,699, to Dubai it is Rs7,399, to Muscat it is Rs6,999, among other sectors.The low airfare sale started by Air India and IndiGo has already seen over 20%-40% growth in travel bookings for the upcoming summer vacation period, said travel firms.Sources from travel and hotel booking e-commerce website ixigo said that they witnessed a growth in domestic bookings amid the recent sales.“We have seen a 23% growth in domestic flight bookings for the period February 15-18 as compared to last week. In fact, New Delhi-Pune was among the top 10 domestic routes booked during the sale. From Pune, some cheapest popular bookings were for Nashik , Belgaum, Bengaluru, Dubai, among others,” the source said.Travel Agents Association of Pune (TAAP) director Nilesh Bhansali said, “With international travel also dipping after Covid-19 fears, some airlines are offering discounts and flash sales to push up bookings. Generally, there is a 20%-25% increase in flight bookings due to an ongoing flash sale, with business travellers and those having a planned trip in mind making bookings. As part of the sale offered on international sectors, some popular destinations have been Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Muscat, Male and Doha, especially since travel to southeast Asia has dropped significantly after Covid-19.”

Title: Amit Shah in Itanagar, govt junks China objection
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: After China objected to home minister Amit Shah ’s visit to Arunachal Pradesh, India hit back and said Beijing’s objection to government functionaries visiting the state did not “stand to reason and understanding of the Indian people’’.

India’s position on Arunachal Pradesh had been clear and consistent that it was an integral and inalienable part of the country , foreign ministry spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said. “Indian leaders routinely travel to the state of Arunachal Pradesh as they do to any other state of India,’’ he added.

China, which claims Arunachal Pradesh as part of south Tibet , objected to Shah's visit to the state, saying it violated Beijing's "territorial sovereignty".

“China's position on the eastern sector of the China-India boundary, or the southern part of China's Tibet region, is consistent and clear," China's foreign ministry spokesman Geng Shuang told reporters in Beijing on Thursday.

“The Chinese government has never recognised the so-called ‘Arunachal Pradesh' and is firmly opposed to the Indian politician's visit to the southern part of China's Tibet region as it violated China's territorial sovereignty, undermined stability of the border area, sabotaged political mutual trust, and violated relevant bilateral agreement," he added.

Shah was in Arunachal Pradesh to attend the 34th Statehood Day function and launched a number of development projects.

Addressing a rally at Indira Gandhi Park in Itanagar , Shah said, “Misinformation was spread after abrogation of Article 370 that Article 371 will also be scrapped. It will never happen and nobody can do it.” He added that the NDA government was committed to preserve and protect the unique culture and tradition of the north-east.

Article 371 has special provisions to preserve the cultural heritage and customary laws of north-eastern states.

The home minister said, “Previously, the region got importance on political lines. But PM Narendra Modi initiated efforts to unite the NE with the rest of the country.” Shah said central ministers visited the region more than 200 times in the past five years and the PM visited 30 times.

He added that the north-east enjoyed a special place in the country for its unique culture and tradition and unless the region was developed, cultural integration could not take place.

China routinely objects to Indian politicians visits to Arunachal Pradesh. The India-China border dispute covers the 3,488-km Line of Actual Control. The two countries have so far held 22 rounds of special representative talks to resolve the border dispute.

Title: De-addiction centres yet to take shape even after 6 mths
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: Even after six months of the new excise policy coming into force, de-addiction centres remain a non-starter in the state.

The government brought in the new excise policy with an aim to impose a complete liquor ban in a phased manner. As part of implementing the complete liquor prohibition , the state government proposed the establishment of de-addiction centres across the state to help tipplers give up their habit.

The government was proposed the setting up of at least one de-addiction centre in every district in the first phase and to increase the number as needed. However, these centres have not taken off yet anywhere in the state. Though the previous government mooted the establoshemtn of de-addiction centres under project ‘Jagruthi’, the proposal still remained on paper.

The YSRC government, which came up with and implemented complete liquor prohibition as a policy, emphasised on the establishment of de-addiction centres to rehabilitate people seriously addicted to liquor. Officials have even studied the models of Kerala and Punjab where the state governments are successfully running de-addiction centres, but little progress was made in starting the centres in AP.

In August, the government announced that these centres will be established by coordinating with the medical and health departments by recruiting expert counsellors, psychiatrists and other medical staff required. Nothing has materialised till now and all the proposals are still in the planning stage.

Speaking to TOI, V Lakshmana Reddy, chairman of Madya Vimochana Prachara Committee said that the state government has identified the locations to establish the de-addiction centres in all 13 districts. “The basic idea is to attach these centres to the teaching hospitals wherever possible. The staff recruitment and infrastructure procurement is going on and they will start functioning soon. Apart from the 13 centres being established by the state government, six de-addiction centres also coming up in the state with the help and funding of union government,” he said.

Vivek Yadav, commissioner of prohibition and excise department, said that there are many de-addiction centres in the state in the private sector which are not up to the mark. “The establishment of de-addiction centres is a work in progress and they will start functioning soon,” he said.

Title: Brash student beats up principal in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Yogesh Sindhav who thrashed principal of a college in Jamnagar

RAJKOT: In a brazen case of hooligansim in a college, a 19-year-old student hurled profanities at a woman lecturer and thrashed the principal in Sikka town near Jamnagar.

The incident happened in the arts and commerce college run by Jamnagar Digvijay Gram Panchayat on Wednesday when the second-year BCom student Yogesh Sindhav barged into the class the middle of the lecture without permission. He was stopped by teacher Dr Hetal Bhatt who asked him to wait until the class got over.

However, Sindhav got enraged and started hurling expletives at her in front of all other students. He then threatened Bhatt and asked her to get out of the classroom. Bhatt immediately went to principal Mahavirsinh Jadeja who rushed to the classroom and talked to Sindhav. But an unapologetic Sindhav started abusing Jadeja too and started thrashing him. Jadeja suffered minor injuries after he fell on the ground when Sindhav pushed him.

Hearing the commotion, other students and staff members rushed to the classroom and caught hold of Sindhav. While leaving, Sindhav dared Jadeja to lodge a complaint against and threatened to kill him if he did so.

Principal Jadeja confirmed that Sindhav has a penchant of threatening teachers in the college. “Last semester, he had brazenly tried to copy in the exam. But after villagers intervened, he gave a written apology."

Investigating officer RK Gadhvi told TOI that Sindhav’s father Lakshman is a listed bootlegger and a detainee under Prevention of Anti-Social Activities (PASA) Act.

Sindhav is a habitual offender and often gets into arguments with the teachers. Talking to TOI, Dr Bhatt said, “Sindhav often comes late into the class and has got ATKT in the first semester. In December too, he had behaved rudely with teachers.”

RK Gadhvi, investigating officer, Sikka police station said, “Entire college has CCTV network. In the footages, Sindhav is clearly seen forcibly entering the classroom and then intimidating the lecturer. He is also seen smashing the principal after which students force him out the campus.”Sindhav has fled after the complaint was lodged against him.

Title: We will complete Char Dham project works by 2021 Kumbh Mela, says Gen VK Singh
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Retired gen VK Singh who was accompanied by CM Trivendra Singh Rawat

UTTARKASHI: All ongoing construction works of Char Dham All Weather Road Project in Uttarakhand will be completed before Kumbh Mela, which will be held at Haridwar in 2021. The statement was given by Gen VK Singh, minister of state for road transport and highways, during his visit to Uttarkashi on Thursday.

Addressing media persons, he said, “Government is aiming to complete all the projects of Char Dham All Weather Road by the 2021 Kumbh Mela. So, pilgrims coming to Uttarakhand can also visit all four Himalayan shrines easily.”

“High power committee of SC has submitted its interim report regarding 100 km stretch from Uttarkashi to Gangotri, where road widening work has halted due to eco-sensitive zone. We will start the work on this stretch, soon after getting the clearance,” he added.

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said, “All-weather road project works are moving ahead with good pace and quality across the state. Besides, we will soon start the construction work at Gangotri valley region, as high power committee has finally submitted its interim report.” He added, “The number of tourists and pilgrims coming to state is increasing every year. Therefore, we are aiming to complete the project at the earliest so that tourists and local people can get better transportation facilities.”

Earlier, Gen VK Singh, who was accompanied by CM Rawat, conducted an aerial survey of ongoing all-weather road project work at Tehri, Narendranagar, Chamba, Chinyalisaur, Barkot and other regions. They also surveyed Bhairon Ghati region of Bhatwari block, where project has still not started due to restrictions of eco-sensitive zone. After survey, they reached Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP) camp in Matli village and chaired a meeting .

During the meeting, officials of National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), Border Roads Organisation (BRO) and National Highways and Infrastructure Development Corporation Limited (NHIDCL) briefed the Union minister.

Meanwhile, Gen VK Singh said, “We will not stop any work during Char Dham yatra. And, we will try to complete the work in maximum areas so that pilgrims and locals do not face any difficulties.”

CM Rawat added, “We will try to complete maximum work before the yatra season, as we did last year.”

Title: Dehradun: Some FSSAI norms difficult to follow, say meat sellers
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

DEHRADUN: A team comprising officials of the district Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) conducted a raid at several meat shops in Dehradun on Thursday.

The inspection drive was conducted to check whether the meat sellers were complying with the FSSAI norms and maintaining hygiene standards. “We are ready to follow the FSSAI norms but some of them are just impossible for us to follow. The administration is asking us not to slaughter birds inside our shops. But, there are no authorised slaughterhouses for birds in the city,” said Tarvinder Singh, a local meat seller. “The DMC penalise meat sellers if they are not maintaining the hygiene standards while other things are concerned with the FSSAI department. Our team keeps a check on the meat sellers on a regular basis,” Kailash Joshi, chief health officer of DMC, said.

“As far as the issue of an authorised slaughterhouse is concerned, it is not permissible under the Doon Valley Notification 1989. The slaughterhouse is categorised as a red industry and as per the notification, there can’t be any red industry in Dehradun,” Joshi added.

Title: ‘Won’t allow Naidu’s yatra to budge’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: Nagari MLA RK Roja warned TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu that his Praja Chaitanya Yatra would not be allowed to move even by an inch if TDP continues to encourage its activists to attack YSRC legislators.

Alleging that TDP goons tried to attack her at Inavolu village in the guise of farmers, Roja said the state government is committed to do justice to farmers of the capital city and there was no going back on the promise.

“The TDP has deployed a number of its activists and real estate agents to create law and order problem in the name of farmers. Naidu should keep in mind that he is out of power and can’t face us. He is playing dirty politics by hiding behind the cover of farmers. His yatra will not move an inch if we want to block him,” she warned.

Roja added that Naidu is worried as the Enforcement Directorate and income tax departments have intensified investigation into his misdeeds and appealed to the “real farmers” not to fall into Naidu’s trap.

Title: Kasu Vengala Reddy to be immortalised
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Guntur: State government has decided to name the Zilla Parishad building after late ZP chairman Kasu Vengala Reddy. The government has asked the panchayath raj commissioner to rename the ZP building as Kasu Vengala Reddy Bhavan in view of the services rendered by the veteran leader to the panchayat raj institutions.

Vengala Reddy served as ZP chairman twice during 1962-64 and 1971-1976. He was longest serving ZP chief in the district and was considered a good administrator, who was the backbone of his brother Brahmananda Reddy when the latter was CM of undivided AP. Brahmananda Reddy was one of the longest serving CMs of AP.

Gurazala legislator and grandson of Vengala Reddy, Kasu Mahesh Reddy, recently met the chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy and submitted a representation to name the ZP office after veteran leader. Subsequently, the CM asked the panchayat raj department to consider the request. tnn

Title: 2-day civic school games to start today
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

New Delhi: Over 500 students from various municipal bodies across the country will be participating in the first ‘National Municipal School Games’ being organised by the south corporation. The two-day event, starting from February 21, will see competitions in various categories, including throwball, table tennis, volleyball, chess, football, kabaddi and kho-kho.

Most of the games will be held at Dr Sahib Singh Verma Stadium while football. Formally inaugurating the event at Dr Sahib Singh Verma Stadium in Kakrola on Thursday, SDMC mayor Sunita Kangra said that it is aimed at promoting school games and showcasing students’ skills in sports.

Mumbai Municipal Corporation and Pune Corporation are among the many civic bodies participating in the event.

Title: Miscreants rob from under-construction electrical sub-station near Bhagwanpur
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

ROORKEE: Four unidentified miscreants reportedly robbed a guard and a labourer at an under-construction electrical sub-station in Bhagwanpur near Roorkee late on Wednesday night.

The miscreants stole metal plates and a guard’s gun from the sub-station. At 12.30am, four armed miscreants reportedly came on a small loader and took the guard and a labourer in custody at gun-point and locked them in a room after snatching a gun and mobiles from the victims. Police have registered a case under section 394 (voluntarily causing hurt in committing the robbery) of IPC against unidentified miscreants. No arrest has yet been done in this connection.

Title: Woman jumps off Prakasam Barrage
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: A woman attempted suicide by jumping into Krishna river from the Prakasam Barrage on Wednesday morning.

The incident came to light after CCTV camera footage of Madhuri’s suicide attempt went viral on social media.

According to One Town police, the incident happened at around 10 am on Wednesday.

The video showed the woman—identified as Madhuri Rajini (23)—and her two-year-old son walking on the footpath near gate number 50.

Suddenly, she abandons the kid, scales the wall of the barrage and jumps into the river. Cops explained that local swimmers, who were quick to notice the incident, dived in and rescued her.

Upon receiving information, the police reached the spot and rushed Madhuri to Vijayawada government hospital where doctors said she was out of danger.

One Town police said the woman is a resident of Mahanadu area of Tadepalli in Guntur district.

Almost three years ago, Madhuri had married Eswar Reddy and they had a son together.

However, both of them began fighting due to a number of issues, which ranged from relatives to financial issues, which led her to take the extreme step.

The police registered a case and summoned Eswar Reddy to counsel them.
