Title: Changing client tastes reflect in traditional Pithora paintings
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pithora artwork depicting tribal gods and ancestors

Vadodara: If the post-migration city-sleek tribals of central Gujarat have changed their sartorial tastes drastically, how can their deities lag behind? So, to suit changing preferences, the entire culture gets a massive makeover — both for the deity and the devotee. All of them are now denim-clad, technologically advanced, gun-totting metrosexuals!

All of these emerging trends are getting mirrored in the traditional Pithora paintings too.

Traditional Pithora artists, or Lakharas, too have thrown out the ‘dhoti’, ‘langot’ and horses from their artworks to depict deities in trousers, driving a truck or riding a bike!

Pithora artwork which adorns every household of the Rathwa community depict tribal gods and even ancestors in these paintings. The acquired taste is, however, prominently becoming visible on public buildings like health centres and schools in Chhota Udepur.

“These new additions are being made on demands from the clients,” explained Nandu Rathwa of Baroj village. According to Rathwa, the clients no longer like the look of their gods in human forms wearing ‘dhoti’, as they do not look good on the walls!

“So, we have no option but to show them wearing pants,” said the painter who has been making such artwork since he was 10 years old. Lakhara, however, vouches that the sartorial changes will not destroy the traditional Pithora artwork as every Rathwa continues to patronize the traditional paintings at their homes.

Ratan Rathwa’s paintings have a few additional accessories to match the deities outfit — like a gun instead of the original bow and arrow! The painter asserted with pride that along with the demands of clients, these are his own ideas added to the paintings.

City-based art promoter Sachin Kaluskar, however, pitched in for the tribal painters. He said: “An artist brings out what he sees or observes around himself. Secondly, to sell or to make people accept their art, they bring out elements that people from urban areas can connect with.”

Kaluskar had curated a project wherein two American artists and five Pithora artists had come together to create a Glo-Cal art wall on the façade of Sir Sayaji Nagargruh in Akota.

Title: VMC set to beautify canal bunds at cost of Rs 400 crore
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: Canal bunds across the district, which resemble dumping sites, are all set to get a major facelift soon. The project is estimated to cost Rs 400 crore.

The district administration is gearing up to strengthen canal bunds across the state and transform them into beautiful landscapes. Following the directions of chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, the district administration will clear around 1,344 kilometres of canal bands in the district in the first phase.

Irrigation canals have a great significance in the city. Three irrigation canals—Eluru canal, Ryves Canal and Bandar canal—pass through the city. A major portion of tje city is located in the middle of these three irrigation canals. With the population growing in the city, canal bunds have become a hub for dumping garbage and construction waste.

The Telugu Desam-led state government, which focused on canal bund development, had failed to complete beautification works.

Krishna district administration and Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) started a canal cleaning drive in city and identified around 350 locations where drain water was flowing into the canals. Officials said mini sewage treatment plants would be constructed at these locations to prevent this.

“We are happy that chief minister appreciated our efforts in cleaning the canals. We have designed a special plan to clear around 36 canals in the district. We have already erected fences on bridges to prevent garbage being dumped into the canals. We will soon strengthen the canal bunds and develop parks, walking tracks and open gyms,” district collector A Mohammed Imtiaz said.

Three irrigation canals—Eluru canal, Ryves Canal and Bandar canal—pass through the city. A major portion of tje city is located in the middle of these canals

Title: Hunt for 3 absconding ‘Taadpatri’ gang members on
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The detection of crime branch (DCB) has launched a manhunt for tracing the three missing members of the ‘ Taadpatri ’ gang who were involved in a theft and attack on the police team.

The trio — identified as Amro Bhil, Alpesh Bariya and Ratna Meetha — was roped in by the key gang members for stealing valuables from trucks and transporting them safely, said cops, adding that they are also trying to recover goods stolen by the gang in several similar thefts in the past.

“This gang has nine members and we have already nabbed six of them. Efforts are on to trace the remaining trio who were paid to steal for the gang,” said a crime branch official.

“This gang operates from Godhra and usually strikes in different cities of Gujarat . Godhra has about five to six such gangs and they all have similar modus operandi. They steal valuables from trucks by cutting open the tarpaulin. The valuables are then sold off,” the police said.

The gang usually operates in evening or night so that passers-by don’t notice them when they steal from the trucks parked on the highway or near hotels. This gang had attacked the cops on February 4 when they were spotted while stealing some valuables from a truck. They managed to flee from the spot after damaging two police vehicles before getting nabbed by the crime branch.

Title: HC posts petitions challenging GO72 to March 12
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court, on Thursday, posted the hearing on a batch of petitions challenging GO 72 issued by the health, medical and family welfare department fixing the fee structure for various courses in unaided and non-minority medical colleges. However, the high court posted the matter for fresh hearing on March 12 as the composition of the bench changed.

The GO increasing the fee for MD, MS and diploma courses in medical colleges and MDS courses in dental colleges was issued on May 3, 2017. The high court was moved with a public interest litigation (PIL) back in 2017 and two other writ petitions were also moved by students.

Earlier, the case was heard in part by the high court. Now, as the composition of judges has changed in the chief justice court, the bench on Thursday said would hear the matter afresh on March 12.

The petitioners sought relief from the high court contending GO 72, according to which the tuition fee in medical and dental colleges has been increased. They argued that the hike in fee is exorbitant and is in violation of Andhra Pradesh Educational Institutions Act and the Supreme Court judgments on similar matters.

The petitioners sought directions to set aside the GO 72 through which the fees have been increased manifold and to restore the old fee structure prior to the issuance of impugned GO. They also sought directions to refund the excess amount collected by the college managements, with interest.

Title: Over 170-year-old milestones with Tamil numerals found in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The milestones were found adjacent to a travellers bungalow located on the Trichy-Thanjavur national highway

TRICHY: Two milestones, believed to be over 170-year-old, with Tamil numerals to denote distance on highways were found near Sengipatti in Thajavur district . If confirmed, it will establish the wide prevalence of Tamil numerals during pre-independence era.

The milestones were found adjacent to a travellers bungalow located on the Trichy-Thanjavur national highway.

“These milestones were erected in 1849 by the British Government during the road improvement phase,” said Manganoor A Manikandan, a research fellow in the Department of Ancient science of Tanjore Tamil University . He led a team consisting of Karu Rajendran and T Manisekaran to Sengipatti in Thanjavur where the milestones were spotted by social activist M Sekar.

Manikandan said that the milestones were erected during the British regime when a new road was laid and named road number 7 from Trichy to Tanjore via Thiruvarambur and termed it a significant finding that shows the use of Tamil numerals in daily life of the common folks. “The road has a bridge and was in a good state, writes Lewis Moore, in the District Manual of the Tiruchirappalli under presidency of Madras, on June 28, 1878. This helps us establish the date of the milestones,” he said.

Title: Steady crowd retains tempo of anti-CAA protest in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Anti-CAA protests continued to keep the police on their toes in Trichy

TRICHY: Anti-CAA protests continued to keep the police on their toes in Trichy and other districts in the central region for the fourth consecutive day on Thursday. While the sit-in by a group of Muslims entered the third day at Uzhavar Sandhai grounds here, the protesters kept the flock together with about 200 people present anytime.

Trichy city police had already booked over 200 people in the past two days for unlawful assembly at the Uzhavar Sandhai grounds. In all, 16 leaders of Muslim outfits including PFI and parties like CPM and Naam Tamilar Katchi were booked besides 2,484 people including 50 women for intentionally insulting with an intent to cause an offence against the state and public tranquillity by staging an agitation near district collector office on Wednesday.

Students of Jamal Mohammed College (JMC) in Trichy and from some other colleges in the city staged a demonstration in front of JMC on Thursday afternoon also. It was the show of dissent by the students for the third consecutive day. The students went ahead with the protests despite the police naming the leading protesters in the first information report for the past two days. A police officer said that case will be filed against those staging protests without permission from the police.

The KK Nagar police booked three students of JMC, MIET college and Urumu Dhanalakshmi College in Trichy and 50 others for unlawful assembly over the CAA issue near the college on Wednesday. The three students had already been booked by KK Nagar police for spearheading the protest on Tuesday also. CPI also staged a demonstration against CAA near Gandhi market led by party state president R Muthrasan. The police said about 50 people took part in the demonstration.

Muslim outfits in the districts in the central region also maintained the tempo by carrying out protests at 13 places in Pudukottai , Thanjavur, Tiruvarur and Nagappattinam districts on Thursday. Going by the calculation of the police, about 3,000 people including 2,000 Muslim women participated in the protests.

Title: PSUs plan PR blitz to spruce up govt image
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government is lining up a public relations blitz to tom-tom its ‘achievements’ with the tagline, ‘Har ek kaam desh ke naam (each work is for the country), a move seen as the BJP ’s attempt to refurbish its ‘development party’ image that had taken some beating during the Delhi assembly election campaign.

The oil ministry, one of the Centre’s key public interface has got off to an early start, asking executives of PSUs under its wings to plan mass campaigns explaining how the work done by the ministry is improving people’s lives. The company honchos — usually reluctant to open their mouth — have also been put on the job and advised to, as one source said, “actively spread the good word”.

The ministry has given each of the flagship companies a theme to work on. The country’s largest refiner-retailer IndianOil, for example, has been asked to use the imminent countrywide launch of BS-VI fuels as the launchpad for its campaign and showcase it as an anti-pollution and public health milestone. Same is the case for gas utility GAIL, which will use the proposed rollout of city gas networks in 400 districts as a means to help cities breathe easy.

“The law of diminishing returns have caught up with Ujjwala (the scheme for giving free LPG connections to poor households), the Narendra Modi government’s social welfare blockbuster that had yielded rich political dividends. There is a belief that the BJP’s image as a development-oriented party suffered due to its shrill campaign during the Delhi election. There is also an air of despondency over the economy. BS-VI rollout is a big achievement and a perfect prop to rejuvenate the government’s image,” a person in the know said requesting anonymity.

India is set to leapfrog from BS-IV to BS-VI vehicles and fuels from April 1. BS-VI has nearly the same — or better in some areas — emission parameters as a CNG ( compressed natural gas ) vehicle. Delhi had switched to BS-VI two years before the deadline, while the entire NCR (national capital region) covering cities in UP and Haryana neighbouring Delhi had done so in October 2019.

The companies are likely to go to town with billboards and hoardings at their petrol stations as well as advertisements. This is the second time in recent times that the ministry wants to create public awareness about an initiative that touches people’s lives. It had a fortnight back held a brainstorming session with states and other stakeholders for launching city gas services in 400 districts. Here too, a blue flame denoting cleaner air in cities subtly highlighted the event’s public health underpinning, transforming a business gathering to a social welfare event.

Being one of the Centre’s key public interface, the oil ministry is no stranger to stepping up to promoting government’s objectives. In the aftermath of demonetisation, the state-run fuel retail companies had played a major role in promoting digital payments and later easing cash woes by offering limited cash withdrawals through cards.

Title: Focus on school infra, skills as education gets over Rs 39k crore
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

EDITED

Jaipur: With the allocation of Rs 39,524 crore to the education sector, the state government will be focusing on enhancing infrastructure of schools and colleges this year.

The government has also announced to open 167 English-medium schools at block levels this financial year. CM Ashok Gehlot has said that buildings will be constructed for the 18 new colleges announced last year.

To fulfil the long-standing demand for extra rooms in the schools, the Budget has proposed to build extra rooms in 200 higher secondary schools in the state. In rural areas, many government schools do not have subjects like science and mathematics, so the government has announced that new subjects will be introduced as per requirement in 300 secondary schools. A special cadre for computer teachers has also been proposed. To promote girls’ education, 66 new Kasturba Gandhi Residential Schools have been proposed.

The state government will also be focusing on skill development. Skill Enhancement and Employable Training (SEET) will be started for students studying in colleges. CM Ashok Gehlot announced around 10,000 students will be trained every year under SEET with the help of Skills University and Rajasthan Skill & Livelihoods Development Corporation.

Gehlot announced Rajiv Gandhi E-Content scheme under which lectures will be uploaded online and could be accessed by all college students. “This will help students, especially from the economically weaker sections, in understanding the subjects better,” Gehlot said in the assembly.

As a refinery has been established in the state and to improve research in natural gases, MBM Engineering College, Jodhpur, will be upgraded as a university. For this, Rs 20 crore has been sanctioned by the government in the Budget. MBM college is the oldest in the state.

Key Points -

- To open 167 English-medium schools at block levels this financial year

- Budget has proposed to build extra rooms in 200 higher secondary schools in the state

- To promote girls’ education, 66 new Kasturba Gandhi Residential Schools have been proposed

- Skill Enhancement and Employable Training (SEET) will be started for students studying in colleges

Title: Mumbai woman trekker dies after falling off fort near Pune
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Siddhi Kamte (20) fell off Hadsar Fort from a height of 350 feet

THANE/PUNE: Siddhi Kamte, a 20-year-old trekker from Saat Rasta , died after falling off a cliff during a trekking expedition at Hadsar Fort in Pune district on Wednesday.

Siddhi, a commerce student of a Mumbai-based college and a native of Pune, was an avid trekker. Her family said she left home to accompany a group of around 35 trekkers on Tuesday.

She was part of the group at Hadsar Fort, which is located around 13km from Shivneri Fort, when she reportedly lost her balance and fell off a height of 350 feet, said a member of the rescue team. “The incident took place around 10am on Wednesday when the group members were climbing the fort to conduct a cleanliness drive on reaching the top to mark the birth anniversary of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. While trekking, Siddhi lost her balance and fell from a height of more than 350 feet,” said an officer from Junnar police station.

The college student was taken to a nearby hospital with the help of local residents, rescuers and police personnel, where she was declared brought dead, said an officer.

Siddhi, who is survived by her mother, a widow, and younger sister, had taken to trekking a few years back.

Her family said she was shy by nature but would light up whenever she was allowed to go for treks.

She lost her father at a young age and aspired to be a chartered accountant to support her family.

“Siddhi had recently celebrated her birthday and we were shocked to hear of the mishap. I rushed to the hospital after I was alerted of the fall and never expected that the young life could be snuffed out this soon,” said her uncle Sudhir from her native place in Fursungi, Pune.

Meanwhile, trekkers have called in for more safety measures for those undertaking expeditions. It may be noted that the Thane district administration is considering a drone survey to track all treacherous routes for trekkers. The survey, said officials, will be used to understand the danger spots and suggest safer alternatives to ensure lives are not lost to similar mishaps.

Title: Post office employee arrested for misappropriating money
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: City police have arrested an employee of the Beema Nagar post office for creating a fake document in the name of a woman and misappropriating funds worth Rs 1.15 lakh. Police are also searching for a woman involved in the case who is on the run.

The accused, M Jeyakumar, 33, a resident of Jailpettai in Palakkarai, is a temporary employee at the post office while the woman, R Sarasu, lives in Mariyamman temple street, Thennur. Based on a complaint lodged by S Ragu Ramakrishnanan, assistant superintendent, sub post office, Trichy , the sessions court police arrested Jeyakumar and booked him under sections 419, 464, 465, 468, 471 and 42 IPC. He has been remanded in judicial custody at the central prison, police said.

Sarasu had a savings account at the Beema Nagar branch post office but it had become inactive. Meanwhile, another woman also by the name R Sarasu, a resident of Andakondan, had been maintaining a savings account with the same post office with a balance of Rs 1.15 lakh.

According to the complaint, Jeyakumar prepared forged documents and fake passbook in the name of R Sarasu, but bearing the address of Andakondan and withdrew Rs 1.15 lakh with the help of the accused Sarasu from the account. The cheating came to light when the genuine account holder approached the post office to withdraw money, police said.

Title: PMC to work on metro proposals with PMRDA
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The elected representatives have proposed the extension of metro on different stretches measuring 100km (File ... Read More

PUNE: The corporation will work in coordination with the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority on the proposed extension of Metro routes, connecting the core city areas with the outskirts.

The elected representatives have proposed the extension of Metro on different stretches measuring 100km. The proposals include extending the service up to Wagholi, Khadakwasla, Hadapsar and Warje. At present, work has been initiated on three Metro routes — Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation to Swaragte, Vanaz to Ramwadi (both being executed by MahaMetro) and Hinjewadi to Shivajinagar (executed by the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority).

Pune municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad said preliminary talks would be initiated with the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA) on the proposals and on how expenses for drafting the detailed project reports (DPR) of these routes could be shared to prevent complications. He said the Metro would play a vital role in strengthening the public transport in the Pune region in the days to come. Proper planning should be done after considering the requirements for the next three decades, he said.

The civic administration has given its go-ahead for the DPR (detailed project report) of Swargate-Katraj extension, but it has received many other proposals for the extension of the Metro services in the past one year. “The proposals are from all over the city. The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC)’s standing committee has given approval for preparation of DPRs of various routes. But mere approval to proposals will not be enough. The civic body will have to appoint an agency and make adequate provision of funds to carry out the studies,” a senior corporator said.

Sources claimed that the possibility of appointing a single agency to prepare a collective DPR of new routes was being explored. For instance, studies of the proposed extension of Metro up to Katraj, Chandni Chowk and Nigdi were being studied by MahaMetro, the sources added.

Hadapsar MLA and NCP’s city unit chief Chetan Tupe said the Metro extension proposals were discussed during the recent meeting conducted by district guardian minister Ajit Pawar. The minister sought a detail study of every route, Tupe said.

Extension of Metro up to areas like Hadapsar and Wagholi was essential, the MLA said.

It was now the responsibility of the PMC, PMRDA and MahaMetro to work in coordination to expedite the studies, Tupe said.

Title: Fire breaks out in godown near Halol
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A major fire broke out in a scrap godown near Halol in Panchmahal district on Thursday night. Fire fighters from Halol, Vadodara and industries in the area rushed to the site to douse the flames.

According to sources, the godown located on the Pavagadh Road had a large stock of tyres in it apart from other material.

This made the task of controlling the fire difficult for firemen . Police as well as other officials rushed to the spot.

Title: Cops issue advisory to warn buyers against online fraud
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Visakhapatnam: As an increasing number of residents in the city fall prey to fake advertisements on online classified advertisement platforms, city police have stepped up action to create awareness of cyber fraud.

Hoardings at strategic locations across the city caution residents to be careful before making an online transaction on certain sites and applications.

Explaining the modus operandi behind such cybercrimes, a senior police official said fraudsters pose as army officers or company executives to fool a prospective buyer into believing that the product in the advertisement is being sold at a low price as the seller is moving to another city.

Once the buyer, who hopes to make a purchase at a comparatively low price, is convinced of the ‘genuineness’ of the product, the seller asks him to make an online money transfer. The seller absconds after the money has been transferred.

“It is indeed difficult to verify the genuineness of sellers online. In fact, it becomes difficult for us to trace the fraudsters as they can open a fake profile from any corner of the country. The best way to avoid such a situation is to visit the advertiser and physically verify the product before making any payment,” a police official added.

Most cases of online marketplace fraud, police said, relate to sale of used cars.

“Although our investigations has revealed that these fraudsters are based in other cities, they actually display car pictures that are registered in Visakhapatnam city. Thus victims are convinced that the advertisers are genuine,” the official added.

As precautionary measures, police advise physical verification of the products and checking the original documents and bills for the products before making a payment.

The advisory also states buyers to not trust the identity cards of sellers and other buyers as fraudsters may use fake identity cards which a buyer cannot verify.

Title: BBA writes to PM over Nyay Mandir cleanliness
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Members of Hindu Jagran Manch had cleaned-up the heritage premises on Sunday

VADODARA: After two lawyers and some members of Hindu Jagran Manch entered the heritage Nyay Mandir building to clean it, the Baroda Bar Association (BBA) has now shown its concern for the maintenance of the building.

The president of the lawyers’ body Hasmukh Bhatt wrote a letter addressing it to the Prime Minister Narendra Modi, chief minister Vijay Rupani, minister of state for home and law and justice Pradipsinh Jadeja and others on Thursday. Bhatt, in his letter, has stated that the Nyay Mandir building was under the possession of the district court administration, but either due to lack of funding from the state government or some other reasons cleanliness is not being taken up inside the premises.

Bhatt also said that either the central government or the state government should take over the building so that the importance of the building be maintained. He also wrote that the structure built during the times of Maharaja Sayajirao III is the pride of people.

Meanwhile, the talking point at the district court in Diwalipura remained the FIR that was registered against the two lawyers – Neeraj Jain and Prakash Jha – for entering the building on February 16 for cleaning it. The WhatsApp groups also remained abuzz with chatter over the issue. “This is a heritage structure and there are penalties prescribed in the Heritage Conservation and Preservation Act for neglect or violation of the act,” said senior advocate Kishor Kini. He also said, “If we talk about Swachh Bharat mission then it is the district collector’s duty to make sure that this public building is kept clean.”

Title: Bees sting 25 in funeral procession
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

RAJKOT: A group of 25 people going to cremate a dead persons had to be rushed to the hospital after they were stung by honeybees in Liliya village of Amreli district on Thursday.

This was the second time in as many days that bees have stung members in funeral procession. According to sources, the victims called 108 emergency ambulance and all were shifted to a local government hospital.

On Wednesday too, 10 people in a funeral procession were attacked by bees, but it was after the last rites of the deceased were completed. Babu Dhamat , sarpanch of Liliya said, “Not just crematorium, but honeybees threat looms in in schools too. We have informed forest and agriculture department but non of them came to help us.”

Title: Pune: Two minor girls go missing from home for destitute
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Two minors, aged 8 and 10 years, went missing from a home for destitute girls and women in the city on Wednesday morning.

The two girls were residents of Ahmednagar and lodged at the home for destitute. A complaint has been lodged in this connection with the Deccan Gymkhana police.

Sub-inspector B R Zarekar of the Deccan Gymkhana police station told TOI, “The two girls were detained by the Government Railway Police (GRP) for stealing some articles from the platforms of Pune railway station on February 12.”

He said, “The girls were sent to the home for the time being following the direction of the Juvenile Justice Board. They were supposed to be handed to their parents on Monday.”

The police have registered a case of kidnapping against some unidentified persons after contacting their parents. “They told the police that the girls had not reached their respective homes,” Zarekar said.

Around 10am on Wednesday, the girls were summoned by the home authorities to watch television. The officer said both the girls told the home authorities that they needed to visit the washroom before watching the television. “They then left the home and ran away,” he said.

Zarekar said police teams were searching for both the girls at various railway stations and different stands of the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation.

Title: Rajkot: Depressed girl student hangs self
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Depressed over ATKT she got in the final year of her engineering exam, a girl student hanged herself to death from the ceiling of her hostel room in Sanjayraj Rajyaguru Engineering College on the outskirts of Rajkot on Wednesday evening.

The deceased was identified as Rita Gohel (20), a native of Jamnagar.

“Gohel’s family members and the hostel mates said that she had sunk into depression ever since she had received ATKT in the final exam. On the fateful evening, she locked herself up in her room and hanged herself, using her dupatta,” said Raidhan Dangar, assistant sub-inspector with Kuwadawa Road police station.

Title: ‘Cheater’ priest evading multiple court summons
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Dr Prashant Upadhyay

VADODARA: The priest of Shri Baglamukhi Brahmastra Vidya Mandir Dr Prashant Upadhyay is on run not only to evade arrest in the recent cases of cheating and criminal intimidation, but also to avoid appearing in a trial of a case registered against him and six others in 2015.

Upadhyay and his aides had thrashed an insurance agent Pragnesh Shah at his temple in Warasia in August 2015.

Shah had once gone to the temple to offer prayers as his relationship with his wife had soured and they were living separately. He was advised by Upadhyay to divorce his wife.

Upadhyay promised to get him married to anyone of his woman followers and was asked to transfer the ownership of his house to the temple trust. However, Shah was not convinced by the idea. A month later, when Shah was passing by the same temple, another priest of the temple asked him to attend a mass sermon at Gotri. Shah was forcibly taken where he had asked questions related to Ramayan and human virtues which were not taken in a good taste.

Next day, Upadhyay called Shah to express his displeasure about the questions and asked him to come over. On August 10, 2015, when Shah went to meet Upadhyay with his friend, an argument ensued and Upadhyay’s aides thrashed him with sticks injuring him.

Shah had then registered a complaint of assault and criminal intimidation at City police station.

The police completed investigation within a month and had filed chargesheet against Upadhyay, his aides Harshal alias Hari Om Mistry, Kinjal Vyas, Dharmesh Vyas, Annama George, Rashmika Upadhyay and Unnati Joshi.

A court of additional chief judicial magistrate has been issuing summons to the accused to appear before the court but in last over four years the case has hardly moved. On Thursday too, the case was listed but as no accused appeared the court adjourned the hearing for April 15.

Title: Sastra, Navis ink MoU to develop talent pool
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Navis-one of the world leaders in developing software for the maritime industry-has partnered with Sastra university by signing a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to develop a talent pool, on Thursday.

V Badrinath, dean, corporate relations, said that the MoU is aimed at bridging the gap between the industry and academia by conducting a slew of programs like in-plant training, project work, industrial internships, faculty development programs and special lectures by industry experts. Lakshmanan, vice-president and general manager of Navis, opined that developing a passion and cultivating a habit of giving back are very much required for budding engineers to succeed in their career. A customer-centric approach apart from upholding ethics and values are equally important, he said.

S L Alagappan, senior support manager, Navis, said that modern ICT tools help the shipping industry by saving space, time and energy through optimum utilization of terminal resources. Executives from Navis, faculty from Sastrauniversity and more a than hundred students participated in the program.

Title: Govt hikes DA by 5%, to fill over 53k posts
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Edited

Jaipur: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Thursday announced five per cent increase in the dearness allowance (DA) of the government employees raising it to 17% from 12% which will be effective from July 2019. He also promised to fill vacant posts by recruiting 53,181 employees in 2020-21.

The chief minister also proposed that Mukhyamantri Kaushal Marg Darshan Yojana will be initiated in the state. This scheme will help in skill development of students from 11th standard according to their talent and interest.

Under Rajiv Gandhi Digital Skill Programme, online digital courses on Artificial Intelligence, Big Data Analysis and Robotics will be introduced through Rajasthan Knowledge Corporation Limited (RKSCL) with assistance from Rajasthan ILD Skills University (RISU).

He also announced setting up of Pravasi Rajasthani Shramik Kalyan Kosh at Rs 10 crore. The government will also set up e-class rooms at all the 229 government Industrial Training Institutes (ITIs). Under RSLDC and RISU, skill enhancement and employable training (SEET) will given to 10,000 students every year for skill development.

In 2020-21, Gehlot said 53,181 posts will be filled, which include, 4,369 posts in medical and health department, 573 in medical education, 1,000 in cooperative, 41,000 in education, 1,039 in local self government, 5,000 in home department, 200 in General Administration Department (GAD).

Gehlot also said that during the current tenure of the government, 34,682 new recruitments have been made in government jobs so far and 82,000 recruitments are in process.

Under tribal area development (TAD) department, skill developmental centres at Pratapgarh, Dungarpur and Udaipur will be set up. The government will also increase capacity of tribal residential schools up to 2,400 with expenditure of Rs 10 crore apart from establishing a separate cadre for hostel wardens.

Gajendra Singh Rathore, president, All Rajasthan Employees' Federation (United), welcomed the increase of dearness allowance by the government. "This was pending since September last year. Now, there will be 5% increase in the basic salary of the employees. We also demand that Samant committee report should be made public and merger of grade pay 5, 6, 7 as one level and 8, 9 as one (as per Central government norms)."

Title: Tank & aircraft to be unveiled at Camp school
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pune: The Bishop’s School, Camp, acquired an MiG-21 aircraft and a T-55 tank, which the institute will unveil on Friday evening.

The school’s principal Joel Edwin said the aircraft and tank were acquired to motivate students to look at a career in the Armed forces.

The event will be attended by Maj Gen Navneet Kumar, General Officer Commanding, Dakshin Maharashtra Sub Area, Pune, and Lt Gen A B Shivane (retd), Director General, Mechanised Forces, officials of Pune Cantonment Board, Air Cdre Rahul Bhasin VM, Air Officer Commanding, 2 Wing Air Force Station, Pune and the school’s governing body. Many former students of the school who have served in the Armed forces will also be present.

Title: New NFAI vault to focus on digital, non-film, tape material
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The vault project is a continuation of the National Film Heritage Mission

PUNE: The National Film Archive of India (NFAI) plans to begin constructing its newest vaults at its Kothrud Phase-II campus. Officials have confirmed that besides celluloid and other film reels, focus will also be on ‘born-digital’ films, tapes, and non-film cinema material.

Over the past year, NFAI has consulted with a number of experts and institutions, including Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay (IIT-B) and Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC), to come up with a concrete policy to help create the infrastructure needed to store vast volumes of digital content.

The new vault project is a continuation of the National Film Heritage Mission (NFHM), which is being carried out by the NFAI as the nodal agency. “We had sent the concept project report for the vault construction to the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting for approval in December. Once the approval arrives, the construction will take two years to complete. We have also brought an architect on board for the planning and construction,” said NFAI director Prakash Magdum.

He added that, once approved, the vaults will be constructed by public sector entity National Buildings Construction Corporation Limited (NBCC).

At the vaults, the NFAI has planned facilities to store celluloid reels as well as magnetic tape formats like U-Matic and VHS, which were one of the preludes to digital cinema.

But emphasis has also been laid on ‘born digital’ cinema, where films are shot, produced and distributed as digital cinema packages.

“Storage for born digital material does not take up too much physical space but there needs to be relevant infrastructure and technical support to maintain the facility. Besides celluloid and paper material, we will also have infrastructure to store magnetic tape formats like U-Matic, BETA tapes, and VHS,” Magdum said.

“These formats helped in the transition to the digital formats as they exist now,” Magdum stated.

Title: AMC’s parking policy lacks planning
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) on Tuesday approved a parking policy for private and commercial vehicles with a view to increase its revenue and to streamline traffic movement. However, with AMC’s garbage vehicles being parked on roads since the last five months due to lack of parking space, the policy seems impractical.

According to the resolution passed by the municipal corporation, four-wheelers and heavy vehicles will be charged for parking based on the width of the road.

The roads having width between 60 and 24 m are included in A category, the roads having width between 24 to 18 m fall into the B category bracket whereas those have width between 18 and 9 come under the C category.

The resolution proposes night parking charges at Nirala Bazar, Aurangapura, Railway Station Road, Gopal T point, Kranti Chowk, Pundalik Nagar, Connaught Place, Town Hall, TV Centre, Jalgaon Road, Cidco N-1 and Adalat Road.An agency will likely be hired to collect the parking charges. The charges may differ from Rs 5 to Rs 100 per day.

The policy, however, fails to explain as to how the municipal corporation will allot parking spaces on roads when they are already used by citizens for parking their vehicles. Traffic police ACP Dinesh Kolhe said that the AMC needs to assign parking spaces so that the traffic police can ensure that the vehicles are parked in their designated spots.

According to Aparna Thete, who heads the estate department of the AMC, the work on identifying specified parking spaces in city is underway. It is jointly being carried out by the estate, town planning and garden department of the AMC.

Title: Mumbai: Indrani Mukerjea’s bail plea opposed for fifth time
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

File photo of Indrani Mukerjea

MUMBAI: Opposing Indrani Mukerjea ’s fifth bail plea in the murder case of her daughter Sheena Bora , the prosecution told the special trial court on Thursday that her role is entirely different from co-accused and ex-husband Peter Mukerjea, who was recently granted bail by the Bombay high court. Among her bail arguments, Indrani had sought parity with Peter.

Refuting this, special public prosecutor Manoj Chaladan cited a paragraph from the high court’s February 6 order. The high court had observed that even if were presumed that Peter had shown disapproval to the “love relationship” between his son Rahul Mukerjea and Sheena, there was material to infer that such disapproval was based on the directions of Indrani. The high court had further observed that the material on record demonstrated that the disappearance of Sheena was even suppressed from Peter, as, after the murder Indrani was operating the victim’s email account and mobile phone.

However, one of the defence advocates in the case pointed out that at the end of the same order, the high court had said, “It is made clear, that the observations made herein are prima facie, and the trial court shall decide the case on its own merits, in accordance with law, uninfluenced by the observations made in this order.” The high court had stayed its order by six weeks to enable an appeal by the CBI.

Seeking bail, Indrani had cited the deposition of several witnesses and said that their versions were concocted and riddled with discrepancies. However, Chaladan said that at this stage the court cannot go into the credibility and reliability of witnesses. “It can only look at if there are reasonable grounds or not,” the prosecutor said.

The prosecution also said that witnesses such as Indrani’s former driver and accused-turned-approver, Shyamvar Rai, former assistant Kajal Sharma and son Mekhail Bora had spoken about her role in various aspects of the crime. “The prosecution had got prima facie material to show the active role of the accused and how grave the offence is,” Chaladan said. He also said that there was apprehension that Indrani would abscond as she was a British citizen. Standing in the witness box, Indrani quipped that her passport was with the court.

Concluding his submissions, Chaladan said, “Considering the gravity of the offence, role of the accused, status of accused in society…the accused is not entitled for bail at this stage.”

Indrani will submit her rejoinder to the prosecution’s arguments on February 25.

Title: 13 anganwadis for Aurangabad Cantonment likely to be approved next week
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Cantonment ’s long wait for anganwadis under the central government’s Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme is set to end soon.

The district women and child development office has proposed to the state government for setting up of 13 anganwadis in the Aurangabad Cantonment. This development comes after the activists from an NGO filed a public interest litigation (PIL) in the Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court seeking the establishment of anganwadis in the cantonment.

In the PIL filed in November 2019, the activists of Cantonment Jan Adhikar Manch (CJAM) had sought the establishment of anganwadis in the Aurangabad Cantonment. Laxman Deshmukh, one of the petitioners, said that they had to take the course of PIL as there is not a single anganwadi in Aurangabad Cantonment which houses 25,000 registered voters. The court had issued a notice to the Ministry of Defence (MoD) among other government establishments in this regard.

Abhay Rathod, on the behalf of the petitioners, said that the anganwadis are established under the National Policy for Children, 2013, which protects the fundamental rights of children.

In the hearing held on January 29, the bench comprising justice SV Gangapurwala and justice Shrikant D Kulkarni had asked the women and child development department to conduct a survey within 10 days to explore suitable places for establishing anganwadis.

When asked, Pramod Yendole, child development project officer, Aurangabad-Urban A, said that following a survey, it has been decided that 13 anganwadis should be established in the Aurangabad Cantonment. “Last month, the central government had approved 97 new anganwadis for Maharashtra. We have proposed to the state women and child welfare department for the approval of 13 anganwadis for Aurangabad Cantonment out of these 97 new anganwadis. We expect an approval by next week,” Yendole said.

Title: Maharashtra: Farmers sell 75 tonnes of organic produce in four days
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose

PUNE: The recent visit to the city was a pleasant experience for Nitin Ingale and 40 other farmers from Purandar , as they sold their produce directly to consumers during an organic produce festival.The state government’s Agricultural Technology Management Agency (ATMA), engaged in training farmers in adopting organic farming practices, had organised the festival between February 6 and 9.As many as 42 farmers’ groups from across the district participated in the event and sold around 75 tonnes of organic produce that fetched them Rs50 lakh. This was the highest turnover the festival had seen in the last four years of its run.“The response to the festival was overwhelming. We had kept organically-cultivated fruits, such as guava, chikoo, pomegranate and horse gram, produced in large quantity in our area,” Ingale said.He added that his group had also introduced processed food items, including pulp of mango and blueberry, at the exhibition.“All the products were processed without any preservatives. They could be tagged as 100% organic,” Ingale said.ATMA officials said the festival was a unique experience for the farmers, as they could directly sell their produce to the buyers. The exhibition was initially planned for three days but had to be extended by a day following the consumers’ demand.“All types of farm produce, including pulses, cereals and vegetables, were available for sale with an emphasis on rice and wheat. ATMA had ensured that every product at the exhibition was cultivated through organic farming techniques. All the products were tested at reputed labs before being declared organic”, the official said.According to ATMA, there has been an increase in response to organic farming. The association has been running a scheme for organic farming for the past four years. In the first phase, over 2,000 acres of farmland were brought under organic farming with the participation of 1,892 farmers and 40 groups of cultivators.In the second phase, 1,100 acres of land have been identified under the scheme with 703 farmers joining the initiative so far.“There has been an increase in the turnover for the last four years and the sales in 2020 were the highest. In 2016-17, 40 tonnes of produce fetched a turnover of Rs25 lakh. In 2017-18, the figures rose to 55 tonnes. The revised data showed the figure currently stands at 75 tonnes with a turnover of Rs50 lakh”, the ATMA official said.

Title: Budget focus on solar power
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Edited

Team TOI

Jaipur: The state budget has allocated Rs 18,530.75 crore for the power sector. Focus is on solar power as the state has tremendous potential in this sector.

The state had set an ambitious target of 30,000 MW from solar energy. In his budget speech, chief minister Ashok Gehlot said ultra-mega solar parks would be development in collaboration with private sector.

To reduce dependence on coal and pollution from coal-based thermal power plants, state-owned Rajasthan Vidyut Utpatan Nigam (RVUNL) will set up solar power plants to produce 800 MW of power. The budget also lays emphasis on roof-top solar system and ‘green energy cities’. The government plans to generate 300 MW from roof-top solar system in the next five years.

The budget announced that the government’s endeavour was to provide power to farmers for irrigation during the day as well. Currently, farmers get power for Rabi crops at night to reduce the load factor.

It said farmers could get power during the day in two blocks so that they need not got out in the biting cold to irrigate their farms in the winter season. In the next three years, 220 grid sub-stations(GSS), 30 new 130 KV GSS and 33 KV sub-stations 287 have been proposed. Capacity of 1,500 sub-stations will be augmented.

Title: 2,555 special buses during Sivarathri
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: The Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (APSRTC) will run 2,555 special buses to various Lord Shiva temples in the state to facilitate devotees visiting Shiva temples on Sivarathri.

As many as 792 buses have been planned to Kotappakonda in Guntur district from various places across the state. APSRTC has arranged 466 special services to Srisailam from all districts in the state and 75 buses to Amaravati from Krishna and Guntur regions.

To monitor passenger rush, traffic management, and demand for buses, 850 supervisors have been deployed across all regions. Apart from the main temples, special buses have also been arranged to temples in all districts where Sivarathri celebrations will be held on a grand scale. The special services will also available on Friday and Saturday as many devotees are likely to stay for the day on Friday and return only on Saturday.

Vice-chairman and managing director of APSRTC M Prathap has said that they have made all arrangements to clear extra rush to the Shiva temples. The special buses will be monitored in real time basis and arrangements have been made to send extra buses on the need basis he said.

Title: Man poses as income tax officer, dupes Pune trader of Rs 24,000
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Chandannagar police have booked a man for masquerading as an income tax officer and stealing Rs 24,000 from a shopowner on the pretext of counting cash.

He diverted the attention of the owner before stealing cash. The incident occurred around 11.25am on Thursday.

The shopowner, a woman, and her husband runs a plywood and hardware shop at Wadgaonsheri.

The woman, in her FIR, said that a carpentry work was going in the shop when she saw a man alighting from a car. “The man introduced himself as an I-T officer. He said he would verify if we had paid GST.”

She said that the man asked her to remove money from the cash box, which, he said, he would return after counting. “He pocketed some cash and hurriedly walked out.”

On counting the cash, the couple found that the impostor had pocketed 12 currency notes of Rs2,000 denomination, the police said.

Senior inspector Shankar Khatke from the Chandannagar police said, “We are checking CCTV cameras for establishing the identity of the impostor. We are working on certain clues and hope to crack the case at the earliest.”

Title: Passengers continue to suffer as auto drivers refuse to ply my meter
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: The regional transport office ( RTO ) has not been able to deal with the problem of autorickshaw drivers plying in the city without meters.

Though it is mandatory for rickshaws plying on city roads to have a functional meter installed and charge the passengers according to it, not many auto drivers abide by this rule.

Owing to this, passengers are forced to pay an exorbitant amount every time they hire an autorickshaw. According to a Jawahar Colony resident, Sonia Doke, there is absolutely no rule of law prevalent in rickshaw business in the city.

“You either agree to pay whatever the auto drivers ask for or use your own vehicle. For areas within city for example from Cidco N-4 to Mill Corner they charge as high as Rs 150 during the day,” she said.

According to meter, one has to pay Rs 14 per kilometer, but the auto drivers in the city are charging a minimum fare of Rs 30.

Regional transport officer Satish Sadamate said the RTO has a record of 9,920 auto rickshaws that have a valid permit and functional meters.

“In a meeting held with commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad two days ago, it was decided that all these rickshaws will display a sticker that would help us identify that they have clear papers, a working meter and are displaying the mandatory information on the vehicle. The traffic police will work with the RTO to ensure that authorised stickers are distributed to the auto drivers,” he said.

He added that the only 15 days ago, the RTO undertook a drive during which 62 rickshaws were found to be plying on road without proper papers or working meters. These vehicles were seized by the RTO.

Meanwhile, Nisar Ahmed Khan of Rickshaw Chalak Sanyukt Sangharsh Kruti Mahasangh said rising inflation along with surge in diesel and petrol prices makes it difficult for auto drivers to charge as per meter rates.

“We have placed several memorandums of demand before the RTO and the road transport ministry asking them to increase the rates, but our demands have not been heard,” Ahmed said.

Title: City gears up for 2nd Happy Streets on Sunday
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: After successful implementation of Happy Streets on February 16, the Times of India’s initiative will now be held on February 23 from 6 am to 9 am in front of the Times of India office.

The initiative is getting overwhelming response and queries regarding the event have already started pouring in.

Giving a break to heavy traffic from Osmanpura Circle to Kranti Chowk, the stretch is made free from vehicular traffic for three hours under the Happy Streets initiative. The event is being organised by the Times of India and Maharashtra Times in association with the Aurangabad city police.

The annual event is an initiative to allow people to enjoy the city roads without the obstruction of vehicular traffic. People of all age groups get a chance to participate in a range of activities. In the previous Happy Streets held on February 16, revellers engaged in physical activities like Zumba dance, aerobics, skating, cycling, cricket and skipping. Children played the board game ‘snakes and ladders.’ The game was recreated in a unique way with children and grown-ups playing as pawns on a mega board placed on the road. Some preferred to play carom during the event.

Those having an artistic inclination expressed their talent through nail art, face painting, abstract painting, canvas painting and rangoli. In the musical stand, professional singers as well as common people sang songs and played music from different genres. Revellers recorded sweet moments of the event on their mobile phones by clicking selfies at the selfie stand. Young and elderly alike made the most of the event’s colourful and cheerful milieu.

All this and more is planned for the forthcoming editions of Happy Streets to be held on February 23 and March 1, organisers said.

Title: Durga temple trust board announced
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: After a long wait, the endowments department of the Andhra Pradesh state government issued orders constituting the trust board for Sri Durga Malleswara Swamyvarla Devastanams, in the city. Following a stiff competition, 15 members secured a place in the temple trust board. The endowments department issued orders constituting non-hereditary members for the trust board.

Senior YSRCP leader Paila Sominaidu, Katakam Sridevi, DVRK Prasad, Busireddy Subbayamma, Puli Chandrakala, OV Ramana, Ganta Prasada Rao, Rachamallu Siva Prasada Reddy, Chakka Vara Lakshmi, Karthika Rajya Lakshmi, Netikoppula Sujatha, N Ambika, Kanugula Venkata Ramana, Nerusu Satish, Bandaru Jyothi were appointed as members of the temple trust board.

Temple chief priest LD Prasad was appointed as an ex-officio member of the trust board. The trustees will hold office for two years from the day of taking the oath.

Meanwhile, the chairman for the trust board is yet to be announced.

A few aspirants from the city who expected a place in the trust board were unhappy with the orders issued, which gave a place for non-locals.

Hindu associations welcomed the appointments and asked the newly elected trustees to respect the sentiments of the devotees. The trust board constituted during the Telugu Desam tenure was involved in some major controversies.

Title: ‘Online life key to language longevity’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: For non-English users of internet, the content consists of less than half of searchable indexed data. “But for a large population not speaking English , it could be a barrier while attempting to access the world,” said Prasenjit Majumder, associate professor with DAIICT .

“For example, a Gujarati native speaker will not have much option vis-a-vis English.”

As International Mother Language Day, celebrated annually on February 21, will be marked with theme of ‘Languages without Borders,’ the team led by Prof Majumder at Information Retrieval Lab attempts to bridge the gap between Indian languages — especially Gujarati — and concepts such as machine learning and artificial intelligence.

The team from DAIICT has already tasted success in analysis of tweets and online content in Gujarati and has started work on Named Entity Recognition (NER) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) for Gujarati in collaboration with IITs. The researchers said that compared to English, it’s difficult to work with language like Gujarati. “NLP tools for Indian languages have not yet reached that level because of lack of annotated data and lexical resources. Majority of Indian languages are highly inflected languages due to which many of the techniques used for English do not work here,” said a researcher. Citing an example, the team members said that Indian names do not have capital letters to denote a name, making it difficult for system to recognize one in data.“Language longevity will be decided by their online presence in time to come. Once the systems for regional languages are developed, features such as audio input, predictive texting, etc. could be developed. But it requires multi-pronged approach involving programmers, linguists, lexicographers and so on,” said Prof Majumder. Experts point at a phenomenal rise in regional content with cheaper internet and better online tools for translation and input - factors which have enabled an entire generation to use social media and platforms such as WhatsApp without knowledge of English.

Title: Mob booked for rioting in Tarsali
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A mob of 200 to 300 persons was booked for rioting and other offences as they vandalized as a traffic police cabin and got into a melee with policemen following a fatal accident at Susen circle in Tarsali on Vadsar road on Wednesday morning.

According to police, as a dumping truck ran over Bansi Surti (65) on Wednesday morning, a large group of people had blocked the road and had started thrashing the truck driver. When the traffic assistant sub-inspector Ashok Ramanbhai intervened and locked up the driver in the police cabin to save him from public wrath, the cabin was vandalized. The traffic cop called for more police as the mob swelled.

Even as more number of policemen reached the spot, the agitators got into melee with an inspector and even hurt a lok rakshak dal personnel. The traffic cop stated in his complaint that the mob even made attempts to torch the truck but when they were stopped, some persons pelted stones and damaged its windshield. An unidentified man also showed cash at cops and asked if they wanted more money, the complaint stated.

Later, as senior police officials and additional force reached, the crowd was dispersed and the road was cleared for traffic. An offence of rioting, deterring public servant from performing duty and criminal intimidation was registered. Police said that two persons – Jayesh Darji and Ajay Patel – have been identified from the mob.

Surti, a resident of Makarpura , was mowed down by the truck when he was on his way to his brother’s home near Nava Bazaar.

Title: City all set for colourful Mahasivarathri
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The Srisailam temple decked up ahead of Mahasivarathri

Vijayawada: Authorities of the Sri Durga Malleswara Swamy Varla Devastanams and the Krishna district administration have made elaborate arrangements for Sivarathri celebrations.

Taking a holy dip in the Krishna river in the wee hours of the morning on Sivarathri is an age-old tradition. Authorities estimate that around 2.5 lakh devotees will be taking a dip in the Krishna this year. Expert swimmers and rescue boats will be available at all river ghats in the city.

Officials said that they have arranged for helpline counters at multiple locations. Special forces of the state disaster response force (SDRF) have also been deployed to handle emergencies. Endowments authorities have made special arrangements for ‘pinda pradhanas’ and other holy rituals at river ghats.

The Malleswara Swamy temple atop the Indrakeeladri hill has also been decked up for Sivarathri celebrations. Temple authorities announced that Mahanyasa Abhishekhams and the Rudra Abhishekam will be held from the wee hours of Friday morning.

The city police too have made huge arrangements at Old Shivalayam in One Town. One and a half kilometres long queues have been erected to manage the rush of devotees. Bilvarchana, Lingarchana, Annaabhishekam, and other holy offerings will be performed at Vijayeswara Alayam near Prakasam Barrage.

Around 100 prabha bandulu (decorated chariots) will be at the Ramalingeswara Swamy temple atop Yenamalakudur hill as a part of celebrations on Friday night.

Title: Cops do U-turn, give nod for Carnival on Panaji main road
Content:
MERRIMENT: 28 participants have registered to put up tableaux for the Carnival parade in Panaji, mayor Uday Ma... Read More

PANAJI: After initially denying permission to hold the annual Carnival parade along its traditional route in the city, Panaji police and traffic cell of Goa police gave their nod following a meeting with the North Goa collector, Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP), including city mayor, on Thursday.With the CCP getting the permission from North Goa collector, this year’s Carnival parade, which will be held on Saturday, will commence at the Santa Monica jetty and end at Kala Academy , Panaji MLA Atanasio Monserrate said on Thursday.The collector has given permission, Monserrate told TOI. “It is police who have to manage the traffic and they cannot refuse to do it. If the Prime Minister wants to see the city, then will the police say that due to traffic congestion they will not allow the PM to visit the city?” he said.Madkaikar said that the parade was shifted from its traditional route a few years ago due to the construction work of the third bridge over the Mandovi. At the time there was no parking space for the tableaus below the bridge, but with the areas now cleared there is no problem in hold the Carnival on the old route, he said.When the route was changed, the parade was held from Miramar circle to Dona Paula circle.After patiently hearing us, the North Goa collector has allowed the carnival parade on the city route, the mayor told reporters.“When the collector asked Panaji police and traffic cell about their decision, both of them agreed to deploy personnel to manage the traffic,” he said.As of now, 28 participants have registered to put up tableaux for the parade, but the mayor said that he expected over 60 to participate.He said that due to protests over the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), they will scrutinise each and every tableau so that the Carnival is not used for either pro- or anti-CAA protests.“We have given instructions to police that if a pro- or anti-CAA tableau enters the route unnoticed, then, the moment it is noticed, it should be removed,” Madkaikar said.

Title: Shivaratri maha aarti to mark opening of revived Sursagar on Friday
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The venue will also witness a Maha Aarti of the Sarveshwar Mahadev idol in the pond that will be performed at ... Read More

VADODARA: Sursagar is all decked up and ready for its inauguration on Friday, on the occasion of Maha Shivratri. The venue will also witness a Maha Aarti of the Sarveshwar Mahadev idol in the pond that will be performed at the culmination of Shivji Ki Savari procession.

The chariot procession will carry with it the family of Lord Shiva sitting on Nandi. The grand statue has Shiva along with Goddess Parvati and their sons Ganesha and Kartikeya. Narad Muni will also accompany the family on the chariot.

The procession will begin from the Ranmukteshwar Temple in Pratapnagar and culminate at Sursagar after meandering through various areas in the city. Floats of 14 government departments will also participate in the procession apart from various other private organisations.

Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) officials are working overtime to ensure that Sursagar is ready for the aarti as well as for its inauguration. City police in large numbers along with sniffer dogs and equipment scanned the entire surroundings of the pond as Union home minister Amit Shah is scheduled to attend the grand event along with chief minister Vijay Rupani and other dignitaries.

The civic body has been testing lightings on the boundary of the pond as well as illumination of the grand Sarveshwar Mahadev idol in the centre and other heritage monuments in area. Work is expected to get over late on Thursday night.

Title: College students should get tested for thalassemia and sickle cell
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: Vice-president of Maharashtra Medical Council and Director of Thalassemia and Sickle Cell Centre, Dr Vinky Rughwani recently met the vice-chancellor of Rashtrasant Tukadoji Maharaj Nagpur University, Dr S P Kane recently and apprised him of the problems faced by thalassemia and sickle cell patients.

Rughwani explained that these two diseases could be brought under control only if precautions are taken by checking thalassemia minor and sickle cell trait test of every student taking admission in the university. Once this trait is found, precautions could be taken to ensure that children are not born with any major disease. Kane assured Rughwani that steps would be taken to issue instructions to all colleges regarding check up concerning thalassemia and sickle cell trait.

Title: BSNL to lease out vacant land, buildings
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Visakhapatnam: General manager of BSNL-Visakhapatnam, Paul William said that the telecom company plans to lease out its vacant quarters and buildings to other organisations and had called for an expression of interest (EOI).

William said uninterrupted customer services would continue even though a majority of employees had taken voluntary retirement. The department, he said, has taken measures to maintain services by requesting staff who have opted for the voluntary retirement scheme ( VRS ) to work till an alternative arrangement was made.

Addressing the media here on Thursday, William said that 576 staff members, including 495 non-executives and 81 executives, had opted for VRS in the district. Services of some subcontractors would also be utilised at the sub-divisional level.

“We are going for e-tendering in external plant network and door (OD) maintenance and cell tower maintenance. All the tenders are in process and would be made effective from April 1. The present staff and the retired staff (VRS) are working hard in maintaining OD network in an uninterrupted manner,” William said.

Staff are taking care of leased circuits for banks, state and central government offices, besides business establishments, William said.

Title: Gujarat: Five men loot Rs 6 lakh from PSU bank in Morbi
Content:
Villagers helping cops nab the robbers in Tupni village near Halvad on Thursday

RAJKOT: In a broad daylight robbery , five unidentified persons barged into a public sector bank and looted Rs six lakh from two cashiers by holding them at a gunpoint in Morbi on Thursday.The entire robbery was carried out within just seven minutes, said police. Four of them were nabbed from a field in Tupni village of Halvad taluka in Morbi late in the evening when they tried to escape after abandoning the car.People of Tupani village spotted the car of the accused and nabbed them. The villagers were already alert as they had received the information about the robbery on WhatsApp. They knew that the robbers had fled in a car.“When the villagers spotted the car moving suspiciously, they tried to stop the vehicle. When the robbers tried to flee, the villagers chased the car on two-wheelers. When the scared robbers abandoned their car and started running, the villagers nabbed them. Later, the villagers handed over the custody of the accused to us,” said Karanraj Vaghela, Morbi superintendent of police.At around 2:50pm, the robbers had arrived at Mahendranagar crossroads, a bustling spot in Morbi, and parked their car on the road opposite to the Bank of Baroda and Dena Bank. Both banks operate from the same premises.“They were armed with two country-made pistols and knives. They first robbed the security guard of his 12 bore gun and then got inside. They asked the staff to assemble together in the corner of the bank and held guns at the cashiers of Bank of Baroda and Dena Bank,” said R T Vyas, inspector with Morbi B division police station.They robbed Bank of Baroda cashier of Rs 4.50 lakh cash and Dena Bank cashier of Rs 1.50 lakh.Police suspect the accused were from other state as they were speaking in Hindi.Bank robberies are rare in Gujarat. The last such crime was reported in Axis Bank’s branch at at the Chhatral GIDC in Kalol when three men with country-made pistols stormed inside and took away Rs 44 lakh. They had even shot one employee in the leg.In Video: On cam: Robbers loot Rs 6 lakh from PSU banks in Gujarat

Title: Creaticity says realignment complete, now onto being profitable
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pune: Creaticity , Pune’s one-of its-kind furniture and home-decor mall housing over 15 brands furniture brands under one-roof, has completed right-sizing its business to enable it to grow its revenue.

The mall, formerly known as Ishanya — when it was concentrated with largely only furniture brands, has now realigned itself to have 50% of the space dedicated to home décor and furniture, 20% of the space to food and beverages and entertainment , and the balance to office space. This has given Creaticity a very healthy 84% occupancy levels.

Resultantly, the company’s revenues have grown to about Rs 24 crore in the current fiscal from about Rs 14.5 crore two years ago when it rebranded itself. “The rise in income is a result of right-sizing…there have been only 2-3 exits but seven new additions in the last two years. Some brands have also right-sized,” Mahesh, CEO, Creaticity, said.

The real-estate arm of publicly listed, Deepak Fertilisers and Petrochemicals Corp, also has managed to get about 6 lakh visitors so far this year (from about 5 lakh the year before). Mahesh said his mandate was to become profitable in a couple of years.

“It requires a lot of work to sustain in this business and when we decided to be just more than a space rental company, it has been a lot of fun. It is about constant improvement and continuous refresh,” he said.

Surappa Raju

Title: Bengaluru: Traffic plaints on PublicEye app up 150% in 2019
Content:
The number of complaints lodged by law-abiding citizens against traffic offenders on the PublicEye app witness... Read More

TimesView Law enforcement has been crowdsourced. This was inevitable, given the kind of traffic Bengaluru deals with and the issues caused by the limited number of police personnel on roads. While it might be satisfying to film an offender committing an egregious breach of traffic laws and endangering people, it’s not a healthy development. It may have short-term benefits, but it could lead to other forms of citizen justice — which is not far from mob rule. Long-term solutions would be more investment in the police department, better training and traffic planning. But while people bemoan the state of law enforcement, funding for police departments is always hard to come by.

BENGALURU: The trend of citizens turning watchdogs is growing in Bengaluru. The number of complaints lodged by law-abiding citizens against traffic offenders on the PublicEye app witnessed a 150 per cent year-on-year increase in 2019.PublicEye, an initiative launched by traffic police and Janaagraha Centre for Citizenship Democracy five years ago, allows citizens to click photographs of traffic violations and report them to police. If the photographic submission, in which the vehicle’s registration number is visible, is corroborated with supporting evidence, the offender will be penalised.While the number of complaints reported on PublicEye was 13,803 in 2015, it increased to 60,738 in 2018 and crossed 1,52,000 in 2019. This translates into an average of 417 complaints registered every day. “This is a pointer to increased citizen participation in policing. Bengalureans are becoming more vigilant on the roads,” said joint commissioner (traffic) BR Ravikanthe Gowda.The most common violations include riding without a helmet, parking in the wrong place, riding in the opposite direction on a one-way stretch, riding on footpaths and jumping traffic signals.But why has the number of complaints shots up drastically in 2019? Ravikanthe Gowda attributed it to the increased social media presence of traffic police. “Interest in traffic-related issues has gone up. People find it easy to access police on social media as we have amplified our presence on digital platforms,” he said.Another factor is the growing public contempt for traffic offenders. “A majority of vehicle users prefer to follow traffic rules even if they are caught in a jam instead of taking short-cuts like riding on pavements. When someone brazenly violates traffic rules, fellow motorists capture them on camera. Tolerance for rule-breakers is thinning in the city,” another police officer said.However, challans are not raised with regard to all complaints reported on PublicEye. In 2019, police rejected 27 per cent (40,329) of the complaints registered. “If the violation is found to be valid after appropriate checks by police, the offender is penalised as per the prescribed fine regime. For the offence to be considered valid, the vehicle registration number and violation committed should be visible in the complaint. For example, no parking board should be seen in a photograph which reports a no-parking violation. If the complaint doesn’t meet the required parameters, it’s rejected. There are 13 categories of violations listed on PublicEye,” explained police.What’s more interesting is the nature of offences reported from different areas. While a majority of complaints from the central business district (CBD) pertained to riding without helmet, in Bellandur, one-way rule violations dominated.

Title: Unclaimed vehicles: Hyderabad regional transport authority offices turn garages
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Rusty mountain: Unclaimed vehicles piled on top of each other near the regional transport authority office in ... Read More

HYDERABAD: Open areas near many regional transport authority ( RTA ) offices have turned into mass garages for vehicles that have remained unclaimed by their owners, in some cases, for over a decade.

These mounting piles of unclaimed vehicles are eating up open spaces which otherwise could have been used as parking spaces for vehicles of those who visit these offices. Instead, these unclaimed vehicles of which many have rusted bodies, occupy the spaces as people prefer not to take them even after cases against them have been settled.

During a visit to Trimulgherry RTA office, TOI found many auto rickshaws, cars and other vehicles piled on top of each other, all gathering dust. Similar was the case in Nagole where vehicles were left abandoned in an open space opposite Balaji temple. RTA officials are supposed to conduct an auction if the vehicle is not claimed, however, in most cases they fail to even send a notice to the owner.

“The RTA cannot keep vehicles for years together. They have to dispose them through auction or by sending a notice to the owner for release of these vehicles. If the owner does not pay the penalty, the department must take action as per Motor Vehicle Act,” said Telangana Auto and Motor Welfare Union general secretary, M Dayanand.

The Act states that the department should give a notification in the newspaper saying that on a given date, the vehicle will be put up for auction. “After the notice is given, a tender officer will be appointed to conduct the auction which will be organised in the presence of the public. This should be the process but because the RTA is not sending notices, the vehicles are gathering rust and just lying in open spaces for several years,” said Dayanand.

When contacted, joint transport commissioner C Ramesh said: “We have sent notices to owners and it is in process. The vehicles will be disposed in auction if they don’t come forward to claim them.”

Title: Gold price breaches Rs 43,000-mark in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Continuing its upward rally, gold prices breached the Rs 43,000-mark to touch a new record high and settle at Rs 43,205 per 10 gram in the Ahmedabad market on Thursday.

Pure gold price in Ahmedabad remained the second-highest in India, while the highest price being in the Hyderabad market, at Rs 43,250 per 10 gram.

The yellow metal prices rose in the international market, on account of growing concerns over the impact of the widespread coronavirus infection in China.

“Gold prices jumped by Rs 335 per 10 gram in the Ahmedabad market. Imports and exports of various countries including India is dependent on China and therefore, the extension of vacation in China due to the coronavirus infection would have an impact on global economy. Gold prices have shot up as a result of this in the international market,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers' Association (IBJA).

Overall gold prices have remained above the Rs 42,000-mark as a result of which the demand has showed a significant deceleration. “Gold jewellery demand has significantly declined due to high prices of gold. There was no relief provided to jewellers even during the Union Budget in the form of cut on basic customs duty. If prices continue to remain high, sales of jewellery as well as bullion is expected to decline and will impact employment in the sector,” said Acharya.

Despite the ongoing wedding season, high gold prices pushed gold imports in Gujarat to a five-month low at 0.92 metric tonne (MT).
