“Due to the Kamurta period, which is often considered inauspicious for gold purchases, coupled with high prices, gold imports plunged significantly low in January,” said a city-based jeweller.

“More than 70% transactions are being made through exchange of old gold. The ongoing wedding season is keeping sales upbeat as of now but if the prices continue to remain high,it may deter customers from purchase,” said Manoj Soni, member, Jewellers’ Association of Ahmedabad (JAA).

Title: Officer to probe Aquem project plaint
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

PANAJI: Director of urban development Tariq Thomas has appointed deputy director Deepesh Priolkar to conduct an inquiry into the complaint that a commercial project at Aquem, which was granted ‘part occupancy ’ certificate by Margao Municipal Council (MMC) in 2019, stood on wetland.

Thomas issued the order on Thursday following a fresh complaint by Margao resident Shirish Kamat.

Priolkar has been ordered to inspect the site while the chief officer at MMC has been asked to offer necessary assistance such as deployment of engineers and staff to assist him.

In his earlier order issued recently on an appeal filed by Kamat, the urban development director had kept in abeyance the part occupancy certificate that was issued until further orders.

As requested by the vigilance department, the inquiry has to be completed within ten days.

In his earlier complaint, Kamat had pointed out that there is no such provision in the law to issue any such thing called 'part occupancy' and that the certificate issued by MMC wasn't as per format specified in the Goa Land and Development Building Construction Regulation 2010.

Title: Ageing bad: 100-year-old Osmansagar rippling with pollutants
Content:
File photo of Osmansagar dam

HYDERABAD: The water quality in Osmansagar dam across the Musi river has deteriorated over the years. The reservoir, which turned 100 this year, is polluted with discharge from industrial and residential units whose activities have been on the rise over the past decade. It serves as a source of drinking water for a sizeable population but contamination — chemical, industrial and biological — in the Musi river has taken a heavy toll on the health of this water body.According to a recent research, the water quality index (WQI) of Osmansagar was recorded at 52.84 — just a shade above the “bad” category. While a WQI of between 50 to 70 falls under the “medium” category, the quality of Osmansagar is barely two notches above the bad category due to presence of pollutants.Another study published in the International Journal of Recent Technology and Engineering (IJRTE) reveals that, of the 16 water quality parameters, the Osmansagar passed the test in only parameter — pertaining to pH levels. Under the other 15 categories, waters of the Osmansagar fall under the “undesirable” category. The water is said to contain coliform indicating contamination by human discharge.Furthermore, analysis of the water collected from Osmansagar by the Telangana State Pollution Control Board (TSPCB) since 2011 shows that only twice — in 2017 and 2019 — had it passed the dissolved oxygen (DO) test. DO is an essential requirement for survival for aquatic life. The water also fails the test when it comes to biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which determines the availability of oxygen for living species. The levels often ranges between 6 to 10. A BOD level below 3.5 is deemed desirable.The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) has put Osmansagar under “B” category which means the water is fit for outdoor bathing but not for drinking unless treated through conventional means. Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board’s (HMWS&SB) general manager for quality assurance and testing, J Sunil Kumar claims that while treated water from the reservoir is 99% safe, in its raw form, the water is highly turbid with high levels of biological and chemical contaminants. “We remove all pollutants during the conventional treatment and ensure only safe drinking water is supplied through taps,” Sunil Kumar told TOI.While a drinking water source should not contain any faecal coliform bacteria, analysis of Osmansagar water shows a coliform count ranging between 15 to 378. In terms of total coliform bacteria, the water body had a minimum if 41 to maximum of 1,350 as per TSPCB data. The count should be nil. However, the water can be consumed after thorough treatment. “We have been carrying tests covering all parameters every month. Our analysis shows that Osmansagar water is potable but after treatment as it falls under ‘B’ category. Only category ‘A’ water can be consumed without conventional treatment but after disinfection,” TSPCB consultant senior scientist, N Murali Mohan told TOI.The study published in IJRTE shows that as far as pH levels of surface water is concerned, water from Osmansagar does not require treatment. The pH value was recorded at 7.55 which falls within the permissible range of 6.5 to 8.5 for drinking water. However another study by scholars Akhil Gurijala, SS Asadi, and D Satish Chandra, shows that the water has high odour when drinking water should have agreeable odour. The total hardness of surface water was reported to be 801mg per litre as against the permissible range of 200 to 600 mg per litre.

Title: Shiv Jayanti celebration turns sour, youth stabbed to death
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A 21-year-old youth was stabbed to death following a dispute over a flag in the procession to mark Shiv Jayanti in the city on Wednesday.

The Pundaliknagar police on Thursday arrested a 24-year-old man for allegedly stabbing the youth, who had refused to lend his flag to two suspects during the procession at around 9 pm on Wednesday.

Assistant police inspector Ghanshyam Sonwane, in charge of the Pundaliknagar police station, said Shrikant Gopichand Shinde, of Hussain Colony in Garkheda, was carrying a huge flag in a small procession that was on its way to join the main procession in the city.

Two people — identified as Rahul Bhosale (22) and Vijay Vaidya (24) — approached Shinde and asked him to hand over the flag to them for some time. Shinde refused. This led to heated arguments, following which, Bhosale allegedly drew out a knife and stabbed Shinde in the chest and stomach. Bhosale and Vaidya then fled the scene.

For a while, people participating in the procession could not fathom what had transpired. Some youths accompanying Shinde alerted his father, who rushed to the spot and took his son to a nearby private hospital. Shinde, however, was declared dead.

Sonwane said the police had immediately pressed four teams into action and had arrested Vaidya from the Karmad area, about 25 km from the city, early on Thursday. Vaidya has some previous cases against him. The police have now sent teams to look for Bhosale.

Meanwhile, the Pundaliknagar residents resorted to an agitation demanding the immediate arrest of the suspects. Meenatai Gayake, the Shiv Sena corporator from the area, said initially the residents were reluctant to take Shinde’s body. However, after one suspect was arrested, the relatives took the body and the youth’s last rites were performed, she said.

Title: Bengaluru: Govt vehicles whisked away for President convoy; officials stranded
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: With the government being informed about President Ram Nath Kovind’s Friday visit to Bengaluru only four days earlier, transport officials went on a spree collecting government vehicles, especially SUVs and jeeps, for deployment in the presidential convoy.In all, 150 government vehicles were picked up on Tuesday and Wednesday, and several officials were in for a shock with their vehicles being taken away without prior notice.However, not all 150 vehicles will be used for the President’s convoy, sources said. “Thirty vehicles will be used to ferry officials and police in the President’s convoy. Officials from the enforcement department will inspect the vehicles, check their condition and select 30,” they added.In its order on February 17, the department of personnel and administrative reforms said around 15 vehicles from each government department should be taken away by February 19. Accordingly, inspectors from the 10 RTOs were told to ‘swiftly collect’ the vehicles.In several instances, RTO officials literally whisked away the vehicles, leaving the officials whom they were allotted to and their drivers shocked. A driver from a government department told TOI he was flagged down near Palace Guttahalli and his vehicle was driven away by officials. He and the officer he was ferrying had to take an autorickshaw to reach office.“I was ferrying the officer to which the vehicle has been allotted after dropping some other officials at Vidhana Soudha. RTO officials stopped our vehicle and asked us and to take an auto. They showed us a notice from the enforcement department. Left with no choice, we stepped down and boarded an auto,” said the driver.An RTO official confirmed they had driven away several vehicles from the middle of the road. “We had no choice. Please don’t think we enjoy doing this. Some officials threatened us with action for taking away their vehicle. We were running out of time and hence, we forced them to hand it over,” an official said.Another expressed dismay over the development, saying there should be a proper way to arrange for vehicles during VIP visits. “Bengaluru hosts VIPs every now and then. There is no harm in the government reserving around 50 vehicles for such purposes. For 30-40 years, we have been following the same method of hurriedly collecting vehicles, ” he said.Transport commissioner N Shivakumar did not respond to calls and messages. Most of the vehicles have been stationed at the government’s Kumara Krupa guest house.

Title: TSRTC to run special buses to Srisailam
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Telangana State Road Transport Corporation (TSRTC) will operate special buses to Srisailam for the next two days in order to accommodate the Mahashivratri passenger rush. The corporation will run 325 special buses from the city, including 10 AC mini buses.

“These services will operate from the twin cities to Srisailam till February 23. The corporation has also made facilities available for reservation for these services,” said Ramachander Rao, DVM Rangareddy. The Vajra buses will run from Lingampally and MGBS to Srisailam.

Apart from Vajra buses, super luxury, deluxe and express buses will also operate from Neredmet, Miyapur, KPHB, Jubilee Bus Station , Uppal X Road, LB Nagar, Vanasthalipuram and BN Reddy Nagar.

Title: Haphazard, unauthorised parking leads to traffic issues across city
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: The menace of haphazard and unauthorised parking of vehicles on roads across the city is affecting movement of vehicular traffic and pedestrians alike.

Lack of parking space provided by marriage halls, hotels and commercial establishments is just adding to the problem and authorities have failed to deal with this issue in an effective manner.

Service lanes along important roads like Jalna Road, Jalgaon Road and Beed Bypass, meant for local residents and commercial visitors, are plagued with the issue of unauthorised parking. In addition, the market areas of Nirala Bazar, Aurangapura, Gulmandi, City Chowk and Pundalik Nagar also witness haphazard parking by motorists all day long.

Though traffic police and Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) claim to be serious about dealing with this menace, nothing concrete has been done by them so far.

According to Avinash Salve, an engineering student, there is major lack of awareness among the general people about traffic rules and regulations.

“The authorities concerned should put up boards and LED displays asking people to follow traffic regulations. Implementation of rules should be stricter so that there is a fear among errant motorists,” Salve said.

Aam Aadmi Party district convener Sugriv Munde, who led a campaign against a public sector bank for provision of parking space for visitors, said the civic body should see to it that commercial establishments have parking space before giving them building permission.

According to the AMC’s town planning department official RS Mahajan, the civic body approves the building plan only if there is a provision for parking.

“We cannot say about the old buildings, but all newly-approved buildings have provisions for parking space,” he said.

Title: DPR for metro rail ready, says Botcha
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Minister of municipal administration and urban development Botcha Satyanarayana said that the detailed project report (DPR) for the metro rail project is ready and the project office would shortly start work in Vizag. A budget of around Rs Rs 1,000 crore has been allocated for the project, the minister said, and added that the project has been extended to Bhogapuram.

The minister reviewed smart city projects, the metro rail and other projects at the Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA) office here on Thursday.

Satyanarayana also held reviews of summer action plans for drinking water and housing projects with the municipal commissioners of north Andhra and East Godavari districts at the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC) office, along with principal secretary J Syamala Rao.

A pipeline from the Godavari river to Vizag city would be laid for round-the-clock water supply, the minister said. “We have already initiated an action plan for drinking water in the summer in all 56 municipalities in the state. We have reviewed the issue keeping in mind water scarcity in summer. A review with officials of Rayalaseema districts would be held very soon,” he said.

As part of its election promise, the government would provide 300 sq ft houses free of cost and bank loans would be provided for purchasing 365 sq ft and 430 sq ft houses, the minister said.

Altogether 41,462 applications were received for the building plan regularisation scheme in the state, the minister said, of which 13,778 applications are from north Andhra and East Godavari districts.

Around 54 per cent of applications have been approved, two per cent rejected, 33 per cent are pending and 11 per cent are being processed. The government would also take action against illegal layouts, he said.

On the three capital cities proposal, the minister said, “we are not acquiring ponds and endowment lands for housing projects for the poor. We not going for forcible land acquisition.”

Title: Devotees gear up for mega Shivratri celebrations in T
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Hyderabad: Devotees were gearing up to head to Keerseragutta in the outskirts of the city on Thursday, ahead of Mahashivratri. Several devotees had planned on staying overnight to get an early darshan. “I have come to purchase flowers for tomorrow as I do not want to leave this for the last minute,” said Revathi Reddy, who was spotted at a local market in Domalguda.

Swathi Rao, another city resident, said that she would be heading to her local temple in Sri Nagar colony to seek blessings. On this day, to please the Lord, devotees fast as well as offer fruits and milk to the Shiva lingam. Many women also pray to be blessed with a good husband.

Shivratri marks the night Lord Shiva saved mankind by consuming a pot of poison during Samudra Manthan or the mythical churning of the ocean. Within the city, temples in SPR Hills in Motinagar and Shankar mutt at Nallakunta were among several that wore a festive look ahead of celebrations.

Shivratri celebrations also began at Vemulawada in Rajana Sircilla district on Thursday. The state has planned massive celebrations in Vemulawada as well as Siddipet this year. Over 2,500 performers are set to take the stage over the two days. “A 13-hour non-stop cultural show was organised for the Jaagaran at the Sri Raja Rajeshwari temple,” said Hari Krishna, director, department of culture.

Elaborate arrangements have been made on the occasion since a huge number of devotees are expected from the two Telugu states as well as Karnataka, Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh.

On the eve of Shivaratri, several performances were on show by artists from across Telangana including Kuchipudi, Bharatnatyam and Kathak performances.

Over five lakh devotees will attend celebrations over a period of two days in Vemulawada alone. This is the fourth consecutive year that such a cultural performance is being organised in massive scale for two days.

Title: Bengaluru: Condoms, jibes greet parking offenders in Whitefield
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vehicles parked on a footpath in Whitefield.

BENGALURU: A bad-tempered protest against motorists who illegally park in public spaces or reserved spots has usually involved deflating the car tyres or scratching the paint. On Thursday, a Whitefield resident registered his/her annoyance in a very different fashion: the person stuck condoms on the windshields of a few cars and left a note with some cutting commentary.

“You park like an A******. Please don’t reproduce,” read the message for the parking offenders .

Locals and Whitefield traffic police, who struggled a bit to hide their amusement, said two to three cars parked on a pavement of Whitefield Main Road, behind General Electric Digital Bangalore hub in Hoodi, were targeted.

Anjali Saini, a local resident, said cars carelessly parked on sidewalks and even on the road were a major irritant in the area. “The area lacks planning when it comes to parking zones and open spaces. Civic and government agencies must enforce the rules strictly to prevent illegal parking,” she said. Saini added she had no idea who could be behind Thursday’s stunt.

Banaswadi resident Vinay Nambiar posted pictures of the stuck condoms and the note on Facebook. He clarified he didn’t resort to this form of protest, but said it was normal in the West to shame irresponsible vehicle owners this way.

“I hope what has happened in Whitefield is an eye-opener, and motorists realise that they cannot leave their cars on pavements, which is meant for pedestrians,” he said.

In 2019, traffic police recorded over 10.8 lakh parking-zone violations across the city. In January this year, 66,664 cases were registered.

“There’s not enough space for parking in ITPL. Commercial establishments like restaurants also don’t provide parking to their customers. So, most people leave their rides on footpaths of Whitefield Main Road and ITPL Main Road,” said an officer with the traffic police. “We tow vehicles away, but it doesn’t the desired impact.”

A senior official said a traffic subdivision would be started in Whitefield this year. The proposed division will have four to six police stations and over 100 personnel. Currently, Whitefield and nearby areas are part of the east traffic division.

“We have been demanding a separate traffic division for Whitefield for years now. There have been a number of fatal accidents and pedestrians are forced to walk on the road as pavements are full of parked vehicles. There are not enough traffic police personnel on the ground,” said a member of citizens’ group Whitefield Rising.

Title: Vadodara: Two aides of a temple priest held for threatening woman
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: Warasia police arrested two aides of temple priest of Shri Baglamukhi Brahmastra Vidya Mandir in connection with a threat complaint filed against him. Police arrested Kiran Chandani and her daughter Pinky Chandani after they got a tip-off about their whereabouts on Thursday.

Temple priest Baglamukhi Prashant Upadhyay, who is the prime accused, is still on the run. Police said they had issued a lookout notice for Upadhyay. Kiran and Pinky were accused of threatening Minaxi Shah, who was a follower of Upadhyay.

According to Shah, her younger son Kalpesh was a follower of Upadhyay and used to go to the temple regularly. In 2006, Kalpesh had asked his elder brother Jignesh to come and attend Upadhyay’s sermons to which the latter refused. Kalpesh, however, continued visiting the temple and spent most of his time there.

Shah told the cops that one day when she went to meet Kalpesh in the temple he was nowhere to be seen. When she asked Upadhyay about her son, he told her that she shouldn’t worry and that Kalpesh will return home soon. Kalpesh didn’t return for many days and Upadhyay began avoiding her.

Shah was told that Kalpesh was working at Upadhyay’s house in Gotri as helper but she couldn’t find him there too. Kalpesh suddenly resurfaced after a decade in 2017. But he again went to Delhi after telling Shah that he will have to spend nine months there. When Kalpesh again went missing, Shah approached Upadhyay who didn’t give her proper answers. She then submitted an application to police.

Shah said that when Upadhyay learned about her move, he started threatening her to withdraw her complaint.

Later, Upadhyay’s two aides Kiran and Pinky came to her house on Warasia Ring Road and threatened her of dire consequences if she spoke ill about the priest.

The woman registered a police complaint against Upadhyay who is already facing probe in a cheating case filed by a businessman.

Title: Snowfall may be key to why some Himalayan glaciers aren’t melting
Content: Face shields for an added protection when you step out of your home

Title: Ponda to host Carnival event on February 25
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

PONDA: The Carnival parade at Ponda will be sponsored by the state government after Ponda legislator Ravi Naik intervened and met chief minister Pramod Sawant and tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar .

Ponda Municipal Council chairperson Venkatesh Naik said the Ponda Carnival would be celebrated on February 25 instead of February 23 that was previously finalised, to avoid overlapping of a similar event at a nearby town.

The Carnival parade would follow the same route this year, from Casa Menino to Tisk Ponda, Naik said.

In keeping with tradition of having a different King Momo here, Melvyn Fernandes will lead the parade at Ponda.

Meanwhile, the Mapusa Carnival parade will be held on February 25, 3pm onwards, from St Jerome’s Church. The festivities that will commence on February 22 will be organised by the Mapusa Carnival Committee.

A host of events that include Goan traditional dance, live music, and a performace by Lorna have been lined up from Saturday onwards leading up to the parade day.

Title: Food outlets fined Rs 80,000 for selling misbranded products
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: The Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) on Thursday imposed fine of Rs 80,000 on various food outlets for selling misbranded items.

During RMC’s inspection it was found that that non-alcoholic beer being sold at Shiv Shakti traders of Vaniya Vadi road, had no FSSAI license number mentioned on the bottles. It was also not clear from where the beer was imported. The civic body imposed a fine of Rs 25,000 on the owners of the trading firm.

The civic body officials also imposed a fine of Rs 25,000 on Jokar Gathiya on Jawahar road. The unit was found using synthetic colour in the papaya sauce serve with gathiya.

RMC health officials found that Shree Gurukrupa Bhel house on Kalavad Road too was using synthetic colours in sweet chatni. Owner of the unit was fined Rs 15,000. Maruti Shopping store on University Road was found selling rotten peanuts and was fined Rs 15,000.

According to a statement issued by the RMC, a sample of chikki taken from Santosh Season Store taken a few days back had failed quality test because the packet did not mention FSSAI license number, nutritional value and date of packaging and expiry, which is mandatory under the Food Safety and Standard Act-2006.

Title: Meet on gender studies held
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: The Yeshwantrao Chavan College, Sillod, recently organised one-day national conference on “Gender Studies: Literature, Culture , Media and Society .”

During the meet, Prabhakar Palodkar, former Zilla Parishad president, said that growth in crimes against women are a shameful to the “so-called modern” society.

Palodkar, who is also president of the Rajarshi Education Society, Sillod, asserted that that the judiciary should play a vital role in ensuring justice to victims and that setting up of fast track courts can help give justice to the victims.

He said that the conference was inaugurated by Dr M A Waheed, a retired professor of the Osmania University, Hyderabad.

Title: BJP MLA slams construction along Vishwamitri riverbank
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Enough margin had not been left out while constructing buildings on the banks of the river, alleges MLA Shaile... Read More

VADODARA: The constructions on the bank of Vishwamitri sparked a row in the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) general board meeting on Thursday. Not only the opposition, but the ruling BJP MLA and corporator Shailesh Mehta alias Sotta also raised the issue.

Mehta has been making critical remarks about the state of affairs in the civic body since Wednesday. On Wednesday, he had targeted the civic body over the issue of newly constructed residential schemes not being given water connections despite being occupied and had also raised difficult questions about town planning schemes sent by VMC to the state government not getting approved.

The discussion on Vishwamitri began with leader of opposition Chandrakant Shrivastava alias Bhattu raising the issue of how the purpose of use of green belt land along the river was changed to residential or commercial. Mehta too joined the discussion and questioned such constructions.

Mehta said that enough margin had not been left out while constructing buildings on the banks of the river. He said that this was in clear violation of rules. Mehta said that he had raised the issue even when the permissions for the buildings were given, but nothing was done by the civic body.

He also pointed out that land on the banks that was earmarked for housing schemes for the poor was shown as the location for the Swarnim Garden and then for the crocodile park.

Mehta slammed the administration saying that issues were being raised in the general board, but nothing was done regarding them. He said that the administration should look into the representations and tell the general board members if they were right or wrong.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Retired Allahabad high court judge booked for ‘beating cop at CAA meet’
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Mushaffey Ahmad

PILIBHIT: A retired judge of the Allahabad high court was among 33 people booked for allegedly “assaulting and illegally confining” a police constable during discussions on CAA and NRC held on private premises in Pilibhit on February 13.

Mushaffey Ahmad, who served as a judge in the high court between 2012 and 2013, told TOI that he had not attended the gathering but had counselled some members of the group when they met him the same day to seek advice on how to express their views on CAA and NRC without violating laws.

Police booked the 33 identified individuals and 100 unidentified people under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 188 (disobedience to order promulgated by public servant), 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 333 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt to public servant), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 342 (wrongful confinement), 506 (criminal intimidation) and section 7 of Criminal Law Amendment Act.

Ahmad said on Thursday that he was “shocked to see my name in the FIR. I wasn’t even present in the meeting. I had met the group and told them that this gathering would be in violation of section 144 of the CrPC that is in force in the district, but that peaceful expression of their views was well within their constitutional rights”.

The 68-year-old also said that he found it “hard to believe” that a constable was assaulted at the meeting and confined overnight. He added, “Suppressing peaceful protests against CAA and NRC is unfortunate for the democratic values of the country as well as the dignity of the Indian constitution.”

He has now approached the chief justice of Allahabad HC and sought a high-level probe into the matter. “Policemen should be booked for falsely implicating me in an FIR. I will also meet the home secretary in this regard.”

Asked if police knew that Ahmad was a retired judge, officiating SHO, Pilibhit Kotwali police station, Mukesh Chand, said, “This can only be answered by the SHO who lodged the FIR. The SHO, Srikant Dwivedi, is on a week-long leave.”

Police stuck to their version that constable Dushyant Kumar was assaulted. A police officer said, “The protesters caught him and thrashed him. They even dragged him to an adjoining house and locked him up before threatening to kill him if he raised an alarm. However, he managed to escape on Friday and reached the police station where he narrated his ordeal.”

Congress district president Harpreet Singh Chaba, Bhim Army district president Atul Valmiki, district in-charge of Rashtriya Kisan Majdoor Sangathan Yusuf Malik and five women were among the 33 people booked for the incident.

Meanwhile, a joint delegation of Swaraj Abhiyan, UP Coordination Committee against CAA, NRC and Samvidhan Rakshak Sabha visited the area on Thursday. Ajit Singh Yadav , a member of Swaraj Abhiyan’s national working committee, alleged that police had lodged a false FIR. “Mohammad Bi whose house Kumar was supposedly dragged into and confined has denied such an incident. She said that her house had CCTVs and the footage can easily reveal the truth.”

Title: Court denies bail to three in Narol fire case
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A sessions court on the Mirzapur rural court campus on Thursday rejected bail applications filed by three officials of Nandan Denim Ltd in Narol, where a unit had caught fire resulting in the deaths of seven employees earlier this month.

While rejecting the bail pleas filed by the company’s director P K Sharma, general manager of the shirting division B C Patel and fire safety officer Ravikant Sinha, the court said that the settlement between the victims’ kin and the accused by paying them compensation of Rs 10 lakh each cannot be a grounds for the court to show leniency to the accused.

Title: NDMC gears up for US President Donald Trump's visit
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

US President Donald Trump. (AP photo)

NEW DELHI: The New Delhi Municipal Council ( NDMC ) has initiated a special beautification and cleanliness drive before the arrival of United States President Donald Trump and his delegation.

NDMC has also arranged for 10,000-15,000 pots of selected flowers near gate numbers 1, 37 and 38 of Rastrapati Bhavan, and at Hyderabad House and other roundabouts in addition to seasonal plants, including tulips, already adorning these places.

“We have made flower boards to welcome dignitaries and going to install them at prominent spots on the route of the delegation,” said a senior official of the horticulture department. While most of the flower pots were ready in its nurseries, multi-colour hybrid dahlias have been ordered from outside the city as the appropriate temperature and season for their blooming is yet to arrive in Delhi, the official added.

The sanitation department has also formed teams for intensive cleaning of roads using machi-nes at regular intervals.

Title: UPPCB slaps Rs 9 crore fine on seven godown owners for storing animal skin illegally in Moradabad
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bareilly: Coming down heavily on the godown operators for illegally storing animal skins, triggering air pollution and flouting UPPCB norms, the Pollution Control Board has imposed a hefty penalty of Rs 9.58 crore on seven godown operators in Asalatpura area of UP’s Moradabad. Officials at UPPCB said that during inspections, the godowns were found to be flouting norms and they did lack pollution control system.

Officials at Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board, Moradabad, said that after repeated complaints from local residents regarding illegal operations and foul smell in the residential area, inspections were conducted last year and seven godowns were found to be operating illegally under Galshaheed police station limits. An inquiry was ordered from the headquarters and legal action has now been taken.

Speaking with TOI, UPPCB regional officer Ajay Sharma said, “Earlier, animal skins in huge quantities were recovered from the godowns located in Asalatpura area and initial inspections had also revealed that the operators did not follow the legal procedure. The godowns did not acquire licences or no-objection certificates (NOC) from the pollution control board. A probe was ordered from the Central Pollution Control Board and hefty penalties have now been imposed on the erring godown operators as per NGT guidelines and pollution board norms.”

Sharma added, “A recent inspection of the godowns revealed that cattle skin was being stored in huge quantities. The identified godowns were established in residential areas and were operating against UPPCB’s consent; hence, these were unauthorized. The godowns also did lack mechanism to control pollution and were resulting in contamination of environment.”

The UPPCB has slapped a penalty of Rs 9.58 crore (Rs 1.36 crore each) on godown operators and granted a week’s time to pay the fine; failing which, further legal action will be initiated.

“The district administration has also been asked to restrict operations of the erring godowns. Besides, we have written to the civic authorities and power corporation to disconnect water and power supply to these illegal establishments. The board constantly keeps a tab on the slaughterhouses, godowns registered with UPPCB, to check whether they are flouting norms. The crackdown will continue in the city,” Sharma said.

The Moradabad police had last year launched a major crackdown on people involved in alleged illegal slaughtering of animals under Galshaheed police station, following which, 49 accused persons were arrested. Police had also recovered 117 animals from their possession, including bovines which were kept for slaughter. The police had also recovered meat in large quantity, 12 vehicles and Rs 10 lakh from them.

Title: Withdraw cases against farmers, demands PK
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan asked the state government to lift the criminal cases against capital area farmers for staging protests in front of revenue officials who came for land survey.

“It indicates the autocracy of this government, which is registering cases using different sections of the IPC against farmers who protested in front of revenue officials in Krishnayapalem village under the limits of capital city region. The government is trying to terrorise farmers by foisting cases against 426 people who belong to villages under the limits of the capital city of Amaravati ,” he alleged.

The future of farmers has become uncertain since the announcement of the three capitals proposal, Pawan said, adding that they have been left with no option other than expressing their anger through protests against the government’s decision to distribute lands given by them for building the capital city as house sites to the poor.

Demanding the government withdraw the cases, Pawan said. “The farmers are holding the protests peacefully from day one. The government’s action to file cases without holding talks with them is undemocratic,” he said.

Pawan, who was in Delhi on Thursday, handed over a cheque of Rs 1 crore to the Central Sainik Board which he had announced on the occasion of Armed Forces Flag Day. He also addressed the Indian Students’ Parliament (ISP) at Vigyan Bhavan in the national capital.

Title: Contractual VMC drivers seek regular employment
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

VADODARA: Workers roped in through contractors to drive vehicles of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) went on a flash strike on Thursday demanding that they should be absorbed into service by VMC in the same way as the sanitation workers. They have threatened to continue the stir till their demands are not met.

VMC relies heavily on drivers for its vehicles as it has several vacancies of drivers that are not being filled up. It ropes in vendors to supply it drivers who drive vehicles ranging from official cars of functionaries to trucks and other heavy vehicles.

Gujarat Mazdoor Sena general secretary Manoj Pandit said that there were around 250 vacancies of drivers that could be filled up giving employment to drivers already working for VMC through contractors.

“Interviews were also conducted earlier, but appointments were not made,” he said.

Title: Region has irrigation backlog of Rs4.5k cr: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: Water management experts on Thursday said that the government, over a period of last nine years, owes irrigation backlog to the tune of Rs 4,500 crore towards Marathwada.

Addressing a summit on water issues, Shankar Nagare, expert member (irrigation) of Marathwada Development Board, said the state government kept the region starved for funds, but released money for Amravati division.

“Amravati division kept receiving funds towards irrigation backlog on a regular basis since 2010. However, Marathwada did not get the same relief. If we assume release of minimum Rs 500 crore ever year, Marathwada has huge irrigation backlog of Rs 4,500 crore,” he said.

Raising the issue of alleged additional irrigation projects constructed in the upstream areas of Jayakwadi major irrigation project in Nashik and Ahmednagar districts, Nagare said such dams have a combined intake capacity of 45 TMC.

“The state government must compensate Marathwada for its share of water snatched by upstream areas. To achieve this, the government must divert excess water from Konkan to Marathwada via Vaitarna dam,” he said.

Nagare, a former executive director of Godavari Marathwada Irrigation Development Corporation (GMIDC), also highlighted the key provisions of Nagpur Pact, 1953.

“As per the pact, Marathwada needs 150 TMC water in order to take the region at par with the state in terms of irrigation and other needs. Considering the 18 TMC water required for efficient functioning of the proposed Water Grid project for Marathwada, the region needs total 168 TMC water to become water-sufficient. The government must ensure this by diverting water from basins of other rivers,” he said.

Senior lawyer and president of advocacy group Marathwada Janta Vikas Parishad Pradeep Deshmukh raised the issue of alleged miscalculations while deciding equitable distribution of water for Marathwada.

“The water needs of Ahmednagar and Nashik districts are inflated, while that of Aurangabad , Jalna, Beed, Parbhani and Nanded are deflated while deciding equitable distribution. The stock of water available in minor irrigation projects from Ahmednagar and Nashik districts remain unaccounted ever year. These two districts together consume 42 TMC water and it is never taken into account,” he said.

Addressing the summit, water management expert Pradeep Purandare shed light on the effect of climate change and its possible impacts.

“The average annual temperature of Marathwada is 26.46 degrees celsius. As per credible studies, it is likely to increase by 1.44 degrees celsius to 1.56 degrees celsius by 2030 and further in the range of 2.15 degrees celsius to 2.3 degrees celsius by 2050. This increase could lead to surge in evaporation and evapotranspiration, which could affect net irrigation requirement and possible decline the crop yield,” he said.

Title: No nod yet for Margao tableau route says Government to High court
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

High court of Bombay at Goa

PANAJI: The government has not granted any permissions for the Carnival parade to be held on the old route in Margao on February 23.

The high court of Bombay at Goa is hearing a petition filed by Custodio Dias challenging the holding of the parade through the town.

Additional government advocate Pravin Faldessai told the court on Thursday that no permissions have been issued yet to hold the parade on the old route—the national highway which runs from Holy Spirit Church via Hospicio Hospital to the Margao municipal building.

He stated that no permissions have been issued yet, although the government has received a proposal from the carnival organisation committee to hold the parade on this route.

Faldessai said he will place the material on the basis of which the proposal will be considered, before the court on Friday.

The high court issued a notice that is returnable on Friday to the Margao Carnival Committee.

The Carnival committee had decided to shift the Carnival parade held last year at Fatorda to the traditional route in the town.

The Carnival parade routes at Mapusa and Vasco will remain unchanged.

Title: Gujarat HC seeks CP’s affidavit on continuous use of Section 144 CrPC
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court on Thursday ordered the city police commissioner to file an affidavit in reply to a petition challenging the continued imposition of Section 144 of the CrPC and Section 37 of the Bombay Police Act restraining a gathering of more than four persons in public places in Ahmedabad.

Earlier this month, an assistant commissioner of police had filed an affidavit in which he had tried to justify the continuous application of restraining provisions in the city. Justice S H Vora, however, said that a reply filed by any other officer, but the commissioner of police would not work. Since the notifications for imposition of restraining sections are issued in the name of the police commissioner, he should file an affidavit and reply to the court’s queries. The HC has sought the commissioner’s reply by March 6, sources said.

On February 5, an assistant commissioner of police told the HC that there were 496 incidents of rioting reported in Ahmedabad in last three years. His affidavit said that if the restrictions are removed, it “would lead to chaos in law and order situation in Ahmedabad”. The affidavit had also claimed that imposition of Section 144 of CrPC has “benign” effects too and enumerated five such beneficial effects.

The HC has also asked the cops to respond to its query that why the continued restraint orders on part of the police should not be perceived as if the city is under constant threat.

Five petitioners including a faculty member of the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad (IIM-A) has challenged the police action after people were not allowed to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in the city two months ago.

Title: Hindu Sena sings paeans to US President Donald Trump
Content:
In 2017, photos of the Hindu Sena chief feeding Trump’s poster had gone viral.

NEW DELHI: The Right-wing fringe group , Hindu Sena , which had earlier celebrated US President Donald Trump ’s birthday by cutting a cake , has welcomed his upcoming India tour. Calling him a “hero”, they have recorded a song to welcome him.“We will celebrate his arrival in India as we consider him a saviour of humanity,” said the Hindu Sena chief Vishnu Gupta.In the video of the song, the group has hailed Trump as one who cut Pakistan to size and eliminated global threats with the killing of ISIS chief Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. They also hailed the US for the assassination of Iranian general Qasem Soleimani.In the 1 minute 46 second video, Gupta and his followers are seen singing the song while holding a piece of cake in front of Trump’s photo. It also had visuals of explosions and Trump with PM Narendra Modi. They have also used a photo of Trump standing on an Abrams tank holding a sniper rifle. The logo of Hindu Sena is pasted under it.Hindu Sena has appealed to all Indian-Americans to vote for Trump in the next US presidential election with the slogan “Phir Ek Bar, Trump Sarkar”. “As the US presidential election will be held later this year, Hindu Sena appeals to all Indian-Americans to vote for Mr Donald Trump and help make America great again so that India-US ties grow and prosper hand-in-hand,” said Gupta, concluding with “Bharat Mata ki Jai”.In 2017, photos of Gupta feeding Trump’s photo on his birthday went viral on social media. The outfit cut a cake weighing 7.1kg in New Delhi. In 2016 too, the group had held a havan for Trump, wishing him success in the US general election, which he won.

Title: Woman calls off wedding after she sees groom hitting sis in public
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bareilly: A display of bad temper and misbehaviour with his sister cost an Army man dear at his wedding as his bride-to-be refused to go through with it. When she saw the groom hit his sister with a chair in front of all the guests as she had refused to stop dancing, the bride considered it to be a glimpse of her fiancé’s real character. She said, “Today, he beat up his sister, in future he may mistreat me as well. I choose not to spend my life with a short-tempered man who has no respect for women.”

It all started in a banquet hall in Meerganj here on Wednesday. The wedding ceremonies of a Devhari village resident of Rampur district and woman of Lakha village in Shishgarh area in Bareilly were underway. The “ghud-chadhi” ceremony had been completed and the groom was sitting on the stage decorated for the couple-to-be.

According to witnesses, guests from groom’s side were dancing on the DJ floor. His younger sister joined them, dancing with gusto. For some reason, seeing the young girl dancing annoyed the groom. He asked her to leave the dance floor. But the girl did not pay any heed to her brother and continued to dance.

This enraged the groom who lost his cool. He went up to the dance floor, picked up a chair and flung it at his sister, hitting her. His behavior stunned the guests to silence.

Meanwhile, the bride had arrived on the stage with a “var-mala (wedding garland) in her hands. After witnessing the entire episode, she about- turned and walked off the stage. It is learnt that the groom was also drunk.

Back in her room, woman asked her parents to cancel the marriage.

Upon learning the bride’s decision, the groom’s family was furious and confronted her family members who had already alerted police.

Vijay Kumar, SHO, said police reached the wedding venue and tried to broker a compromise between both families, but in vain. The “baraat” went back without solemnising the marriage, the SHO added.

Title: Four robbers arrested in Anjar
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Rajkot: Four robbers were arrested on Wednesday for their alleged involvement in loot of Rs16 lakh in Anjar of Kutch district in December 2018.

Police said Harsh Thakkar (19), Deepak Thakkar (27) and Chandresh Bhatia (24) had allegedly provided information about the victim to main accused. Also arrested was Karan Bhatia (26), one of the accused, who had committed the loot.

Bhatia, Haresh Makwana, Mahendra Gohil, Vinod Vaghela and Sagar Nai had thrown chilli powder in the eyes of a staffer of an automobile showroom and snatched his bag containing Rs16 lakh cash before fleeing on their motorcycles.

“We arrested the accused on the basis of a tip-off about their hideout in Gandhidham,” said M S Rana, sub-inspector with Gandhidham local crime branch.

Title: Discoms to deploy drones to monitor power network
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The drones will provide BSES field teams a bird’s eye view of the potential problem areas.

NEW DELHI: BSES discoms in the city have drawn an elaborate programme for using drones for monitoring the electricity network, including high-voltage (HV) lines and grid substations.

Using high-resolution imagery and infrared thermo scanning, it will involve inspection of the overhead lines and equipment, grid substations, connections, damaged switches, capacitors, detection of theft of equipment and intelligent line profiling, an official said.

This will provide BSES’ field teams with a bird’s eye view of the potential problem areas (physical condition of the assets and hotspots) and help in taking preventive actions by flagging irregularities timely.

“BSES discoms are committed to ensuring quality and reliable power supply. For this, the discoms have been exploring and deploying the latest and suitable technologies in their areas of operation. Preventive and predictive maintenance of the existing distribution network holds the key in ensuring seamless power supply,” he said.

According to him, the BSES drone programme, which has already taken off, will be used for accurately mapping assets on the GIS with high accuracy, power theft detection, inspection of rooftop solar installations, accurate assessment of rooftop solar potential along with obstructions and assessment of vegetation encroachment (around discom infrastructure).

The BSES Yamuna Power Limited (BYPL), which operates in east and central Delhi, and BSES Rajdhani Power Limited (BRPL), which operates in south and west Delhi, have collaborated with Garuda UAV, a leading drone service provider, for visual and thermal mapping of the electrical infrastructure.

According to a BSES spokesperson, timely detection of potential trouble spots and issues plays a crucial role in ensuring reliable power supply. “Though BSES has a very robust system of undertaking preventing and predictive maintenance of its distribution network, the use of drone technology will be a force multiplier in its arsenal. It will help the discom in faster patrolling, accurate capturing of data using high-definition images and videos, hotspot identification and better preventive maintenance to lesser outages,” the spokesperson said.

Title: Lions prey on a bull on Rajula-Pipavav road
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

RAJKOT: Two lions were seen moving freely on Rajula-Pipavav road in Amreli district on Wednesday.

The scene captured in the CCTV camera of a hotel shows the lions preying on a bull and thereafter feasting on it. Even the locals were surprised by the late night incident.

Title: Make judicious use of water, says minister
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Aurangabad: Cabinet minister Rajesh Tope on Thursday said that water conservation should become the DNA of people in Marathwada region.

“Marathwada is a drought-prone region and has been facing more vagaries of monsoon since years. All stakeholders, including residents, farmers and industries must ensure judicious use of water,” he said.

Addressing a water summit organized by Shiv Sena functionary and former city MP Chandrakant Khaire in the city on Thursday, Tope stressed on the need of improving water distribution network of major dams from Marathwada.

“The canal systems of key dams such as Jayakwadi and Lower Dudhna are in poor shape, causing distribution losses. The poor distribution network restricts the dam water from reaching the tail-end. Even if official records show a certain amount of water release, the discharge does not reach the target areas,” he said.

Tope also stressed upon the need for diversion of water from different river basins towards Marathwada.

“Diversion of water from Krishna Basin can address water woes of some parts of the region, includingsome areas in Beed, Osmanabad and Latur districts. The excess rainwater flowing into the sea in the Konkan area must also be diverted for the benefit of Marathwada. Routing excess water from Painganga River towards Marathwada can offer relief to parts of Nanded district and nearby areas,” the minister said.

Earlier in his introductory speech, Khaire said that the water summit was organized as per the suggestion of chief minister Uddhav Thackeray.

“Different resource persons have been invited for the summit. We will be preparing a list of key demands based on the discussions and deliberations discussed during the event. The demands will be presented before the chief minister, who is expected to give justice to it during the upcoming session of the state legislature,” he said.

Title: Rape survivor seeks Gujarat HC nod to abortion 22-week fetus
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

Title: Top cop leads drive against history-sheeters
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nashik: Police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil led a team of over 200 police personnel in a two-hour special drive against history-sheeters.

During the operation, police took action against 89 criminals. Four police officers of deputy commissioner of police rank were also part of the drive that started on February 18 at 11pm and continued till 1am on Wednesday.

“Various teams were formed for the exercise in different areas of the city including at Sinnar Phata, Ambad and Cidco. These teams checked over 336 vehicles and took action against 26 for violations of various natures. We also collected Rs 6,000 as fines from errant motorists,” a police officer said.

According to police, the teams scanned 26 slums and took action against 26 people for nefarious activities.

“The teams also scanned 84 dhabas, lodges and hotels during the special drive. We were on the lookout for 129 history-sheeters and during the drive 89 of them were arrested. Similarly we took action against 29 miscreants against whom summons/warrants were issued,” the officer added.

Another police officer, part of the drive, said similar exercises will be undertaken in the future as well to keep a check on criminals.

Title: Tauqeer Raza to surrender before Sambhal police: IMC
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bareilly: After an FIR was lodged against Sunni Barelvi cleric Maulana Tauqeer Raza Khan for allegedly making derogatory remarks against PM Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah during an anti-CAA protest in Sambhal, Ittehad-e-Millat Council (IMC) on Thursday announced that the cleric along with his supporters will go to Sambhal to surrender before police.

Nafees Khan, national general secretary and spokesperson of IMC, said, “Maulana Tauqeer Raza has been accused of using foul language against leaders holding constitutional posts but no FIR has been lodged against the people who passed objectionable remarks against Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal and women silently protesting against CAA. By lodging FIRs against us, police want to suppress our voice against CAA, National Register of Citizens and the proposed National Population Register (NPR).

A meeting of IMC members took place here on Thursday against the FIR lodged against the cleric. Nafees Khan said, “Maulana Tauqeer the proposed National Population Register. However, we are ready to face more FIRs. We are not against police and administration but we are protesting against government’s policy.”

Raza Khan is currently visiting Hyderabad and Bihar. When he is back to Bareilly, he along with his supporters will surrender en masse before Sambhal police.”

Title: College students should get tested for thalassemia and sickle cell
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: Vice-president of Maharashtra Medical Council and Director of Thalassemia and Sickle Cell Centre, Dr Vinky Rughwani recently met the vice-chancellor of Rashtrasant Tukadoji Maharaj Nagpur University, Dr S P Kane recently and apprised him of the problems faced by thalassemia and sickle cell patients.

Rughwani explained that these two diseases could be brought under control only if precautions are taken by checking thalassemia minor and sickle cell trait test of every student taking admission in the university. Once this trait is found, precautions could be taken to ensure that children are not born with any major disease. Kane assured Rughwani that steps would be taken to issue instructions to all colleges regarding check up concerning thalassemia and sickle cell trait.

Title: RMC begins clearing solid waste at Nakravadi site
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Disposal of municipal solid waste generated by Rajkot city was stopped abruptly

Rajkot: Over six years after disposal of the ‘legacy’ waste of 4 lakh tonne solid waste at landfill site Nakravadi was halted, the Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) resumed work on Thursday.

The disposal of municipal solid waste (MSW) generated by Rajkot city was stopped abruptly in December 2013 after the agency assigned the job backed out. The RMC was only able to appoint the second agency after three years of efforts but that agency also failed to resume work.

Finally on Thursday, the third agency appointed by the civic body began clearing the MSW from the landfill site spread across 6 acres. Sources said that garbage heap, over the years, had grown to size of a six floor building. Rajkot city generated about 600 tonnes of solid waste everyday.

RMC environment engineer Nilesh Parmar said, “At Nakravadi a machine that segregate plastic, organic waste and other type of waste has been installed. From plastic waste Refuse Derived Fuel (RDF) will be generated which has a calorific value of 3,000.”

He said that the fuel will be used to run the waste-to-energy power plant that will produce 14MW electricity. The power will be supplied to the state-run power distributor Paschim Gujarat Vij Company Ltd (PGVCL).

The waste-to-energy plant at Nakaravadi was inaugurated last month. The waste collection at Nakaravadi over the years had created health issues for surrounding villages. A new landfill site has been made about 100 meters from the old site in 15 acre land.

Title: Delhi: Four new clips of rioters storming Jamia Millia Islamia library with stones emerge
Content:
Rioters carrying stone enter the campus

NEW DELHI: Fresh CCTV footage has emerged of the December 15 violence in which stone-pelters can be seen rushing inside Dr Zakir Husain library at Jamia Millia Islamia . In another footage, a group of masked youths is seen pelting stones at students. Police suspect that the stone-pelters, who used the library as a safe haven, were trying to flare up the situation.On Thursday, the Special Investigation Team (SIT) of Crime Branch issued a notice to 10 Jamia students who had got their medico-legal case done after the riots. Four of them told the SIT their version of the events. They were also shown photographs of some of the masked suspects for identification.Sources said on Wednesday, four new videos surfaced from cameras installed at the entrance of the new library and gate number 7 of the university. Around 5.06pm, a group of youths is seen pelting stones at a police team. They had divided themselves into teams of two, one of whom pelted stones while the other supplied them with it.In the second video, which is time-stamped 6.20pm, a crowd comprising 50-60 people is seen rushing into the library. Two youths with their faces covered are seen picking up stones kept near the stairway and throwing them at the police teams. They then run inside the library. Around the same time, another group is seen shutting the library door and placing tables against it to block police from entering.The third clip recovered from gate number 7 shows youths walking in carrying stones. A few outside are seen pelting stones. When the guard at the gate tries to stop the stone-pelters, they threaten him and walk inside to join the students inside the library.Another footage of 6.27pm shows a group pelting stones at students inside the library. One of their associates, who also has his face covered, stops them and pushes them out.Police said efforts are being made to identify the masked men mingling with the students to evade the cops who had entered the university premises to nab them.Sources said the stone-pelters had used the students as a shield and hidden on the university premises. This was evident from the interrogation of the 17 people who were arrested after the riots. The arrested people claimed that some former and current students of Jamia had advised them to use the university as a safe haven on the presumption that police would not enter the premises without permission.The SIT has also recovered the duty roster of the policemen present during the riots and will question them individually. Senior officers said that strict action will be taken against the policemen seen smashing CCTV cameras.In Video: Fresh CCTV footage emerges in Jamia violence; pelters seen rushing inside the library

Title: Panaji: Congress may not contest Zilla Panchayat elections on party lines
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

GPCC members opposed the BJP government’s attempt to trample on the Constitution and amend provision of reserv... Read More

PANAJI: Peeved over the delay in announcing the reservation of seats for the Zilla Panchayat elections, Congress MLAs met on Thursday and unanimously decided that it was in the party’s interests not to fight the elections on party lines.

The MLAs, who have yet to convey their decision to state party president Girish Chodankar, said that they would back the candidates informally.

“There is confusion around the reservation of seats. They (state Election Commission) has made a mess of it. Because they are not creating a level-playing field, we felt that we should not contest the ZP elections on party lines,” opposition leader and Margao MLA Digambar Kamat said.

“We will convey the same to the party president. Ultimately the party president has to decide and convey the message to party workers,” Kamat said.

Chodankar said that he would call an executive committee meeting to discuss the decision taken by the CLP regarding the ZP polls.

“I will abide by whatever decision the executive committee takes,” Chodankar said.

However, insiders said that the Congress camp remains divided over the issue of fighting the ZP elections under the Congress banner. Many party workers rue that after the elections are held, the winning candidates sometimes change loyalties.

Title: MHA studying ED's report linking PFI to anti-CAA stir
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: The home ministry is examining a report submitted recently by the Enforcement Directorate alleging a link between Popular Front of India (PFI) and the ongoing protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ).

"The home ministry has received the report from the ED on PFI and it is being examined," a government official said.

He added that the central government had also received inputs from some state governments and other agencies on PFI's alleged involvement in anti-CAA protests . PFI, on its part, has denied its link with any anti-CAA protest in the country.

The ED report is purportedly based on disclosures made by some PFI functionaries during questioning in connection with a money laundering probe against the outfit and an NGO linked to it.

Half-a-dozen office-bearers of the Kerala-based organisation were questioned by the ED early this month about the finances, expenditure, sources of funding and beneficiaries of the funds generated or distributed by it. TNN

The central probe agency, sources said, also recorded their statements under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA).

The ED is probing PFI and NGO Rehab India Foundation (RIF) under criminal provisions of the PMLA as part of an enforcement case information report (ECIR) or FIR filed in 2018. It is also probing charges that the organisations received and distributed funds from their bank accounts that were allegedly used to fuel some protests against the CAA in various parts of the country.

Title: Man booked for ‘bid to cause riots’ ahead of Donald Trump's Ahmedabad visit
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

A screebgrab of Thakor’s post

AHMEDABAD: Crime branch officials on Thursday said they had arrested a man for allegedly posting a video showing a few hawkers’ carts being demolished by a JCB machine and alleged that poor people’s lives had become miserable ahead of US president Donald Trump ’s visit to Ahmedabad.

City crime branch in a statement said that the Vinod Thakor, 31, a resident of Shankheswar in Patan district and the president of the Congress social media cell in Patan had tried to instigate people ahead of Trump’s visit on February 24. The statement says officials of crime branch and cyber cell were keeping tabs on social media posts ahead of Trump’s visit.

A PSI of the wireless cell, H N Prajapati, on February 9 saw the post by Thakor. Thakor had written: “As the US president is coming to Ahmedabad, the BJP government is ruining the lives of poor people.” Thakor had shared a video showing purported workers breaking carts with vegetables and fruits on them with a JCB.

The crime branch statement claims Thakor had instigated people by attributing the video to Gujarat even though it was from Odisha. Prahapati then filed a complaint with city crime branch under IPC Sections 153 (provocative statements with intent to cause riots) and 504 (intentional insult to provoke breach of peace).

The statement says Thakor was arrested from his house at Khodiyarnagar Society in Shankheswar town of Patan district late on Wednesday night. Crime branch officials did not clarify how Thakor was booked for attempting to cause riots over the wrongly attributed video. Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation commissioner Vijay Nehra had on February 17 tweeted a clarification about the video, stating that it was not from the city and but from Odisha, while citing a report by a fact-check portal.

Title: Bharat bandh: Join day of revolution, says Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad at Hauz Rani
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad speaks to media during a protest march from Mandi House to Jantar Mantar, ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Urging people to participate in the Bharat bandh on Sunday, Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad addressed the anti-CAA protesters in Hauz Rani on Thursday evening. The protest at Hauz Rani has been going on for over a month now.

Azad walked up to the stage with the Constitution in his hand and began the address saying: “I am going to give an outrageous speech.” It was followed by him reading out the Preamble even as the protesters repeated it behind him.

“People, who are following the Constitution and stating what’s written in it, are being called out for giving outrageous statements. Any revolution begins with a single spark and here it began through Shaheen Bagh and Jama Masjid. I have visited seven states and everywhere the protests are going strong,” claimed Azad.

While important issues of the country are being sidelined, discriminatory laws are being introduced, he alleged.

While most of the protesters refused to speak to the media, a few identified themselves as “Hindustan” and “Bharat.”

The Bhim Army spokesperson said Azad would visit three other anti-CAA protest sites on Thursday night.

“Muslims have taken the responsibility of saving the country. I want the youth and others to participate so that the protest can grow stronger. The government should remember that we can continue the protest for five more years,” Azad added.

He urged people to shut their shops on Sunday and paste posters reading “Aaj Bharat bandh hai” on their doors. “It’s a day of revolution and we all need to come out and protest peacefully,” Azad said.

Title: Crack down on city school vehicles soon: RTO
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Bareilly: To ensure that children are ferried safely to school and back, Bareilly Regional Transport Officer (RTO) is set to step up its enforcement drive against erring school vehicles plying on city roads.

According to the information from Bareilly RTO, around 450 school vehicles are being operated on city roads and of these, most of the vehicles are run on contract basis. Earlier this month, around 300 school vehicles were checked by the transport authorities and around 65 drivers were issued challans for flouting various traffic rules.

Giving details about the latest move, transport authorities said all school vehicles will be checked to see if the safety norms set by the government and Supreme Court are in place. Under these norms it is mandatory for the vehicles to have first-aid kits, fire extinguishing device, an alarm system and speed governors. It is also mandatory that an attendant is present in school buses. Besides, the vehicles will also be inspected to ensure that general traffic rules are being followed. These relate to overloading, speeding, use of seat belt by driver and vehicle fitness among other norms.

Officials said school vehicles not having CCTV cameras are being exempted for the present.

Speaking with TOI, senior assistant regional transport officer (ARTO), Bareilly, RP Singh said, “The department is gearing up to intensify the enforcement activity against erring school vehicles across the city and a plan is being prepared for the drive. We have been planning frequent drives to check school vehicles as it is a matter of concern among parents as violation of Motor Vehicle norms is very common among school vehicles. The drive will be taken up shortly to check if they have necessary equipment like a first-aid kit, fire extinguisher and alarm system among others. Besides, we will be checking whether an attendant has been appointed in the vehicles, especially in buses, whether the drivers are using seatbelts, etc.”

Officials said the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act calls for installation of CCTV cameras and global positioning system in vehicles besides a display of driver’s details. These are being exempted for now. “The vehicle operators who do not have these devices will be served notices and time will be granted to them to install them,” added the ARTO.

Title: Thread unit catches fire
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

A major fire broke out in a thread manufacturing unit near Rajgadh village

A major fire broke out in a thread manufacturing unit near Rajgadh village of Dhrangadhra taluka in Surendranagar district on Thursday afternoon.

Fire tenders from Dhrangadhra, Morbi, Halvad and Surendranagar rushed to the spot for carrying out a firefighting operation. The cotton bales caught fire possibly due to a short-circuit. The fire was not doused till the time of going to the press.

Title: CAA: Muslim women in Malegaon continue stir
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nashik: The ongoing peaceful sit-in stir by a section of Muslim women of Malegaon, to protest against CAA and the proposed NRC, completed one month on Thursday.

These women had started the agitation drawing inspiration from their counterparts in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh. Haji Md Yusuf Md Illyas, the chief of the Sunni Council of Malegaon, said the peaceful stir by the Malegaon women would continue as long as the Shaheen Bagh protestors continued their agitation.

“I am unable to look after my child’s studies. But I am determined to be a part of the dharna as our future is at stake,” said Mahrul Nisha Asfaque Ahmed, who has been a part of the agitation from the start. “We are even prepared to continue indefinitely,” she added. According to her, the Malegaon women want to draw the attention to the imperative need to roll back the CAA and the NRC.

The protestors said that, on an average, more than 4,000 women are taking part in the dharna every day at the Hussain Seth compound on Agra Road. The agitation starts at 10am and concludes at 10pm. Programmes like qawwali, mushaira etc, to highlight the adverse impacts of CAA and NRC, are organised at night.

“We fear for the future of the Muslim community if the CAA and NRC are implemented. I have joined the agitation and even my family is supporting me,” added Zulekha Akhil Ahmed, another protester. Nashik rural police have been deploying personnel at the agitation venue every day. “Since women are taking part in the agitation, we have ensured that there is adequate police presence to prevent any kind of untoward incident,” said police sources.

Title: Piaggio to expand e-auto footprint in southern states
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: Italian manufacturer Piaggio, which is known for its two-wheelers and small commercial vehicles, plans to expand its footprint in south India through Ape E-City , its recently-launched e-autorickshaw.

“We launched the Ape E-City electric autorickshaw in December. Vijayawada is the first city in south India where we have launched this vehicle which is assembled at the Piaggio plant in Baramati, Maharashtra. The company is expecting traction in the electric vehicles segment,” Saju ES Nair, executive vice-president, commercial vehicles business, told TOI on Thursday.

Nair said the electric autorickshaw has been designed by Piaggio in Italy. “The battery in our product can be swapped at Ramcor, the dealership in Vijayawada. Each charged battery will give about 60-70 km. The driver can replace his vehicle’s battery at the dealership. He will be charged only for the level of charging needed in the battery, like a pay-as-you-use service,” he added.

He said Piaggio has tied up with Sun Mobility for supply of batteries for the vehicles. “The battery is lithium-ion and can be charged in one hour. We launched in Vijayawada because the autorickshaw provides last-mile connectivity. It has a top speed of 45 km,” he said.

According to KVS Prakash Rao, owner of Ramcor, the street price of the Ape E-City is Rs 2.06 lakh. “The vehicle does not release any pollution because it is battery-driven. It has a digital instrument cluster with information like state of charge, drive modes and service alerts,” Prakash Rao said.

Title: First national waterway floating jetty ready for launch today
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Chief minister Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The first of the four floating jetties planned in the state under the national waterways (NW) project is ready. Union minister of state for shipping Mansukh Mandaviya and chief minister Pramod Sawant will commission it on Friday.

The floating jetty, which is an extension of the existing Captain of Ports (CoP) floating jetty, will serve as a mooring point for boats operated by the offshore casinos, said CoP officials.

According to officials, the concrete floating jetty boasts of fenders, water facilities, fire extinguishing systems, electrical cabling, lights, drainage outlets and pumps in order to facilitate smooth operations of small vessels. A separate location will be setup for discharge and disposal of sewage. It has been setup by Marinetek India as part of the Inland Waterways Authority of India ’s (IWAI) national waterways project.

Around mid-2018, in the face of stiff opposition from locals to the Centre’s river nationalisation plan, the state government, Mormugao Port Trust and IWAI quietly inked a tripartite memorandum of understanding whereby it was agreed that MPT would implement the national waterways project on behalf of IWAI. In October 2018, MPT floated the tender for the design and commissioning of three concrete floating jetties on Mandovi (NW 68) and one on Chapora (NW 25).

At that time, the cost of all four floating jetties was pegged at Rs 13 crore.

According to officials, IWAI has provided the funds for the floating jetties. “The pre-fab work on the pontoons for the second floating jetty at Old Goa has also started and is nearing completion,” said Marinetek India director Gautama Dutta.

The other two floating jetties planned are at the Panaji-Betim ferry point and in the Chapora river, on the west side of Siolim-Chopdem bridge.

Six rivers — Mandovi (44km), Zuari (50km), Cumbharjua (17km), Chapora (33km), Mapusa (27km) and Sal (14km) — in the state have been identified as rivers of national importance under the nationalisation of waterways project.

Title: HC imposes Rs 25k fine on principal secy, forest for not appearing in court
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pilibhit: Justice Munishwar Nath Bhandari and Justice Manish Kumar of the Allahabad High Court’s Lucknow Bench have imposed a fine of Rs 25,000 on principal secretary of forest, UP government, Sudhir Garg for not appearing before the court.

Earlier on January 7, the court had directed the senior official to be present in person before it in connection with a case relating to framing of norms for recruitment of personnel for Special Tiger Protection Force (STPF) in UP and given him six weeks’ time for the same. However, Garg did not appear before the Bench on Monday. Then, the judges imposed a fine on him and directed him to deposit the penalty amount with state legal services authority within 15 days.

Giving this information to TOI along with a copy of the order concerned, Lucknow-based petitioner Satish Kumar Mishra said the penalty was imposed by the court after the Bench observed the principal secretary’s utter disregard of the court’s previous order.

“It was only after the court intended to give notice for contempt to the principal secretary that the latter sought half an hour’s time through his lawyer,” Mishra said.

Regarding the court’s direction on the completion of process for framing STPF norms, Mishra said the principal secretary has sought three months more time with the commitment that no extension would be prayed for in future for compliance with court’s orders. The court allowed it with instructions that the copy of the order be sent to all the government departments like home, finance and personnel, which have a role in the process.

Title: Goa government forms two committees to propel SEZ land auction
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

problem solving

PANAJI: Getting a move on with the auction a fraction of the land parcels of the Special Economic Zones (SEZ), which was taken back from the original promoters, the state government has constituted a monitoring committee and a selection committee to oversee the auction.

The five-member selection committee, to be headed by industries secretary Nila Mohanan, will appoint a consultant to help Goa Industrial Development Corporation (GIDC) auction around 5 lakh sqm of prime industrial land.

Overseeing the auction will be a seven-member monitoring committee headed by industries minister Vishwajit Rane.

“The government is pleased to constitute a selection committee to initiate, finalise the process of getting on-board a property consultant on SEZ land matter, with an international profile and adequate experience, subject to terms of reference as recommended by the committee and approved by government,” industries under-secretary A S Mahatme said.

Other members of the selection committee, along with Mahatme, are additional secretary for finance Sunil Masurkar; director of trade industries and commerce Deepak Bandekar and managing director of GIDC Derrick Neto.

In the last week of December, the industries department had issued an order to GIDC asking it to go ahead with the auction of a fraction of the 38 lakh sqm of SEZ land and submit an action taken report.
