Nashik: Shiv Sena’s Panchavati corporator Poonam Mogre has warned the civic authorities that if they failed to resolve the garbage collection issue in the area, the Panchavati residents would start dumping garbage in front of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) headquarters.

Mogre said in absence of proper garbage collection, the entire area is stinking and is covered in filth.

“The NMC administration has assured that the problem will be resolved within the next fortnight as it is in the process of appointing new contractors to lift the garbage from Panchavati and Cidco,” she said. “We will wait for a fortnight and will launch severe agitation if the garbage collection system is not regularised ,” she said.

“I have been getting complaints from residents about the garbage not being lifted by NMC,” she said.

Another corporator from Panchavati division, Ashok Murtadak of MNS, said the NMC has to take immediate measures to clear all the garbage.

“Garbage vans have not been coming in my area for the many days. NMC administration needs to start garbage collection on its own,” said Swati Pagare, a resident of Panchavati division.

This situation was created after the NMC terminated the garbage collection contracts of a Pune-based contractor, who was entrusted with lifting garbage from the area.

“After the termination of the contract, we had given the work to contractors from other divisions. Earlier, they had inadequate numbers of vehicles operating in these two divisions. But the number of the vehicles has been increased. We are making efforts to regularise garbage vans in both the divisions,” said Sunil Bukane, director, solid waste department of NMC.

During the recent general body meeting, municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game and mayor Satish Kulkarni had said that measures are being taken to regularise the garbage collection system. They said that they will soon initiate a tender process to appoint a new contractor. Until then, the work is to be done by the two existing garbage collection contractors.

Title: Tiger, 4, dies of ailment in STR
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

ERODE: A four-year-old male tiger was found dead at Neithalapuram in Thalavadi forest range in Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve (STR) on Thursday. The forest department is yet to ascertain the cause of animal’s death .

S Sivakumar, ranger, Thalavadi forest range, said the carcass of the animal was first spotted by local villagers. “They immediately alerted us. Though initially we suspected it to be a case of poaching, we ruled out that possibility later as its nails and teeth were intact. It seems that the animal has been suffering from some ailment and has not been taking food for days,” he said.

Veterinarians attached to the forest department performed postmortem at the spot itself and later buried the carcass in the reserve forest. “We have collected vital organs of the tiger to ascertain the exact cause of its death. They would be sent for lab test,” the ranger said.

Title: Dehradun: Residents protest against Shishambara waste plant
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: Residents of Selaqui and other nearby areas staged a protest against the Shishambara waste management plant at the DM office on Thursday.

The residents protested for a while before issuing a memorandum to the officials. “Our demand is that the waste management plant should be removed from that particular site. The waste is polluting the nearby Asan river, due to which residents are contracting numerous diseases. We are planning to go to the NGT headquarters in Delhi. We will also march to the PM office,” said Satpal Dhaniya, a protester.

Title: Naidu’s assets grew by Rs 87 lakh, Lokesh’s decreased by Rs 2 crore
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Amaravati: TDP national general secretary Nara Lokesh has dared his political opponents to prove the charges of illegal assets owned by his family, adding that if the charges are proved his family would return all such assets to them as gift.

Lokesh, who declared the assets of his family members at the TDP office on Thursday, said they have been following the practice of declaring their assets to the public for the past nine years. “Instead of depending on the Enforcement Directorate, CBI and income tax authorities to declare his assets, chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy should himself come out in open to reveal his assets,” he demanded.

Stating that there was nothing to hide about his family’s earnings and assets, he said anyone, including YSRC functionaries, are free to come out with proof about their undeclared assets and take them away. “We are ready to gift such properties to those who come out with proof instead of spreading a smear campaign,” he added.

Lokesh said the net assets of his father, TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu , grew by Rs 87 lakh in the last one year (Rs 3 crore to Rs 3.87 crore). Though Naidu’s total assets were around Rs 9 crore, he had debts to the tune of Rs 5.13 crore, leaving his net assets at Rs 3.87 crore. “My mother Bhuvaneswari’s net assets have decreased in the last 12 months. My own assets have also decreased to Rs 19 crore from Rs 21 crore, while (wife) Brahmani’s net assets increased from Rs 7 crore to Rs 11.5 crore. My son Devansh’s net assets have grown by Rs 1 crore to Rs 19 crore. My family-owned investment firm Nirvana’s net assets have increased from Rs 6.8 crore to Rs 9 crore,” said Lokesh.

He said TDP is the only party in the country to disclose the assets of its top leaders for the past nine years. He explained that the value of the assets were arrived at the rate at which they were bought and not at current market price, since current value can rise or fall based on several socioeconomic factors. He added that the performance of Heritage group, set up by Naidu about 27 years ago to ensure that the family had financial independence irrespective of their political challenges, played a big role in the growth of their assets. He said they were taking up charitable programmes through NTR Trust.

Lokesh also wanted to know why Jagan has not been reacting to their demands to disclose his family’s assets. “Jagan’s assets were just around Rs 9 lakh according to the election affidavit filed by him in 2009 but rose to Rs 42,000 crore by the time the CBI carried out searches at his residences,” he said, while adding that Jagan has so far done only three works successfully — painting government offices with YSRC colours, attacking TDP activists, and going back on his own promises.

Title: Stop letting sewage water into irrigation canal, Gobichettipalayam folk tell officials
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Erode: Gobichettipalayam farmers on Thursday demanded the district administration and the municipality to stop letting sewage water into a canal that was meant for irrigation purposes.

Talking to TOI, M Suresh Kumar, a farmer, said sewage water from Gobichettipalayam taluk was entering Thadapalli canal at more than 10 places. “At least 24,504 acres is directly benefitted from the canal water,” he said.

Pointing out that they had recently desilted the canal near Singiyam at a cost of Rs40 lakh under the Kudimaramathu scheme, the farmers said, “However, owing to unchecked sewage water flow, the canal pathway is today filled with water hyacinth and other waste.”

It is to be noted that Public Works Department (PWD) officials had started releasing water into the canal from Kodiveri dam on February 1. The farmers said the water had not reached the tail end village Singiyam so far, as the water pathway has been blocked by water hyacinth.

They said they had taken up the issue with the Gobichettipalayam municipality several times, but to no avail. “How can we use water mixed with sewage to irrigate food crops such as paddy?”

The farmers have also petitioned Gobichettipalayam revenue divisional officer Jayaraman, seeking to redress the issue. “I will convene a meeting with revenue, PWD and municipality officials to settle the issue,” the officer said.

The farmers, meanwhile, threatened to take out a series of protests if their demands were not met.

Title: Jasmine Shah back as vice-chairperson of govt think tank
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

New Delhi: Delhi government has re-appointed Jasmine Shah as the vice-chairperson of Dialogue and Development Commission of Delhi (DDC), the think tank of the government.

DDC was set up with the aim of bridging the knowledge and capacity deficit in government, and to take advantage of the vast pool of domain expertise that lies outside the government for the inclusive development of the national capital.

Shah was earlier appointed DDC vice-chairman in October, 2018. He had replaced Ashish Khetan, who had resigned in April, 2018.

The key objective of the commission is to consider ideas, identify the best practices and policies from around the world, and translate these into concrete recommendations to the government.

Earlier, the commission has helped in better planning in several sectors, including health, energy and higher education.

“It is an honour and privilege to have the opportunity to serve as vice-chairperson of Delhi government’s think tank. CM Arvind Kejriwal has set a new narrative in Indian politics, that of ‘Kaam ki Rajneeti’. DDC’s focus in the next five years will be to work closely with the citizens to make Delhi a 21st century city that every Indian can be proud of,” Shah said.

Coordinated delivery of the 10-point guarantee card, fighting air pollution, cleaning Yamuna and modernising the public transport system will be among the other focus areas.

Title: BJP blames Andhra Pradesh govt for attack on temples
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

BJP’s Andhra Pradesh unit president Kanna Lakshminarayana

VIJAYAWADA: BJP’s state unit president Kanna Lakshminarayana on Thursday alleged that temples are being attacked across AP with the support of the state government. Speaking at the party’s state committee meeting, the former minister condemned the attacks on temples and sought severe action against those responsible. He also criticised the police for booking false cases against BJP activists and harassing them.

Kanna said a party delegation met DGP Gautham Sawang and complained to him against the false cases and also on the attacks on temples. However, he regretted that no action has been taken by the DGP so far. He also expressed concern over the increasing attacks and intimidation of BJP workers in the state by the police.

The BJP chief also saw the role of the state government in the targeting of temples. He alleged that evangelisation was on the rise in the state these days and the government was encouraging conversions. “Attacks on temples, evangelisation and false cases on BJP workers has the support of the state government. There is no doubt about the government’s support to these activities,” he alleged.

He also blamed the government for its failure to keep prices under control. “The government has failed in all aspects in the last nine months. Prices are out of control, law and order is a total failure, political victimisation is increasing,” he claimed. Party leaders GVL Narasimha Rao, Daggubati Purandheswari, Kambhampati Haribabu, Somu Veerraju, PVN Madhav, P Manikyala Raju and others were present.

Title: Nashik campus project of SPPU to become reality soon
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik campus project of the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) will soon take shape after over three years of uncertainty.

“An allocation has been made for the Nashik campus in the varsity’s budget proposal. The budget proposals would be placed before the senate in a meeting on March 14. We have concrete feedback that the state government will also make an allocation for the project in its budget,” highly placed varsity sources told TOI.

A senior SPPU official said that with the fund allocation, the work for the construction of the campus, spread across 63 acres in Dindori taluka, would start.

“The varsity is committed to making the Nashik campus project successful. Our administrative department is looking into the technical issues and resolving them with priority,” the SPPU official added.

The SPPU had conceived the Nashik project in 2017. But the project was not developed despite demands from students and faculty members of the varsity hailing from Nashik.

Recently, SPPU senate member from Nashik, Amit Patil, had taken up the issue with chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and the state higher and technical education minister Uday Samant.

Patil had said that both of them had assured him that they would look into the issue seriously.

Once the campus comes up in the city, students from Nashik will not have to go to the SPPU headquarters at Pune to resolve their problems and issues

“They will have access to the authorities at the campus here and the authorities will be able to take immediate decisions,” SPPU officials said.

Currently, Nashik has one sub-centre, which is a link between the varsity and the students. But it cannot take major decisions and the problems have to be addressed at the main campus.

According to SPPU authorities, once the varsity’s Nashik campus becomes a reality, it would have an administrative set up and the students can pursue higher studies in the Nashik campus of the university.

Title: Ratan Tata to felicitate Dr Bang couple for their contribution to public health
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: Eminent industrialist and Tata Group Chairman emeritus Ratan Tata will felicitate Dr Rani Bang and Dr Abhay Bang at a special event to mark the 50th year of Population Foundation of India scheduled to be held on February 28 in New Delhi.

The ceremony, to be held at the Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium, will also premier Feroz Abbas Khan’s highly acclaimed new romantic musical ‘Raunaq & Jassi,’ inspired by William Shakespeare’s classic, Romeo and Juliet.

The Bangs will receive the JRD Tata Award for Excellence in Public Service, instituted by Population Foundation of India in its 50th year, for their pioneering research in public health and for their contribution in promoting the well-being of communities in the tribal district of Maharasthra’s Gadchiroli.

Keshav Desiraju, chairperson, Population Foundation of India’s Governing Board, said that the Tatas strongly believed in equality and social justice and was particularly concerned about the needs of those left behind on the path to development. “Dr Rani Bang and Dr Abhay Bang’s work over the last 40 years shows the same commitment and devotion to ensuring the reach of basic health care to the poorest communities. Their pioneering innovations in Gadchiroli have transformed the way public health care is delivered in rural areas,” he added.

Poonam Muttreja, Executive Director of Population Foundation, said, “Dr Rani Bang and Dr Abhay Bang have been a remarkable source of inspiration to many of us. Their work in community health has been extremely influential in shaping reproductive and child health programmes in India and abroad. We are honoured to begin our 50th year celebrations in the presence of such incredible change-makers.”

In its 50th year, Population Foundation of India is instituting the JRD Tata Award for Excellence in Public Service to honour JRD Tata’s vision of establishing a just and equitable society in India. The award is given in recognition of an individual’s contribution to promoting social justice, gender equality, women’s empowerment and the well-being of society.

Title: Karnataka moots ‘plug-and-play’ factories for industries
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

BENGALURU: In a bid to reduce time taken for firms to launch manufacturing activity, the industries department is proposing to offer industries a slew of plug-and-play factories — pre-constructed facilities with all necessary infrastructure — across various industrial parks and estates.

These facilities will be offered on lease which will reduce industries’ upfront investment and help them channel more funds into technology and innovation. Industry members TOI spoke with said such facilities, which are common in China, Taiwan and some other countries, would be a great benefit.

Gaurav Gupta, principal secretary, industries department, told TOI: “We are looking at different models and are talking to heads of industry and other stakeholders about this. There is a lot of potential and we will have to see what kind of response we get. We cannot go about building things if there is no response.”

Gupta, while insisting such ready-to-occupy facilities will not be restricted to any one sector, said that the government may begin with various clusters it is planning as part of the flagship ‘Industrial Cluster Development Programme’.

The government intends on developing various clusters under this programme, including ones in the agriculture/food processing sector. “The idea is to help reduce the turnaround time — from the time a project gets approval to start of operations — of industries and also to attract new investments,” Gupta said.

He said the government may build these factories by floating tenders for the project, or get builders to do it. “Each model has various nuances that need to be worked out. We will work out the details once we know what kind of response we’ll get. That process is already on,” Gupta said.

Manu Jain, vice-president, Xiaomi, and managing director, Xiaomi-India said at a press conference that plug-and-play facilities in China are huge.

Devesh Agarwal, president, Bangalore Chamber of Industries and Commerce (BCIC), told TOI: “Our chamber has made two proposals to the government. One is to adopt a cluster approach, which has been taken seriously, and the second is to offer plug-and-play units. Karnataka ’s industrial policy has always been very progressive and we are glad that the government is looking into both these suggestions.”

He pointed out that this won’t be the first time Karnataka has offered such facilities to industries. “More than 40 years ago, KSSIDC (Karnataka State Small Industries Development Corporation ) had offered similar facilities in Peenya Industrial Estate. It was a massive success, but for reasons we are unaware of, it was never emulated anywhere else in the state,” Agarwal said.

Stating that the industry will welcome the initiative, Agarwal said that the department could even look at a model that allows builders to draw up an agreement with the government and build estates that have such factories.

Title: Corporators prevail, get mayor to order resumption of works stalled by Tukaram Mundhe
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe

NAGPUR: Mayor Sandip Joshi on Thursday directed the civic administration to lift ban imposed by municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe to stop development works irrespective of whether work orders were issued or not.

On February 13, Mundhe had told the special general body meeting that the NMC’s financial condition was very critical so he had no option but to stop development works whether work orders were issued or not. He has also stopped the administration from floating new tenders.

Though Mundhe tried to draw attention of the House by presenting NMC’s Rs496 crore liabilities till January 31 and also informed about future liabilities, the corporators felt unconvinced by his justification.

Mundhe also refuted the demand of corporators to introduce one time amnesty scheme or waive off penalty imposed on defaulters of property tax and water bills. To this, mayor assured the house that a meeting of all party leaders and senior corporators along with municipal commissioner will be convened before February 29.

Senior BJP corporator Dayashankar Tiwari demanded the civic chief to table last 12 years’ balance sheet. “Even during last special general body meeting, the mayor had given the directives to the civic chief,” he said. To this, the mayor sought information from Mundhe who sought one month to submit 12 years’ balance sheet.

Mundhe, however, continued with his justification about the stoppage of new works and explained that this year’s budget target set by standing committee of Rs3,100 crore, the NMC will hardly reach Rs2,300 crore by March end.

Tiwari demanded the mayor to ask the commissioner to table year-wise liabilities of the NMC.

Tiwari and Datke also informed the house that the commissioner cannot stop works sanctioned by the standing committee. Even the administration read out the MMC Act, which clearly mentioned that the civic chief has no power to stop works sanctioned by the standing committee.

The house also unanimously decided to send back chief accounts and finance officer Mona Thakur to her original department in state’s treasury. Recently, Thakur was given additional charge of CAFO of NMC after the civic body’s CAFO had proceeded on sick leave.

The house took the decision after BJP corporator Dharmpal Meshram brought adjournment motion demanding to relieve her from the NMC. Tabling the motion, Meshram said as per act NMC, the charge of CAFO cannot be given to any person who had earlier held the auditor’s post in the NMC and Thakur had held that position.

Corporators from all the parties supported Meshram’s demand following which the mayor ruled to send back Thakur to the state government. According to sources, the demand against Thakur was made as she held back many pending bills and suggested Mundhe to stop works following financial crisis.

The ruling party also opposed the civic administration’s proposal to sanction town planning scheme of Smart City as it has many discrepancies.

Independent corporator Abha Pande questioned over functioning of counselling centres operating in 10 zones. The NMC is spending Rs33.60 lakh per annum for running 10 counselling centres but there are many irregularities like it is not functional 24X7. Even NMC is paying water and electricity bills of these centres, said Pande. Mayor directed deputy municipal commissioner to inquire in to the allegations made by Pande and table the report before the house.

Meanwhile, the house also elected nine standing committee members: BJP corporators Vijay Zalke, Pramod Karote, Khan Nasrinbano, Anil Gendre, Rajesh Ghodpage, Pramila Mathrani, Vishakha Bante, Vikram Gwalbanshi and Congress corporator Ayesha Uike. Of them, Zalke is all set to become standing committee chairman as present panel chief Pradip Pohane will retire next month.

Title: Nagpur Municipal Corporation gets notice for building road on private land in Wathoda
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

NAGPUR: A part of an internal road in Wathoda was allegedly laid on private land by the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC). Land owner Vinod Bangade recently erected a fence to block the road on his land, but it was demolished by NMC, fuelling another controversy.

The road in dispute links the main road connecting Inner Ring Road to Symbiosis University , with Radhakrishna Nagar at Wathoda. It is the only direct approach for residents of Radhakrishna Nagar.

Some days ago, Bangade served notice to NMC Nehru Nagar Zone and also submitted a memorandum to mayor Sandip Joshi alleging trespass by NMC on his property and claiming compensation for his land. He also announced the intention to erect a fence again to protect his land.

Bangade told TOI his ancestors owned 4.04 acre land at Wathoda since 1954. The Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) had acquired the land for Sewage Disposal Scheme in 1964, but returned it in 1997. “After disputes within the family, I paid Rs10.5 lakh to my family members in district court and got complete ownership in 2012,” said Bangade. He also created a layout with 21 plots and sold 20 of them, with the remaining 13,400 sq ft plot lying abandoned.

When his case was pending in court for years, people of Radhakrishna Nagar, which is also an unauthorized layout, had started to use his land to approach the main road. “Without any intimation to us, NIT constructed a road on it two years ago. I gathered all documents and approached NIT and NMC, but no one paid heed. I fenced the road on the two ends of my plot a couple of months ago. NMC team on January 30 demolished the fencing,” he said.

Corporator Dharampal Meshram, also an advocate, said NMC initiated the action on his complaint. “People came to me and requested to open the road as it is the only one to approach many residential areas. NMC issued notice and opened the road for traffic. I have gone through Bangade’s documents and his ownership claim seems correct. NMC should verify the documents and take appropriate action. But no one can block a road, so it should remain open till the case is settled,” he said.

Bangade has no problem in giving his land for the road but wants the norms to be followed. “NMC should have consulted me before demolishing my fencing. I incurred huge loss in the action. NMC acted after a conspiracy by few people. I should be given compensation for the land used for the road. I have verified city’s development plan (DP) and there is no road on my property,” he said.

The case has once again highlighted NIT’s improper development of unauthorized layouts. Before providing basic amenities, NIT had regularized unauthorized layouts, leaving people to suffer disputes between property owners and NMC, which replaced NIT as planning authority a few months ago.

Mayor Joshi has reportedly directed officials of Nehru Nagar zone to verify Bangade’s documents, check DP, and resolve the case.

Title: Women set the tone for protest
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: As the sit-in against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Registry of Citizens (NRC) and the National People’s Register (NPR) entered the second day on Thursday, several hundred women flocked to the protest venue that was christened Coimbatore’s Shaheen Bagh to join the proceedings.

“This is our emotion,” said 46-year-old Shakeela Kadar pointing to 1000-odd hijab-clad women sitting under a canopy and raising slogans at the Masjid ground at Aathupalam Junction in the city.

Like most of the women there, Shakila had come to the protest venue after finishing household chores and sending children to school. “Many of us are earning members and have children, who go to school and colleges. Yet, we have come here. We are fighting for our soil. We need our soil,” she said.

Shameema Habeeb, 54, another protester, said, “The BJP government has turned ordinary public into protesters.”

Like Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh, it is the emotion of women that leads the anti-CAA protest in the city. The sit-in began on Wednesday night following a massive rally against the CAA, NPR and NRC, and the state government, which the protesters said needed to pass a resolution against the draconian laws.

The women, who have gathered from Kuniyamuthur, Podanur, Karumbukkadai, Oppanakkara Street and other areas in the city, said they were determined to conduct the protest peacefully and with discipline. Shameema said, “We will protest peacefully in Gandhian way till they repeal the act. We won’t create any situation for police to intervene.”

Coimbatore’s Shaheen Bagh comes after several protests and rallies conducted by the Federation of all Jamaths and Muslim organizations in the city over the past two months. Before Wednesday’s rally, they had taken out a massive rally on February 2 from Ukkadam till south taluk office. Around 25,000 people had turned up for that rally.

Speaking of the timing of the indefinite sit-in, Shabeena Shamsudeen , 39, another protester, said, “We have been staging protests at several places, but there has been no solution. We have come here to find a solution. We will not budge till CAA, NPR and NRC are repealed.”

Men at the venue said they have foregone their day’s pay to participate in the protest. Mohammed Ibrahim, 56, said, “I work as a coolie at a glass works shop. My pay is Rs500 a day. But I have come here, as my citizenship is more important that a day’s pay.”

Mohammed Ashraf, 18, a Class XII student, said he was afraid of the future. “I’m afraid whether we would remain citizens of the country if the CAA, NPR and NRC are implemented.”

While the protest began with around 2,000 people on Thursday morning, women started pouring in as the day progressed.

Title: Chennai: DRI scanner on customs officials
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

CHENNAI: The international airport in the city on Wednesday turned into the epicentre of a ‘ turf war ’ between Customs and directorate of revenue intelligence (DRI) over apprehension of gold smugglers. Two customs officials are under DRI scanner , while DRI officials themselves were allegedly attacked by a mob after they seized 12.693 kg of gold valued at Rs 5.44 crore from 18 passengers.

Sources said officials of DRI, an agency whose mandate is to gather intelligence and bust major cases, went into the immigration area of the international airport to apprehend those said to be carrying the gold concealed in the rectum. A source in Chennai airport Customs said that if the passengers had reached the Customs area, they would have been apprehended by the agency, as is the norm.

The passengers apprehended by DRI had arrived by flights AK 11 from Malaysia, 6E 1212 from Colombo, EK 544 from Dubai and UL 121 from Colombo.

DRI said that as a follow-up investigation, the Kolathur house of a customs tax assistant who had recently quit his post was searched. He was allegedly co-ordinating the smuggling operation.

However, high drama prevailed once the DRI officials exited the airport arrival hall. While the officials made the 18 smugglers board a vehicle, a mob of 50 people gathered and hurled abuses at them. Two officials were allegedly manhandled and in the ensuing melee, some passengers ran away. Some were seen entering the arrival hall again, DRI said in a release. When DRI approached the airport police to file a complaint, some of the members of the mob followed them. DRI later called them to its office in T Nagar on Thursday for further inquiry and 13 of the 18 turned up. DRI said it had begun an investigation to identify the mastermind behind the racket.

While in the official release, DRI appreciated the role of Customs in effecting seizure of gold on a regular basis at the airport, customs officials are unhappy over their turf being encroached.

In the past one year, Customs had shown a 67% increase in the number of cases booked. Gold smuggling cases booked saw an increase of 116%, compared to the previous year, with Rs 123 crore worth gold being seized. Moreover, 14 wildlife seizures, especially of exotic animals, were also made by Customs.

Title: Coimbatore: Handymen just a phone call away
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Are you tired of searching for a plumber to fix that leaking bathroom tap? Or a carpenter to fix that creaking armchair?

Fret not. From next month, you will be able to get in touch with electricians, plumbers , painters , gardeners and even domestic workers by calling the city’s first City Livelihood Centre (CLC) at 1800 599 3300.

“Those in search of skilled labourers can call the toll-free number and register their request to avail our service. We will connect them with skilled workers,” said an official with the Tamil Nadu corporation for development of women (TNCDW).

The centre, which will be based in the Town Hall, will bridge the gap between demand and supply of services in the city by connecting residents with skilled labourers, who are living below the poverty line in urban areas, the official said. “Our business support service will uplift the livelihood of local skilled labourers.”

Three such centres, established under the National Urban Livelihood Mission (NULM), will be set up in the district. Two will be functioning in the corporation limit – at Town Hall and Kuniyamuthur. The other one will be set up in Pollachi.

As many as 500 skilled labourers, mostly electricians, plumbers, carpenters and cooks, have already registered with the centre. “Our field workers are in the process of identify more workers. The government will fix the basic wage for the labourers and the service charge for the centre. We will get feedback from the customers about the quality of service,” the official said.

The centre will also offer e-seva services and provide all sorts of online services right from booking train and flight tickets to paying property tax and bills. “We are also planning to provide skill training to deserved people through the centre, apart from using it to market the goods produced by self-help groups (SHGs),” the official added.

Title: Saurabh Bharadwaj: Will ask for a grand statue of Hanuman in Ayodhya
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

AAP candidate from Greater Kailash constituency, Saurabh Bharadwaj. (ANI Photo)

NEW DELHI: AAP MLA from Greater Kailash, Saurabh Bharadwaj , on Thursday said he would send a formal request to Ram Janmabhoomi Trust to build a “grand statue” of Hanuman in Ayodhya. The remarks came a day after Bharadwaj announced his decision to organise the recitation of “Sunderkand” on the first Tuesday of every month in his constituency.

Bharadwaj told a news agency on Thursday, “I think a grand statue of Hanuman-ji should be built on Ram Temple premises as Hanuman-ji was Lord Ram’s favourite. Hanuman-ji is a symbol of selfless service.” He later tweeted, “Thousands of people have been sending me messages since we did Sundar Kaand announcement. Crores of Hindus want a Lord Hanuman Idol at Ayodhya Temple Complex. It’s a small & humble demand (sic).”

Meanwhile, Shri Dutt Sharma, former MLA from Ghonda, said he would set up Aam Aadmi Bajrang Dal to organise “Sunderkand” recitations across the constituency. He told TOI, “It is not a copy of Bajrang Dal. It is being formed with the aim of organising recitation of Sunderkand in different areas of the constituency on every second Saturday of the month.” He added, “We have been organising Sunderkand recitations at Sanatan Mandir in Bhajanpura every second Saturday. The new organisation will expand it to other places.”

Title: NMC develops 20th Urban Primary Health Centre
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) in association with Tata Trusts has developed the 20th Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) under the central government’s National Urban Health Mission at Nara in North Nagpur. Mayor Sandip Joshi inaugurated the UPHC at a programme held on Thursday.

Former MLA Dr Milind Mane, chairman of NMC health consultative committee Virendra Kukreja, vice-president of Rashtriya Sindhi Bhasha Vikas Parishad Ghanshyam Kukreja, chairperson of NMC Mangalwari Zone Gargi Chopra, chairman of NMC tax consultative committee Mahendra Dhanvijay, corporators and officials were present.

NMC additional assistant health officer Dr Vijay Joshi, Dr Rajesh Bhure, Laxman Shinde, Gokul Hingwe from Tata Trusts and their teams took efforts for development of UPHC under the guidance of municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe, medical officer Dr Bhavna Sonkusre, director of health department of Tata Trusts Shrinivas Hundi and project coordinator Amar Navkar.

TB screening and guidance centre was also opened at UPHC.

The UPHC will remain open from Monday to Saturday from 8am to 2pm. Patients can get facilities like OPD services, maternity checkup, pediatric, family planning counseling, vaccinations, RTI and STI counseling, leprosy, diagnosis and treatment of epilepsy and asthma, diabetes, diagnosis and treatment of vector-bornde diseases etc.

The NMC in association with Tata Trusts is providing 59 types of blood tests free for patients. UPHCs are linked with state-of-the-art pathology lab developed by Tata Trusts at Sadar. A representative from Tata Trusts collect samples from UPHCs and reports are uploaded online which is accessible to all centres.

Tata Trusts has provided laptops, computers, software, air conditioners, cabins etc at UPHC. Even, Tata Trusts gave training to all doctors and staff.

Title: Nagpur Mayor Sandip Joshi clears proposal to fine owners for garbage on vacant plots
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur Mayor Sandip Joshi

NAGPUR: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) general body on Thursday passed a proposal to impose fine on owners of vacant plots in NMC limits if they fail to stop people from littering their property.

Mayor Sandip Joshi okayed the health department’s proposal to impose garbage lifting charge of Rs50 per sq mt from such owners. Joshi also gave nod to auction such properties if owners fail to keep the place clean.

Though the proposal, which was earlier cleared by the standing committee, was not submitted before the general body for its nod, corporators from both ruling BJP and opposition unanimously demanded the mayor to clear it.

Title: Nagpur: Rather than nomination, CWC should elect members, says Prithviraj Chavan
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

former chief minister Prithviraj Chavan

NAGPUR: In an indication towards growing fissures in the Congress, former chief minister Prithviraj Chavan said the party suffered immensely due to nomination culture brought in the Congress Working Committee (CWC) after Sonia Gandhi took over as president in 1998. He is second Congressman after senior party leader Shashi Tharoor demanded that the polls should be conducted for party president’s post.

During his courtesy visit to TOI-MT office on Thursday, Chavan further admitted that the probe into multi-crore irrigation scam, which he had first launched as CM, wouldn’t progress much since those facing accusations “were in power”.

While demanding to conduct polls for CWC’s 10 elected members, he said only then good state-level leaders would come out. “During tenures of former premier PV Narasimha Rao and Sitaram Kesri, there used to be polls for CWC’s ten seats from where good leaders like Madhavrao Scindia and Rajesh Pilot had emerged. There used to be 10 elected and 11 nominated seats on the CWC, but now all are nominated members. The coterie around Gandhi didn’t let the polls to be conducted in all these years, due to which good leaders are not emerging.”

Citing examples of how the “good leaders” were denied opportunity, Chavan said, “In Haryana, former CM Bhupinder Singh Hooda was brought back as the party’s chief just five months prior to the polls. Of course, the party needs younger and energetic leaders, but experience shouldn’t be ignored. NCP supremo Sharad Pawar is the best example of vast network of supporters,” he said.

“In Madhya Pradesh, after appointing Kamal Nath as CM, the state chief’s post should have been granted to Jyotiraje Scindia or his close aide from the party. In Rajasthan as well, there are same issues, which could be sorted out,” Chavan added.

Speaking on Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA), Chavan made a startling claim that had BJP retained power in the state, it would have spelt doom for the Congress and the NCP as the former had destroyed its strongholds sectors like cooperatives, dairy and sugar. “They had also carried out many defections from our party. Ex-CM Devendra Fadnavis had made full preparations of ending our domination had he come back. I was the first one to convince Gandhi on forming the government, although she was reluctant. It wasn’t easy to stitch an alliance but we came together with the only aim of keeping the common enemy (BJP) away from power.”

Explaining the party’s stand on the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), the ex-CM said they would oppose it tooth and nail. “PM Narendra Modi’s image has taken a hit due the ongoing protests. His dream to come at par with former US president Barack Obama is over. It (CAA) was brought with a view to polarize the people.”

Opposing CM Uddhav Thackeray’s stand of allowing National Investigation Agency (NIA) to take over the Elgar Parishad probe, Chavan said MVA should have constituted SIT for incident. “NIA’s track record is worst, although we can’t stop it from taking over as per the NIA law.”

Title: Jewellery park will revive ailing sector, say Coimbatore goldsmiths
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

COIMBATORE: Goldsmiths in the city welcomed the State government’s decision to set up a gold jewellery industrial park here. The park will give a boost to the sector, which has been facing a decline from the last decade due to competition from big corporates, they said.

Minister for rural industries P Benjamin had recently made the announcement in the State assembly regarding the park, to be set up in Perur in Thondamuthur constituency.

It was a long-standing demand, said managing director of Coimbatore Gold Jewellery Cluster S M Kamalhasan. “There were 50,000 micro jewellery units in the city and two lakh people depended on the sector. In the last few years, several people had to abandon the profession and find other jobs mainly due to competition from big corporate jewellers,” he said. The park will bring together all micro goldsmith units in the city and provide more stability and security for them. It will help develop the sector and also attract the next generation,” he said.

The proposed Coimbatore Gold Jewellery Cluster on Vysial Street, undertaken by goldsmiths, will have the latest machinery and infrastructure for jewellery making. It is in the process of getting final approvals. “Once the industrial park is established, we will shift our cluster to the campus,” Kamalhasan said.

Title: Nagpur: Temples gear up to welcome devout on Mahashivaratri
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Mahashivaratri

NAGPUR: The early morning calm will become more peaceful and pious as devotees of Lord Shiva offer prayers and panchamrut (a mixture of five ingredients) amid the fragrance of essence sticks at temples on the holy occasion of Mahashivratri today. Lord Shiva temples across town have geared up to welcome devotees lining up to offer prayers.

Temples and their surroundings in the city are draped in the colours of celebrations, as devotees and Shiv bhakts would offer prayers and witness ‘abhishek’ and pujas. On the darkest night of the year, devotees stay awake and offer prayers, perform rituals and pay obeisance to Lord Shiva.

Nikhil Tandulkar, a sevak at Prachin Shiv Mandir in the city, expressed his excitement about the holy festival, “Our temple is very old, and carries a special place in the hearts of the devotees. The puja begins at the temple at around four in the morning, followed by Rudra-Abhishek and aarti.”

Shivlakhan Solkar, another sevak at a local Shiv Mandir, added, “Devotees look forward to attending the abhishek, we offer bhasm, leaves, flowers and chandan to the pind of Shiva. We have made adequate arrangements for prasad, as thousands of devotees come each year.”

Devotees fast and pray to Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. While performing abhishek, they bathe the Shiva Linga with milk and flowers. “The Shiv lingam or pind is bathed with the five sacred offerings of a cow, called the ‘panchagavya’ — milk, sour milk, urine, butter, and dung at the temple. We have decorated the premises with flowers and installed railings so devotees can come in a proper queue to offer prayers,” said Dinesh Pedliwar , member of Shiv Mandir Panch committee.

Shivratri has a special significance for the city and areas surrounding it, as there were a large number of Nag temples here. Nandu Sontakke, from Shiv Mandir, Katol Road, explained the religious significance of the day and offered a glimpse into the tasty feast that will be distributed to the devotees.

“People feel inner peace and calm after visiting the temple on this pious occasion. We will serve rabdi, halwa, rice and other prasad to the devotees. The temple is expecting footfall of over 10,000 devotees, like every year. And each one will be an equal partner in the celebration,” he said.

Apart from the beautifully decorated temples, citizens also celebrate Mahashivratri at homes with great excitement. “We offer bel patra, three in numbers, and flowers to the linga. Later, the family members come together to chant ‘Maha mrutunjay jap’. It fills the house with warmth and positivity,” said Akshata Nakshine, a law student.

Title: Goa needs 94 thousand million cubic feet water for consumption, not 33 thousand million cubic feet
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The total water demand pleaded and established by Goa is 145tmc ft

KERI: While the Supreme Court on Thursday asked the Centre to notify the award given by the Mhadei Water Disputes Tribunal on August 14, 2018, Goa continues to fight a tricky battle.

The state’s contention is very clear and it has already filed a special leave petition on July 18, 2019, in the hope that things might go its way.

Goa has taken objection to the tribunal’s 2018 decision allotting Karnataka 13.4tmc ft, including 3.9tmc ft for drinking purposes through diversions, against its demand for 7.5tmc ft. It has maintained that the detailed project report for diversion of water to Malaprabha, submitted by Karnataka government, has many factual inconsistencies.

The state has established that the demand for its human consumption is 94.02tmc ft and for maintaining environment flow, the estimated requirement is 50.11tmc ft. The total demand pleaded and established by Goa is 145.16tmc ft. The tribunal has allowed Goa a mere 33.395tmc ft for human use.

In 1993, the Central Water Commission conducted a study of water availability in all rivers, estimating the average water availability in the Mandovi basin at 146.17tmc ft. Goa has found the yield estimated by the tribunal on the higher side.

Title: BS Yediyurappa admits financial crisis, says Karnataka govt forced to juggle allocations
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: Chief minister BS Yediyurappa admitted in the assembly on Thursday, that the state is facing a serious financial crisis and the government has been forced to “rationalise funds” allocated to “certain” constituencies by the coalition regime.

During a debate on the government suspended development work, PWD minister Govind Karjol, who provided a break-up of allocations, said constituencies of JD(S) legislators had been allocated six to 10 times more funding by the coalition government headed by HD Kumaraswamy .

“While Holenarsipura was allocated Rs 200 crore, Ramanagara got Rs 193 crore and Sakleshpur got 183 crore,” Karjol said. “However, other constituencies in coastal and north Karnataka were only given between Rs 20 crore and Rs 30 crore. To remove this discriminatory, we decided to suspend certain work in one constituency and use the same funds elsewhere.”

While objecting to the suspension of the development projects, Kumaraswamy, JD(S) floor leader, candidly admitted allocations were heavily in favour of constituencies of JD(S) legislators.

He justified it saying, “We were out of power for 10 years and there were development works which remained unfinished. So when we came to power, we allocated more to our constituencies. This has been the norm not only with our political party but with all others as well.”

BJP members immediately raised objections, claiming Kumaraswamy was “biased” and had ignored north Karnataka. However, Yediyurappa intervened and calmed tempers by admitting what Kumaraswamy had said is true.

“It is a fact that whichever party comes to power and whoever becomes the CM, he generally allocates more funds to his own constituency and his home district. This has been the case not today, but forever,” Yediyurappa said.

But Yediyurappa justified suspending projects sanctioned by the coalition government by admitting a shortfall in revenue and insisting financial management is imperative.

“I assure you that no projects sanctioned during the coalition government will be stopped. However, for now, due to the financial concerns, we are suspending it. We will take it up soon once the situation improves,” Yediyurappa said.

The CM had hardly finished when Bengaluru legislators from Congress and JD(S) said there were cuts in constituency allocations under various heads. Kumaraswamy claimed the government had allocated Rs 50 crore each to BJP constituencies, but not to segments headed by opposition parties. Former industries minister KJ George backed Kumaraswamy. Yediyurappa promised to set right the discrimination.

Earlier, a war of words broke out between Karjol and former PWD minister HD Revanna over allegations that projects worth thousands of crores were tendered without finance department approval.

While Revanna said he had never issued any tenders without FD clearances, Karjol said projects worth Rs 6,300 crore were on-going without finance department approval.

But the debate remained inconclusive with JD(S) and Congress seeking a white paper on the issue.

Title: NGT seeks clarity on 3 AP projects
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Vijayawada: The National Green Tribunal ( NGT ) bench on Thursday criticized the Union environment ministry and termed their claims that certain irrigation projects in AP didn’t require clearances as ‘ambiguous’.

Shravan Kumar, the advocate representing the petitioners, argued against the government for allowing the construction of Purushothapatnam , Pattiseema and Chintalapudi lift irrigation projects. He said the environment suffered ‘irreparable damage’ due to the projects that cannot be estimated.

After hearing the arguments, the four-member NGT bench led by Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel ordered the environment ministry’s expert appraisal committee to submit a detailed study in consultation with Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).

They asked for the report to be submitted within a month’s time and posted the next hearing to May.

Title: Register or face action, North Delhi Municipal Corporation tells schools
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: In a strict action against unrecognised schools in north Delhi, the civic agency has given a deadline of one month for registration.

In an order published on Thursday by North Delhi Municipal Corporation ’s education department, it has been clarified that all such private as well as aided schools should get themselves registered till March 31 else they will face major penalties of over Rs 1 lakh.

According to an estimate, there are about 3,000-5,000 unrecognised schools operating in various neighbourhoods in north Delhi , each having an average of 200 students.

“As per the provision of Section 18 of RTE Act, 2009, schools cannot run without any legal recognition certificate. If any unrecognised school is found to be operational after March 31, then penalty of Rs 1 lakh will be imposed. In case of further violation, penalty of Rs 10,000 per day will be imposed on the violator,” stated the order.

All students enrolled in unrecognised schools will be admitted in nearby government or recognised schools after the action is taken.

Meanwhile, a delegation of school owners on Thursday met the north corporation mayor and expressed concern over the short deadline given to obtain the registration certificate.

“We will soon hold a joint meeting of the officials concerned and the school owners to find out a solution as the matter concerns future of thousands of students,” said Avtar Singh, the mayor.

Title: Plan to revive panel on sexual harassment
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The district administration is all set to revive the local complaints committee (LCC), that was formed based on the Vishaka guidelines, to address sexual harassment of women at workplace.

A complaint box will be placed at a prominent place inside the collectorate on Monday, collector K Rajamani, who called a meeting with the officials, said. “We plan to revive the committee,” he said.

Referring to the anonymous complaints the administration had received, the collector said that not just the working women, anyone can deposit complaint letters in the box. “Even anonymous letters will be taken up for inquiry.”

As per the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, government departments, private companies and educational institutions that have more than 10 women employees, should have internal complaint committee (ICC). A district-level committee called LCC should be formed to monitor them.

While ICCs should have three members with a woman employee as its head, the district-level committee should consist of five members – collector, district social welfare officer (DSWO), two representatives from non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and an advocate.

TOI had earlier reported that the committee had not received even a single complaint even though it was formed in 2014.

An official from the committee said that even though more than 75% of the government departments and a few private companies had formed the committees and submitted quarterly reports, not even a complaint was registered through the committee. “We had investigated a couple of sexual harassment complaints. But they were addressed directly to the collector and not to the committee,” the official said.

Title: Nagpur Mayor Sandip Joshi starts process to denotify Itwari, Mahal as slums
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur Mayor Sandip Joshi

NAGPUR: Mayor Sandip Joshi on Thursday directed Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) administration to start the process to de-notify Itwari, Mahal and areas alongside Central Avenue from the list of recognized slums of Nagpur city.

He gave the ruling after former mayor Pravin Datke raised the issue of rise of unauthorized constructions in Mahal despite serving notices under relevant sections of Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act and Maharashtra Regional Town Planning Authority. He also drew attention that on July 20, 2017, the house had decided to denotify slums where all basic amenities had been provided. “But even after two years, the administration has failed to take any decision,” Datke said.

TOI had highlighted that commercial areas such as Sitabuldi, Sadar, Mahal etc are still marked as slums in state government and NMC records, and continue to get backward class funds while actual slums are deprived of basic amenities.

Datke informed the house that there is no rule to take action against unauthorized constructions in notified slums. Since Mahal is still part of slum, many property owners take undue advantage of this rule and indulge in unauthorized constructions. Even new multi-storey commercial shops are coming up without any provision for parking spaces.

Since the administration had failed to denotify these areas despite development, corporators are utilizing backward class development funds, and residents are availing subsidized services.

As per NMC records, there are 484 slums across the city, of which 295 are notified where slum dwellers are entitled to subsidized services like drinking water and property tax.

Endorsing Datke, senior BJP corporator Dayashankar Tiwari too drew the attention of the house to similar situation in other notified slum areas like alongside Central Avenue and Itwari.

Datke also raised the issue of zonal offices issuing notices to unauthorized constructions under sections 52, 53 and 54 of MRTP Act, though most of the owners have obtained stay by appealing in urban development ministry.

Following this, mayor Joshi directed the civic administration to start the process to denotify developed areas like Mahal, Itwari, Central Avenue from the list of slums. He also asked all assistant municipal commissioners to submit action initiated against unauthorized constructions in their respective zones.

Title: Coimbatore KSRTC bus tragedy: What led to accident that killed 19
Content:
The container got detached after the truck hit the median, crossed to the other lane and ripped the right side... Read More

The container truck driver was booked under Sections 279 (rash driving or riding on a public way), 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) and 304 A (causing death by negligence) of the Indian Penal Code.

The truck hit the 30-cm-high median and crossed over to the other side of the lane.

The driver of the truck K A Hemaraj apparently dozed off and lost control of the vehicle

Kerala transport minister A K Saseendran and agriculture minister V S Sunilkumar visited the spot and consoled relatives of the deceased.

COIMBATORE: Nineteen people were killed and 25 injured when a speeding container truck rammed a Kerala Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) bus near Tirupur in Tamil Nadu in the early hours of Thursday. The dead included two bus drivers and five women.Police said there were 48 passengers in the bus and the accident happened near Avinashi (Tirupur district) on the Avinashi-Salem bypass at 3.40 am. The Garuda Volvo bus was on way to Ernakulam from Bengaluru. The container truck carrying 25 tonnes of floor tiles was going to Bengaluru from Kochi.The driver of the truck K A Hemaraj, 37, from Kollathumkundil at Ottapalam near Palakkad, apparently dozed off and lost control of the vehicle. The truck hit the 30-cm-high median and crossed over to the other side of the lane. In the impact the container got detached and ripped the right side of the bus. Most of the people sitting on this side were killed.Survivors were not able to come out as the front portion of the bus was completely mangled in the collision. Passing motorists informed the Tirupur city police who rushed to the spot. Fire and rescue services personnel also arrived and started rescue work. The public too joined them in breaking open the glass panes of the bus and helping the passengers to come out.The bodies were sent to the Avinashi Government Hospital and then to the Tirupur Government Hospital for postmortem. Rescue work was completed around 8.30 am. Police had blocked the stretch on the Avinashi-Salem NHAI road and diverted vehicles.With the help of two earth movers, the bus was taken to a spot and 3 km away. The public were seen at the spot clicking photographs.Tirupur city police commissioner Sanjay Kumar said the truck driver who was arrested by the Tamil Nadu police said he had dozed off and lost control of the vehicle. The rear tyres were damaged after they hit the centre median.The container truck driver was booked under Sections 279 (rash driving or riding on a public way), 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) and 304 A (causing death by negligence) of the Indian Penal Code.V K Sreekandan, Palakkad MP, D Balamurali, Palakkad collector, G Shiva Vikaram, Palakkad superintendent of police, and other police officials were at the accident spot coordinating the rescue work.Kerala transport minister A K Saseendran and agriculture minister V S Sunilkumar visited the spot and consoled relatives of the deceased. The transport minister announced a solatium of Rs 10 lakh to the family of each passenger and Rs 30 lakh each to the drivers.Officials from the regional transport office visited the accident spot and checked the KSRTC bus and the container truck.Following the postmortem, the bodies were handed over to the family members.Tamil Nadu governor Banwarilal Purohit and chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami condoled the deaths. “I convey my deep condolences to the bereaved members of the families. I pray to God to rest the departed souls in peace and to give strength to their families to overcome this unfathomable loss. I also pray for the speedy recovery of the injured,” Purohit said in a statement.Palaniswami read out a statement in the assembly condoling the deaths.

Title: Nagpur: High court raps cops, reserves order on Bhim Army plea for rally permit
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Thursday reserved its order on the Bhim Army’s petition against the police refusing permission for a rally at Reshimbagh Grounds, next to the RSS’ centre. The judges also pulled up the cops for not relying on any specific reason, such as intelligence inputs or other grounds, to refuse clearance.

One of the reasons mentioned by the police in its affidavit for refusing permission was that Bhim Army professes an ideology opposite to that of the RSS. Holding a protest at a site next to the RSS administrative centre could lead to a law and order disturbance due to the differences, it said. The police expressed readiness to grant permission for any other site.

The court observed that mere difference of ideology of any organization located close by cannot be a reason for denial of permission for a rally. “Rather the police should have come up with a stronger case, it said. Suppression can prove to be adverse and such protests on the other hand provide a safety valve,” observed justice Sunil Shukre. The petition was before the division bench of Shukre and justice Madhav Jamdar .

The Bhim Army plans to hold a rally on February 22, where issues like CAA-NRC and reservation will be discussed by speakers. One of the speakers is the outfit’s chief Chandrashekhar Azad Ravan, who has been at the fore-front of anti-CAA-NRC protests and also in midst of controversies. The organizers have given an estimate that 10,000 persons would gather for the event.

Even as the outfit got permission from NIT, which has jurisdiction over the ground, the police denied approval citing law and order reasons, leading to Bhim Army moving the court.

In a later development, RSS-leaning organization Lok Jagruti Morcha and other outfits have planned a rally at Sakkardara Chowk, around a kilometre away from Reshimbagh on the same day. RSS sources, however, clarified that the organizers were an independent outfit.

Bhim Army’s counsel Firdaus Mirza argued that denial of permission was a violation of the fundamental right to protest. He said the very intent of denying permission was mala fide. The police is ready to allow the Bhim Army to hold the event at any other site but not at the Reshimbagh Grounds. Mirza argued that if the event did not pose a threat to law and order at any other site, then how could it be so only at Reshimbagh Grounds. Mirza also argued that there is no specific law barring such rallies.

The proceedings also revealed that the police had also denied Bhim Army permission at two other sites, Chitnavis Park and premises of Hazrat Mazoom Shah Dargah nearby, in Mahal, where the RSS headquarter is located.

Ketki Joshi, the government lawyer, arguing for the police, said that the Bhim Army had not stated its agenda for the meet. Even as it has been billed to be a workers’ meet, it did not appear to be purely a gathering of the outfit’s cadre. Joshi said the petitioner had also hidden the criminal antecedents, as the district chief of Bhim Army Praful Shende had faced charges of not abiding with lawful directions in two cases. She also expressed concern about the credentials of Ravan, given the background of offences registered against him.

Title: Kolkata: PWD seeks railway help for Majerhat nod
Content:
The under-construction Majerhat bridge

KOLKATA: The state public works department (PWD), implementing the Majerhat road overbridge (ROB) reconstruction project, on Wednesday submitted a host of documents to Eastern Railways (ER) that will be sent to the Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS).PWD officials on Thursday told TOI that Railways has passed on the documents to CRS, which in a letter to ER on January 13, refused approval for building the Majerhat ROB’s superstructure, pointing out 31 procedural and technical lapses. PWD is trying to fix some of these issues. The state agency has sought help from the Railways so that some of the objections can be ‘overlooked’.The CRS, under the ministry of civil aviation, gives safety clearance to any railway project across the country. The PWD needs its nod to start building the superstructure by launching girders over the railway tracks.A span of the ROB, which comes within the ambit of Eastern Railway (ER), collapsed on September 4, 2018. The new bridge, being built since January last year, has already missed two deadlines. The Bengal government has held Railways responsible for the delay. On November 25 last year, CM Mamata Banerjee wrote to railway minister Piyush Goyal seeking his intervention to expedite ER’s nods for building the bridge’s superstructure over the tracks and in getting the CRS sanction. But now, the crucial CRS approval is pending with the civil aviation ministry. Railways merely acts as a messenger between the state government and the CRS, which won’t give its go-ahead unless all its objections have been taken care of.A PWD official said, “ER is supposed to submit the documents provided by us to CRS with the plea that if all the issues raised by CRS need to be addressed now, then the bridge’s commissioning will be delayed further. The bridge was supposed to be completed by September 27, last year.”

Title: Nagpur: Set up markets before launching anti-encroachment drive says, Praful Gudadhe
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Praful Gudadhe

NAGPUR: Opposition and ruling corporators were at loggerhead over the NMC’s anti-encroachment drives. Raising the issue, Praful Gudadhe said that of the 10 zones, Laxmi Nagar, Nehru Nagar and Lakadganj zones have no authorized vegetable markets.

With a population of 30 lakh, the city has only eight weekly and four daily designated markets. Hence, citizens have no option but to buy vegetables from vendors doing business on roads and footpaths, he said. Hence, he suggested that the NMC should first designate markets before resorting to action against encroachers.

He maintained that the NMC should not launch anti-encroachment drive against illegal hawkers when it is yet to set up town vending committee. Gudadhe faced stiff opposition from ruling party corporators including Dayashankar Tiwari, former mayors Pravin Datke, Nanda Jichkar who said that the administration should keep roads free of all encroachments.

Mayor Sandip Joshi ordered the administration to identify places reserved in city’s development plan for markets and also asked to speed up the process for setting up town vending committee.

Title: Panaji: Town and Country Planning to consider raising floor area ratio for affordable housing project
Content:
TCP minister Chandrakant Kavalekar

PANAJI: The Town and Country Planning (TCP) board on Thursday constituted a four-member committee headed by Aldona MLA Glen Ticlo to inspect and submit a report on a proposal to increase floor area ratio (FAR) for an affordable housing project coming up in Xeldem, Quepem, under the Prime Minister Awas Yojana (housing scheme).TCP minister Chandrakant Kavalekar said that some of the land where the Goa housing board proposes to build homes for PMAY beneficiaries is situated on a slope. “Increase of FAR from 80 to 100 was sought for a housing board project at Xeldem under the PMAY. We have sought a detailed report along with the list of beneficiaries.The four-member committee will conduct an inspection and submit a report,” said Kavalekar. Along with Ticlo, three officials from the TCP department will complete the four-member committee. The committee has also been tasked with looking into a case between Goa University and Suresh Shetty.The minister also announced that the 57 applications for change of zone were taken up under Section 16B of the TCP Act. Of these, 45 applications were cleared, while 10 were rejected and two were deferred.“Eight of the applications rejected were in forest land, one was in a water body and one plot was khazan land. Two cases have been deferred for slope analysis. There were 34 applicants who have got provisional approval where the plot is below 500sqm, and 11 cases where the plot size is more than 500sqm,” said Kavalekar.The minister, who also holds the agriculture portfolio, announced that the finance department had granted approval for further disbursement of compensation to farmers whose crops were damaged due to floods and heavy rainfall.“Around Rs 6.5 crores compensation was to be paid of which Rs 1.80 crores had already been paid,” he said.

Title: Kolkata: Cops, KMDA bank on RITES report to reopen new Karunamoyee slip bridge
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The bridge over Tolly Nullah; the expansion of the width of the approach road resulted in the narrowing of the... Read More

KOLKATA: Cops, along with KMDA, are banking on a recent RITES report to finally begin operations on the bridge connecting Karunamoyee Bridge and Siriti in the Tollygunge area, the construction of which was finished around five months ago.

The RITES report revealed that there is no obstruction in the flow in the Tolly’s Nullah due to the bridge, rebutting activists’ claim that widening of the road had hindered the normal flow. It was on this ground that the bridge was not opened — as activists knocked on the doors of the green bench and forced KMDA to get a survey carried out by an independent agency.

This has led to daily traffic congestions, especially in the evenings. The MG Road stretch towards Haridevpur bears most of the brunt. Cops now hope that diverting at least autos via the narrow bridge will help take off load in the zone. With two major high-rises in the area and buses routes multiplying, following the Majerhat bridge crash, managing traffic has become a challenge there, conceded Lalbazar sources.

KMDA sources said that they also want to have talks with the police to see if the canal bridge can be opened for traffic. “As per the RITES report, there is no obstruction in the flow of water due to the bridge,” said a source.

The Karunamoyee canal bridge has remained closed, following an NGT order last year.

Green activist Subhas Dutta said he did not object to the bridge. “I only object to the connecting road that has been widened. Instead of widening the canal, its width has been narrowed,” he said, adding that he plans to challenge the findings of RITES at the NGT.

KMDA had set up the Rs 7-crore bridge over Tolly Nullah at Karunamoyee. Work of setting up the bridge had started in November 2018. It was inaugurated on September 30 last year, only to be closed a day later as the approach road was not wide enough for vehicles to ply smoothly and it would have created traffic snarls during Puja.

Police, meanwhile, are urging vehicle owners to use the Izzatullah Lane Bridge from the Prince Anwar Shah crossing. “Vehicles coming from Prince Anwar Shah Road can take the Izzatullah Lane Bridge directly, avoiding Tollygunge Phanri and Tollygunge Circular Road,” an officer from the south-west traffic guard said.

Title: Coimbatore KSRTC bus tragedy: Crash jolted us awake and sent us hurling, says passenger
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The right half of the bus was completely ripped off, killing most passengers sitting on that side

COIMBATORE: A deafening crash jolted him awake and sent him hurling. P Jordin Xavier, 38, from Nemmara in Palakkad district , said if he and his wife Anu Mathai had got seats on the right side of the bus their names would have been among the deceased. Jordin, who was returning from Bengaluru, got away with injuries in the hands and legs.

Jordin said they were returning home after his wife wrote an exam in Bengaluru on Wednesday for a job in Saudi Arabia. “We were in seats no 19 and 20. We were deep asleep. We suffered minor injuries in the collision. We were in shock after seeing many passengers lying dead in their seats,” said Jordin.

The couple were rescued by fire and rescue services personnel and were admitted to the Tirupur Government Hospital. Around 1 pm, the couple left for their home town.

Siddhu Malawad, 44, from Bengaluru, an employee of an MNC company, said he was fast asleep and didn’t know how the accident happened. “When I woke up after the loud noise and the jolt, all I could see was blood soaked passengers, some dead and some unconscious,’’ he said. Survivors are in a state of trauma.

He said he was on an official visit to Kochi from Bengaluru. “All the passengers had been deep asleep. After the crash, passengers in the front seats were lying dead. I helped the rescuers and later I was treated as an outpatient in a hospital near the accident spot,” said Siddhu Malawad.

K Vijayakarthikeyan, Tirupur collector, said two possibilities are being cited as reasons for the accident - the driver was asleep; and the rear tyres of the container truck burst. He said he has instructed the regional transport officer to conduct an inquiry into the cause of the accident. Addressing media persons at the Tirupur Government Hospital, he said 25 passengers were injured and they were admitted to various hospitals. Their condition is stable.

Death certificates have been issued immediately to family members of the victims.

D Balamurali, Palakkad collector, said: “The Kerala government will bear the medical expenses of the injured passengers. Those who suffered minor injuries will be sent home after treatment. People who suffered major injuries will be transferred to hospitals in Kerala after getting the opinion of doctors and their relatives,” said Balamurali.

Title: Wedlock amidst deadlock
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Days after the anti-CAA protest venue at Old Washermanpet in Chennai hosted a marriage, Coimbatore’s Shaheen Bagh turned into a wedding venue for 24-year-old Abdul Kalam and 19-year-old K Reshma Shirin on Thursday. Immediately after the bride and groom took their marriage vows, they shouted slogans against the CAA.

Their marriage was fixed three months ago and like any other couple, they were planning to get married in a marriage hall. However, the current political climate forced them to change their plans.

On Thursday, their marriage was solemnized under a canopy at Athupalam Junction that was erected to provide shade to around 2,000 people, who are protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), the National Registry of Citizens (NRC) and the National People’s Register (NPR).

The couple said they wanted to get married at the venue, “amid people”.

Abdul Kalam, the groom, who is a vegetable dealer from Kuniyamuthur, said, “When everyone is protesting, it didn’t feel right for us to get married in a hall. We are happy that we got married in the presence of such a large crowd, but at the same time we are sad that we had to start our married life here because of such laws. There are several others like us. We don’t want this to happen to them. The CAA, NPR and NRC should be repealed.” he said.

On her part, Reshma Shirin, of Karumbukkadai, said they were happy that they could send out a statement through their marriage. “We think our nikkah was revolutionary. We want the CAA, NPR and NRC to be repealed,” she said.

Representatives of Jamath organizations said the families of the bride and groom had decided to have the marriage at the protest venue to express their solidarity with the ongoing anti-CAA protests.

The marriage was conducted as per Islamic tradition. The groom gave a 25g gold chain as ‘Mahr’, a customary offering to the bride. Representatives said the marriage was held in a simple way, in which all Islamic marriages should ideally be held.

On Monday, Shahin Shah and Sumayya had got married at the anti-CAA protest venue at Old Washermanpet in Chennai.

Title: Nagpur court grants bail to Fadnavis on Rs15k PR bond
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: Former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis on Thursday managed to get the bail from chief judicial magistrate’s (CJM) court in the case of allegedly suppressing information on two pending criminal cases in an affidavit for 2014 assembly polls.

While allowing his application for bail, CJM PS Ingle directed the former CM, who was present in the court after being granted last chance, to furnish a personal release (PR) bond of Rs15,000. Before scheduling the next hearing on March 30, he was told to appear in subsequent hearings as and when directed by the court.

The onlookers, including the lawyers and litigants, crowded district and sessions court’s premises since the news of ex-CM attending the hearing went viral on the social media. The police had maintained strict security and even personnel from the riot control force were present at the spot to prevent any untoward incident.

Fadnavis, who was made an accused in the case, arrived with senior counsel Sunil Manohar and lawyer Uday Dable at about 11.15am and presented himself in the CJM’s court. His trusted allies, including former power minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule and MLC Parinay Fuke, accompanied him along with other BJP activists from the city.

“Presence of the accused is secured. There seem to be no chance of absconding. As the offence in bailable, he may be granted bail,” the judge said before adjourning the hearing.

Earlier, arguing for the South West MLA, Manohar submitted a bail application contending that his client had already filed a review petition in the Supreme Court on whose orders the case was remanded back to trial court.

Stressing that the apex court had reserved the orders in his case, Manohar requested for bail to the accused on PR bond till the verdict comes out.

Strongly opposing this, applicant Satish Uke argued that Fadnavis had thrice skipped the hearings on December 4, January 4 and February 10 citing various excuses. Pointing out a similar case involving Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal, he contended that the former had faced jail and was released on a bond of Rs15,000.

Further stating that he had filed a contempt case against Fadnavis for skipping the court summons, the applicant requested the court of applying law of equality to all.

Later talking to the media, Uke denied any political controversy in the entire issue. “If he loses, he could face a jail term of six months or Rs10,000 fine or both,” he said.

Uke had accused Fadnavis of alleged failure to mention summary case no. 232 of 1996 (u/s 500 of IPC — defamation) and regular criminal case no. 343 of 2003 under various sections of IPC, which were pending before the JMFC.

Before remanding back the case to JMFC court for retrial on October 1 last year, the SC had ruled against Fadnavis clarifying that a candidate must disclose all criminal cases in which court has taken cognisance at the time of contesting election. JMFC judge SB Mehta had issued summons to the ex-CM as an accused and asked him to remain present on December 4 for seeking bail.

Title: NCP confusing people on Elgar probe, says Devendra Fadnavis
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Devendra Fadnavis

NAGPUR: Flaying NCP supremo Sharad Pawar ’s demand to constitute a Special Investigation Team (SIT) to probe Elgar Parishad case, leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis on Thursday accused the party of confusing people.

Pawar had opposed National Investigation Agency ’s (NIA) decision to take over the case, and home minister Anil Deshmukh had written to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to oppose NIA, and requested him to form the SIT. The CM, however, cleared the way for NIA, which led to differences between the two coalition partners.
