Title: Cockroach found in food, eatery fined
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Hyderabad: The GHMC penalised a restaurant in Jubilee Hills after a customer found a cockroach in a biryani dish. A GHMC official said that they imposed Rs 5,000 fine on the restaurant on Wednesday. A customer had raised the complaint in My GHMC app on February 10. GHMC officials inspected the place on Wednesday. TNN

Title: Extra security measures trump residents living within 500 metres of Taj Mahal
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Agra: Local residents, who were issued passes for their vehicles by the road transport authorities to ply within 500-metre radius of the Taj Mahal, have been facing restrictions on their movement in view of the US President Donald Trump’s February 24 visit. A Supreme Court order of 1998 had banned entry of all private vehicles within 500 metres of the Mughal-era monument, following which local residents living in proximity of the Taj Mahal were issued passes allowing their vehicles to ply.

Local resident Sandeep Arora, who has a valid vehicle pass, however, said that he was stopped on Wednesday night and was told that due to security reasons, no vehicle would be allowed in the restricted zone till February 24. “Denying us permission to ply our vehicles for five days is like a house arrest,” he said.

Raju Kohli, who lives in Tajganj, told TOI that his residence is just 62 metres from the West gate of the Taj Mahal and he has a valid special permit that allows his vehicle to ply within the prohibited zone. “When I asked the security personnel the reason of stopping my vehicle, I was told that there were orders from the higher authority not to allow any vehicle within restricted zone of the Taj Mahal,” he said.

Following the 1998 SC order, the road transport officer was directed to identify the records, number of vehicles of the local residents and as to which of them should be permitted ingress and egress within 500-metre zone of the Taj Mahal. The officer was also directed to insist upon the vehicle owners to use stickers granted to them.

Besides, local administrative and other official vehicles have also been directed not to move frequently and try to restrict their movement as US security officials are raising issues of movement of vehicles in the prohibited area.

Agra district magistrate Prabhu N Singh told TOI that there is no complete ban as such on movement of vehicles in the restricted area. “We are just regulating the movement and advising residents not to make frequent trips in the area because of security reasons,” he said.

Title: Seven focus areas as pledges
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

The state Budget for the first time announced seven focus areas as pledges. These are: Healthcare; prosperity of farmers, women, child and senior citizens; competent workers, students and youth; delivery of education; water, power and road; skill development and technical education. Almost all allocations in Budget are centered around these priority areas.

Rs 10 crore for sexed sorted semen: The Budget announced Rs 10 crore for sexed sorted semen, under which chances of birth of female calf are higher.

Information Technology: The Budget proposed a Rs 75 core fund for startup on the name “Rajiv Gandhi @75 Fund”.

Title: Zama to speak on mine workers’ occupational diseases
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: Secretary general of the Indian National Mineworkers’ Federation (INMF) affiliated to INTUC Union, SQ Zama will speak on occupational diseases faced by the employees working in mines at an international event organized at Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia, between February 25 and 27.

INMF-INTUC is affiliated to Industrial Global Union with its headquarters at Geneva (Switzerland). On invitation from Australia’s largest trade union— Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union (CFMEU), Zama left for the Gold Coast.

In a press release issued here, spokesperson of the union, Ateeque Ghazi said, “Zama has been invited as the only expert trade union representative from India on occupational, health, safety and slow death caused to the mining workers out of pneumoconiosis, silicosis, manganese poisoning etc which are caused due to dust generated during mining activities. The conference will be attended by representatives from many fields, including coal, mining, trade union, health professional, lawyers, academics and government representatives from major mining countries, including USA, Russia, Ukraine, Colombia, Indonesia, Mongolia, South Africa, Philippine and many African and Latin American Countries. The three-day conference may device a system to combat the occupational disease by use of modern technology, including digitalization and artificial intelligence.”

Title: Unlocking taboos: Opening doors to people with mental illness
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

CHENNAI: Five years ago, G Kodhainayagi opened her doors to Rajathi, a client of Better Chances, a Chennai-based NGO promoting holistic wellbeing of people with mental health issues.

The 40-year-old had been diagnosed with acute schizophrenia after her parents died within two months of each other, and her elder brother could no longer handle her psychotic episodes.

Rajathi had quite a temper, didn’t like being told what to do, and was spaced out a lot. But she also wore great makeup, loved gardening and watched the 9pm serial without a miss. Today, these are among the things that define her friendship with Kodhainayagi.

"She is part of the family now. She shares her kitchen recipes with me and I ensure she takes her medicines on time," says Poorna Chandrika, director Institute of Mental Health, who has also empowered their clients to live on their own.

Read the entire story on TOI+

If only India could open doors like them for mentally ill

Title: 'Indian 2' shooting accident: Where death lurks behind the scenes
Content:
The crane fell on crew members of ‘Indian 2’ at the EVP Film City near Poonamallee

CHENNAI: Wednesday’s crane accident on the sets of ‘ Indian 2 ’, which left three dead and 10 more injured, is an eye-opener for the film industry which seldom follows safety norms. .Angamuthu Shanmugam, general secretary, Film Employees Federation of South India (FEFSI), which comprises around 25,000 workers/technicians from 23 union representing various crafts of film production, blamed the use of an industrial crane for the tragedy and improper maintenance of the floor at EVP.According to police, the crane used was 100ft tall. “We have been asking Tamil Film Producers’ Council (TFPC) to utilize the services of FEFSI members. We provide training in using new equipment including 40ft and 60ft cranes. In this case, an industrial crane was deployed and the floor was weak, resulting in the accident,” he said.As tragedy struck home, Kamal Haasan was unsparing in his criticism. “When we spend hundreds of crores of rupees making films, it is despicable that the film industry does not provide basic protection for its lower rung workers. Personally, this (the accident) is an insult to me.”Leading art director Sabu Cyril said such accidents should be wake-up calls for movie crew. “In Mumbai, a scaffolding cannot be more than 35ft high. Not sure if such rules are followed in the south. This rule was implemented after an accident and Bollywood adopted safety on sets as a byword. In foreign locations, nobody can take rules for granted. The governments concerned are strict and monitor the movements of people. Safety audit happens at shooting spots. In Dubai, an inspector visits the spot to make sure no untoward incident occurs,” he said.Stunt master Peter Hain said accidents on sets are not a single person’s error. “It is unfortunate that lives were lost, but the takeaway from this episode is people, no matter how big or small, must take their safety seriously. Mostly, the stuntmen don’t care about their wellbeing. They are willing to take risks, not understanding how their family may suffer if anything goes awry,” he said.A veteran art director, who did not want to be named, said the way things were going in the industry, anything can happen anytime. “Everything happens in a jiffy. There is no thought process. Double call sheet, overworked technicians and zero concern for their lives are a recipe for disasters. Only now light boys have got ladders, otherwise they had only ropes to hang for safety. Now, they have steel grids to walk without getting hurt,” he said.Film producer S R Prabhu said life matters more than money. “This is an accident. No one wants to be careless. Actors and stuntmen insist on an ambulance and the presence of a doctor when shooting for stunt scenes. Insurance has become a key thing,” he said.As ‘Indian 2’ was insured, the family of the deceased would get ₹10 lakh each (besides the ₹1 crore Kamal has promised for the three families together). “We pushed them to take insurance. Unlike Bollywood, not all producers opt for insurance here, which is not seen as a priority by them,” says K Abhishek Bharati, a business consultant enabling sale of key insurance products to the film industry.

Title: MSRTC’s e-buses to stay off Pune-Mumbai route
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

MSRTC’s e-bus service is expected to start only by June (File photo)

PUNE: While the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) isn’t ready to ply e-buses between Pune and Mumbai yet, a private entity has decided to operate 20 e-buses on the route by the end of the year.

“We feel that there is no need to run e-buses between Pune and Mumbai. We have the Shivneri bus service on this route and it is doing a good job. There is no logic in stopping the Shivneri service to launch e-buses. The e-buses will be launched on the Pune-Nashik, Pune-Kolhapur and Pune-Aurangabad routes,” a senior MSRTC official told TOI.

Earlier, MSRTC officials had stated that e-buses would ply in the ghat section after certain technical issues were taken into consideration. “There will be studies and some test runs before we take a decision on whether to run e-buses on the Pune-Mumbai section,” Ranjit Singh Deol, former vice chairman and managing director of MSRTC had said.

Last week, Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari launched the first e-bus on the Pune-Mumbai route, making it the first inter-city e-bus service in the country. Prasanna Purple Mobility Solutions Pvt Ltd has started the e-bus service. Prasanna Patwardhan, chairman and managing director of the company, confirmed that more e-buses are expected to ply on the route.

“One bus now starts from Kothrud in Pune at 6am and goes to Borivli. The same bus returns at 5pm. We will get another bus within a fortnight. We aim to have at least 20 e-buses between Pune and Mumbai by this year,” said Patwardhan.

MSRTC officials, meanwhile, said that its e-bus service is expected to start only by June. “We have some buses right now but we need to set up charging points. There has been a slight delay in setting up the charging stations as many approvals are needed. 12 charging points are to be set up at the Pune headquarters by May. During the same period, Kolhapur , Nashik, Aurangabad and Solapur divisions will also get two, seven, six and three stations respectively,” the official said.

A source, however, pointed out that the launch of the service may be delayed. “MSRTC has floated tenders to set up charging points and the process is expected to be completed by May. It seems doubtful that they will be able to start operations by June as many a times, re-tendering needs to be done,” the source said.

Title: In a first, separate Rs100cr corpus for children in Raj
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Jaipur: A separate fund of Rs100 crore has been proposed for rehabilitation of children who are rescued from child labour and those who need support and care of the state government. It is for the first time that any state has proposed a separate budget for children, said officials of Rajasthan State Commission for Protection of Child Rights (RSCPCR).

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot in his budget speech said that Rs100 crore is proposed for Nehru Bal Sanrakshan Fund.

RSCPCR member Vijendra Singh said that nowhere in the country is there a separate fund for rehabilitation of children.

“Usually, the fund is proposed for women and children collectively but not solely for children. Such a separate budget will be helpful for children who are rescued from child labour, or those who need support and care after being sodomised or raped or those abandoned by their parents on streets and hospitals,” he said.

While announcing the budget for children, Gehlot said the funds will also be utilised for preventing child labour, child trafficking and other such activities.

Title: Man hit by speeding truck, dies
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Pune: A 21-year-old pedestrian died after he was hit by a speeding truck near Talab masjid on Kondhwa-Saswad Road around 2pm on Tuesday.

Police identified the deceased as Rafique Shaikh from Nanded currently residing at Kondhwa Budruk.

Police said Shaikh, a labourer, was on way home to Kondhwa from Khadi Machine chowk when the truck driver plying at high speed lost control of the vehicle and hit him.

Passersby rushed Shaikh to the Sassoon General Hospital where he passed away around 5.50pm, police said. The hospital in its post-mortem report said that the cause of the victim’s death was due to multiple injuries.

Title: Mohali: Feeling deceived, owners seek answers
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Councillor’s husband protests, detained

MOHALI: Why did the Indian Air Force not demarcate 100-metre land from the defence installation boundary wall in 1960? If it was illegal, then why MC allowed constructions in the airport’s vicinity? Why did the government charge fee to sanction building plans? Why did the MC charge property tax if structures were unauthorised?

These were some of the questions raised by the owners of structures in Zirakpur that fall within the 100-metre radius.

Owners of 83-odd structures, out of which 12 were demolished on Thursday, asked why 100-metre radius from the defence installation boundary wall was not left by the Indian Air Force when the land was acquired in 1960?

Home to the newly-raised Number 42 and 44 Squadrons, 12 Wing Air Force Station was established on March 1, 1961. Since then, it is one of the premier transport bases in the IAF. Over the years, the pride of the IAF’s heavy-lift fleet — An-12s, Il-76s, Mi-26s — were stationed at 12 Wing. The station was carved out of the land belonging to the residents of Pabhat village in Zirakpur after they were compensated.

Affected by the drive in Pabhat village, Jagjit Singh, Ramesh Kumar, Anil Kumar, Pardeep Bhardwaj, Bharat Bhushan and Harpreet Singh Preet , asked in unison if all these structures were illegal, then why their construction was allowed and why the government accepted requisite fee for sanctioning their building plans. “The Air Force did not cordon off the 100-metre area with a barbed wire in 1960. It means they did not see the threat, which after 60 years they are seeing,” they said.

The owners demanded that the government as well as the civic body be made party to their case and booked for fraudulently accepting fee and property tax for structures marked illegal.

Many owners came up with building plan orders approved in 2018. The structures were declared illegal two years ago. Questioning the working of the civic body, they said if the structures were illegal, then why did the government approve plans?

Led by Satnam Singh of NGO Punjab Against Corruption, architect Ranjit Singh and advocate Rajwinder Singh , chairman, Punjab Human Rights Organization , they alleged that the government was attempting to challenge its own scheme of Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana by forcing residents to become homeless.

Title: Donald Trump visit: 417 students to report early for board exams in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

US President Donald Trump (AFP Photo)

AHMEDABAD: Some 417 students from across 10 schools of the city will be forced to report way too early to their exam centre on February 24, thanks to the curbs that will be imposed in Ahmedabad on account of the visit of US President Donald Trump .

Students of 10 schools including DPS East and Anandniketan in Hirapur, Kendriya Vidyalaya in Shahibaug and Cantonment, Poddar International School and ONGC School would be forced to report at their exam centres by 8am on Monday.

The exam is scheduled to start at 10am but students will be forced to reach the centre two hours prior because the roads around these exam centres will be cordoned for traffic, owing to the VVIP movement. All these centres have been instructed that students as well as their parents must reach the centre early.

Title: Chandigarh: Online cheats dupe MP's private secretary of Rs 80,000
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Online fraudsters have duped the private secretary of MP Kirron Kher of Rs 80,000 on the pretext of activating his debit card, police said on Thursday after registering a cheating case.

Oma Kant Tiwari, the MP’s private secretary, said in his police complaint, “I had received a new debit card on January 20, 2019, but did not activate it. Later, I received a phone call from a man who introduced himself as Rajbir Singh, an employee of SBI Bank. Promising to activate the debit card, he sought my bank account as well as the card details. After I gave him the information, I started receiving messages of withdrawal of money from my account. First, Rs 49,500 were withdrawn and then Rs 9,999 each in subsequent three transactions.”

After receiving the messages, Tiwari, a resident of Phase VI, Mohali, contacted the bank officials and got his ATM card and account blocked.

Even as he had filed a cheating complaint at SSP public window on January 21, 2019, the police registered an FIR on Thursday after verifying the facts.

On September 5, 2019, police had booked four persons of Uttar Pradesh for duping the UT DGP’s cook of Rs 17.18 lakh after promising him huge profits on an investment in a radio taxi company.

On September 4, 2019, online fraudsters posing as SBI employees had cheated retired Chief Justice of Andhra Pradesh High Court Manmohan Singh Liberhan, a resident of Sector 9, of Rs 2.25 lakh after obtaining his bank details. The retired Chief Justice had led the Liberhan Ayodhya Commission for 17 years.

Title: AIIMS Nagpur wins inter-collegiate quiz
Content:
This story is from February 21, 2020

Nagpur: For the first time, AIIMS Nagpur organized an inter-collegiate quiz competition on its campus in MIHAN. AIIMS Nagpur also won the contest.

AIIMS Nagpur conducted “UbiQuizone’, a Vidarbha-level quiz in biochemistry, on February 15. The Department of Biochemistry, AIIMS Nagpur, organized the quiz for MBBS students in which all medical colleges of Vidarbha were invited.

This was the first time that an intercollegiate quiz was hosted by the the premier medical institute under the guidance of Maj Gen (Dr) Vibha Dutta, SM, Director and CEO, AIIMS Nagpur.

Dr Seema Garg, organizing chairperson & amp, Prof and Head, Department of Biochemistry welcomed all the participating teams and faculty. The quiz competition had an innovative and unique format. Dr Siddharth Dubhashi, Prof and Head, General Surgery, AIIMS Nagpur, was the observer for the quiz and impartiality of the quiz was ensured by an independent quizmaster.

A vote of thanks was proposed by Dr Dnyanesh Amle, Assistant professor, Deptartment of Biochemistry and Organizing Secretary of UbiQuizone.

AIIMS Nagpur was represented by Abhijeet Brizwasi and Swayam Swaroop Misra and emerged as the winners of the quiz. The teams from JN Medical College, Sawangi Meghe and Government Medical College and Hospital, Nagpur were the first and second runners- up, respectively.

The Quiz Competition was an academic feast for students as well as the faculty members from the institute and other participating colleges. The quiz was highly appreciated for the innovative rounds and impartial conduct.
